Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I think you're overreacting, cubensis.  jslee was responding only 
tangentially, and I don't think he meant it at all personally as you
felt it was.

You talk about not being a raver now.  In retrospect, my firm belief is
that "raving" in SF meant a quite different experience than in many
other places, in part because of its "Disco City" history.  Acid house
seems to have made a bigger impact there than most other places, and
I count myself lucky that I lived through some of that.  There's onluy
a glimmer of those times any more, and that's what John was really
talking about.

I had a long talk with someone the other night that some of you may know --
he was an original Rave Called Sharon partner, worked at DV8 and 1015,
he knows what's up.  After hearing his perspective a bit -- which helped
fill in some of my own history -- it just reaffirmed that what happened
in SF was similar to but so much different than elsewhere.  It couldn't
have, and never did, stay in the same place very long, and as always our
memories highlight the exceptional experience.  But it *was* truly
exceptional, and I even missed out on most of the earlier phases.

That time will come again, it always does, maybe not in SF, but we'll
know about it when it does and if we're lucky, we'll be part of it once
again.  

In the meantime, while the scene as a whole is jaded, the bright spots
are still there and shine as brightly in SF as anywhere.  Sunset, Harmony,
F&F, daytimes at Golden Gate Park, great house parties, the once-in-a-blue-
moon top megaparty . . . I've been chained to my desk for over three months
now, and I can't tell you how much I miss it.

But I'll be back!

In the meantime, a small word of advice for those who look askance on jslee's
claims to have been there, done that and got the postcards.

He was, he did, and he does :-)

phred

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

KaySEE:
>  As for people who have been
>doing it from the beginning (greater than 6 years), I don't know what they
>do, I'm not there.  Some people start making the music which appears to be
>a natural progression.  There is a contiuum of experiences with raving and
>age.  People just simply find themselves at different points.

I still find it hard to compare any experience with the peak moments
I've had dancing at the better raves in my life.   I'm not going
to bore everyone with all the reasons why those peak moments seem harder
to come by these days.  But one thing that has become clear over the
last 2 years, is that some of us reach a point where we want more in
our lives than an ongoing continuim of amazing Nows.  The Reality Beyond
calls for our attention: there's a big, weird world out there, for
better or worse.  The metaphysical connections some make to it through
the rhythm/dance/plur experience of raving can start to feel
illusionary and shallow if not accompanied by a more "reality"-based
involvement with the things happening around us.

For many, the responsibilities of careers/family/health call us away.
Others choose paths that seem to have more substance in a political,
creative, spiritual or social sense.  There are other thriving scenes
and intimate social circles in the SF Bay Area that attempt to do many 
of the things that raving has only touches upon.

Despite its flaws, the rave scene still seems like a wonderful place
to be.  As long as you have your clique of raver friends, it's
pretty hard not to have some great times.  I used to wonder if there
would ever be anything to replace it in my life.  I'm happy to say that
the Universe is an infinitely rich place for endless exploration.

Lee
_________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com  (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )  lee@hyperreal.com

me on a tape cover he made about 3 years ago....... 
 
I was in charge of the DJ line-up in the small room at one of the community
benefits held at the richmond auditorium, and I already had too many DJ's
and I already excluded myself (as a DJ that nite), to help give everyone
have a chance to play....... 
 
now somebody (I won't say who), told ghost he could play, and I had already
nixed him as a possible DJ because of time restraints and I felt at the
time his techno was too hard for the room (not nessesarily the right
reason, but it was my decision to make), anyway.....he shows up with his
records and expected to spin.......... I explained to him he was
mis-informed and the person was out of line to tell him he could spin......
I truly felt bad about the situation and tried to apologize and smooth it
over, however.......... 
 
.......... it was a bad vibe and so life goes on..........until about a
month or so later when he puts out a tape, and he thanks all the people of
SF etc......bla bla bla............. and then at the end of his list of
thanks he puts.........and no thanks to the brit posse & moonpup....... 
 
I thought ......what a jerk...........he may have his hard feelings and
granted, maybe he felt slighted, and justified to slag me off,
..........but on a tape !!!!!    well ever since, I have had no respect for
his style or vibe........ just another bad vibe story from the
pupster..........     moonpup    oh yeah......... the party went off and
the vibe was awsome......

 This is just for future readers:  This began in 1996, not much of
 a past, but it works.  So here are the rules:
 
 *If you read this on a Sunday, wish for a  really fun week
 *If you read this on a Monday, wish for money
 *If you read this on a Tuesday, wish for love
 *If you read this on a Wednesday, wish for success
 *If you read this on a Thursday, wish for anything you want
 *If you read this on a Friday, wish for a really hot date
 *If you read this on a Saturday, wish for an important phone call
 
 Send this to seven people (after you make a wish).  Make sure
 it is mailed as soon as you read it or your wish won't come true.
 And check your horoscope, it could be very useful.
 
 REMEMBER, make a WISH, send this letter (and hope it happens).

Hello SFR,

This is the voice of the Cloud Factory...

This Saturday and Sunday, October 12-13, 2:00pm-2:00pm, 1996, .... PLANETARIUM

There is a $15 suggested donation for tickets, with proceeds split between
Omar's Healing Fund
and Cloud Sound.    (408) 457-7726

In East Bay we have tickets at Drop Beat, a new record store in Oakland!
        www.dropbeat.com
        5417 College Avenue, Oakland

In SF we have tickets at Frequency-8,
                www.frequency-8.com (mars this isnt working for some reason?)
        1816 Haight Street

In San Jose we have tickets at Solid Grooves
        368 S. Bascom, San Jose

There will also be tickets available on the mountain.  Everyone who gets
there before sunset will get a special treat.

You can get more info about the party and see pictures of the site
(whoohooo!) at our website @
                www.cloudfactory.org/upcoming.html

Preparations:

        If you are planning on attending this weekend, there are several
things you should keep in mind. The last hour of the drive is a dirt road
that is fairly steep and bumpy. If you are driving your car should be at
least 8-10 inches above the ground.  Make sure you have a fair amount of
gas when you leave the freeway--that's not the end of the journey.

        Remember we are a LONG way from town, so if you haven't stopped to
get supplies by the time you get to Healdsburg, you better hit a store.
Here's some goodies that might come in handy:

                                * a gallon of water
                                * food
                                * sleeping bag or blankets
                                * smile, or three
                                * tent
                                * sun screen
                                * bug repellant
                                * snacks


Schedule--Turntable Instumentalists and Live Acts:


        System A:                            System B:

                > 02:00 Spinsilver                   >02:00 Jason
                > 03:45 Gizmo                         >03:45 Lee
                > 05:30 Astronaut Scott         >05:30 drenalin
                > 07:15 15 min break             >07:15 Jeyson
                > 07:30 Mike Clay                   >09:00 15 min. break
                > 09:00 10 Bass T                    >09:15 swoops
                > 10:15 Brian Flipp                  >11:00 inTIMidator
                > 12:00 K-Go                           >12:45 Cloud
                > 02:00 Maya                          >02:30 Deaks
                > 03:45 15 min. break             >04:15 John Carel
                > 04:00 Elflord                         >06:00 15 min. break
                > 05:45 Stonie                         >06:15 Joe Rice
(plus one)
                > 07:30                                    >08:00 Brad
                > 09:15 Rich                            >09:45 Sig/Tina
                > 11:00 Christian                    >11:30 Monty
                > 12:45 Gabba Dave



Directions:

      From San Francisco:
            *101 North towards Healdsburg, go past Santa Rosa
            *Exit on Dry Creek Road, the third exit in Healdsburg (make
sure you have a full tank)
            *Turn left on Dry Creek Road, set your odometer
            *at 12.1 miles turn left, the sign will read

                            Skagg Springs Road
                            Annapolis
                            Highway 1

            *watch for the sign with a Saturn picture on it
            *turn left and reset that odometer baby, use your lower gears
and not your brakes
            *at 11.5 miles the road gets narrow,
            *at 12.0 miles take a right on the dirt road, follow signs to
the spot

Reasons to make sure to get there early:

        * Sunset on Saturday
        * If you get there before sunset Sabin has a special surprise for you.
        * The Exxon at Dry Creek Rd. closes at 9:30 pm (you need gas before
you start up Dry Creek)
        * If you come up during the day the drive is through beautiful wine
country
        * It is safer for you to drive the dirt road during the day
        * We want to spend more time with you =)




                        SEE YOU THERE................

                                   Tim McKnew
                               mcknew@salinas.net

From: "matthew d. p. k. lanier" <mdpkl@best.com>
Subject: to the posting police
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

yo-

to the recently self-appointed posting police: chill out just a little.

we are about communicating ideas, not about enforcing structure.  the rules
of grammer, while making your ideas clearer and easier to the reader, also
have this nasty tendency to constrain your ideas.  when we start spending
more energy on the structure of our posts, that energy comes at the expense
of our ideas, thoughts, and other creative energies.

imho, this largely unexplored medium, (the internet) is all about casting
out the old structural ideas and developing new ones.  plus, many
individuals may have different ideas about how to structure posts and
communication.  so, deal.

that's my $2 (everything's expensive in south park)


on the other hand, we do need to be concerned about people's ability to
understand out ideas.  it's a fine line.

"creativity at the expense of netiquette"

love-

matt
matthew d. p. k. lanier
professional hugger and empath
mdpkl@best.com
415-752-3218

me? I usually alwayz get a bad vibe at the ravez. I am Jeff... That one guy
that dancez like Bernie. You know. The Bernie on the movie "Weekend at
Bernie'z"..  I sometimes wear my cool red sweat jacket, and alwayz wear
black sweats. And da girls seem to enjoy watching me dance.You wanna know
why I don't hit on any of them girls at the raves.? No! It iz defonetly not
a gay thing!!! The reason being iz... Well ....  I am a freakin idiot,
thats why!!! Frankly, I don't know why. My jaw bone just locks up after
adding "E".... I have some kind of cronic shyness.... And it iz not
entirely my fault either,,,,, I mean.. The girls just come up and stand
near me. They don't say anything either... I am not stuck up, not gay, and
I don't have aids or nuffin.. I just need to be comferted or something.. I
could go on for dayz. But I need to go back to work. Work iz cool though..
Without it. Ravez would only be a dream. I am going to try and make it to
Ground Zero though.. Hopefully the Dj,z take turnz mixin old school tunes
(like they did last time) agian.
 But I do usually leave the rave thinking. "God,, I am SO stupid!! That
girl waz so beautiful.. And I let he get away" But oh well.. Hopefully for
me.. Good things will come to me who waits.. But I am not really waiting..
I am ready.. I just need a girl to rape me nStuff!! I will prolly take a
couple of baby tylenolz at Ground Zero though.. It feels SO GOOD to dance
on E, don't you agree?.....

peace out scout'z....
P.S. No this izn't an inportiant update.. But it got your attention didn't
it?

I'm still a big fan of Moonpup's set on the legendary Connection II
tapes.  For those who might not know, Connection II was an sfraves-sponsored
gathering in March of 1993 "where it rained so hard the needle made a wake
on the record."  Bob Ramstad did an awesome job of dubbing off six hours
of music to four cassette tapes which, if you look around, are probably
sitting on your friends' shelves.  I've just been relistening to them
again and once more am knocked out by the variety and taste in the music
and mixing styles.

phred

> Date: Thu, 10 Oct 1996 13:08:44 -0700
> From: "matthew d. p. k. lanier" <mdpkl@best.com>
> 
> yo-
> 
> to the recently self-appointed posting police: chill out just a little.
> 
> we are about communicating ideas, not about enforcing structure.  the rules
> of grammer, while making your ideas clearer and easier to the reader, also
> have this nasty tendency to constrain your ideas.  when we start spending
> more energy on the structure of our posts, that energy comes at the expense
> of our ideas, thoughts, and other creative energies.

I don't agree. If I can't read a post because it contains 1 page of
headers, three pages of quoted response, a half a page of quoted
signatures, and then the text of the message is a two page badly
formatted un-proofread uni-paragraph, then there's no way any idea
could possibly be communicated to me.

If I got drunk and slurred every other word, would you be able to
understand me? Of course not. How about a radio show with ten minutes
of ads for every one minute of content? Would you be able to follow
it? Not me.

Communicating ideas is also about presenting them in an accessable
form.  Look at the web, and how important it is to have a well laid
out web page. Matt, if you designed a web page that communicated
everything your boss was trying to say, but had a terrible layout and
interface, how do you think he would feel about that?

Although noone is perfect, using good grammar is imporant. Sometimes
it can be confusing or unclear to read something with bad
grammar. Especially with the written word, where other cues like vocal
inflections and body language are removed, it's a little more
important to be clear about what you're saying.

For the record, there are many people on this list who use good
grammar and have a good posting style (Mike (lachim), SDream, Randy
and many others!!!) and can express what they need to say very well,
with no "constraints" of any sort on their ideas. It's not an
"either/or" thing; recheck your boolean operators :)

I love flaming my friends!
Here's a happy *hug* for you, Matt :)

as always,
my 5 drachmas 
(I hope they don't shift the exchange rate) :)

love,
Steve

I've thought about this question a lot. Pretension or no??- in putting up 
my flyers on the wall. Maybe even putting that much thought into it makes 
it even worse. But I think I put them up primarily to remember what went 
on.If my friends threw it, if I met rad people, or if weird things 
happened in association with that flyer, if the party was -the shit-, or if 
it is just too damn cute.Sometimes i have to wonder if I'm a poser or not but 
I think if I didn't have my flyers all of this would dissipate 
into one big blur (albeit ecstatic).

Yay!
Rebecca

pass on the message that my friends can't use that name, but this we own 
this name bullshit and the attitude that comes with it is really lame.

> I just wanted to say that I have zero respect for DJ ghost since he dissed me on a tape cover he made about 3 years ago....... 

I hesitated about mentioning this opinion of mine but it seems I'm not
alone (which means it's same for my feeble will to speak) so..
The way I always judge a DJ is by how appriciative (sp) they are of a
persons thanks for spinning that night and the job they did. Virtually
every time I have told a Dj: "Hey man you ripped it up tonight!!" They
always are very sencire and grateful that I took the time to compliment
their set. Example: Me:"Man that was a killer set!" Dj: "Hey man thanks!
I appreciate that!! I'm glad you felt it! " 

Here's what happend at the last Five party then I talked to Ghost.

Me: "Hey man that was a killer set!"
Ghost: "ya man thanks" (looking like I just asked him what time it was)

Oh and BTW, at that party they failed to keep the lines in control.
Which caused the Boys in Blue to pay a visit and take some lovley photos
to give to the City council to show them "what Raves are". Ghost and
security people spent 3 hours yelling at the top of their lungs for the
crowd to "back the fuck up". They used pepper spray on the crowd (which
does wonders for any vibe). I heard of worse things as well. But this is
what I observed with my own eyes.

-=Pengo=-
Blake "Pengo" Merriam

earth 1st?!?"

Received: from smtplink.acer.com ([204.160.139.137]) by acergw3.acer.com (8.7.3/8.7.3) with SMTP id PAA03514 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 10 Oct 1996 15:37:39 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from ccMail by smtplink.acer.com (SMTPLINK V2.11.01)
	id AA844987371; Wed, 09 Oct 96 12:08:08 pst
Date: Wed, 09 Oct 96 12:08:08 pst
From: "Andy Wyszkowski" <awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com>
Message-Id: <9609108449.AA844987371@smtplink.acer.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Sorta NRR > CD ideas for those asking.
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     
     What kind of music do you like?
     
     I like a lot of different things, with my tastes leaning away from 
     house, disco and gabber.  I like really trippy stuff.
     
     Here's some juicy bits I picked up recently...
     
     Autechre > Tri Repetae++ (this is available with a bonus cd for a 
     couple extra bucks if you look around).  Gorgeous ambient, interesting 
     experimental, great working music.  Some good slow grooves, orchestral 
     stuff and staticy weirdness but mostly kickback stuff.
     
     The Mind of Goa > Various Artists (on 'Jumpin and Pumpin'/Passion 
     Music)
     Totally hyper beautiful goa.  Pretty solid all the way through.  No 
     real lemon tracks.  Worst piece on the album is the first track, and 
     it's okay.  I've been asked for so many tapes of this CD... 
     
     Funky Desert Breaks > DJ John Kelly
     I love this disc!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  It's the Moontribe sunrise sound 
     on CD.  Killer shit, from them notorious Full Moon Gathering events.  
     Los Angeles Breaks done right.  Nonstop hard hard hard!!!
     
     Hardfloor > Homerun
     Ahhhh!  This one is sick as well.  Funky acid sound throughout (grrr 
     grr grrr grrr 'blip! grrr grrooooowwwwwlll), from the people that made 
     it okay again.  Available as a double vinyl that sounds even better.  
     (their EP just prior to Homerun *DONT REMEMBER NAME* is sooo stoney)
     
     Meat Beat Manifesto > Their new one (can't remember)
     Slow dark grooves that step on me.  This is my turn out the lights but 
     I can't go to sleep disc.  Spooky and gorgeous.  I have the LP (double 
     vinyl plus extra 12"), but the CD is a double cd, and the first one 
     alone has like 20 tracks.
     
     LJT Bukem > Logical Progression
     Drum and Bass with gentle weaving melodies.  Really minimalistic 
     layers.  Almost an ambient album that you can dance to.  My couch 
     lifts off the ground when I play this one in the right mood.
     
     Hope that helps...
     AndyW

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Oct 10 17:01:46 1996

Received: from smtplink.acer.com ([204.160.139.137]) by acergw3.acer.com (8.7.3/8.7.3) with SMTP id QAA06790 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 10 Oct 1996 16:57:41 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from ccMail by smtplink.acer.com (SMTPLINK V2.11.01)
	id AA844992291; Thu, 10 Oct 96 12:18:31 pst
Date: Thu, 10 Oct 96 12:18:31 pst
From: "Andy Wyszkowski" <awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com>
Message-Id: <9609108449.AA844992291@smtplink.acer.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re[2]: What happened to... -Reply
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hey...

I went to my first rave around four years ago, it was in LA, and it 
sucked (I could not deal with the music at all).  The house was horrible, 
the sound wasn't that good, almost everything was horrible.  There was a 
lot of crank going around, and a lot of leather and attitude.  Everybody 
seemed either full of themselves or full of shit.

A friend, knowing how much I love music, started turning me on to some 
more recent techno last year, and by this year I started driving down to 
LA for raves.  I liked the music, and the vibe was good.  I started 
wanting to go to them more often than I could afford to drive.  So I went 
to one here.  Alone.  Wow.  I've been pretty steady ever since.

There are some crappy ass parties around here, and it's not impossible to 
detect them (the large flyer rule seems to be batting about .900 from 
what I've seen lately).  The small parties I've been to (200 or less) 
have all been mindblowing so far, and I'm really glad I started going.  
I've been floored by the people I've met, and they're some of the most 
amazing personalities I've ever had step into my life.  Geniuses and 
artists and lovers of life and closet philosophers gather together to 
enjoy togetherness and music and the notion that we've been missing 
something from our lives for a while.  I'm finding glimpses of it, and I 
think that's enough to keep me going strong.  I've been happier and more 
outgoing, in my life in general.  I've made it a point to stop being such 
an asshole and listen for a change.

You're all amazing, and if the scene was better a few years ago here, I'm 
impressed.  I don't honestly know if it would have been for me, so I'm 
glad to be here now.  I've noticed myself that as I start to get to know 
more and more people at parties that the experience is changing, but in 
many ways it's getting better.

You're all really groovin folks.

If there are 'posers' amongst us, you'll never know it till they move 
onto something else.  It's the ones who are doing it for the wrong 
reasons that will try too hard, and have the clothes, the attitude the 
talk etc down cold.  Hope nobody minds if I show up to one once in a 
while, and smile, dance, talk, laugh, smoke, sleep, wait in line for 
bathrooms, experiment, explore, touch, plan, share, eat, hug, listen, 
joke, philosophize, and daydream with you all.

Love,
AndyW

Subject: Cloud Factory - Planetarium - Ride (RRR) RaveRideRelated
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     
     I've got room for one (1) brave soul who...
     
     *  Can weather the elements.  Convertibles aren't for everybody.
     
     *  Doesn't want to pan out.  That's right... thanks to the crack 
     design staff at Suzuki, my super stock Samurai is jacked up to boldly 
     clear rocks and dips up to 6"!!!  Cool for that last hour of driving.  
     Did I mention it's 4X4 (sorta)?
     
     *  Enjoys really talkative drivers who tell bad jokes.
     
     *  Doesn't mind that the brakes make "a noise".
     
     *  Can tolerate a three hour drive with no music except your own 
     drumming/singing (not enough room for trombone).  My stereo got ripped 
     off a while back.  Portable player might work... I'll bring some 
     healthy portions of tapes if you have one.
     
     *  Warm fuzzy IMITATION cow skin seat covers.
     
     *  Is hoping it doesn't rain (I'll bring the top, but it's ripped, old 
     and generally hosed).
     
     *  Wants to find out what Saben's surprise is really bad (that would 
     mean earlier Saturday).
     
     *  Lives somewhere near the 101 between here and there.  Here is South 
     San Jose.  There is 'whine' country (are we there yet..?).
     
     *  Will pitch in for gas, oil, coolant, or any of the other things my 
     car needs to have replaced all the time ($10-$20 would be sweet).
     
     Please reply personally, unless you feel everybody should know you're 
     willing to accept such a pathetic offer.
     
     Peace peace peace
     (Starting to get perky here...)
     AndyW
     
     408-435-5259 Daytime & Voicemail

Friday's benefit for Prop 215 should be a good show, then it's time to
head out of town, either to Planetarium or Tribal Future.  If you stay,
catch Doc Martin at Out-A-Sight...


                                THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://www.hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/gencal.cgi

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench. Varied techno sub-genres, noise, spoken word, world
       music. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
   For a _search_ interface to the calendar, see the Late Train club
   section (http://www.latetrain.com/clubs/).
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
 Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Oct 10 18:49:36 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id SAA20863; Thu, 10 Oct 1996 18:49:36 -0700 (PDT)

Received: from plasticdreams.sonoma.edu (SA-6EN38.sonoma.edu)
 by SONOMA.EDU (PMDF V5.0-5 #8366) id <01IAHKZ7R7LSA0UIU3@SONOMA.EDU>; Thu,

From: Jonas Hanning <hanning@SONOMA.EDU>
Subject: Aurora Chapter 1
X-Sender: hanning@sonoma.edu
To: Ola Persson <d95olape@ostrabo.uddevalla.se>,
        Goa Mailinglist <goa@party.net>, SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Cc: john.francis@impact-music.se
Message-id: <3.0b34.32.19961010184907.006c4b68@sonoma.edu>
MIME-version: 1.0
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Pro Version 3.0b34 (32)
Content-type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Just got this in the mail (big ups to John at Dancebeat!), and I 
figured I'd tell you about it...

First of all, for those who don't know, it's a double CD (if it
sells well, there will be a vinyl release. So buy this!!!) with some
of the best psychedelic trance to ever come out of Scandinavia.

CD #1:

* Timo Maas "Germany" - Not too speedy with a vocal sample that goes
round and round. Pretty good stuff. =)
* Joel Mull "The Runner" - More technoish stuff. A really slow track.
Not something for me, but that's just a matter of taste. =)
* Pagan Acid "Close Encounters" - Another slow track, this time with
an acidic sound that makes me go bonkers! 
* Kosmic B "Liquid" - Back on the psychedelic track, but still a bit
slow. This track is a killer though!
* Saia & Catha "I Whip You [spank me mix]" - This is a great track of
psych trance with some hard acid influences. Loses in tempo after a
few minutes, but then kicks back after some vocals (look at the title
and take a guess).
* Mirios "Insanity" - Ambient? Well, it sure isn't psychedelic. It's
a pretty neat track, but totally out of place...
* Planet Kaos "Sunburn" - Not headbanging but damn close. The melody
won't stop going around in my head. =)
* Pinocchio "Redline" - A slow starter, but soon turns into a major
stomper. Has ACID written all over it, and is headbanging.
* K "Simple Technology from Earth" - We're back in the land of laidback
beats. At least for a few minutes, then the fat beats kick in.

CD #2:

* Conundrum "Wild E" - Freaky techno, nothing I'd spin in front of a
crowd wanting to go crazy. After 5 minutes ambience sets in, and this
is probably the best part of the tune. Majorly laidback beats that make
you feel good.
* Joel Mull "Air Born" - Slow trance, but still pretty good. 
* Zack "Spirit 'n Soul" - WOO HOO! One of the fattest tracks on this comp.
Total psychedelic madness!
* Mirios "Trace and Trance" - TRIPPY is the first word that comes to mind
when listening to this track. Sounds like something Kraftwerk would come
up with had they tried to produce psychedelic trance. And just like most
of Kraftwerk's material, this ROCKS!!!
* Cut Off Frequency "High Position" - Heavy acid coming your way. And I
mean HEAVY ACID. 8 minutes of the same boring beat.
* Mirios "The Scale" - The piano riff is just SO beautiful! The rest of
the tune is a stairway to acid heaven!
* Bob Manning "Shine on You [bound 2 da bass mix]" - Starts off with a 
housy sample ('keep on stepping'), and just when you're about to give up
any hopes of it picking up, it turns into this mellow techno piece that
really makes you feel good. And that sample just keeps getting better and
better throughout the song!
* M-Zone "U.K." - How appropriate that the first and last tracks on this
compilation have names that are also countries. =) This track starts off
as a technoish thingy, but then develops into some kind of laidback hybrid
of techno, acid and psychedelic trance. Not bad, but not too exciting
either.

Altogether, this is a pretty good compilation of Scandinavian dance music.
The highlights are Planet Kaos "Sunburn", Zack "Spirit 'n Soul", and Mirios 
"Trace and Trance". If you like techno, acid and psychedelic trance, this
is a great compilation for you! And it's apparently being sold as 2 CDs for
the price of one! And as I said, if enough of us buy this, there might very
well be a vinyl release! =)

reespect, jonas
***********************************************************
* <<dj e(skimo!)>>    <<<jonas hanning>>>    <<dabalhed>> *
*      <<<http://www.sonoma.edu/students/hanning/>>>      *
*    "still listening to wax, i'm not using the cd..."    *
***********************************************************

----------------------------
You know, there are many people in the country today who, through no
fault of their own, are sane.  Some of them were born sane.  Some of
them became sane later in their lives.  It is up to people like you
and me who are out of our tiny little minds to try and help these
people overcome their sanity.
                                           -- Monty Python
---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Thu, 10 Oct 1996 09:59:52 -0700
From: He who is called cme <cme@reboot.com>
To: pounce@vcn.bc.ca
Subject: joke

Pounce, How's the rave scene? It's been a while.
Joke for ya.


	Two young guys were picked up by the cops for smoking dope and appeared
 in court before the judge. The judge said,

	"You seem like nice young men, and I'd like to give you a second chance
		rather than jail time. I want you to go out this weekend and
try to show 		others the evils of drug use and get them to give up
drugs forever. I'll 		see you back in court Monday."

Monday, the two guys were in court, and the judge said to the first one,

	"How did you do over the weekend?"

	"Well, your honor, I persuaded 17  people to give up drugs forever."

	"17 people? That's wonderful. What did you tell them?"  "I used a
	diagram, your honor. I drew two circles like this

 	         ___
	       /     \
	      |      |        O
  	       \ __ /

	and told them this (the big circle) is your brain before drugs and this
	(small circle) is your brain after drugs."

	"That's admirable," said the judge. "And you, how did you do?"
	(to the 2nd boy)

	"Well, your honor, I persuaded 156 people to give up drugs forever."

	"156 people! That's amazing! How did you manage to do that!"

	"Well, I used a similar approach. (draws two circles) I said (pointing
	to small circle) this is your asshole before prison.


--

>         If you are planning on attending this weekend, there are several
> things you should keep in mind. The last hour of the drive is a dirt road
> that is fairly steep and bumpy. If you are driving your car should be at
> least 8-10 inches above the ground.

8-10 inches of ground clearance is more than most 4x4 sport utility
vehicles, e.g.
	Ford Explorer      -- 6.7"
	Mitsubishi Montero -- 7.1"
	Subaru Outback     -- 7.3"

I guess this means that most of us normal car drivers won't be able
to make it up there without screwing up our cars.

Can anybody clarify if this is the case -- has anybody made it up there
with a normal car? Will I be able to make it up there in a Mazda Rx7??
(Probably Not :-( ). Hey wayne -- are you going?? How are you getting
up there??

On Oct 9,  9:39am, nathan.b.beckord wrote:
> Subject: another cd suggest request
> Howdy folks-
>
> Since we're already talking about suggested albums, could anyone suggest the
> following:
>
> 1.  a really TRIPPY, Trippy trippy trippy, techno cd, kinda hardcore,
something
> with lot's of low frequency tones, and haunting, surreal-ish feel? Anything
out
> there that kind of sends shivers down your back when you listen to it, and
> makes you feel like you're having a flashback?  And you can only listen to it
> every now and then, because it's just too eerie?

Speedy J's "Ginger" is one of those records (just one, dunno about his CD's)
for me. Very haunting. Joey Beltram's "Energy Flash" (12"), and Carl Cox's
double CD (mixed by him, forgot the title, check it out, they're pretty good).

> 2. a killer ambient disc, something mellow, that you would listen to while
> watching the sunrise, meditating, reading a book on a rainy day, etc.
Emphasis
> on mellow.

Definitely my all time favorite is "Visions of the past" by Robert Leiner.
May be hard to get hold of here, I bought mine in Europe, it's on the R&S
label I think. I haven't come accross anybody who didn't appreciate that
record, no matter what their taste in music. He made some other stuff too
that's harder but still very well done.
>

> Oh...  one more question....
> Who is the artist (female), of that older housy song that was out a few years
> ago, that went:
>
> So baby if you want me,
> you've got to show me love
> words are so easy to (hide??)
> oh ah, you've got to show me luh-huv

I had to search the web for this one, forgot completely, but it's Robin S.
Brought up some memories...


The Frying Dutchman

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Oct 10 22:56:26 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id WAA09611; Thu, 10 Oct 1996 22:56:26 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from aimnet.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with ESMTP id WAA09605; Thu, 10 Oct 1996 22:56:24 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from drakiel (dial-bp1-30.iway.aimnet.com [205.219.41.94]) by aimnet.com (8.7.6/8.7.1) with ESMTP id WAA24434 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 10 Oct 1996 22:56:20 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <199610110556.WAA24434@aimnet.com>
From: "Jason Lucas" <drakiel@aimnet.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Bad Vibes at Ground Zero... (long)
Date: Thu, 10 Oct 1996 22:56:31 -0700
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Priority: 3
X-Mailer: Microsoft Internet Mail 4.70.1155
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey all...
I've had something on my mind this whole week and I just can't come to
peace with it.  Maybe you guys can help me out with a little
reassurance...anyway, here's my story.
Last Friday I planned on going to the Ground Zero rave with a few friends. 
They dogged me (actually...their idea of a better party came up, go to a
park and drink until they pass out...whoo hoo ;P ) so I was asking around
at a book store/coffee shop that I hand out at in Livermore.  This girl
named Alaina who I had met just a few days before overhead my conversation
about my dilemna and asked if she could go with me.  I figured, what the
heck, she seems like a really open-minded person.  Let's do it!  So we went
to the party...got there at about midnight after getting EXTREMELY lost in
SF.  :)  We danced around a little bit (She doesn't like to dance tht
much...but me, on the other hand...can't help it when I start hearing the
beat! So that proposed a problem...) then I found a guy to buy some e from.
 I asked her if she wanted to try it and she said 'sure.'  So I asked her
again just to make sure and she still wanted some.  So I bought a few and
we went downstairs to buy some water.  I explained her the effects that she
should feel and the dangers of doing it.  She seemed like she was ready so
we dropped around 1:30.  We danced around a little more and just chilled on
a couch for a while.  Still waiting for the e to kick in.  Nope...bunk
doses.  Couldn't believe it.  Oh well.  I still wanted to dance...so I went
downstairs and danced some more.  When I came back.  Some guy was sitting
with her and talking to her.  I asked her if she wanted me to help her out
and she said yes to I very politely told the guy to take a hike.  :)  She
pulled out this little baggy and showed it to me while telling me that the
guy had given her a pill.  He said that it was extacy (sp?  Geez...I feel
really dumb right about now!) So she took it.  We chilled out for a while
longer and then all of a sudden she sat up and went "Oh Shit!  I'm feeling
it now!"  Then she got this big ole frown on her face and just sat back and
held her stomach.  I told her to calm down...just go with it.  Let the e
take over your soul.  It's a wonderful feeling.  She wasn't liking it at
all...After sitting next to her watching her eyes glass over and her
breating getting more and more rapid I picked her up and carried her to the
bathroom where she threw it up.  After she threw it up she told me she felt
fine and stood up and gave me a big old hug.  Then she thanked me for
saving her life.  I honestly don't think that I saved her life.  But she
can believe what she wants.  We went outside and danced some more (she said
she was feeling fine).  Then we went back upstairs and sat down on the
pillows.  She crawled on top of me and started talking to me while stroking
my hair and telling me how gorgeous I was.  I knew it was the e talking so
I payed it no mind.  Then she started kissing me.  I had been attracted to
this woman since I first met her so of course I kissed her back.  Then I
thought better of it since she was pretty fucked up and I had heard that
she was kinda sorta seeing this guy back home.  For those of you that were
there, you know that the last DJ didn't show so we left around 4.  I took
her home and haven't heard from her since.  No wait, I take that back, I
saw her the next day at the coffee shop where she gave me a quick kiss and
then ran off.  I was talking to one of her friends today about the Ground
Zero (here comes the point) rave on Saturday and she told me that I should
watch my back there.  I was totally shocked...watch my back at a rave? 
Why?  Why should I have to worry about anything negative happening to me at
a rave?  She told me that her self-appointed boyfriend (Alex) was on the
rampage after me since last Saturday when she found out what happened to
Alaina.  Anyway, my questions being...A: Should I even go to the rave
knowing that some thuggish wannabe gangsta is going to be looking for me
there?  B:  Does anyone have any other suggestions for Saturday night?  C: 
If you guys see me there with a knife in my back and a bunch of smashed
bicycle lights around me...please pull the knife out and stuff the lights
in my pockets...I'll probably need them at the next rave....  :)

Peace, Love, and many thanks for putting up with my incredibly thoughtless
waste of bandwidth for this post

-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
>From the dawn of time man has sought to
Eat, Sleep, Reproduce and Alter Conciousness...
pLuR
*************************************************
Jason Lucas -=[]=- Drakiel@Aimnet.Com

OK OK Ok...
This is me...
My name is Jason Lucas.  I am a Computer Technician for CompUSA in Newark. 
I am fresh out of high school (graduated in June).  18 years old. (Please
paste nasty age/maturity labels here).  I have only been to four raves
myself.  Fortunately my first one being the Harmony rave about a month ago
up at the campsite in San Jose.  I went with about four friends who had
been going to raves for a while and fell in love with the scene.  I still
can't believe how wonderfully happy everybody is.  The sense of unity at
these events is so strong it can be felt for days afterwards.  I am about
5'11'.  Blue eyes, blond hair.  I live in Livermore (about 45 miles SE of
SF)  If any of you have seen me at a rave.  I usually go all decked out
with glo stiks and bike lights and a whistle to keep the beat if the sound
goes out (which seems to happen at every rave I have gone to). 
Well...that's me.  Any questions?

On Thu, 10 Oct 1996, Niels P. Mayer wrote:

> >         If you are planning on attending this weekend, there are several
> > things you should keep in mind. The last hour of the drive is a dirt road
> > that is fairly steep and bumpy. If you are driving your car should be at
> > least 8-10 inches above the ground.
> 
> 8-10 inches of ground clearance is more than most 4x4 sport utility
> vehicles, e.g.
> 	Ford Explorer      -- 6.7"
> 	Mitsubishi Montero -- 7.1"
> 	Subaru Outback     -- 7.3"
> 
> I guess this means that most of us normal car drivers won't be able
> to make it up there without screwing up our cars.
> 

Well, Scott did make it there in a minivan with 8 people in it.  Many 
different types of cars have driven the road (including a large truck 
carrying a house).  The imporatant thing is that your car is reliable 
(especially your brakes).  If you think that your car can handle a narrow 
windy dirt road up (then down) a moutain then you should be A.O.K.:). 

yay! what an adventure...

tina

hey everyone,

its been a long time since i wrote anything to sfraves.  since i got
filtering mail program (say goodbye to NRRs!) i've made it a habit to read
sfrave mail.  between finishing my 4th year in school and life.. there
hasn't been much time for dancing, but my soul is craving it!!

i'm thinking very strongly of going to stompy a week from now.  i haven't
been dancing in a while and stompy's crowd and music seem to do it for me.
stompy has a really diverse crowd.  i've never seen so many asians in one
club!  and i think townsend has a beautiful light system and clean sound
system early in the night.. i was fortunate enough to hear Johnny Fiasco
the last time I went to Stompy.  I guess i'll have to go out to stompy,
rest, and then to 'get down get down get down' the day after with Terry
Mullan, Johnny Fiasco, Mark Farina, Robbie Hardkiss, Steve Loria, Doran.

My question about Stompy is.. who's Merran from Club Heaven UK?  I've heard
Preston before.  I think Neon Leon has been around for years in SF right?
And is this Mauricio person local.. or is it that guy that makes deep
soothing techno?

i will try to go to both parties.. but i'll make it to at least one..

sun

down you will have to unscrew it out of your tongue. Regardless of if it hurts
and bleeds you need to get it out before it get infected.

On Thu, 10 Oct 1996, Niels P. Mayer wrote:

> >         If you are planning on attending this weekend, there are several
> > things you should keep in mind. The last hour of the drive is a dirt road
> > that is fairly steep and bumpy. If you are driving your car should be at
> > least 8-10 inches above the ground.
> 
> 8-10 inches of ground clearance is more than most 4x4 sport utility
> vehicles, e.g.
> 	Ford Explorer      -- 6.7"
> 	Mitsubishi Montero -- 7.1"
> 	Subaru Outback     -- 7.3"
> 
> I guess this means that most of us normal car drivers won't be able
> to make it up there without screwing up our cars.
> 
> Can anybody clarify if this is the case -- has anybody made it up there
> with a normal car? Will I be able to make it up there in a Mazda Rx7??
> (Probably Not :-( ). Hey wayne -- are you going?? How are you getting
> up there??

That estimate is probably a little high.  I think what Tim was trying to 
convey when he wrote that is that this isnt a sissy road.  There arent 
deep ruts, the only thing that might get some 'low' cars is rocks ons the 
road.  There have been small cars that made it up there.  My minivan does 
it no troubles at all.  If you've been to parties out in the woods on 
dirt roads before and you fellt comfy your car will make it.  Just make 
sure you have good traction and that you travel/drive at a safe speed and 
you will be fine.  

hope to see you there

love scott

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject:  Friday Poetry
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


A little poem I wrote for all of you...

 * * * * * * * *
As I woke up this morning, a frown on my face,
I thought to myself "My life's a disgrace."
The sky was still dim, the air still cool,
And my face was stiff with that nasty morning drool.

"I just hate everything" was all I could say
As I stumbled towards the bathroom to start another day.
"I'm going to brush my teeth, then get in the shower,
Then I'm going to get in my car and drive for an hour,
Over the Dumbarton Bridge, all brakes and stop and go,
Till I arrive in my hell of Shallow Alto."

As I stormed around the house, pissing and moaning,
I managed to hear the radio, out-shouting my groaning.
"T.G.I.F.!" said the DJ in his usual cheezy manner,
And I jumped with shock!  Where was my daily planner?
I flipped through the pages, past old days and weeks,
And when I found what I sought, I really started to tweak!
Much to my suprise, the dj was right:
It was Friday morn already, which means soon:  FRIDAY NIGHT!
So there I was in my skivies, at quarter to seven,
Shouting to the world "I FORGOT TODAY WAS FRIDAY!  THANK GOD, I'M IN
HEAVEN!"

The commute went quickly, and work has been fine,
Because I've been smiling quite broadly and dancing in my mind,
To the music in my head that no-one else can hear,
But the beats are strong and the 303s clear.
It's FRIDAY everybody, the week is finally done!
And with working out of the way, it's TIME TO HAVE FUN!
So I'll see you all tonight, at 215
Or maybe at PLANETARIUM...I might be seen
Regardless where we are or what we all shall do
HAVE A SUPER WEEKEND EVERYONE!  ALL MY LOVE TO YOU!

* * * * * * * *

Much plur to all my fellow corporate ravers!

Ariel
The Wee Li'l Document Specialist.

just sit on it, so I replied to myself, self, you're not stupid, you're not
sitting on that bench because you haven't got close enough to it to sit
down, if you tried to sit now, you'd just fall and hurt yourself, and that's
no good. So I moved to the bench and sat down, I was happy, but soon enough,
this girly came over and sat by me. She was a pretty girl, I like pretty
girls, so I just stared at her. I noticed she was uncomfortable with me
staring at her, I don't know why, it's just that whenever I see a pretty
girly, I think, mmmmm, pretty girl, uuuhuhuhuhuhhhhhh. . . and start to

myself, self, you're stupid, whydin'tyamackondabitch, so I was sad, and I

: Hey all...
: I've had something on my mind this whole week and I just can't come to

: Last Friday I planned on going to the Ground Zero rave with a few
friends. 
: They dogged me (actually...their idea of a better party came up, go to a
: park and drink until they pass out...whoo hoo ;P ) so I was asking around
: at a book store/coffee shop that I hand out at in Livermore.  This girl
: named Alaina who I had met just a few days before overhead my
conversation
: about my dilemna and asked if she could go with me.  I figured, what the
: heck, she seems like a really open-minded person.  Let's do it!  So we
went
: to the party...got there at about midnight after getting EXTREMELY lost
in
: SF.  :)  We danced around a little bit (She doesn't like to dance tht
: much...but me, on the other hand...can't help it when I start hearing the
: beat! So that proposed a problem...) then I found a guy to buy some e
from.
:  I asked her if she wanted to try it and she said 'sure.'  So I asked her
: again just to make sure and she still wanted some.  So I bought a few and
: we went downstairs to buy some water.  I explained her the effects that
she
: should feel and the dangers of doing it.  She seemed like she was ready
so
: we dropped around 1:30.  We danced around a little more and just chilled
on
: a couch for a while.  Still waiting for the e to kick in.  Nope...bunk
: doses.  Couldn't believe it.  Oh well.  I still wanted to dance...so I
went
: downstairs and danced some more.  When I came back.  Some guy was sitting
: with her and talking to her.  I asked her if she wanted me to help her
out
: and she said yes to I very politely told the guy to take a hike.  :)  She
: pulled out this little baggy and showed it to me while telling me that
the
: guy had given her a pill.  He said that it was extacy (sp?  Geez...I feel
: really dumb right about now!) So she took it.  We chilled out for a while
: longer and then all of a sudden she sat up and went "Oh Shit!  I'm
feeling
: it now!"  Then she got this big ole frown on her face and just sat back
and
: held her stomach.  I told her to calm down...just go with it.  Let the e
: take over your soul.  It's a wonderful feeling.  She wasn't liking it at
: all...After sitting next to her watching her eyes glass over and her
: breating getting more and more rapid I picked her up and carried her to
the
: bathroom where she threw it up.  After she threw it up she told me she
felt
: fine and stood up and gave me a big old hug.  Then she thanked me for
: saving her life.  I honestly don't think that I saved her life.  But she
: can believe what she wants.  We went outside and danced some more (she
said
: she was feeling fine).  Then we went back upstairs and sat down on the
: pillows.  She crawled on top of me and started talking to me while
stroking
: my hair and telling me how gorgeous I was.  I knew it was the e talking
so
: I payed it no mind.  Then she started kissing me.  I had been attracted
to
: this woman since I first met her so of course I kissed her back.  Then I
: thought better of it since she was pretty fucked up and I had heard that
: she was kinda sorta seeing this guy back home.  For those of you that
were
: there, you know that the last DJ didn't show so we left around 4.  I took
: her home and haven't heard from her since.  No wait, I take that back, I
: saw her the next day at the coffee shop where she gave me a quick kiss
and
: then ran off.  I was talking to one of her friends today about the Ground
: Zero (here comes the point) rave on Saturday and she told me that I
should
: watch my back there.  I was totally shocked...watch my back at a rave? 
: Why?  Why should I have to worry about anything negative happening to me
at

: rampage after me since last Saturday when she found out what happened to

>         Well, I had an acrylic bar in my tongue the other day, and it kept
> coming loose and falling out. Yesterday, the ball came off while I was   
> eating and I accidentily swallowed it (shit), so I couldn't find anything  
> else to put in place of the bar, except a long screw and a couple nuts.
> Today  I went down to Zebra's and got me a new bar, but the problem is. . .
> The screw won't come out! It won't twist, pull, or budge at all. I suppose
> my tongue healed around the threads of the screw. Now, will the hole
> eventually loosen up (it's slight;y swollen at the moment) and let me get  
> the damn screw out, or do I have to stretch it or somethin? Will sucking on
> ice make my tongue shrink a little and loosen it's grip on the screw?

Yeah, one time I was hammering some barbed wire through my earhole,
just to see if any chunks of brain would come out the other side, cause
I was hungry for some food. And instead of coming out -- it got stuck!
So I used the clawhammer and pulled like a mothafucka and it came out
along with a big chunq o' brain. OOOh that smarts! But now I'm happy
all the time and want to hug everything in site, especially fluffly
lil' sheep. <sinatra>bleating in the night... oh how i love bleating
in the night</sinatra>

PS: someone who knows about this piercing shit suggested -- between
howls of derisive laughter -- that you ice your tongue (a lot) to
reduce the swelling. Then get your ass to a piercing shop (gauntlet or
body manipulations) and let them do the rest. They in turn will perhaps
refer you to a clinic/doctor for antibiotics or further treatment. The
swelling might be due to infection, and/or allergic reaction (hope the
screw wasn't nickel plated). If you're too embarassed to show anybody
-- are you a member of the darwin club?? -- don't try aspirin to
relieve pain or reduce swelling as it will also prevent blood clotting.
Perhaps you might try some over-the-counter ambesol (lydocaine) to numb
your tongue, then use a vice-grip and pull/twist real hard (remember,
righty-tighty, llefty-loosie) ... of course, if you cause major trauma
to your tongue you could bleed to death, especially if you are taking
any aspirin products (try tylenol or advil perhaps). Please take
pictures for us and put it up on the "evolution in action" web site. 

PPS: I am not medically trained you should not take this as official
medical advice. in fact, I think tongue/genital piercing is pretty
stupid but that's just my opinion. it's all fun and games till someone ...

>A little poem I wrote for all of you...
>
> * * * * * * * *
>As I woke up this morning, a frown on my face,
>I thought to myself "My life's a disgrace."
>The sky was still dim, the air still cool,
>And my face was stiff with that nasty morning drool.
>
>"I just hate everything" was all I could say
>As I stumbled towards the bathroom to start another day.
>"I'm going to brush my teeth, then get in the shower,
>Then I'm going to get in my car and drive for an hour,
>Over the Dumbarton Bridge, all brakes and stop and go,
>Till I arrive in my hell of Shallow Alto."
>
>As I stormed around the house, pissing and moaning,
>I managed to hear the radio, out-shouting my groaning.
>"T.G.I.F.!" said the DJ in his usual cheezy manner,
>And I jumped with shock!  Where was my daily planner?
>I flipped through the pages, past old days and weeks,
>And when I found what I sought, I really started to tweak!
>Much to my suprise, the dj was right:
>It was Friday morn already, which means soon:  FRIDAY NIGHT!
>So there I was in my skivies, at quarter to seven,
>Shouting to the world "I FORGOT TODAY WAS FRIDAY!  THANK GOD, I'M IN
>HEAVEN!"
>
>The commute went quickly, and work has been fine,
>Because I've been smiling quite broadly and dancing in my mind,
>To the music in my head that no-one else can hear,
>But the beats are strong and the 303s clear.
>It's FRIDAY everybody, the week is finally done!
>And with working out of the way, it's TIME TO HAVE FUN!
>So I'll see you all tonight, at 215
>Or maybe at PLANETARIUM...I might be seen
>Regardless where we are or what we all shall do
>HAVE A SUPER WEEKEND EVERYONE!  ALL MY LOVE TO YOU!
>
>* * * * * * * *
>
>Much plur to all my fellow corporate ravers!
>
>Ariel
>The Wee Li'l Document Specialist.

Date: Fri, 11 Oct 1996 13:54:08 -0700
From: Alex <bwret@best.com>
X-Mailer: Mozilla 2.02 (Macintosh; I; 68K)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: record bag 10/11/96
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Fresh stack of Jungle plates for anyone interested...
--------------------------------------------------------------
Paul Z, One small step, Prophesy recordings

An excellent mellow 12" perfect for the beginning or end of a night. One 
Small Step is a chilled steppy track with nice sparse bass and apollo 
moon mission samples. The flip is a gorgeous little song with almost 
housy synth stabs. Armchair music at its best.

NU EMOTIONS EP, Smi)e recordings.

Domestic jungle? who would've thought...actually, all of the 4 artists 
here are known. Jamie Myerson supplies us with a typically lush piece 
filled with plenty of heartstring tugging pianos. Sub Zero offers us 
Pressure, a standard though energetic ditty with a female vocal line. DJ 
DB and Tommy D weigh in with an interesting Acid/jungle song. Finally, 
Jason Mouse finishes up the EP with a banging jazzy choon called Better 
World. Solid stuff, I must say...

Art Of Noise, Camilla.../Something always happens, Indochina

Remixes from a forthcoming album in which drum'n bass artists pay homage 
to a classic synth/electro band. This 12" has Doc Scott doing a super 
mellow 2-step version of Something... with strings that just keep going 
and going. J.Majik pulls up the rear with his patented apache break in 
full effect. Fluffy, but nice.

Roni Size, Brute force, Full cycle

Finally found this one. A banging tune from one of the UK's most 
prolific artists. Brut force is dark and mean, yet mysterious and 
soothing at the same time. Has a great breakdown halfway thru. The flip 
side, "secrets" is a pretty standard Roni Size affair: minimal and deep.

Q-Project, The instrumental/solar system, LGR

What you've come to expect from LTJ Bukem's label. A side is an amazing 
journey through melody bliss. The drums take a while to kick in, but 
once they do, the strings cut out and the mood is REALLY dubby and 
bouncy. The flip is a housy jungle track, but lots of fun to mix. Big 
Ups!

Omni Trio 8, Trippin on Broken Beats, Moving Shadow

Mr. Haigh puts out a nice but predictable track. His bass lines have 
been getting more and more funky with time but unfortunately, I can't 
sit with the diva samples. The flip, though, (Soul Of Darkness) is a 
remake of an old choon, and i found this one to be outstanding. Steady 
breakbeat drums, melodic bass and a cool african sounding vocal sample 
for a change.

St. Etienne, The Sea (PFM rmx), Heavenly records.

No review needed. Buy it before it's gone. Everything you've come to 
love about PFM is present here.

Promo- Juice #8

2 Deep minimal steppy tracks. One side has simple shuffle-step drums and 
an entrancing bass line. The flip has a bit more action going with weird 
sounds pulsating thru the speakers. As the song says,"this stuff is 
dangerous"!

Agent K & Majistrate- 2 for the show, Brain records.

These guys can't fail. A side is a cool jump-up track. harp intro is 
sweet and innocent, but the bass, my friends, has other ideas! Halfway 
thru, after the break, the drums go wild! simple simple simple, but so 
good! Flip side is almost as good, but sticks to one steppy beat. Both 
are monstrous trax.

Underworld- Born Slippy (Alex Reese rmx), Wax Trax

Finally got released domestic after Trainspotting became such a hit. Mr. 
Reese shows a lot of restraint, peeling away the "euro" feel of this 
song and going straight downtown with the vibe. Oi Renton!

Brown #1

I know nothing about this 12", but I guess that's the beauty of buying 
records. Who cares about who made the track as long as it does the job. 
2 experimental hardstep trax. A-side is just a bit too dark for my 
taste. Flip side, though, is a masterpiece. A really cool rippling bass 
line wobbles up and down thoughout, while a chill indian vocal snippit 
pierces the air. Interesting AND playable.

Trunk 2, Step to the Edge, Secret History

The second trunk record is an interesting turn for this duo. "Step..." 
appears in two incarnations, one energetic, versus a more dubby option. 
Neither is particularly original, but the programming is solid. The 
b-side set the tone perfectly with a female vocal sample which repeats: 
"Hello, the aliens are coming" again and again. massive! The song breaks 
into a mellow bass heavy journey which has a pleasent old-school feel. 
Recommended.

Tortoise, Galapagos 1 (Spring Heeled Jack Rmx), Thrill Jockey

A wonderful remix of a wonderful band. In case you haven't heard, 
Tortoise is THE SHIT. In the 3rd remix of their last album, SHJ take a 
bluesy guitar piece and turn it into a stormer- contrasting peaceful 
melodies with a quirky analogue bass hits. A perfect set closer.

---------------------------------------------------------
see you next time....
-alex

"Let me have silence always in the centre of the shouting, that is
essential. Let me have silence so that no pin may drop and not be
heard, and not a whisper. Escape us for all our spouting, nor the
needle scratching upon this gramophone of the circular cosmic spot.
Hear me, mark me, learn me, throw the mind's ear open. Shut up the
mind's eye, all will be music. What sculpture of sound cannot, what
cannot as a fluid token words, that nothing else cannot." 

						-Wyndham Lewis

jondabom said
>>huh?

In case anyone else was confused...

A dissection of my poem:

Rave music is beat oriented.  Ravers sometimes play with toys...
   teddy bears,et.al.
Allen Ginseberg is a "beat" poet known for his fascination with young boys,
and his role in the NAMBLA (N. American Man/Boy Love Assoc.)

Ginsberg's gen was known as the beat gen
So is ours
Let's make some noise (rhymes with boys and toys)


><< Ravers play with toys,
> Ginsberg plays with boys
>
> It's a beat generation
> so make some fuckin noise!
>
> =A9
>
> b))merang
>  >>
>huh?


Peter Sandifer

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Oct 12 01:36:23 1996

From: Karen Hardie <pounce@vcn.bc.ca>
Subject: Re: Why techno?
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9610120122.A21082-0100000@opus.vcn.bc.ca>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I think that the whole rave scene IS very tribal, regardless of the 
technological fantasylands that we tend to immerse ourselves in when 
attending raves.  There is a difference between tribal and religious 
ceremony.  Small but it's there.  :)  For me the whole thought of 
"tribal" involves small groups of people who join together at larger 
events to affirm their basic one-ness - kind of like a Star Trek 
convention ... or even a big Cub Scout meet ...

And don't all of us ravers, in one way or another, "worship" technology? 
We may say nah i'm not a slave to it but if you could never ever ever hear
a really yummy track again as long as you lived cos there were NO
turntables i bet you'd be pretty miserable fo a good long time.  I'm glad
we have all sorts of funky gadgets to make life more amusing, personally. 

And the whole experience of going to a rave is fairly ceremonial, at least
going to the large ones ... getting your tix ...  locating the space ...
preparing your gear for the night so you have whatever you might desire on
hand ... choosing the clothes/headgear/footwear/to glitter or not to
glitter?  :)  and then oftentimes GETTING to the damn thing is an 
expedition in itself ....  everyone has their own little pre-party 
rituals. 

I like raving because of the tribal feel ... like we all are a bunch of 
different tribes getting together on friendly ground for a great big 
stompfest to celebrate individuality and friendship.

my $.02
pounce
----------------------------
You know, there are many people in the country today who, through no
fault of their own, are sane.  Some of them were born sane.  Some of
them became sane later in their lives.  It is up to people like you
and me who are out of our tiny little minds to try and help these
people overcome their sanity.
                                           -- Monty Python

suggestion 1-  don't go to ground zero... there will just be a bunch of 
               homey-G's and gangstas circle dancing there.  if you want	
	       to go to where all the friendly people will be, goto outa 
               sight or planatarium (those are the two that stick out in 
               my head, although there could be more)

	       I have yet to go to a party and come home the next day 
	thinking, "Gee,  the music wasn't that great last night, and I 
	don't think i saw anybody smiling all night, and there wasn't a 
	place to sit comfortably, and water was 3.50 per bottle,.... but 
	did you see the size of the 3-D robot??? It was just incredible! 
	I just wish more parties could be so cool..."

	it's the people, the music, and the vibe that bring me back 
	every weekend...

	       see Alaina again, try to talk to her about...

just my advice

Greetings,

Yet another PHAT party at The Loft...   Shakin booty all night long to the PHAT
House sounds of Mark E. Quark...   for his "Going away" party....    Good
luck in
San Francisco Mark....

And for all you SFRavers up in the Northlands,   WATCH OUT for Mark E.
He'll rock
your sox off..... You got some good DJ'in to look forward to.

Being that I live at the Loft (Well,  not officially of course),   but I
have to say this
party WENT OFF BIG TIME....  I was dancing my ass off all night,  and after
taking a
break from all that House music exposure I've had from San Francisco,  I
have to
say,   this is the finest and PHAT'est house choons I've heard thumpin from
those
speakers in a long time.

The vibe was excellent,  and considering the amount of work that Fletcher
and the
Loft heads had to do to get the 4th floor ready for this gig is nothing
short of
amazing.  I mean,   just hours before the party,  the 4th floor was a disaster.
We jokingly call it the Demilitarized zone....

Also,   Fletcher took my advice and hung the turn tables from the ceiling,
and not
ONE record skip (Except a few places where the Dj or someone standing nearby
caused a musical "glitch")....  A few strange "pops" were heard
occasionally,  but it
was hardly noticeable.

Also,  that same evening,  at the World Beat center,   Ron D. Core was
hammering
out some SICK hardcore,   but those people who went there,   eventually
wound up
at the Loft.

It's really strange,  yet wonderful to live in a space and have 500+ people
dancing
and having fun in your own living space..    Ahhh Yes!!   RAVE HEAVEN....
If I can't
get to raves,  have them come to me....  :-)

T,

If I has an ISP, and I had a major problem, like say; two rats that
chewed into some power cable, crashing my main server, and setting off a
chain reaction across the bay, perhaps I would let my customers KNOW
THAT. Perhaps I wouldn't tell them the problem would be fixed in the
next 30 minutes.  

I would let people know what happened, and suggest that they choose a
hobby outside, in the beautiful Indian-summer day, rather than cling to
their keyboards counting the fucking minutes until its fixed!  I hate
the fact that an ISP thinks I need to be lied to in order to keep my
business.

Slip.net needs a kick in the ass for not having the presence of mind to
IMFORM their clients; and, for not picking up their phone during listed
technical support hours!

Ready for the flames in my asbestos thong underwear, 
D.

which is still a nice little acid box IMHO.

Message-Id: <199610130506.WAA22439@netcom20.netcom.com>
From: Sleepy the Raver <simitzis@netcom.com>

Subject: 215 review from the Steve & Sarah pad
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hey, here's some keyboard in the round party reviews of 215...
Members of the board:
Steve (that's me!), Sarah Aberant (my grooovy housemate), Ryan
(Sarah's friend from Canada).

Steve: music kicked ass. Ambient jungle in the basement was beautiful.
Theta Blip had a killer set, but he should have been earlier. I was
too tired to handle the intensity of his set at that hour. Ethan was
spinning opposite and delivered the perfect set :) Too many floors;
too much walking; the energy of the place seemed very scattered.  The
after-party at Steve & Sarah's (hey, that's us!) capped off the night
perfectly as we watched the sunrise from the roof :) And thanks to all
for giving a listen to saturn5 - it was fun playing to other people

Sarah: music was yummy. mars and mysterE- yipeeeeeeeee!! they really
know how to get a crowd goin. couch in the elevater looked fun, tho 
i didnt get a chance to ride it =( party seemed to die around 530, 
but dats ok cuz i was tired. too much dancin not enough sleep. too 
tired to think now. time to sleep. 
sunrise was beeeeeoooootiful. 

where were ya matt??? we missed ya.

Ryan: woosh -- i'm from toronto canada and this was my first party in SF and
i was kindly impressed by the overall vibe which was warm from the moment i
stepped in the door until i left -- lots of variety in the music, and a
great feeling of purposefullness to the night ... party left a tad early, but
i danced so hard earlier that i needed to sleep anyways.  love the city,
hope to be able to come again for a longer period of time soon... 

love and phleas,
Steve

Subject: Re: NRR:Synth question
To: simitzis@netcom.com (Steve Simitzis)
Date: Sat, 12 Oct 1996 22:34:32 -0700 (PDT)
Cc: camp@apple.com, trose@uclink2.berkeley.edu, sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <199610130411.VAA02638@netcom6.netcom.com> from "Steve Simitzis" at Oct 12, 96 09:11:50 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL17]
Content-Type: text
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Steve Simitzis writes...
> > The Fatman sounds more like a MiniMoog than a 303.  If you're looking for 
> > the 303 sound, buy a 303.....Nothing (at least that I've heard) can even 
> > come close to the sound of a real 303.  
> 
> Unless you get lucky at your local yard sale, plan on spending $1500-$2000
> for a real 303, though. I hear the Syntecno TB303 clone is closest thing.
> Caveat: it's from Europe, direct mail only, but I have some email info
> coming to me in about a week that I can forward if anyone's interested.
> 
> It goes for around $650. For $550, you can get the Novation Bass Station,
> which is still a nice little acid box IMHO.

some of the new boxes like the syntecno sound similar to the 303 but none
so far have come close to really emulating the 303.  the clone boxes
do not have a sequencer on board and so you have to drive them from an
external sequencer.  the way the 303's internal sequencer drives its synth sound
making features (oscillator, filter and amplifier) is what makes it unique.
the clones have the same (or close enough) basic synth (osc, filter, amp), but
you would have to spend a lot of time using a external sequencer to make a
novation pattern sound like a 303 pattern.  what a pain...  also, the 303's
totally user-hostile UI and flaky buttons make it easy to come up with random
patterns, which sometimes are insanely good :)

the cloners are getting close (even roland is a cloner nowadays), but without
the 303 sequencer (or a way to emulate it) and the randomness, people are still
gonna want the 303.  i do have faith that someday, someone will be motivated
enough to really clone the 303, but so far, no dice.

for a starter synth i would recommend a used korg poly 800, casio cz-101
($100ish), sequential circuits six-track ($300ish), or even the novation with
the keyboard.

I saw my first circle dancers last night at the 215 party...weird!!!
I was dancing my booteeee off around 2:00am and some chick starts dancing
around me and some other guy next to me...looking at us &stuff...Im just
like...yeah...Im dancin...give me some space ... but she keeps movin in on
both of us...gettin in my space & stuff, so I back up... so this guy
thinks whatever... it seems like hes like "yeah, Im yours baby" or
soemthing, so they start doin this bizarre mating ritual right in fronmt
of me, he does this dance in a circle for her, taking up this huge space
just so he can do his whatever stoopid footwerk, then they switch & she
does this dance for him...and then they leave together...f*****g weird!!!!
	other than that i had a rad time, floor one (the one you entered
on) kicked my but the whole time...rad tunes...my second sober party in  a
row & I still danced my bootee off for over 4 hours!!
woohoo!!!!

OK OK OK...flame me all you want but I had a BLAST at Ground Zero.  This
was the biggest rave that I have gone to and I loved it!  There were so
many wonderful people there.  I was mostly walking around outside, just
talking to all the people (everyone was trippin' off my spinning bike
light).  Then I went inside and danced my booty off, I even dropped my bike
light a few times, and someone actually followed me all the way across the
room to give it back to me!!!!!  I met some wonderful women there too...It
seems like there were a lot of high school kids there, but I didn't mind. 
They were all dancing their a**es off like the rest of us!!!  Bottom line,
had a blast.

<<<Rave On!!!>>>

P.S.:  Heard DJ Ghost spin for the first time.  This man is AMAZING!!!
       Everyone told me, don't give him any props, he's an arrogant
       sunuvvabitch, so when I was watching him, I was trying to catch
       his vibes.  He seemed like he was a little arrogant in the way that
       he dresses and the expression on his face.  But when we all started
       whistling, he just looked up and out into the crowd and the
       phattest smile busted out on his face.  It was great to see that he 
          
       was having just as much fun spinning for us as we were having
       dancing to his beat.

************************************************

Hugs, Love and much pLuR to ya!
Jason Lucas -=O=- Drakiel@Aimnet.Com

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Oct 13 17:38:12 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id RAA21641; Sun, 13 Oct 1996 17:38:12 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from melvax.sonoma.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with ESMTP id RAA21631; Sun, 13 Oct 1996 17:38:08 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from plasticdreams.sonoma.edu (SA-6EN38.sonoma.edu)
 by SONOMA.EDU (PMDF V5.0-5 #8366) id <01IALPEXNLB496VOGB@SONOMA.EDU> for
 sfraves@hyperreal.com; Sun, 13 Oct 1996 17:37:58 -0800 (PST)
Date: Sun, 13 Oct 1996 17:39:44 -0700
From: Jonas Hanning <hanning@SONOMA.EDU>
Subject: Ground Zero
X-Sender: hanning@sonoma.edu
To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-id: <3.0b36.32.19961013173941.006b4970@sonoma.edu>
MIME-version: 1.0
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Pro Version 3.0b36 (32)
Content-type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Ok, so this was a lot bigger than last week's CCC party. But was it a lot
better? Well, read my "review" and you might figure out how I feel. =)

When we got to HomeBase in Oakland we were met by a HUGE line. Ok, standing
in line isn't THAT terrible. But then the security people started letting
girls walk past all the guys. Excuse me for not being from around here, but
WHAT THE HELL WAS THAT ALL ABOUT??? I thought raves were all about letting
people be who they are, and not putting anyone in front of anyone else. But
I guess that doesn't apply to high school dances (oops, I mean RAVES) in
Oakland.
We did get in after about 45 minutes in line, and the place is not bad for
a rave. In fact, it's a REALLY cool wherehouse. Two "rooms" separated by a
not-too-thick wall. In the big room some hard 4-beat with lots of drum'n'bass
was being spun. I have to admit that I liked the first 2 hours of it, mostly
because of the fat acid beats that were dropped with all this breakbeat.
Then, at 2:30 or something, I made the move into the smaller of the two rooms.
In this room, the room progressed from hard techno to 4-beat and hardcore
during the wee hours of the night. Big ups to whoever was spinning in there
at 3:15am for dropping MARRS' "Pump Up the Volume". Too bad 75% of the crowd
were too young to know what it was. I've never seen so many trainspotters
trying to get a glimpse of the record currently being spun! =)

The crowd yeah...Well, I guess there was nothing else to do for Oakland
teenagers
last night. A high school crowd means two things...gangs wandering around
trying
to look a lot cooler than they really are, and girls all dressed up. I most
definitively do NOT have a problem with the second part, but who'd want to pay
$25 ($20 with a stuffed animal or toy!) to walk around and look cool all
night?
Not me. But most of the crowd seemed really up for it. And no wonder, the vibe
was really good, and so was the music. If you don't happen to think that 
breakbeat is dead. =)

Oh yeah, $2 for a bottle of water! ARGH! Put a f**king tap and let us drink
from
it, we don't need the "good" stuff!

Altogether, a great night. I apologize to all those who tried talking to me. 
When you stand 10 feet from the speakers, it's hard to hear what people are
saying to you. =)

reespect, jonas
***********************************************************
