Here's something that I found interesting. For people that connect on high 
bandwidth. Wouldn't recommend it if your modem is anything less than a 28.8.

Forwarded Information:
>From: PopFlash (pop-info@hotwired.com) on Sun, 13 Oct 1996 11:21:59 -0700 (PDT)
To: pop-announce@hotwired.com
Subject: PopFlash 14 Oct 96

PopFlash
http://www.pop.com/

It's my second week sending out this newsletter about the HotWired
Network's arts and entertainment section Pop, and I've got good news and
bad news.

The bad news is we had to cancel a planned feature that included videos of
Pop staffers doing a striptease while throwing virtual money that literally
flies out of your screen and turns into real money. We just couldn't get
the techology to work right. The good news is we are posting a special
multimedia show, made for Pop by The Future Sound of London.

This feature, which posts on Monday, 14 October, is a sort of surfing
safari. As you listen to 20 minutes of original techno music in RealAudio,
photos and images made by the band (and quotes from interviews) flash on
your screen. By the way, the show runs for a few weeks, then disappears.
So if you want to see it, don't wait too long.

Also coming up this week:

Monday, 14 October:
TeeVee: Harmon Leon tells you all about the new fall shows -
so you don't have to watch them.

Tuesday, 15 October:
Reading: People treat computers like humans and even favor boy computers
over girl computers, as John Alderman discovers by reading the new book,
"The Media Equation."

Wednesday, 16 October:
Music: Rob Levine sticks up for Jon Spencer's faux blues, plus remix
music from Freaky Chakra vs. The Single Cell Orchestra.

Thursday, 17 October:
Movies: Mike Tanner dares to complain about Mike Leigh's
much-loved "Secrets and Lies," plus Barry Levinson talks about "Sleepers."

Friday, 18 October:
Multimedia: HotWired tech expert Mike Kuniavsky explains the problem
with electronic arts festivals.

One last thing: Pop is one of the sponsors of the Low Res Digital Film
Festival, which runs at The Kitchen in New York this week. If you go,
please stop by the Pop booth, so I won't have to sit there alone. And if
you're not in New York, you can see short film clips and hear audio
interviews with the filmmakers on our site.

The Low Res Feature is at:

     http://www.hotwired.com/popfeatures/96/34/index4a.html

See ya,

Michael Small, producer of Pop

---

From: "matthew d. p. k. lanier" <mdpkl@best.com>
Subject: nrr: matt, the virtual raver
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

hello all-

after doing a lot of thinking, i think that i'm finding myself going the
same path as larry ching (having to significantly cut down on the raving for
a while and focus on some other things).

why, do you ask?

well, i find that my priorities have already shifted without me knowing it.
the past 4 weeks, i've wanted to go raving, but something has gotten in the
way every week.  coincidence, or is that my brain trying to tell me something?

plus, i'm finding that raves don't mean nearly as much to me as they used
to.  i love the music, i love the people(i'd like to do a list here, but
that would take far too long), i love the energy, but it's just not speaking
to me any more.  i need to find out why, and to find what will speak to me.

so, i shall restrict myself to the parties that are most special to me (fnf,
f8, harmony), and embark on whatever journey it is that my mind is calling
me on.

love-

matt
matthew d. p. k. lanier
professional hugger and empath
mdpkl@best.com
415-752-3218

Dear Friends & Family,

	For everybody complaining about sportswear at raves, here's a
brief historical tip on where to direct your ire:

"In the late 1970s the American designer Norma Kamali was instrumental in
bringing sportswear into the fashion arena, introducing sweatshirting
ra-ra skirts, bandeau tops, jumpsuits, leotards and leggings.  Stretchy
Lycra yarns, developed by Du Pont in 1959, were in use by the 1970s and
did much to improve the appearance and fit of sports and fashion clothes.
Another significant originator of the sportswear trend was the reggae
musician Bob Marley, who appeared on stage in football gear and tracksuits
from the late 1970s.  By the early 1980s tracksuits and training shoes had
become a fashionable uniform among young urban black youth and were
subsequently adopted by both sexes and all ages, as comfortable leisure
wear."
	-_Costume & Fashion_, pp. 272-273, by James Lavar, (C) 1995

	Now you can give Senor Marley's mural the evil eye when you're walking 
up Haight Street.
   
Much love,
				<<< Starchild >>>

First let me tell you I've decided to come back, I just couldn't leave all
you wonderful people. You all are great.

This weekend was amazing. The 215 party was PHat with a "PH". 5 or 6 floors
with some really good DJs. Great vibe, and great people. Mars, Mystr-E,
Ethan were throwing down some killer sets, but the one that really warped
my mind was DRC. She spun one HELL of an awesome set. Had me going the
whole time.

I'd love to see another party at the CBC again.

Saturday night I went to a little party at Stanford. Well it wasn't so
little in the beginning, but just about half way through the night half of
the people left and then that's when the real party started.  I had a blast
at both parties. I'm really glad I went out this weekend.

Tim (knucklehead)

From: "SpinSilver--'Robertj@Monterey'" <silver@salinas.net>
Subject: Planetarium Campout dreams.....
Sender: owner-sfraves@Hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

hey......it's 6:30am.......The clocks buzzing..I look at it and the first
words out of my mouth are a big "FUCK!!!"  Where was I during the last 36
hours????

I thought I had died an gone to rave heaven...A party on a hilltop,360
degree views that only god could make to remind us to be humble,love nature,
love each other and the MUSIC.  An such music "that would bring tears to the
eyes of the Angels."  Roughly translated, this means "da bomb!!"

I want to thank Joe Rice for needing a little sleep on Sunday morning, and
letting me spin for about 50 minutes.....it was the first time I had played
anywhere other than my living room...I couldn't have asked for a better spot...

I had crawled out of my tent after two hours of sleep and forced myself to
go over to the other music just to see Joe..or see if he was still
playing..I tried to hear some of all the 20 or so dj's playing..he was
asleep, and I was toasted, and barely awake enough to play myself......I
cannot begin to review them all now..I've got a hot bath and coffee waiting
to get me to work...

I was wearing my trusty Ameba dayglow rave shirt for those I didn't get a
chance to meet...

But, to the Cloudfactory crew...Much love and respect, thanks for letting me
be part of the party....andmy deepest bow of respectand offering of love and
appreciation to all the dj's who played and played and played....for future
reference, those of you who were afraid to brave the dreaded 9 mile dirt
road that killed 4 cars..."the harder a party is to get to, the better the
party is gonna be"...

                                              More later......SpinSilver

Happy Monday fellow ravers,

I'd like to say that Prop 215 was one of the most insprational,
mindlifting, thought provking, and just pretty danm good party I've been
to in a looong time...  Between dancing, chatting, breaking away for
some time in solitutde and all in the span of about 10hrs...  Really
good time.  DRC had a real ripping set,  MARS, Mystr-e, @ Ethan did some
fine selections in the trance genre.  I also liked the DJ that spun a
jungle set early on 'round  9:30 or so...  

Highlights:  
		Chilling out with a couple of fellow DJ's discussing the trance scene,
prop 215 itself as we
"We get it..."
ll as the rave culture in general.
		Dancing in a Capoeria circle w/a fellow artist (that's always fun).
		Coming back to this reality and realizing that you've been dancing
almost 5 hrs straight...

Lowlights:
		Having to see the party end.
		Saturday - with the soreness associated with it.

The remainder of the weekend was pretty NRR but interesting never the
less.


---Adam

Precedence: bulk


Hi!

 Well I really wanted to go to Planeterium but my circumstances prevented 
that. Happily the 215 benefit was really fun. For me the best part was 
the crowd. Very aware and diverse crowd who were all there to support a 
vitally important issue; personal control of our own medical care and 
medication [at least that is how I read prop 215].

 The building was a labyrinth of rooms with something for everyone, 
including a live band room. As it was my night off I mostly took it easy. 
Danced to some cool techno in the basement and missed everybodys set that 
I really wanted to catch :(. But that was okay as I met someone who it 
was important for me to meet. The two of us spent most of 4 to 5 hours 
talking about interwoven realities and the light beings who becken from 
beyond. She is a student at Berkley who is attempting to construct a 
major she calls transpersonal psychology.

 It was very cool to run into Steve, Wayne, Marcie, Jonathen and Sharron 
(!?!), Tim, Dutch, Raven, Owen and a few others I'm having trouble 
recalling at this moment.

 Big thanks to my hosts earlier in the evening; the dinner really hit the 
spot and as usual the magick was flowing.


peace ya all,

Ran

                            -=*=-
                              ~



PS; This was originally intended for sfraves but I felt that there were 
    tidbits in here that would be good to share with the knowoneness list.

On Mon, 14 Oct 1996, Randy C Cone wrote:

> 
> Hi!
> 
>  Well I really wanted to go to Planeterium but my circumstances prevented 
> that. Happily the 215 benefit was really fun. For me the best part was 
> the crowd. Very aware and diverse crowd 

this is true. it's things like these, or the Haight St. Fair, that are a
reminder of just how big this blanket term of alternative, or freak,
culture really is. Myia even brought her mom along.

usually whenever I feel too much spectator energy being thrown around at a
party i find myself getting really resentful. it's like, "Fuck you man,
i'm not your Home Entertainment System. you've got muscles, use them."
but this was different. we were guests, or maybe just a novelty act, in
someone else's home/culture. didn't find myself getting resentful even
once that night.

showed up at around 2 to help set up. by 4 i had cleared out most of the
3rd floor and was stoned. by 6 Denis was out of jail, the story had made
ABC news, and i was baked. by 8 i was helping Tristian with the basement
and was comfurtably numb. the music started at around 9:30 and that's when
i moved on to my pharmaceuticals. all in all, a good night for many.

hanging out with Doug in the trance room, i mentioned the high turn out of
raver superheroes that night and Doug goes "yeah, we've all become 
figureheads." and i laughed. but thinking back on it he might of said
"yeah, we've all become pawnheads" or even, "yeah, we've all become 
fishheads." i don't know, we were both pretty fucked up.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Oct 14 09:18:43 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id JAA03922; Mon, 14 Oct 1996 09:18:43 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from gcwf.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with SMTP id JAA03901; Mon, 14 Oct 1996 09:18:38 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from SOCAL-Message_Server by gcwf.com
	with Novell_GroupWise; Mon, 14 Oct 1996 09:18:51 -0700
Message-Id: <s262057b.080@gcwf.com>
X-Mailer: Novell GroupWise 4.1
Date: Mon, 14 Oct 1996 09:22:46 -0700
From: Ariel Stallings <ASTALLINGS@gcwf.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject:  Ariel's 215 Review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


What a space that was!  SIX floors o' fun...although it seemed to me
that the basement, 1st & 3rd floors were the ones to be on...Although
the CHILL space on the 5th floor (literally: the room had to be 20
degrees cooler than the 1st floor) was nice.

A good night and a good crowd, although I have to say it:  I really
like trance, BUT I AM STARTING TO FEEL OVER-SATURATED.  DRC's set was
amazing, honestly, but you KNOW you've heard too much trance when you
start thinking "this is cool, bu-u-u-u-u-ut..."  I spend some time on
the third floor which was nice, but there were some folks with
attitude going on...There was one guy in warmup pants, a white
wife-beater tanktop, fisherman's hat (can we say "CYPRUS HILL,"
kids?) and SUNGLASSES who I was this-->  <---  close to saying "well,
you've got the ATTITUDE to dance, but I haven't seen you move ONCE,
asshole." to.  But I didn't.  (tee hee)

It depressed the hell out of me that everyone cleared out at 5 am or
so...seeing as how I was straight-edge clean for the evening (going
to a prop 215 party not even STONED?  how ironic...) and I was
suddenly surrounded by cracked out folks who were just waiting to
sober up before the drive home...What happened to parties that go
strong until 9am?  It felt like a ghost town by 6!  One minute there
was NO room to dance on ANY floor...next time I checked there were 4
people dancing in the main room.

I have to apologize right now for my slightly negative filter to this
whole night: I realized when I left that I was just over-socialized
and needed to NOT BE AROUND PEOPLE for a while.  You can imagine how
being burnt out on people and sober and tired would make for a wee
li'l grumpy gruver.  So, instead of hanging with my family of friends
in Berkely, I went home alone, took a shower and slept the morning
away.

ahh!

sorry, this got slightly NRR, my apologies!

Ariel

At 5:34 AM -0000 10/13/96, Eric Pederson wrote:

>> Unless you get lucky at your local yard sale, plan on spending $1500-$2000
>> for a real 303, though. I hear the Syntecno TB303 clone is closest thing.
>> Caveat: it's from Europe, direct mail only, but I have some email info
>> coming to me in about a week that I can forward if anyone's interested.

I have a Syntecno TeeBee 303... pretty fuckin killer. Has accent, has
slide, same oscillator, same five potentiometers as the 303, plus full MIDI
control over all the above, plus 4 midi to CV gates each of which you can
assign its own midi channel... tough little box.

Key differencee as noted, is the sequecning UI, I know the box can make the
sounds but figuring out what the hell it looks like in studiovision is not
easy... sigh.

see ya
ethan

     This reminds me of the first circle dancers i saw at the gathering 
     newyesars thning on dec 31 1992 at solano? county fairgrounds.  it was 
     raining.  i remember that.  it was definitely raining.  we stood 
     outside for like 1 1/2 hours in the cold, it hadn't started raining 
     yet, and when we finally got in, it was completely packed.  
     
     when i entered the restroom facility, the floor was covered with about 
     1/2 of water that had overflowed from (somewhere) |(  yuck  
     
     there were circle dancers 
     
     there were couples procreating everywhere.  some of them you wanted to 
     join in, they were gettin pretty heavy.  
     
     that reminds me of the drive back in the rain.  this was only the 2nd 
     party i had been to and i was feeling, well, good.  we fit 5 of us 
     into tiffy's little black car and listened to 'inside the mind' for my 
     first time.  wow.  
     
     those were the days.   
     
     deepfog

Subject: Planeterium...a review

WOW!

A great word to sum up this party and the cloud factory crew.  They did an
amazing job setting up and they have the most incredible vibe.  I rarely
meet a group of people that throw parties that i am so impressed by. Thank
you SO much for the fruit, COFFEE, and muffins in the morning. A VERY nice
touch...hey guess what the water and coffee were FREE, what a strange concept.

The party....
Well first i'd like to thank everyone for driving up there because those of
u that did made my night! I might a lot of cool people and some from
SFraves..Finally! the spot was amazing..atop a mountain in the middle of
nowhere.

The sound system atop the hill was great and the other one pretty good.  The
music and dj's were amazing.  I actually danced sober for quite a while. I
got to see alot of dj's i normally don't get to...thanks for the tunes.
There were also 2 good live acts.

Hello to all my new friends and THANKS..i had a BLAST.

Such a GREAT VIBE there!

much PLUR
Micron

>thinks I am stuck up and is now trying to seek revenge.

chill out jeff... Its just annoying seeing people's personal mail going to
SFR... I'm not trying to police it because there's too much "gray area" in
what shouold or shouldn't go to SFR, but there's definitely some stuff that
just straight up doesn't belong there... like alot of the shit that's been
posted in the past few days: "I'm going to dress up like a raver!" "All
theez girlz iz gotz to be getin with me'zzzzz" etc., etc., etc... Now's
about the time of the year when all the new college freshman discover that
they can do e-mail for free without learning any decent netiquette. (this
was me 1 year ago, so don't think I'm trying to sound uppity or anything)
Please, everytime crap gets posted to the list it wastes my bandwidth, my
time, YOUR time, and bogs hyperreal down even more and fucks up sfraves in
ways that can't just be solved with the delete button (i.e. bounced
messages, overloaded bandwidth, etc.)

So take a big fat gelcap chill pill and smile, because SFR can benefit
everyone but not when it's being abused.

BTW, this discussion shouldnt even be on the list. It finds its way there
far too often... I'm not going to post about it after this one teensy
weensy note (sorry kids!)

Jeff I'd like to meet you some day, because often people come accross in
very wierd, unlike-their-true-selves sorts of ways through e-mail.

smiles and such,
-m.

Hi hugz@pacbell.net!

  Feelings of panic..  What I mean is:

       A few dayz after E'ing, I alwayz get these high ang.. enziaty..
engziatie... (PANIC) attacts..  Like for example... I will be in my car
driving. I want to get into the next lane, so I put my blinker on, but the
car in the lane I want to go into starts to speed up. Either I can cut him
off now, or I can wait for him to pass. No biggy.. But when I get these
panic feelings.. It's like once I notice him creaping up, I feel all light
headed and confused (only for a sec) almost like a feeling of panic. It's
weird. Another discription: I can envoke this feeling by closing my eye
lidz and moving my eyes around rapidly, this also creates the "rush" panic
feeling.
       Oh and. I also get some really weird back painz.


----------

On Wed, 25 Sep 1996, Steve Simitzis wrote:

--> snip <--
> 
> Hence my take on Bagkok parties: cool DJ's, sketchy people, too many
> area codes. 'nuff said.
> 
> Steve
--> snip---
	

	Okay, okay, I know I'm lagging concerning this thread, but you 
didn't go on vacation and have to return to 2000 rave messages.

	I just have to put in my two pence worth (or $25 worth as might be 
the case)...this party SUCKED.  Aside from trying not to get shot by a 
gangsta, dehydrating to death because the moron at the door took 
everyones water bottles (so they can make money selling theirs), getting 
bored by the live acts, the worse offense is when they took my bottle of 
hand lotion AND, get this, took away my _contact lens eye drops_ (thank 
God the girl behind me in line picked it up and sneaked it to me 
later--<hugs & more hugs> to you)
	I don't bitch concerning these things, but going for my eye drops 
was a bit over the top.

	Where was the chill out?  There were supposed to be a bunch of 
rooms, but I only saw three areas.  I basically spent the whole night in 
the room with the black lights and the cool trancy music.  It was not 
worth the price I payed for only one room of music.  This experience 
really questioned my image of the SFRAVE scene.  However, I realized it 
was just a bad pick out of many good ones (remember not to judge a rave by 
its flyer kiddies), and I tried to make the best of it.  If you were 
there, I was the fanatic in line with the two bright blue glowsticks 
jumping up and down and yelling "Jooooaaaannnaaa."


MD

really, I'm not a geek, honest :) , and could never watch a sLEEzA episode

SFRavers,

Pacific Bell Internet is still looking for Technical Analyst positions
(A.K.A. Phone support for an internet service provider).  This place is
growing so fast that they can't hire enough of us... call up the phone
support number and you'll see what I mean (800 708-inet)... be prepared to wait.

All you need to know is Win95, Win3.x and some Mac.  The staffing supervisor
sits right next to me and she said that as long as you are a computer geek
and know windows 95, then you have a damn good shot.  No experience is
necessary... I didn't have much.  They have a two week training program that
you can learn just about everything you need to know.

Check out the job description.  It sounds really technical... but none of it
is really required.

       http://public.pacbell.net/jobs.html#techan

Call Mitra (staffing supervisor) @ 278-5928
 or me @ 278-5121

Good Luck!

--erik

Hi Andy ... I went and didn't have much fun.
Sadly, it's been so long since I've been in the Acme that I didn't realize
that's where we were headed until it was too late. It was really the same old
Acme; a dirty, overcrowded firetrap with holes in the floor you can see 
through. The music was house, house and more house, and only the sound 
system on the main floor was at all adequate.
Not worth $12 IMO.

take care,

> I've been pretty quite lately, and I havn't been to a party since Harmony's 
> 3yr! So that's about ONE WHOLE MONTH WITH NO RAVING! 

Gosh, I haven't been to a "party" since Burning Man, so that makes it 
almost a month since I've been to anything.  I've been getting into some 
other outside interests as well.  For over 2 years, raving has been my 
main outside interest, and now I have about *4* new outside interests and 
now raving is sorta taking a back seat.  Of course, due to my geographic 
disability (soon to be remedied!!!) and lack of money to make a trip to 
SF every weekend, I usually only go to one rave a month anyway.  If they 
are cheap (as in $10 or under) I usually go to more than one a month.  We 
out-of-towners have to consider extra expenses that you lucky locals 
don't have to worry about.  :):)

> So, I'll save myself for F&F or maybe another party. 

Me too.  I am hoping every single day that you all involved with F&F have 
come up with a space for the party.  I'm not exactly in the mood for 
Funky Techno Tribe.  I only wish I could be closer to help out.  Only 2 
more months and I will! (that's when Mel and I are moving to SF!!)

The other party I am definately going to is Tom's party 2o12.  Hell yes.

Amy

It was COOL!!!  When I realized it was at Acme I began to panic and thought I
had made a major mistake in my plans for the night but I decided to trust
there would be no fire or earthquake that night.  Their was neither and I had
an awesome time.  I don't really know if I ever heard Doc Martin.  Everytime
I would ask someone who the current DJ was they always said it was Jeno.
 This was from the time I got there, 11:00 to when I left at 4:00....now I
don't know if that is really true or not so if someone who was actually
paying attention could report what dj's were playing at certain times it
would be nice.  

If anyone cares to know I was the girl with chopsticks in my hair.  I spent
most of the night in the very bottom floor because it was MUCH cooler so I
didn't reallly see everyone.  

I hope everyone who went had a good time.  I also had a good time at 215 but
I left kinda early, 2:30, because I was really tired.  It was nice to have
toilet paper in all the bathrooms for a change and the cannabis club was a
nice place to have a party, lots of nice people.

Love,
           Megan               Czefir

Okay. I'm kinda sad. I just moved up here from orange county. I loved 
the L.A. party scene, I made so many friends and there was always a good 
vibe. The music was great too. I was so happy to come up here because 
everyone always told me how great the sf parties were, that they blew 
away the LA ones.
When I came up here I went to Mega Buzz one and the vibe was kinda bad. 
I think what started it was the fact that within the first half hour of 
being there I got grabbed about 30 times. That's not what this is all 
about! There were all of these little boys running around grabbing 
people and trying to hook up! Also I noticed a lot of gangsters. I 
thought I was gonna get killed. I thought it was just because it was 
such a publicized big event, but all I read about in every e mail here 
is about gangsters and circle dancing and "mateing rituals". Is it this 
bad all the time.

Dear Ms. Tee,

Check out Beautiful People/Harmony parties. They hit me with the silly
stick every time.  Pay attention to what folks say online about upcoming
events...you can get a good idea about what the turn-out *might* be like.
Also, contact jondabomb@aol.com for info on a warmvibey party he's throwing
on November 15.  Jon's da bomb but he won't grab your butt.

You like bigger parties, you say?  Check out 2nd Chakra (put on by Nexus)
on November 9.  Their parties are larger but nice.

Big flyers do not a good party make!

Don't give up on us.  You'll probably need to do a little bit of homework
on the local scene before you figure it all out.

Love,

b))merang

Hey, anyone else feeling like there were slim pickin's for parties
this weekend? Okay, 215 was pretty good (despite the mixed vibe), but

(unless you were up for the road trip style party). And no *Sunset*?
arg!

will coming from the Bahia tonight...

As a side note, Sarah & I caught a view of the Bahia Cabana last
night...  I guess it was salsa night. So creepy to see salsa dancers
groovin' at a raver party spot :) Imagine a death metal show at the
Acme; it was sort of like that.

Whats up with all this Gangster stuff?
 I see alot of people at the big parties that look like gangsters yea. But 
they don't start no trouble. Whats with this stereo typing? Poor people, 
can't dress the way they want with out being classified. And if they really 
are gangsters, give them alittle credit! They seem to be respecting more 
than 50% of the venu'z rules.
 As far as grabbing a$$ez...  Most girls seem alittle more loose at the 
raves (correct me if I'm wrong). Hell most of them that approach me seem to 
want me to be that blunt or rude. I bet that azz grabbing stratagy works 
more than it fails.

  Now don't get me wrong or anything.
  There's no way in hell "I" would indulge myself in such temtations. To 
grab someones booty like that showz you have no respect for women. AND no 
respect for yourself. You might aswell be one of though weirdo'z that 
masterbate in public!
  And I have seen one fight started by "what appeared" to be a gangster at 
a rave. I don't think that all should pay for the acts of the one.

I do believe that this "RAVE" scene iz making a difference in are 
community.
But if all of us start casting out people becouse of the way they look. 
Were going to end up back at the beggining agian.

P.S. Bad spelling, bad timing, and to much calls at work made this letter 
alittle less readable and understandable. Sorry.
  

Jff

Subject: Once again, I've proven myself right.
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


        San Francisco, and the parties that surround that area are the
epitome of what raving is all about.  I've only been there twice, and both
parties I attended are on my top 5 list ( near the top :).  This time it was
Planetarium, thrown by those spectacular Cloud Factory people.
        What can I say?  This party was fantastic.  The location was
brilliant. I don't know how many people I talked to that told me they had
never seen so many stars in their entire life.  And the sunset/sunrise!  I
won't even attempt to describe them in words.  I didn't even know the sky
could get that beautiful. 
        I couldn't believe the Dj'ing that was happening that night, either.
My belief that 80% of the really good DJ's in the world haven't even played
a party yet was confirmed.  People I'd never even _heard_ of were simply
kicking my ass up and down that mountaintop.  I don't know how I'm going to
deal with some of the shoddy spinning around here that passes as "good" now. :)
        The real reason I'm posting, though, is for the people I met.  I
showed up at the sight at about 10:00 on Friday night and knew maybe 1-2
people there ( aside from those I drove up with ).  By the time I left at
12:30 on Sunday, I had around 20 beautiful new friends.  You all down there
are simply amazing.  Never before have I met such a large group of
accepting, embracing people.  Absolutely breathtaking.
        So, to wrap this up, I'd like to ask all those that I managed to
meet, and who are on this mailing list, to get in touch with me.  I don't
want to lose contact with any of you great people.  Always know this, too.
You _have_ a place to stay if you are ever in Eugene, OR ( yes, we do have
parties in Eugene, OR :).  Take care.  I love you all!

Hugs,
Beau

PS If any of you know Shakti ( who lives in Eugene but was visiting for the
weekend ) then _please_ get in contact with me.  
########## #####     #### #### ########## 2  Beau Burke
####    ## #####     #### #### ####    ##    Eugene, OR
########## ######### ######### ##########    beau@gladstone.uoregon.edu
####       ######### ######### ####  ###     beau@hyperreal.com
####       ######### ######### ####   ###    http://www.efn.org/~beau_b

Greetings Hungry Ravers;

Tonight=92s Raver-fest =91O=92 Food will happen in vintage North Beach!  =
Our
last dinners were Thai, Mexican, and Indian, so its about time we had
Italian food.   Parking may be a problem, so try to double up and
ride-share.  Dinner is at 8:30pm, but we always order around 9-ish, and
we wait for latecomers.  It sounds like everyone had a full weekend, so
come and talk about it.  =


Capp's Corner =

                                     =

Italian cuisine at 1600 Powell Street (at Green St.),   San Francisco
Telephone:   (415) 989-2589

Capp's offers four-courses, plus pasta for $11.50. Leg of lamb, osso
bucco or roast chicken star. =

Prices:   Inexpensive, entrees under $7

Directions:

   Use the Civic Center/Van Ness Exit.  Drive North on Van Ness, =

   turn right on Union Street, and turn right on Powell Street.  =

   Proceed up one more block to Green, and you are there. =


Who=92s invited?  If you are reading this; you are!

Afterwards we go to MAD. =


   MAD - trance, electro, old school, minimal, hard, detroit, acid
   w/DJs are Andre Lucero. Joe Rice, and Alex.
   2$ before 11pm
   10pm-2am, 18+, $3. Bahia Cabana, 1600 Market St, SF.

(email) RSVP and we will save you a seat!

Precedence: bulk

The only real event I've been to here in the bay area since I moved here is
Harmony.:)  I didn't realize how important raving was to me until I really
had to work to get to one!! In L.A., it was more like I'd have the thought,
"Gee, I feel like going to a party. Maybe an outdoor thing..." and then I'd
be able to find something to suit my tastes. Here in Monterey, I feel like I
have to go to ANY events that look good for fear that I'll miss the chance to
go have some of the kind of fun I like, and see the people I love to be with.


Overall, I am really grateful for this list. It is my security blanket. I
know that without it , I'd be COMPLETELTY lost, and afraid of losing my
raving roots. And, of course I'm grateful for the people who make up the
list. It's really cool to have a source of insightful people to interact with
(even if it is virtually :O(  ).

 So, I guess that I, too, am a virtual raver. And, if I had to choose, I'd
choose virtually over not at all.

I'm from LA too. And, my roommate and I got really discouraged at first.
(We're in Monterey now, to add insult to injury.) But, we still have hope.
Watch this list and ask for help when you need to hook up. The people here
are really nice and helpful. 

I agree that the vibe is different. I wasn't sure that I was going to find
the kind of openness that I knew in LA. I think, though, that the people here
are just more underground than LAites are. There's gold in the Bay area, you
just gotta be willing to dig and remember to look in less obvious places.

From: Rhoda Rossman <rhoda@via.net>
Subject: Tribal Future
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

As one of the first returnees, I would like to answer the following
frequently-asked questions:  80? people attended, it took 7 hrs. if you
didn't get lost, 10 if you did which was most of us who did not go to burn
the man.  It got down to about 40 at night and not above 75 during the day.
The spring there was a beautiful fountain of thermal water surrounded by
tiered brightly colored mineral deposits - no sulphur odor.  Two 50' dia.
mud bottom 3' deep pools ADJACENT TO - YES the sound system were 95 degrees,
not too hot to make extended soaking possible.  I personally logged a good 4
hours with entertainment as diverse as aquatic dancing, frisbee, teaching
the butterfly, constructing a mud mask and headpiece for one pliant model
frequently referred to as Mud Man, watching the kids play around in an
inflatible boat (thanks, Isaac!)  Oh yes, and the absence of a moon made for
great stellar viewing in the incredible darkness.  It was fun when the sun
rose seeing people who arrived after dark admire the location.  Mark
deserves a lot of credit for organizing this ambitious adventure!  In
addition to some S.F. regulars, people came from the Tahoe area, Santa Cruz,
Harbin Hot Springs, one really cool couple made it from British Columbia-he
being her tatoo artist (designer and execution).

For those of us who like a road trip and good music in a natural
environment, this was the perfect combination.  We enjoyed making camp
together... settlers shoveled cow pies off the dance ground and set up chill
tents... built a fire and brewed tea there all night...made fruit salad for
a hundred in the a.m.  My neighbor made buckwheat pancakes with some stove
on his auto hood and one after another walked up to consume them all with
the same one plate and fork.  Supplies were diverse and freely exchanged,
including specifically some incredible organic Merlot.   

Anyone returning after me - yes, there was raving-on planned until way after
my departure Sun. afternoon:  who went on Sun. nite and did the spring
remain relatively undamaged and did anyone make it back with my blue
drawstring sleeping bag cover?

The fidget-meister speaks true here. I've been going to parties for only
about 10 months but form what I've gathered there are two basic kinds of
parties in the SF scene: What I call "Open" and "Non-Open" parties. The
"Open" parties are what everyone hears about. These parties find you,
you don't have to look very hard and their presence is more noticeable.
"Non-Open" parties, on the other hand limit their exposure and
consequently are reiceved by a select group. (I know this is not exaclty
news to most people here but I've been dying to type this all on paper and
it's in your brain  cells now so youre stuck with it. :P)

But be glad for "Open" parties like Ground Zero, Megga Buzz, ect.!!!
'Raves' are a popular buzzword. People want to go to a 'Rave'. Even if
they don't know what it is. Open parties fill that demand. This enables true
lovers of the scence to function more efectively. So we can do things like
bring Virtual Reality toys from home and let others play with them. (Hint
Hint)

Everyone who reads this is welcome to come to Monday Night Dinner; a
haphazard collection of ravers who get together to properly wind down
their weekend, or, rev their engines for the coming week of parties.  Be
there or be talked about! This week is MAD=92s one year anniversary, it=20
should be fun.

We=92re eating American cuisine tonight at Hamburger Mary's. =20
=20
American cuisine at 1582 Folsom Street (at 12th),   San Francisco
Telephone:   (415) 626-5767

Prices:   Inexpensive, entrees in the range of $5.95 - $7.95.

You feel like you've stepped into somebody's attic at this eclectic
restaurant that serves first-rate hamburgers and good soups.=20

Veggies and vegans take heart! (oh wait, that would be carnivorous: take
note, instead) Hamburger Mary's has a fine selection of dishes for you.

Directions:

Take 80 towards the Golden Gate Bridge.  Use the Ninth Street/Civic
Center Exit.  Turn left on Harrison, and turn right on 12th Street:
you=92re there!

This week is MAD=92s one year anniversary so be sure to join us!  For the
one-year anniversary, the four original residents (Jon Santos, Ethan,
Joe Rice, and Alex) will be playing.

_MAD_ - trance, electro, old school, minimal, hard, Detroit, acid
   2$ before 11pm,    $3   10pm-2am,     18+=20
   Bahia Cabana, 1600 Market St, SF.

oops!  I didn't mean to make my message sound like a flame; I apologize to
Diana and others who thought I was being abrupt when really I was trying
to make sure people understood why I had to forward the message and why it
bounced in the first place.  I do tend to be curt in email only because I
get a lot of it and can't spend more than about 20 seconds in most email
messages, particularly when dealing with list bounces and such, and since
I figured that message was particularly time critical. 

Anyways, I didn't mean to imply that you shouldn't send messages about
dinner to the list; quite the opposite I think it's great to get something
like that going, and I hope to get to a dinner one of these nights, and
more involved in sfraves stuff in general.  Definitely still send notice; 
but if you need to send it personally to a bunch of other people too, I
just recommend making it a separate message.  Actually, there is another
very good reason to do that - if you want to send it personally to a bunch
of people so it doesn't go into people's filtered mailboxes, then
including "sfraves" in the To: field will probably defeat that purpose
anyways. 

Sorry about the confusion.

	Brian

Hi,
	Thank you to everybody who responded with their favourite vinyl shops,
	Adam, Andre, Alex, Shannon, Shimako, illumin8. We basically hit Haight
	in SF and ventured into F8, Housewares, Ameba followed by Zebra & BPM.
	My visiting friend Mark managed to find a few fine tunes which got his
	weekend off to a great start!

	In the evening we hit 1015 Folsom, and had a good time, but we decided that
	we should have hit the 215 party so on Saturday we loaded up and headed for
	PLANETARIUM which was outstanding. A big thank you goes out to Brian (Flipp)
	who let me follow his Jeep up the dirt track in my 6" clearance Corolla and
	another nod to Brian for his great set in the evening. I was rocked !!

	What a great setup, on top of a mountain watching the stars come out one by
	one until there is a brain numbing amount with a brilliant dj line up. The
	diversity of the music and the quality of the djs made it for me. The icing
	on the cake was all the friendly faces :)

	Having been up to 4am on Friday, I only made it to 2.30 (I tried) before I crawled
	into my tent just as Get Decor (Passion) came on (you should have called it HEAVEN).
	Managed to get up briefly for the Sunrise though (very briefly).

	My friend Mark is just back from 2 weeks in Ibiza and thought that this was just
	so cool that it probably topped his experiences over there! He met everybody
	there and introduced my wife (Frances) & I to Chris, John(with the big fluffy collar),
	Kerry, Steve and probably some others. We also met Jason from San Diego who said it
	was worth the trip (it was) and Adam who said he put on Charity which should run
	again in November. See you there =)

	BTW, I was wearing a black woolly hat and a huge grin ;-()

 - Da Funky Scotsman -

P.S.	If any of you want to stay in touch with Mark in the UK his e-mail is mark@bssl.co.uk
	or he can be reached in Denver (for the next few weeks) at myou@gwl.com

Precedence: bulk

[ from Larry Ching to SFRaves list ]

 This is mostly in reaction to parts of Lee Fogel's reply to something 
KaySEE posted , although it could also be considered my contribution to the 
topic of "Aging and Raves" . I'll try to keep the "me too" statements to a 
minimum...
( LF: == Lee Fogel )

LF: "I still find it hard to compare any experience with the peak moments 
I've had dancing at the better raves in my life... But one thing that has 
become clear over the last 2 years, is that some of us reach a point where 
we want more in our lives than an ongoing continuim of amazing Nows.  The 
Reality Beyond calls for our attention: there's a big, weird world out 
there, for better or worse. "

Me: I've had peak experiences at raves that do rate in the "most profound" 
catagory for me as well; and I also feel that I must do more to find 
spiritual experience outside of the rave scene, as well as finding 
spirituality within it.

 As far as the "big, weird world out there" , that reminds me of something 
attributed to the deceased rock concert promotor Bill Graham. He was a mature 
man when he got involved in the late sixties San Francisco music scene . 
During the 1967 Summer Of Love,he happened to be talking to a young teenage 
hippie , who was gushing on about the experience of tripping and how it was 
the ultimate experience in the world. Graham replied something to the effect 
"Well, have you ever gone skiiing? Jumped out of a plane? Gotten married? 
Held your newborn child in your arms? Have a loved one die?" 

 I may be misquoting, and I don't quite remember how the encounter went from 
there, but what I get from the anecdote is that ordinary living can provide 
isolated moments of intensity and emotional profundity that match any trip. 

 By the way, I think what both have in common is that the experiences from 
life and from LSD do not come about without the decision to take on a risk - 
to DO with the knowledge that one may be hurt in body or heart or soul.


LF: "For many, the responsibilities of careers/family/health call us away."

Me:That's spot on for me right now! 

LF: "Others choose paths that seem to have more substance in a political,
creative, spiritual or social sense. "

Me:Hopefully, I can work the careers/family/health issues with some time for 
some of these things too.

LF:"...Despite its flaws, the rave scene still seems like a wonderful place
to be.  As long as you have your clique of raver friends, it's
pretty hard not to have some great times.  I used to wonder if there
would ever be anything to replace it in my life.  I'm happy to say that
the Universe is an infinitely rich place for endless exploration."

Me: I still love our scene too. I feel I'm at a stage where I should look
for more outside it, while not abandoning it altogether.

 I feel that raves can provide a "doorway" experience to aspects of oneself,
but that what lies beyond those doorways must be found outside our rave house.



 I think I should write more , but I don't know what just now, and I want to
go to bed! Goodnight ...

 Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

On Mon, 14 Oct 1996, Larry Ching wrote:

> [ from Larry Ching to SFRaves list ]

> LF: "I still find it hard to compare any experience with the peak moments 
> I've had dancing at the better raves in my life... But one thing that has 
> become clear over the last 2 years, is that some of us reach a point where 
> we want more in our lives than an ongoing continuim of amazing Nows.  The 
> Reality Beyond calls for our attention: there's a big, weird world out 
> there, for better or worse. "
> 
> Me: I've had peak experiences at raves that do rate in the "most profound" 
> catagory for me as well; and I also feel that I must do more to find 
> spiritual experience outside of the rave scene, as well as finding 
> spirituality within it.
 
>  As far as the "big, weird world out there" , that reminds me of something 
> attributed to the deceased rock concert promotor Bill Graham. He was a mature 
> man when he got involved in the late sixties San Francisco music scene . 
> During the 1967 Summer Of Love,he happened to be talking to a young teenage 
> hippie , who was gushing on about the experience of tripping and how it was 
> the ultimate experience in the world. Graham replied something to the effect 
> "Well, have you ever gone skiiing? Jumped out of a plane? Gotten married? 
> Held your newborn child in your arms? Have a loved one die?" 

life is a trip. be here now. ive met some of the most wonderful people in 
the rave scene. friends come, friends go, some are just faint memories in 
the distance of my consciousness, those memories of laughter and warm 
days in teh sun that seemed they'd never end. i learned something from 
them, thay are a part of me. my friends now are beautiful, creative, and 
full of life. we like to be around eachother, and plan these sometimes 
elaborate gatherings that all of us are a creative part of. we love to 
dance, we love electronic music, and we constantly change. the rave scene 
flows from our creative powers, the creative love we have for one 
another. it is appreciation, it is companionship, it is togetherness, 
sometimes in a sweaty warehouse, sometimes on a grassy hill in a daytime 
sun, sometimes in a house, or anywhere doing anything. it is constant 
change, evolution, new ways of communication and creative ways to be 
close with good friends. i will never grow tired of being with good friends.
be here now. were changing faster than we realize. appreciate. 

 ->creation<-
   ->life<-
  ->energy<-


	tom

The Bahia may be kinda square a lot of the time (and I can definitely
do without the soccer-warmup-suit crowd that also infests places like
the Cafe Bastille where Vanilla Fudge is), but I'm all in favor of
any kind of music that involves shakin' yer groove thang to something
other than prefab American rhythms.  

And don't dis salsa too much -- sure it's a commercial, bland style
the way it normally is heard, but the *real* stuff is da shit.  I was
fortunate enough to hear Tito Puente and his orquestra do the do in
Seattle a few years ago, and they were great.  Salsa definitely feeds
on the same powerful stream of musical history that house and techno do.

phred

Hey kaytee - - - :-)

Just one thing...Just like other SFR's have probably told you, try to
eliminate going to the over-publicized, $20-25 raves.  The smaller, less
expensive parties are usually the ones that have the good vibes, less
hassle, and can usually guarantee the location - when I was living up
there, my friends and I had some bad experiences over the summer.  We all
had the gut feeling that the parties we were about to spend $20+ for were
going to get rampaged by good old SFPD, or that bad vibes were going to be
present.  Well what do you know, our gut feelings were right!!!
Yeah, there will be a huge event here and there that may hit it off really
well, but wouldn't you rather spend less and receive more hugs and
smiles?

Have fun up in SF - I know you will!!!

:-) 
Karen

Hi everybody!  I didn't see my review show up on the list, so I'm taking 
a chance and sending it again.  If you've already received it, my humble 
apologies!1 - N



---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Sun, 13 Oct 1996 17:27:48 -0700 (PDT)
From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Cc: joshk@cory.eecs.berkeley.edu, mikep@uclink4.berkeley.edu
Subject: Prop 215 Benefit, review


Until Friday I thought I was taking a roadtrip up to Mendocino for 
Planetarium and therefore skipping the very worthwhile 215 Benefit.

Then I found out, after a couple of weeks of thinking otherwise, that I 
don't get Monday off at work.

BUMMER!  There has got to be nothing worse than having a 3-day weekend 
suddenly taken away. :(

Then Friday night none of my friends wanted, for various 
reasons, to go out raving.  My choices for the night's entertainment 
ranged from drinking and playing cards at home, going to sleep early, or 
going out to bars in the city with some non-raver friends.

BUMMER!  I chose the bars.  We drank at Kate O'Briens, an Irish bar 
where, to my surprise, upstairs was the debut of a new triphop/tribal 
weekly - name escapes me now.  Of course the friends didn't want to pay 
the 3 bux to check out the dj.  :(.  We drove around looking for more 
bars.  I made them drive past the Cannibas Club, just to gaze longingly 
at the line outside.  We drove past it to Haight Street, where we got 
drunker at Mad Dog and across the street at Noc Noc, where my friends 
announce they are ready to go home.  BUMMER!  And then...

COOLNESS! At Noc Noc, who should I run into but 
Raver Eric, who is on his way to 215!!  I dump my understanding friends 
and hop in Eric's car.  :) :) :). 

At 215 is a whole world of raver friends, people I know when I go out 
partying but wouldn't think to call beforehand.  It is strange to 
potentially miss a party just because you don't have someone to go _with_, 
when a whole community awaits you at the party!

Actual party review: WOW! I had never been in the actual Club - five 
floors of serious lounging area, couches, little bars.  I was so pleased 
to be partying for such an important cause.  When I smoked out on the 
dancefloor it felt like a political statement.  Aside from 209 and the 
little matter of the presidential race, this Proposition is among the 
most important issues on the ballot.  The criminalization of marijuana is 
ludicrous, but what we're talking about here - prohibiting its medical 
use to people who are suffering - is nothing less than unconscienable.  
Yea for the rave community for standing up for what's right!  Yea for our 
community for its utmost optimism, its dedication to social causes!  
It is in our faith that change can happen that it will. :)

Down to business: the music ROCKED.  I am pleased to have several new 
favorite dj's.  I have never heard MysterE, Deaks or DRC before - and 
they blew the dancefloor away, down on the first floor (where I was 
planted most of the night).  DRC is a goddess.  Who do I have to give e 
to to make sure she's booked more often???  I know she plays "out" 
(other cities) a lot... I'll just content myself with the next F8 (Mars, 
Dutch and DRC - send me straight to trance heaven!!).  Unfortunately by 
Ethan's set my group was too tired, and we set out home (helping a very good 
party die too early).

Here I have to give the biggest TTTTHHHAAAANNNNKKK YYYYOOOOUUU to Eric D 
and his friends and housemates.  They live in SF.  They agreed to take me 
back to where my car was, at my friend's in Oakland just off the Bay 
Bridge.  And we sat on the Bridge for over an hour (overblown Caltrans 
project or evil conspiracy to break the spirit of renegade dancers?).  
Then all the freeways were closed and we were dumped onto some street in 
Oakland, all of us completely clueless.  Almost two hours after we left 
215 to "quickly" drop me back in the East Bay, they finally were heading 
back to SF, and I was feeling pretty bad about the whole thing.  If you 
see him (or Walter or Janice) give them a hug for me!

And vote on November 5th, all you stoney ravers!

Love you,
Nancy

Joe Rice wrote:
> 
> >B,
> >
> >Many folks on my list filter out posts to ALL in SFRaves.  Doing it the
> >way I do is the most economical (time-wise) way to get the message out.
> >
> >We all have a Delete key on our keyboard...
> >
> >Diana Greer
> 
> I think what he meant was that the list server at hyperreal will
> automatically filter out messages that have a large number of addressees in
> the To: line, as such messages are often spam. Therefore, your messages
> won't show up on SFR unless he manually sends them on, bypassing the
> filters. The easiest way to get around it may be to send one copy of the
> message to SFR only and another copy to all of the other addressees. Either
> that or Bcc: the others.
> 
> Joe
>

I would seriously love it, if we could end this thread.  We really don't 
need to be jumping on Mr. nstuff's back quite to this degree.  Granted 
what he said was not the most well thought-out, enlightened post I have 
ever read, but I am sure many of us have posted something to the list 
that we did not really think out first.  

We are so quick to judge, even though we spout off about love and acceptance.
Let's try not to act so much like a lynch mob.  I think one or two people 
responding to a post that is considered inappropriate for this list is 
one thing, but when everyone has to jump in and call someone a jerk, it 
is just going a bit too far.  It actually attracts more attention than it 
deserves.  Know what I mean?

Asking for someone's apology after he has already been attacked is just a 
little too late in my opinion.  If an apology was going to be requested, 
that should have been done first.  At this point I think Jeff
deserves an apology.

Cheers***
Cami

Ps.  Please flame me privately regarding this post, I don't want to 
subject the list to any more of this bs.

It was great!  Gateway's soundsystem rocked the Bahia.  Lots of friendly
people (as usual at Mad), and by 11:00 the dance floor was a big sea
of energy (well, maybe more like a pool of energy, the Bahia is not THAT
big)  Stayed to hear Jon Santos' and Ethans' set.  I danced a lot.

I wish I could get to Mad more often, but I'm usually pretty tired on
monday after a hectic weekend.  It is nice when there is something
happening at mad, like this 1 year party... or a guest dj.

There is something about the vibe at a good mid-week club that I really
like... especially at Mad.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Oct 15 11:31:02 1996

Date: Tue, 15 Oct 1996 11:23:22 -0700 (PDT)
From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Sexism at Parties
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9610151024.A16896-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


As most people (mostly men!) on this list realize, the rave scene offers 
a haven for women where we are actually treated with respect as human 
beings and not as objectified things.

I have despaired that raving if the _only_ place I can feel comfortable 
being my self, because out in the other world of houseparties and clubs 
and bars, if I smile or say hello to someone who is actually male, if I 
dance, or if I simply walk 
around I am the target of harassment.  NOT friendly attraction, I mean 
HARASSMENT - unwanted touching, leering and intimidating behavior.

As someone so rightly said, imagine someone bigger than you.  Now imagine 
them drunk, singling you out, grabbing you (they are 
much stronger).  If you break away or yell at them they become hostile.  
This is not fun, or flattering.  This is frightening.   

Most of the time I have had my ass grabbed it is NOT by someone who then 
says 
hello.  It is anonymous, a hand on me in a crowd, fondling me then moving 
away before I can yell or determine who it is.  It is saying, ha ha, I 
can do this to you, there is nothing you can do about, you don't even 
know who just violated you.  It is a repulsive feeling.

At parties I experience unbelievable freedom.  I dance with abandon, 
knowing I can express myself without it being interpreted as sexual 
availability.  I can smile and look in people's eyes just because we're 
human beings.  I can walk around exploring without it meaning I'm alone 
and looking.  In this world, these simple pleasures are amazing freedoms 
for women, things we usually are denied.  Think about that.

When the sexist, domineering attitude appears at parties - my refuge - it 
is the cruelest feeling.  It ruins the happy feeling of safety.

One story: at the CCC party, there was a security guard in front of the 
bathroom.  I went up to him to ask to go inside.  He looked at me and 
said, 'you have to hug me first."  This was not a happy raver, let's hug 
each other type of thing.  This was a guy leaning over me, demanding a hug 
before I 
could use the bathroom.  I said I wasn't comfortable with that, and I 
needed to use the bathroom.  he blocked the door, stopped smiling, and 
ordered me to hug him.  I pushed past him and went into the bathroom.  He 
came after me and bodily dragged me out of the bathroom by the arms.  I 
was not allowed to go the bathroom because I hadn't given him a sexual 
favor.  Because he was bigger and stronger than me, he was able to 
punish me for not pressing against him.  

It was hard to be "happy" after that experience, and left soon after.

Some women can just shake it off, but for me, the reminder that I can be 
treated like an object with impunity is so galling.  It is up to men to 
treat us with respect.  Yes you can grab us and we can't do much about 
it.  So we flock to the rave scene for some measure of a safe, respectful 
environment.  "Ass-grabbing" is not so benign; it is a power inequality 
that is frightening and demeaning to women.  When it is accepted in the 
rave scene is the day the scene dies for most women.

N

I've been out of town a lot lately, just trying to get up to date on the 
latest.  About the recent posts and threads:

BRIAN DARKNESS:
Czefir wrote:
><< .......I don't know if I missed the posts...but what happened to Brian
> Darkness?? >>
>He began the story of his arrest and then disappeared.  I was disappointed to
>never here the end of his story.

Brian now goes as THX1138, or something to that effect, but he hasn't been 
posting lately.  I too would like to hear the finale to that saga, but 
apparently Wayne wrestled Brian to the ground and relieved him of his 
computer... <j/k>

GANGSTAS:
I don't care how someone dresses or poses, so long as they respect my space. 
 I'm old enough to realize everyone's pretty much the same underneath the 
latest fashions, and different folks have fun in different ways.  So long as 
I'm able to have my form of fun without hurting anyone and vice versa, it's 
all good.

RESPECT:
As for the moronic post about grabbing women's butts at a party, I think the 
mother of the guy that posted that was less than competent in raising her son.

RAVING:
Thank God Larry Ching is still on this list.  I love hearing his balanced 
views on things.  My sentiment is that raving has provided the wild release 
that balances the mundane aspects of my life.  It has given me some 
fantastic memories and some wonderful friends.

PARTY SIZE:
I choose the party based on size and what I'm looking for.  Major production 
= massive.  PLURry vibe = small underground.  In both cases I look for good 
promoters.

S

Hello-
	Hopefully someone may know someone who may know someone who
knows the someone who walked off with the wrong (or additional?)
black and silver anvil record case at the 215/CBC benefit. If you
walked off with a set of records that sounds nothing like the ones
you expected to be bringing home, could you please return at least
the last 40 or so pieces of vinyl in that crate? I don't think they
are worth much to many people, and I don't care if you want the
crate, I just would like that vinyl back.
	If anyone knows anyone that picked up the wrong crate, or
an extra crate made it in your car with all your gear, please get in
touch with me. If you hear anyone bragging about lifting some poor
saps records at the CBC benefit, can you either take a photo and
mail it to me so I can subtly drop some nuisances on him or her...
If you own a record shop and buy used vinyl, can you watch out for
someone trying to pawn off a load of gabber and techno and trance...
Thanks...

dave

From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Funny "Gangsta" Come-on
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9610151101.A16896-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>

So there's been a lot of talk about the "gangsta" element... but what I 
usually see are a lot of teenagers trying to fit in... hey man addidas 
pants are the shit... and how cool are they to be 16 and going to 
all-night drugfests?  if there was such a thing when I was in high 
school, I woulda been there, with the latest fashions!!  "Cool" and "hip" 
are major deals when you're that age... they're going to parties for 
different reasons than people in their 20's and 30's who are in a 
different stage of life.  (I'm having so much more fun in my 20's than in 
high school!!)

So anyway, at the 215 Benefit, there was this little boy in front of me 
on the dancefloor.  He did a mating circle dance for me, bustin' moves, 
glancin' up at me.  When he's done, he comes up to me, smiles proudly and 
says, "so, what you think of my moves??"  I felt so bad, but I just had 
to laugh to myself.  Here this little boy thought I would be so 
impressed, just like a 16 year old girl, with his fly hat and his 
footwork, that I would want him because he was coolraverboy.  I just told 
him he was a good dancer and then danced away.

Sometimes a "gangsta"
is just a highschoolkid
without a clue

Well I thought in light of all the gangsta post people might have some
serious filters flying and might have missed my last post.  Sorry for being
redundant.

I'm planning to throw BBQ & BEATS III   (Stuff your Face) or (a Feeding
Frenzy) not sure yet. More then likely on Nov 16th.
Time: noonish-9pm
DJs...????? Don't know yet.
location: TBA
More info to come so stay tuned....

We as a SFR family need to get together as a family once more. I've loved
the last two BBQ & BEATS. The people and the music are wonderful. You can
not imagine how great I felt at the last one.  (Except for ANN from New
Moon, who probally has a great picture which I want to see). The few time I
got away from the BBQ and looked at the crowd dancing, sitting talking to
others, throwing stuff on the BBQ, it was all heart warming to see that.
I'm sure some of you that have thrown parties feel that too when you stand
back and look at that.

So call me greedy for wanting to feel that again, who wouldn't want to feel
it. This is why I want to have another one.  Everyone that went to the
other ones made it special, as well as all that help out with them.

I was told by someone that I found something special to do for our
community and that was getting them together in a sorta different aspect of
"raving". All I was trying to do was to make people happy and try and give
back to this community. I wasn't wanting to throw a bad ass party to be
talked about for years to come. All I was concerned about was seeing
peoples smiling faces and seeing them all having a good time. People have
asked, why I don't spin at these. Well, for one I don't feel I'm ready yet
and two, it's not about me, it's about YOU.  This all my sound corny and
all but it's how I feel. I've had some of the best times of my life with
alot of you since I've been raving and this is my way of saying thanks. One
of these days I'll spin out, but not yet. When I do though, look out!

Anyway, just thought I explain way I do this for those new people on here
as well as for those wondering. Plus I was kinda getting tired of reading
the gangsta stuff.

If you want to lend a hand feel free to email me privately

Tim (knucklehead)



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Oct 15 11:52:56 1996

	for <sfraves@hyperreal.com> id LAA06993; Tue, 15 Oct 1996 11:51:50 -0700
Message-Id: <v03007807ae8993501c3a@DialupEudora>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Tue, 15 Oct 1996 11:51:44 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Tony Rotundo <tony@xinet.COM>
Subject: Milestones...Planitarium...
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

There is no greater reward than to have your peers, those people you admire
and respect most in the world, offer you an oportunity to dabble their
medium...and then give you a positive response...

I would walk to the steps of heaven for Cloud Factory, and Friday night
almost did.  You see, our van arrived after the gate was closed and being
the sporting chap I am, I decided I could use a brisk walk at 1am.  After a
wild pig scared me shitless (not a boar, a little pig), I decided I should
sing to scare off other wild vermin.  Singing and walking, walking and
signing.   Rustling in the shrubs.  Louder singing, faster walking, more
rustling in the shrubs.  Yelling loudly, trotting nervously,
rustling...rustling...running...singing really loud...rustling stops,
walking again.

After about two miles I get rescued by Sabin's parents who were coming out
for the night.  I had gone about two miles out of NINE!  Someone said I was
"hard core" for being willing to walk it, and I had to smile and think, "No
I'm just an idiot."

Anyway, heaven it was.  Two sound systems, plenty of space.  There's a
house up there, and they truck fresh water up from a stream below.  The
roads tough, but not too tough for most vehicles.  ("Think Wayne's car will
make it?"  *Snicker*  "What's Marcy drive?")    And the stars!  Oh my
gawd...  Almost as brilliant as the people.  =)

Got to sleep on the hill top the first night (night of the great walk), and
that was amazing.  Woke up completely disoriented but with an amazing
sunrise to bring me back to reality.  Snapped a picture and fell back a
sleep.  'Drenalin woke me later.

Music ran from around 1PM Saturday until about 3PM Sunday.  Braced for rain
a couple times but only during the day.  Windy on the mountain top, but we
braved it.  One of the greatest moments was when the tail end of a wind
storm blew a canopy half apart and while Sig and Tina were putting on crazy
music (i.e, Farmer in the Dell samples, etc...), about 15 people were
trying to get the canopy back together.  It was a scene.  Finally it took
the long arm of Joe Rice to get the canopy back in place, but by then the
storm had passed for good.

Was given a chance to spin some disco/funk at around noon Sunday and for
that I can't thank Cloud Factory enough.  I'm forever indebted...  =)
Well, maybe not FOREVER...

Questions?

Peas and harmony

Tone

If the records were misplaced in someones gear (or whatever) that sucks
because Dave wasn't able to spin at CBC _OR_ the Cloud Factory party.  But
it's forgivable.

However, if they were stolen, it would be easily the most fucked up thing
I've seen in the rave scene.  Not only was this a benefit party, but Dave
was loaning his sound system!  And they were taken before he spun!!

For those of you with excess energy berating one another, ready to take
things "outside", I beseech you to focus that energy on trying to track
down a crate of records we all have grown to appreciate.

In one way or another this will affect everyone in the Bay Area Rave
Community, whether or not you've come to appreciate gabba at the end of
those special parties, or just enjoy Dave's sets in general.

This is a cause worth fighting for...

UGH!

Tony

Warning:  This message contains no flames and makes no references to gangstas.

I just got back from a little trip to Ithaca, NY.  And I had a great time
despite some transportation problems.  I partiEd for the first time while not
at a rave.  Instead I walked around the Cornell campus with friends and 
enjoyed the rivers, lakes, waterfalls, and all the leaves turning red, orange,
yellow, and shades in between.  Thankfully the weather warmed up while I was
there (maybe I brought some of that California sun snuck into my backpack
before I got on the plane) so I didn't have to walk around bundled up in a
big coat.

Things I learned on my trip:
---------------------------
Never fly Continental Express.  They cancelled my flight from Newark to Ithaca
on Thursday night and put me on a 5hr bus ride instead that got into Ithaca
at 3:30am.  They also cancelled my flight Sunday from Ithaca to Newark.  But
that wasn't as bad.  I got to stay an extra day.

Cornell has a beautiful campus.  But its big and you can get lost at night if
you don't know where you're going. :) (Not that that's a bad thing)

I am able to be in two different places at the same time.  

Airport security guards collect books. 

Dogs can't always smell illegal substances.  Even if they walk right past you.


:)  Have a great week!
j

Sorry.  I'm probably commiting a pho-pah by writing.  I've only been 
around a few days...  

Jeff,  quit fighting.  If you haven't yet noticed, every statement you 
make...every effort at explanation gets turned on you.  You are probably 
a nice guy who just made a comment that, in different company would not 
have been taken so seriously or negatively.  I read all these damned 
messages, and it is obvious that you don't go "booty grabbing", you've just 
made some observtions from your perspective, and shared them.

Randy,  everyone knows where you're coming from.  I and many other 
people agree that "booty grabbing" is disrespectful.  Go as far as 
you like on the issue, but bashing character is wrong.  You set a person 
up as a psycho and you'll never be at peace, with him, yourself, or the 
world. 

Negativity is not conducive to presenting ones point of view to someone 
else.  I personally shut out people when there is negativity in their tone 
because it makes me so uncomfortable.  I'd love to see an end to this 
with some shared understanding...

BTW, I already feel really comfortable with the community on 
SFRaves...this bashing was the only thing that hurt me...kind of like 
watching family members fight.  The escallation leads to intolerance, and 
I couldn't bear to see that here.

			Peace and Understanding

				-Kevin-


PS. please tell me if, by writing, I've offended.  Sorry if I have.

were happy, then someone punishes them for it). But again,

From: lesliea@best.com (Leslie Ayres)
Subject: Reviews from the Rave M**
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, I made it back from my 8,500 miles at sea, not to mention the 4,000
miles of air flights to get to San Diego to start my Panama Canal cruise,
and back from lovely Fort Lauderdale via the ever-so-tardy Delta Airlines.

Cruise review:  I was traveling with an 88-year old cranky woman on a ship
filled with another thousand cranky seniors.  Enough said.  However, I saw
lots of interesting places (Cabo, Acupulco, Guatemala/Tikal, Cartegena
Columbia, Grand Cayman and the Bahamas), got to be one of the youngest
passengers on the ship (how scary is that??), drank way too much, ate WAY
too much and too often, made a great new friend who lives in LA (he'll
visit soon and I'll bring him to a party) and fell madly in love with a
Portuguese waiter who, unfortunately due to a number of reasons (oops), was
summarily sent home packing at the end of the cruise.  Shit, now what?

Leeza review:  My VCR kindly did its job so I saw the show when I got home.
(My answering machine, however, did not, sorry if anyone tried to call).
Pretty much what I expected ... though I was offline and can't downlead the
archives from September to see what the SFR people thought afterwards (it
crashes my computer) -- oh well, at least Madame Mercury and Terry looked
cool in the audience, yes?

Planetarium review:  Wow, what a beautiful party.  A little rough on my
car, but well worth the trip just to stand on top of a mountain and look
straight up at more stars than I ever thought possible.  The music was
amazing though it got so cold I spent most of the night snuggled in my
tent, listening half-conscious and wishing I could gather the energy to get
out and dance.  Many thanks to everyone who put this together, most
especially the breakfast complete with coffee!

Job review:  I'm looking for one, if anyone has any leads for me (business
and marketing writing/ proofreading and editing/ desktop publishing/general
administration or whatever) let me know and I'll be eternally grateful.

SFR review:  Whats up here?  Some of our most regular presences are no
longer present ... and in the last few days since I've been back on, the
content of many of the (dare I say it ... too many?) posts has been mostly
off-topic or negative, rude or confusing.  I welcome the evolution of this
list, as people come and go, but it only works when we keep the energy
positive and the information appropriate to the focus of the list.  For the
newcomers, welcome ... and for everyone, a reminder to think twice before
you click that "send" button to ask yourself if your message is indeed
something that many SFRavers will benefit from reading.

Hope to see everyone at MAD tonight!

Much love, Leslie

	id NAA09740; Tue, 15 Oct 1996 13:06:08 -0700

From: simitzis@netcom.com (Steve Simitzis)
Message-Id: <199610152006.NAA09740@netcom17.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Mad for Mad
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Okay, Shamini, here's a Mad review for you :) Hope it doesn't burn
up between all the flames...

For me, the pre-Mad dinner is always part of my Mad experience. 
Hamburger Mary's, despite the name, was very vegan friendly. Good 
SOMA dining spot. Dinner was fun as always...

The first thing I noticed [other than that there were no salsa dancers
;)] when walking into the place was that many of the tables and chairs
had been moved away... and they needed it! That little restaurant got
packed!

I was really happy to hear the Gateway system there. At the last Mad,
one of the woofers of the house system had been blowing out, leading
to a little extra crunchiness. So it was nice to see the familiar big
blue cabinets. Although it was a little dark sounding; the high end
seemed to be somewhat hidden.

The visuals last night were extra good. The graphics all night were
great, and having the lasers was a nice touch. I almost forgot that I
was at the Bahia!

There was some great energy coming from the speakers last night.
The DJ's for the night really pumped it out... there was not
a single moment when I had to stop because I didn't like the
music.

John Santos was playing first when I walked in, and he was spinning
some really good minimal trance. Alex spun a really hard set, although
I went outside for some of it to rest/socialize. Ethan was especially
good; good solid dark trance. I've been enjoying Ethan's sets more and
more lately... perhaps I'm just getting to know his music.

Finally, Joe Rice finished the night. This was the best set I've ever
heard Joe spin! I even heard some Orbital thrown in there. He finished
his set with a couple of tracks that I can describe as "trance-jungle"
(Joe, what were those records?): jungle-ish beats (but sequenced,
rather than than sampled drum loops) with a trance energy around
it... He ended the set with some really pretty music. Like I said,
definitely my favorite Joe Rice set, and it was the one I listened to
the most last night.

The music last night was extra good, and possibly some of the best
techno I've heard in one place in one night. Worth two dollars?
hmmm....maybe... ;)

Steve

SPECIAL NOTE : The following is from Mark Heley (currently residing at
Moonpup's) 
 
This Friday (October 18th), at ACME Gallery, (667 Howard/3rd, SF) sees the
opening of PSYCHEDELICATESSEN,  the largest showing of contemporary
psychedelic art and video brought together anywhere in several years.  
 
Featuring established artists like Alex Grey , (Sacred Mirrors) and Paul
Mavrides (Church Of Subgenius, Zap! comix) along with material from artists
in the  international techno/ trance scene, including 'back-drop' art from
the UK's Earthstar and Nagual,  video installations from South Africa's
Project Love, Japan's Video Drug and the West Coast's Hyperdelic, Synergy,
Cyber Dreams Factory, Repsychled Products, Terbo Ted, Ani Phyo, Sharon
Donahue, Tom Williams, Dan Mapes, Todd & Cindy, Craig Larsen and others. 
 
There will also be an interactive installation of Nick Phillip's new
CD-ROM, Radical Beauty and performances including butoh movement from
Ledoh, spoken word, fire dancing, live music from Reverend Markus and
Reverend Yusen Yamato of the Global Peace Orchestra and a drum circle by
Beyond Race. 
 
Psychedelicatessen opens at 7pm on Friday. There is a sliding scale
donation of $3-10. 
 
On Saturday October 19th there will be a benefit party for The Commitee On
Unfair Sentencing and The Initiative to Legalize Medical Marijuana
(Prop.215) which will feature three floors of  trance, tecno, trip-hop,
house and live performance including environments from members of SPAZ, CCC
and Acme. Sliding scale donation $10-20. 
 
On Monday October 21st we present the Awards ceremony of The Committee on
Unfair Sentencing for acts of 'valorous conduct in the War On Drugs'. These
awards go to long term psychedelic prisoners who have refused to
colloborate with the government. There will also be a sale of  signed
(Laura Huxley, Allen Ginsberg, Sasha Shulgin, Ken Kesey) blotter art to
benefit the Committee. 
 
Psychedelicatessen will run daily 11am-7pm until Saturday October 26th. 
For more info contact Lamont or Mark at Acme on 415. 777-ACME (2263). 
Please come and check it out - we think this show should be mind blowing -
and all profits are going to an extremely good cause. 
 
                                                Mark Heley

[ to sfraves ]
How things mutate in urban folklore - 
> In <some_message_id>, Aryck wrote:
> > Just look at that little boy who
> >kissed this girl on the cheek and got charged??? Some people just have
> >problems, or maybe it's just all of you who partied this weekend and
> >are posting as you're comin off of whatever you were on.
> 
> 	If I have heard about this scenerio correctly, he had asked
> her first, was given permission and then kissed her. Where is the
> sexual harrassment in that? And if I was told the story accurately,
> it was the teacher who intervened, dragged both of them to the
> principle's office where either both or just the guy was suspended
> for a while on the grounds of sexual harrassment. ...But again,
> maybe I didn't hear the story correctly...
> 
> dave

 It just so happens that in today's S.F. Chronicle is an opinion piece
by Ellen Goodman on page A21 ( tues., Oct. 15th ). What is happening
is that two recent cases are being confused together in the public
mind. The first was a case where a 6 year old who kissed a female 
schoolmate without her consent. He was sent to another room for awhile
for "unwanted touching", not suspended for sexual harassment. And his
story wouldn't have made the news except that HIS mom decided to go
on talk-tv with it. The second incident in another part of the country 
involved a boy who repeatedly harassed girls in his school to the point
of getting called on it many times and having his mom called to the
school twice, ending finally in him getting suspended for sexual
harassment. 

 In a great example of urban folklore in action, the two true stories 
have merged to become a fictional one where a boy is suspended from 
school on the PC charge of sexual harassment by a liberal school
administration for the innocent "crime" of kissing a willing schoolmate.

 Ain't humans wonderful ??? 

 Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com
