 * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * 
The Li'l Grumpy Gruver's Ten Ways to Save $$ At A Party:
 * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * 

1.  Go Sober!  (zoinks!  What a thought!)

2.  Go Naked!  Save money on those trendy (and costly!) accessories. 
Although this does pose an interesting question: where do you put your
wallet 'n' chain?

3.  Hide a friend in each phat pant leg and split the ticket three ways!

4.  Sell your old stuffed animals at the door!  Old CARE BEARS bring
extra cash!

5.  Put Pert Plus in clear straws and use 'em as glowsticks!  (Added
bonus: makes for a convenient shower in the morning when you get
home!)

6.  Sell aspirin as e, then cover your butt and get out of the state as
quickly as you possibly can.

7.  Do flyer origami for the person working the door!  "LOok!  It's a crane! 
LoOk!  It's a throwing star!  LoOoK!  It's a pair of FILAS!"  Maybe they will
let you in for less!

8.  Become a DJ Bitch.  "No, really, I +LUV+ how you spin!  Now please,
let me carry your record crate...PLEEEEEZE?"

9.  Wait until 6:30 in the morning, then offer to help clean up...maybe you'll
catch the last few minutes of music in between sweeping up empty
water bottles and cigarette butts!

10.  Avoid parties with excessive decorating, lights or extravagant
sound systems: sit in dark warehouses and listen to youreself breath,
instead!  Fun for the whole raving gang! :)

* * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * 

Hope this brought at least a little grin to your face (even if you're an
ass-grabbin' gangsta -DUCK!-)...these are the words that go with the
pictures for a comic strip that me and a friend are trying to get
together...I'm doing the written and he's doin' the drawn.

I Hope everybody's day is going better than mine...I am the mood swing
queen today and my stupid fucking filing job is NOT helping.

Ariel
Grumpy Li'l Gruver

nancy sez:
>One story: at the CCC party, there was a security guard in front of the
>bathroom.  I went up to him to ask to go inside.  He looked at me and said,
>'you have to hug me first."  This was not a happy raver, let's hug each
>other type of thing.  This was a guy leaning over me, demanding a hug before
>I could use the bathroom.  I said I wasn't comfortable with that, and I
>needed to use the bathroom.  he blocked the door, stopped smiling, and
>ordered me to hug him.  I pushed past him and went into the bathroom.  He
>came after me and bodily dragged me out of the bathroom by the arms.  I was
>not allowed to go the bathroom because I hadn't given him a sexual favor.
>Because he was bigger and stronger than me, he was able to punish me for not
>pressing against him.  

this behavior is institutionalized at clubs that have vip rooms, such as
dv8, 1015 folsom, and i think the dna sometimes.  men can't get in unless
they "know someone" (whatever that means).  women can get in if they look
good and allow the bouncer to fondle them.  i've seen vip room bouncers
allow a women to go in, but keep her boyfriend out, even when they are both
dressed comparably well.

this bugs me.  if i had time, i would take my tiny little camcorder and do
some discreet video taping and sue the club for either harassment or
discrimination.  i would love to see a major club get shut down for this.

RE: the psychedelic art show this Friday (October 18th), at ACME Gallery, 
 (667 Howard/3rd, SF)

 One of the artists is going to be Alex Grey? Fantastic! He's the guy that
seems to be copied in a lot of rave wall hangings ( or , at least he's
the inspiration for a lot of them!) . He's the artist that does paintings
of people with transparent skin and translucent muscles , energy bolts
flying dense likean aura around the figures. Definitely worth checking out.

 Paul Mavrides is no slouch either, but more surreal/satirical than 
Grey's intense chakra mysticism.

"One story: at the CCC party, there was a security guard in front of the 
bathroom.  I went up to him to ask to go inside.  He looked at me and 
said, 'you have to hug me first."  This was not a happy raver, let's hug 
each other type of thing.  This was a guy leaning over me, demanding a hug 
before I 
could use the bathroom.  I said I wasn't comfortable with that, and I 
needed to use the bathroom.  he blocked the door, stopped smiling, and 
ordered me to hug him.  I pushed past him and went into the bathroom.  He 
came after me and bodily dragged me out of the bathroom by the arms.  I 
was not allowed to go the bathroom because I hadn't given him a sexual 
favor.  Because he was bigger and stronger than me, he was able to 
punish me for not pressing against him.  "


Did you report this to the people up front?

 I remember at Eon to Eon. This guy approched my friend Luciana (The mos
beautiful and the most noticed at the rave, person I know, that I call
friend) he wispered something in her ear that outraged her. She turned to
him and said "Get off me" and she amediatly started to walk away. Once he
started walking towards her agian, my smile quickly turned into a look of
confusion. As he grabbed her arm, I approched them and told him to chill
out. I was very nice and possitive in my speech. He looked at me with
confusion, and I walked away with my friend.
 I think that alot of the guys get embarrased when they get dis in such a
mannor infront of there friends, and feel as if they need to get the last
word.
 My friend really blew him off in a strong way. After she would not tell me
what he said, I told her that maybe she should of just been alittle less
dramatic in her wayz.
 I don't know...
 But that security guy should have been reported.
 Even after what people make me out to be. I still have the balls to say
that this type of stuff is not right.
 And when I get to Tribal Massive on the 26th. I will just keep my mouth
shut and dance my ass off like usual.
 If you see a skinny blonde guy that (on the dance floor) looks like Bernie
from the Movie Weekend at Bernies, tapping his feet, shaking his ass, and
rarely missing a que or beat. That might be me.

Peace out scout!

 And the security at big parties (which I know most of) are not perves like
this guy you talk about. They treat people with respect, except when there
job requires them to move people fast , they can be pushy. But they alwayz
know what path is the right one.

Jonathan wrote:

>PREACH ON:
>
>We might not get along. We might disagree. We might write the stupidist shit,
>but this is OUR list and we can say whatever the FUCK we want... Freedom of
>speech.. Now before this turns into another flame war, let's just accept each
>other, and if we have serious disagreements about what people have to say,
>let them know in private. Lets got geet petty!:)
>
>PREACH OFF
>

In some ways I agree, and in some I don't.  Definitely, IMO serious
personal disagreements should ALWAYS be private to begin with, and private
forever.

Yes, this is "our" list.  But the trouble with the "I can say whatever I
want attitude" is that it ignores the needs and choices of the other 480+
people on the list.  Frankly, I'm  not sure I want to remain on a list with
such immaturity and selfishness in so many postings lately -- sure, with so
many people in our group, there are bound to be ignorant people, racist
people, sexist people, and just plain old
I'm-an-unhappy-jerk-so-deal-with-it-people.

But that's NOT what this list is for, and there is a point where the
wading-through-the-ignorant-shit ratio outweights the benefits of being on
the list.

I often wonder if some of these ridiculous idiotic posts would ever happen
in the "real" world?  Do these people stand in the middle of their
classroom or office and just spout off things like "you asshole you don't
know shit" or whatever?  Or do they at least understand about rules of
behavior in real-life situations, but just choose to ignore them in
cyberspace?

The saddest thing is that many of the valuable contributors to this list
have become silent, either because they've stepped back into lurkdom, or
signed off totally because of the high volume of crap, and I can hardly
blame them.

For those newcomers who apparently don't understand what this list is
about, and how great a source of information, support and motivation it can
be, may I suggest you take a foray into the archives?  The first month's
archives will give some background on the original intent of the group, and
you can see how, throughout the years, the same themes and messages appear.


For now, I'm planning on lying low and hoping that things improve.

Leslie

> Date: Tue, 15 Oct 1996 13:48:12 -0700
> From: lesliea@best.com (Leslie Ayres)

> Yes, this is "our" list.  But the trouble with the "I can say whatever I
> want attitude" is that it ignores the needs and choices of the other 480+
> people on the list. 

I just wanted to add something to that:

This list is a forum for the rave community to exchange ideas, get
information, discuss music, plan parties, make new friends, and talk
about aspects of raving.

SFRaves should *not* be something you do to pass the time at work.
Bouncing retorts back and forth all day is completely uninteresting
for everyone else. SFRaves is not a chat line.

There are those us who aren't impressed by how bold your words are
or how snappy of a comeback you can think up. Everyone loses in a
war of words, especially the spectators.

Please, if you want to impress me, post an interesting party
review. Describe an experience you've had as a raver. Plan a
party. Talk about records. Send something to make us laugh.

peace and quiet,
Steve

Hello everyone!!!

        Wow, I come back from a long weekend, and all I am reading is
"Gangsta" slamming!!! Hmmm... Well, what ever!!! I have to thank The Cloud
Factory for an awsome weekend!!!! The space was completely amazing!!!! (You
should have been there if you didn't go!!!)

        So the point of this post is to tell all of you about the first
official fund-raising party for Omar. We intend to throw these parties at
next to no cost, giving Omar's family as much $ as we can, to help them
through this tragedy. We will keep throwing these parties until Omar can
come home and throw them on his own. See, Omar has always dreamed about
throwing a party, and was pretty darn close to doing it. But then this awful
accident happened, and now he can't. So we here at Harmony, figured it would
be a great idea to do this for him, as it would benefit him in many
different ways!!!

        The party is called "A Wrinkle in Time," symbolizing this changing
time in Omar's life. We hope that this will only be a wrinkle in time for
Omar, not a permanent, painful tragedy. He is going through the most trying
time of his life right now, and he knows how much support all of you are
sending him. This party will be the connection between him (in Reno) and us
(in S.F.) There will be a break in the party to provide time for a group
meditation. We want Omar to feel our combined positive energy, and be moved
into a more positive place...

        The date of the party is Saturday, November 16th. The location is in
S.F. The info lines are (408)486-9591  -  (415)263-4885          Call
them!!! There will be much more info about this party as we come closer to
the date, so keep your ears open!

Peace and harmony, 4 Omar,

Greg =)

well, i stopped into f8 to grab a copy of xlr8r last night. they were out,
but five minutes before i got there eric had just gotten a shipment of new
cds in... so i looked them over, and one of them is an astralwerks cd with
a wicked looking cover. it attracts my eye, so i look at it, and the track
listing is incredible! the prodigy, underworld, orbital, leftfield, photek,
the chemical brothers, fluke, source direct, and daft punk. amazing stuff.
it's all hard-edged sounding, along the lines of the prodigy's firestarter
(the instrumental remix is on the cd). anyway, big thumbs up for this
compilation.
but the funny thing is, it's a soundtrack. and it's not a movie soundtrack,
it's a video game soundtrack! awesome.

-brendan-

FORWARDED MESSAGE from Steve Simitzis (SIMITZIS @ SMTP 
{simitzis@netcom.com}) at 10/15/96 2:18 PM

> Date: Tue, 15 Oct 1996 13:48:12 -0700
> From: lesliea@best.com (Leslie Ayres)

> Yes, this is "our" list.  But the trouble with the "I can say whatever I
> want attitude" is that it ignores the needs and choices of the other 480+
> people on the list.

I just wanted to add something to that:

This list is a forum for the rave community to exchange ideas, get
information, discuss music, plan parties, make new friends, and talk
about aspects of raving.

SFRaves should *not* be something you do to pass the time at work.
Bouncing retorts back and forth all day is completely uninteresting
for everyone else. SFRaves is not a chat line.

There are those us who aren't impressed by how bold your words are
or how snappy of a comeback you can think up. Everyone loses in a
war of words, especially the spectators.

Please, if you want to impress me, post an interesting party
review. Describe an experience you've had as a raver. Plan a
party. Talk about records. Send something to make us laugh.

peace and quiet,
Steve

Subject: The art of Circle Dancing...
Date: Tue, 15 Oct 1996 15:10:56 -0700
X-Mailer:  Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.837.3

Sender: owner-sfraves@HYPERREAL.COM
Precedence: bulk

Funny how names change with the times.  I remember it being called
firewalking when I got into it...  I think the mating connotation came
from the breakdancing genre, however, I can just relate to my personal
experiences.

In the past 6+ yrs that I've been in the scene I've been a dancer.  I
"burn" ,"shred", "go off".  I enjoy the feeling of syncing my body to
the beat of the music, and syncing to others frequencies dancing with
them.  The Circle is indeed a grounds of proving.  To who or what your
proving is up to you.  I usually prove to myself that I can express
myself to my fullest. Commune with whatever higher entites may exsit... 
And sometimes to get to that state you need to find other eagles to fly
with (I.e. other firewalkers, breakdancers, circle dances ect...) .  The
Circle is also a learning area if you let it.  The circle welcomes all
as we did the wheelchair bound gentleman @ the prop 215 party.  The
Circle allways has been (and allways will be ) part of my Rave
culture...

And although I've been "bustin' moves" since 90'  not once have I used
this ability to pick up on females... It dosen't upset me to see peoples
perceptions of this, but it does alienate me and make me feel a little
less understood...

---Adam
"Stay Connected..."

I'm not going to participate in today's flame war, but I've got to say this:

As Nancy pointed out, women (usually) feel safer at raves because there is a 
(relatively) high respect level in that environment.  The overwhelming 
majority of women don't like strangers taking liberties with their bodies.  
Apparently a young boy, whose mother failed to instill a healthy, normal 
sense of respect for other people in him, has taken it upon himself to make 
a profoundly sexist statement and then to defend that statement in the most 
immature manner available to him.

Ladies, this page is about raves.  Please PUBLICLY voice your opinion about 
how you wish to be treated at raves.  

The question is simple: do you find it acceptable to have a stranger fondle 
you at a party?

Perhaps by responding publicly, you can take up where this young boy's 
parents left off by instructing him on the right and the wrong of social 
interaction.

S

      Date:  10/15/1996  04:24 pm  (Tuesday)  
      From:  Ariel Stallings
        To:  SOCAL.SMTP("SDream@tgrigsby.com")
   Subject:  RE: Women and Safety At Raves: Please respond to the list
             (LONG)


Ok, here is my personal take on sexual issues at raves.  There are
several issues here, in my opinion.

#1:  Raves are not clubs.
Yes, people dance in both environments, but for different purposes. 
There is crossover between the scenes, of course, both in people and
attitudes, but my experience with the two has been that clubs are much
more sexually oriented.  Maybe this has to do with the fact that people
are drinking, and alcohol *IS* a social lubricant, but so is e (in fact, e is
even MORE so...see below) and I think it has more to do with the
attitudes of WHY people go to each place.  People go to raves TO
DANCE first, SOCIALIZE second.  When I go to clubs I go to socialize first
and dance second (thus, why I don't make it to clubs frequently).  Some
of the confusion with how to behave sexually at raves I think comes
from the impression that raves are just all-night clubs where someone
couldn't get a liquor license.  WRONG.

#2:  E is for ECSTACY, not rEtardation
Ecstacy is an empathogen.  One of the ways to comprehend the
empathy it induces is through feelings of love...and one of the ways to
express love is through touch.  This can be a hug (who's gotten that
HUGE BUZZ off of a hug on e?  I have, I have), or a back-rub or a kiss.  I
think some people get this kind of confused and skip those middle logical
steps and say "OOH!  E MAKEZ YOU REALLY HORNY!"  I have had
boys/men/whatever sit down next to me at parties and ask if I'm on e.  I
don't like to lie (even though I should know better) and say "Yes."  Then
the above said person says totally straight faced "have you found a
groping partner for the evening?"  Like that's what is to be done on e! 
What an abuse of a potentially wonderful drug!

#3:  Raves ARE social situations
And I HAVE met people I'm attracted to at parties and I HAVE hit on them
and (yes) I have been reduced to one of those people making out in a
corner.  It DOES happen.  Just like it could happen in any other
environment, only when you meet someone attractive at a grocery store
you don't typically go curl up in a corner by the boxed cereal and start
making out.  Raves are open environments, so things DO happen, I just
think that it's not fair to assume that they SHOULD.

I have to acknowledge here that there is a double standard.  As a
woman, I have been high on ecstacy started chatting to some cute boy I
really like and reached up, grabbed the back of his head and stuck my
tongue down his throat.  If I was a man this would not seem nearly so
cute and assertive to the recipiant as it has the few times (ew, ok, I'm
exposing my skeletons, here!) I have done such a thing.  It's sick and not
very pc of me to say it, but I can DO things like that because women in
society are the ones who have gotten stuck with being the "green light"
sexually...which means when we want it, a lot (NOT all) of the time we
can get it.  (eek, am I actually saying this?  ...hmm)

Anyway, now that I've offended myself (and probably half the list) I will
ask if anyone has read a document on-line called "E is for Ecstacy."  I've
got it linked to my homepage at
http://weber.u.washington.edu/~ameadow if you want to go find it, but it
has a great point about how women have a lot of fun on e because it
ISN'T a horny drug like alcohol, in fact it can cause impotence in men at
times (hmm, been there, seen that, TEE HEE!  *duck*) and so women feel
more comfortable at raves because they don't feel like they're constantly
fending off horny drunk men.  That whole document is really interesting,
it's worth a read if you can find the address...I wish I had it handy...

ANYWAY.  My point is that sexual relations at raves, like in any social
situation, is complex.  Duh.  Toss in low lights, loud music, ecstacy and
maybe some slightly inexperienced kids and you get TOTAL CONFUSION
and gangsta ass-grabbers.

I don't know if any of this has made any sense...thanks for letting me
type it though.

Ariel

Ummm... I nor any other female that I know of responds in a sexy, 
positive manner to having rear ends slapped, or anything else thrown into 
their personal space without their consent. We are not horses, we do not 
need to be checked for gluteal firmness. If you really want to let 
someone know you really want to -get it on- and you think the chick is the 
really loose type, there are less invasive ways of approaching her and 
really -score(!)-.
Same thing with kissing (it just makes my glasses smear, not make me horny),
same thing with smut dancing (I want to bust my moves not bust a move 
with you!)
Things of this nature have only made me feel disgusted, violated, and cheap.
Usually when it happens I am too astonished to express my astonishment, 
so -beware- if you do those things they are not nice things to do.
Women don't always express their sentiments about being violated. Take 
rape for example; it is such a serious issue yet there is such a stigma 
surrounding it.

chirp chirp
Rebecca

First off, kudos to the sisters who have responded to this whole issue
so far...well put, and very representative of the whole issue...Ariel in
particular put forth a view I never really thought of before...the whole
double standard thing.  This makes it all messy of course.  But I'm
really glad you wrote it Ariel, because it can be true. 

My personal opinion on this is that if you respect the 
person you're dealing with as a human being, you wouldn't want 
to do anything to make them feel bad or violated in any way. 
(I think the assgrabbers or "assgrabbing isn't a big deal" people 
on this list have realized from recent responses that no, women 
DON'T like being groped by strangers at raves (or anyplace else), 
that it makes them feel violated and angry, even if they don't show 
it at the time.  Oh, rest assured, for every woman who is taken 
aback by an unwelcome misogynistic gesture and isn't able to respond 
right away, there are those of us whose first instinct will be to 
kick you VERY HARD in the place that it hurts the most to make our 
opinions very clear. Ok, long aside.)

One thing that we women should think about, is that we shouldn't take
advantage of the social stigmas for our benefit.  Sure, chances are if
we without warning grab a guy's butt or "stick our tongue down his throat"
;-) that he's not going to tell you he feels violated.  Maybe most 
won't feel violated. 
But there ARE some guys who will feel lame about it, but would never 
admit it, perhaps even to themselves, because they'd feel like a ween
because they're "supposed" to want that as a "man".  I've talked to guys
who have shared this viewpoint before.  Guys, care to share your 
take on that?  
I have no problem with spontaneity or making out in corners...show 
your love in whatever way you see appropriate :o) As long as it's a 
mutual thing, you know?  And if you're not sure it's a mutual wanting, 
it's probably a good idea to check first!!  :P

ok, that's this girl's opinion...
shamini

would regularly do this to the president of the company, as well as his
coworkers. They wouldn't fire him because his code output was
equivalent to about 20 "manageable" programmers. I think he spent so
much time behind the computer that he took "flaming" habits into the
realm of real life. Of course, he was always 100% right and brutally
honest in telling everybody how things really were (except for
politics)... I regularly applauded his abusive behavior as the
then-president of the company really was a tie-wearing wanker (also
known as a "stanford MBA") that really didn't know shit about anything
and made so many wrong decisions that his  name is synonymous with
"fool" in Silicon Valley (just little things, like president S.H. being
too miserly to properly support Marc Andreesen's ambitions (you know

(you know the VRML guy) back when he worked here....), not supporting
Simon Spero (you know the HTTP-NG guy) back when he worked here...). 
Good thing S.H. is long gone, long forgotten (and Steve, if yer reading
this for some reason, a big FUCK YOU for the cowardly back-stabbing
after your departure!!!).

of bad engineering that Netscape is perpetrating on the world-wide-web

To: Ariel Stallings <ASTALLINGS@gcwf.com>

Subject: boundaries and sExual issues (was RE: Women and Safety At Raves)
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>think some people get this kind of confused and skip those middle logical
>steps and say "OOH!  E MAKEZ YOU REALLY HORNY!"  I have had

i don't know about others, but E does NOT make me horny... but it does make
me like to hug and touch and kiss in ways that many people would consider
s*xual, even on E.

>What an abuse of a potentially wonderful drug!

i think the abuse comes when people stop respecting other peoples
boundaries... thankfully there is less of that in the rave scene than there
is elsewhere.

>And I HAVE met people I'm attracted to at parties and I HAVE hit on them
>and (yes) I have been reduced to one of those people making out in a
>corner.  It DOES happen.  Just like it could happen in any other
...
>making out.  Raves are open environments, so things DO happen, I just
>think that it's not fair to assume that they SHOULD.

there is a big difference between liking someone and expressing your
fEElings physically (to whatever extent you're both comfortable with)
versus going up to a perfect stranger and _expecting_ them to do
kiss/grope/whatever.

>I have to acknowledge here that there is a double standard.  As a
>woman, I have been high on ecstacy started chatting to some cute boy I
>really like and reached up, grabbed the back of his head and stuck my
>tongue down his throat.  If I was a man this would not seem nearly so
>cute and assertive to the recipiant as it has the few times (ew, ok, I'm
>exposing my skeletons, here!) I have done such a thing.  It's sick and not
>very pc of me to say it, but I can DO things like that because women in
>society are the ones who have gotten stuck with being the "green light"
>sexually...which means when we want it, a lot (NOT all) of the time we
>can get it.  (eek, am I actually saying this?  ...hmm)

very true... i've seen this happen at raves and it always bothers me,
because if i happen to be feeling kissy some night, i can't just be totally
open and forward about it, i have to find people who i already know like to
kiss at raves, or else just forget about it and it'll happen if it happens.
on the other hand, it's still just a matter of peoples boundaries-- women
tend to more easily offend at physicality from ppl they don't know very
well-- and i wish to respect those boundaries...

if you want to _do_ something about that double-standard you can: either
(a) ask first before sticking your tongue in someones mouth, or (b) don't
get offended when some guy who thinks you're cute kisses you all of a
sudden. i think (a) is probably a better (more respectful) solution.

>has a great point about how women have a lot of fun on e because it
>ISN'T a horny drug like alcohol, in fact it can cause impotence in men at
>times (hmm, been there, seen that, TEE HEE!  *duck*) and so women feel
>more comfortable at raves because they don't feel like they're constantly
>fending off horny drunk men.

>ANYWAY.  My point is that sexual relations at raves, like in any social
>situation, is complex.

ok, let me pose a question to the list:

what is sexual and what isn't?

i've had experiences with people that any sober observer would have called
sexual (kissing/"making out" with someone in a chill room) that we didn't
consider sexual at all.

and then i've had experiences, almost indistinguishable from the former to
our hypothetical sober observer, that most definitely _were_ sexual.

i have trouble figuring out where the line is. and if it matters.

so, where do YOU draw the line between "not sexual" and "sexual"? and does
this line coincide with the line between what won't offend you and what
will? or does it depend who you're with?


hugs;

if (i won't offend you with a kiss)
{
        kisses;
}
else
{
        more hugs;
}

brian

Precedence: bulk

Right before somebody gets hauled off to the principal's office for
throwing dirtclods and spitting. Alas, no recess monitors here at SFR.
(Generally a good thing)

I'd just like to offer this suggestion:

If you read something that raises your hackles, go ahead and write whatever
vitriolic spew you'd like in return, but don't send it immediately. Wait 15
minutes and go back and reread what you've written and see if it's really
expressing what you want to say in an intelligent and succint manner or if
it's merely an overwrought emotional reaction. Then decide if you want to
send it, and if you still do, whether or not to send it to the entire list.
I've yet to see a contructive end to a flame war.

All IMHO, of course.

Joe

On Tue, 15 Oct 1996, Thomas Schwarz wrote:


> 
> I remember Mark E. Quark from my time in San Diego. He's awesome. 
> Any more information about having him here in the bay area?
> When does he come, where will he spin?


yeah, Mark's one of the good guys :)

San Diego is a very different world. in terms or raving, you really don't
have the luxary to be selective in your partying. there are ((or at
least at one time: were)) only a handful of DJ's that really had the
skills. Mark was one of those veterans who had achieved a local folk hero
stautus in the community, but without any of the negative aspects normally
associated with that title. no one really talked shit about him, there
weren't any rock star accusations, the guy didn't do heroin, and he tended
to put out good tapes. Mark's just a real likeable guy.

Word is that he and Lotus are moving into a house in these parts.

From: branka@sirius.com (*B*)
Subject: Re: Women and Safety At Raves: Please respond to the list
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

        OK, I am bored at work, so considering that I am female gender I
feel like saying something on this topic.

        Intro: I've been raving for 8 months now, and last 5 I spend raving
with Marc (my BF), so some of my opinions might have been influenced by
that.

        I don't like when people touch me - grab me, at raves or any other
places.  I don't like when people check me out and make rude comments about
the way I look (verbally or just with their expressions).  And, maybe I ask
for it, by wearing tiny tops that show my belly-button, although that is
not my intention.  Sometimes I get angry (happened to me at 215, and I was
in the state of mind when I wasn't scared, and I was ready to punch this
big 'G' kind of guy - I tried to get Marc's attention but he was in a
different world.  If you know me, you know I would have gotten my ass
kicked big time).  Almost always I can control my anger for my own good :).

        I used to be able to deal with it better - when I lived in bar /
club world.  That's the way people are, and you get used to it, by behaving
like that in return.  I used to be able to walk up to a cute guy, talk to
him, get him drinks, ask-for-whatever-I-wanted and usually get it...  I
used to drink a lot and alcohol just makes me very confident, horny and
ready to do whatever it takes to get what I want.

        At raves, I feel totally different.  Majority of people who are
there are not there to get laid (or maybe I am just a naive silly person),
but rather to meet other people and make friendships.  If somebody was
grabbing me at a rave I would feel angry and maybe even scared, because my
'protective wall' is down and I feel more relaxed and secure in that
atmosphere.  I don't feel like I have to act bitchy or be tough just to be
a small part of the scene, because being who I am makes me a part of it (at
least I hope).
        I am not one of those people who like puppy-piles and hugging
everybody.  I hug my friends, but I don't believe in kissing/making out
with every possible creature that happens to be next to me.  I know people
who do, which is cool if everybody is into it - it's just not something for
me.

       Another thing that changed for me since bar world (I am saying this
in response to Ariel's post) is that I don't have that confidence I used to
have.  Maybe I just envy her for beeing the way I used to be :(.  Before
Marc and I started going out (I don't do it now) I used to see cute guys
and just be able to look at them and think how great would be to kiss them
or even just talk to them.  But that's where it would end at.  Same feeling
most people have when they are 11 years old.  Pretty silly, cosidering that
I have no problem talking to other people.  And I am not sure if there is
anything I could do about it.  I don't have to worry about that now, but
there will be time, when I will feel like talking to a cute guy and wishing
I had couple beers and my confidence back...

        OK, enough babbling, I should get back to work.  Sorry this got off
tangent.

Hugz,
*B*

about the tired ones). And, for work and home listening I've been
purchacing some ambient and other stuff. Actually I still listen to
Goa Trance, Prana, Dragonfly or the like in the morning, but ...

The ambient music stuff has been growing more than any other type of
electronic music, or so it seems to me. One interesting style is the
"Drum and Bass" stuff. To my ear it is like a combination of jungle
and ambient.

I picked up this CD by PLUG called "drum'n'bass for papa" on blue
angel records. I really like it. It is very sample based, very
intricate, and I think it is made quite well (production, taste,
original, etc.). It often sounds like movie sound track music, but too
much movement for an actual sound track. It gets me going in a totally
different way than trance. Kindof "picks you up while it relaxes" like
they say in those old coffee achiever commercials.

With my own music, I often try to do trancy stuff, but it often comes
out sounding a bit like this stuff, only with beats other the the
classic jungle break. People often say my stuff sounds like movie
sound track sounds, because it sort of takes you on a journey (I like
to think). So, I was quite pleased to hear this stuff. I've also added
some jungle beats recently.

Anyway, does anyone know who else sounds like PLUG, or have a more
clear definition of drum'n'bass, or any comments. It seems like
trip-hop and ambient dominates the chill rooms. Are you hearing
drum'n'bass in chill romms more? I'm usually not so carefull a
listener in the chill rooms.


=Darrel Etter
darrele@netcom.com

On Tue, 15 Oct 1996, Ariel Stallings wrote:

> I have to acknowledge here that there is a double standard.  As a
> woman, I have been high on ecstacy started chatting to some cute boy I
> really like and reached up, grabbed the back of his head and stuck my
> tongue down his throat.  If I was a man this would not seem nearly so
> cute and assertive to the recipiant as it has the few times (ew, ok, I'm
> exposing my skeletons, here!) I have done such a thing.  It's sick and not
> very pc of me to say it, but I can DO things like that because women in
> society are the ones who have gotten stuck with being the "green light"
> sexually...which means when we want it, a lot (NOT all) of the time we
> can get it.  (eek, am I actually saying this?  ...hmm)

  Before I get into this, I want to say - great post!  I was really glad
to see some more balanced perspectives show up on the list.  Flamefests
are cool & all, but when nobody is actually *saying* anything, they're
boring as hell.
  Anyway, the issues of double standards & physical boundaries are really
fascinating and I do have some things I'd like to add.  First, quickly, I
would personally be upset, angered, and hurt if anyone kissed me without
my say-so.  Generally, I think it's a good idea to bear in mind that
others may have different physical boundaries than yourself.
  In general, I think it's important to communicate.  Empathy counts, by
the way, and so do body language, etc.  It's possible without words to
tell someone you'd like to hug, ... them - no need to be extremist.  But
respect is a huge part of PLUR.  I'm a firm believer in empathy, however -
I'm confident that for the simple reason that I'm *not* into kissing, no
one will ever surprise kiss me (there may be other reasons too <-- note
self-deprecating humor... eliminates the need to flame!).  But that's
extremely optimistic, and apparently doesn't work too well in the
butt-grabbing dept. for many people... :(
  I guess I think it's really important that everyone be clear in their
own head what their boundaries are *before* messing around with
psychoactives.  And it's even more important to bear in mind that everyone
has different boundaries, and that those boundaries should **always be
respected**.  If you're not sure, ASK - don't GUESS.
  Anyway, now that this has actually evolved into a relevant and
interesting *discussion* (as opposed to a flamefest between several people
- - all with severe foot-in-mouth disease) I'm interested in hearing
reactions!  Keep it up!
  And if you feel the need to flame me for whatever reason, keep it off
the list please!

Wow, now we're getting some good stuff out, here!  Intelligent   
conversation springing up out of what started as pure crap... gotta love   
it.

My compliments to Ariel and Shamini for some thoughtful and open   
responses.  Shamini, it's really refreshing to hear a note of   
thoughtfulness about the position social stereotypes can put a guy in, in   
a world that seems to often assume that only women suffer from   
stereotypes.

I find this REALLY interesting... I'm trying to find an honest reply.  I   
guess it all comes back to whether or not the interest is mutual.  If a   
woman I find interesting and attractive is assertive enough to put   
herself on the line and make an advance, I expect I'd think it was great.   
 It's happened on rare occasion, and it was a great to have the burden of   
making the first move lifted.  Besides, it's powerfully attractive when   
someone knows what they want and is willing to take risks to make it   
happen.  (The downside is that there is a little strange voice inside   
that says, "Hey, wasn't _I_ supposed to do that?"  But then, just because   
old habits die hard, doesn't mean they shouldn't die.)

But that all presupposes that there's at least some mutual interest.  If   
there's not, if some woman I didn't care for came up and stuck her tongue   
in my mouth, well, I'd be utterly revolted, and I don't know _what_ the   
hell I'd do, but I wouldn't be happy.

Maybe there's nothing new said here; it's always been a judgement call,   
you read the signs, make your best guess, gamble a little.  To read the   
signs, you've got to have previous interaction.  So the verdict on random   
butt-grabbing is pretty clear, but hey, that's not even the interesting   
topic here anymore.

 -Roy

Hello again.  I just thought ofan appropriate quote on the subject of 
sexual issues and raves.  It responds (kinda) to Brian's question...

 On Tue, 15 Oct 1996, Brian Denny wrote:

> ok, let me pose a question to the list:
> 
> what is sexual and what isn't?
> 
> i've had experiences with people that any sober observer would have called
> sexual (kissing/"making out" with someone in a chill room) that we didn't
> consider sexual at all.
> 
> and then i've had experiences, almost indistinguishable from the former to
> our hypothetical sober observer, that most definitely _were_ sexual.

Okay, here it is:

	"Sexual love is an effort to gain friendship resulting from the 
	appearance of beauty; and it is not directed at intercourse, but at 
	friendship."

This is a quote by one of the Stoics.

So how does this relate to raves?  Well the obvious is raves are full of 
beautiful people, beauty in all it's forms.  And raves are full of 
potential friends also.  It's the most friendly atmosphere I've ever 
experienced.  I love it!  (there I go again...)  :)  I never stop singing 
the praises of raves.  Anyway, if this "Stoic" is to be believed, then a 
rave is where Sexual Love gets expressed sometimes in an attempt to make 
new friends.  There is still some ambiguity as to whether he meant that 
Sexual love "does" happen or "could" happen this way.  I lean toward 
"could".  

In Brian's examples, either is an attempt at friendship.  This is justa 
musing thing.  Thought I'd share.  

			-Kevin O'Neal-

PS  I see PLUR on here a lot.  I've never seen itbefore, but does it 
stand for Peace, Love, Unity, Respect?  It makes sense, but I'd liketo be 
sure.  :)

>blue cabinets. Although it was a little dark sounding; the high end

personally, i was a little dissapointed with the way the sound was tuned.
to my ear, anyway, the bass was much too muddy sounding, and the midtones
weren't loud enough nor sharp enough to give the drums a good sound.
maybe i'm just not in tune with the "sf sound" yet. ;)

>The visuals last night were extra good. The graphics all night were
>great, and having the lasers was a nice touch. I almost forgot that I
am i the only one who is bored by lasers (rhetorical question)? i mean, i
even thought they were cheesy when i saw them back in the 80's for the
first time (ahh.. new wave hits at the Toronto planetarium).
but i have seen some cool effects with lasers. a couple parties i've been
to at the deli (and my last there, i learned my lesson [boycott the deli!])
had stuff hanging that the laser got caught up in and created a nice effect.
would it be so hard to have a hundred or so balloons hanging from the
ceiling so that the laser could hit them and they would glow? 
-brendan-

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Oct 16 00:14:34 1996

From: Karen Hardie <pounce@vcn.bc.ca>
Subject: sorta women and safety-ish
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9610160017.A29261-0100000@opus.vcn.bc.ca>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The whole thing is a tough call.  There are some men that i really don't
mind getting big squooshy hugs from on a short acquaintance, regardless of
whether i find them sexually attractive.  Then there are the guys who,
although physically they might be pretty happening, just give off evil
vibes ... cos you KNOW they're the kind of person who will simply NOT
LEAVE YOU ALONE!!   :P

And then there are the people who SEEMED okay for the first hour or so,
but as the evening wears on, get weirder and weirder on you.  These are
the most difficult i think ... cos it's hard to justify why you were being
so nice to them at first and then become so much more aloof, without being
rude ... but they usually MAKE you get rude, don't they?  :) "Wanna
dance?"  "no, thank you, i'm a little tired just now."  "So?  come dance
with me!  come on!" arrrghh ... 

There used to be a time when almost all the people i was meeting at raves
were intelligent, thoughtful people with diverse interests.  Ever since
the explosion of speedfreaks up here, however, i am WAY more careful about
the people i will approach, or welcome into my space.  It sort of saddens 
me, as i once looked on raving as a glorious time to ramble and roam and 
communicate and laugh with complete freedom and no worries about what i 
might be getting myself into.

By no means am i limiting these experiences to women only.  I know 
there's just as many weird girls out there who probably have annoyed a 
goodly number of you guys. :)  I guess this is really the one thing which 
bugs me most about the growing popularity of the MASSIVE scene ... the 
more people who go to these things, the more chances for utter idiots to 
make life aggravating for everyone else.

pounce
----------------------------
You know, there are many people in the country today who, through no
fault of their own, are sane.  Some of them were born sane.  Some of
them became sane later in their lives.  It is up to people like you
and me who are out of our tiny little minds to try and help these
people overcome their sanity.
                                           -- Monty Python

Subject: sexuality at raves
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



Some women definitely are interested in sexual 'expression' and/or contact
at raves, you cannot deny this.  As an (often single) man, I often find
myself in very ambiguous situations at some of these parties.  I mean I like
sex as much as everybody, and it can be a fine line between flirtatiousness
and actually sexual invitation/desire, especially when E is involved.  In
fact, this is true in other aspects of living in SF too.

Moving from a place of much less sexual activity (people have girlfriends
for years, etc..) i'm still struggling with the local customs, rules, and
so forth about sexual interaction.  My question is (ladies, help me on this)
should one explicitly ask before any sort of contact (even if it totally
feels like the right thing to do) (e.g. "may I give you a kiss/whatever?")
or should one just try to go with the flow and risk overstepping the
bounds (which I've done innocently and felt bad about later)??  

The subtleties involved are many, and to compound the problem you get
a lot of young (and not so young) GIRLS who flirt way too much then you
say hi and they act suprised or worse.  So much insecurity out there, in
this shallow capitalist society(I could go on and on).

Then sometimes I feel like an outcast just because I'm horny, although
this may be partly imagined.  

I'm sure many besides myself would like some feedback on all this.

Thanks,

Bruce  (My name's Bruce and I'm a Goa addict.)

Precedence: bulk

At 06:54 PM 10/15/96 -0700, you wrote:

>Are you hearing
>drum'n'bass in chill romms more? I'm usually not so carefull a
>listener in the chill rooms.

I've been an ambient dj for a few years now, and recently I've been getting
into more drum and bass type stuff.  Now I've even started writing the
stuff.  Half time stuff though, where the main emphisis of the beat is like
at 80 or 90 bpm's with quick little occasional shots of double time breaks
thrown in....and ofcourse the ambient washy stuff over the top.  It's like
the ambient part relaxes you, and the complicated rhythm patterns tinker
with your intellect.  I always find myself struggling to *understand*
jungle....to see it's complicated structure in my mind.  So yea, when I
play, you will hear a little drum in bass in the chill room as well as other
forms of electronica.

Rick

"Let me have silence always in the centre of the shouting, that is
essential. Let me have silence so that no pin may drop and not be
heard, and not a whisper. Escape us for all our spouting, nor the
needle scratching upon this gramophone of the circular cosmic spot.
Hear me, mark me, learn me, throw the mind's ear open. Shut up the
mind's eye, all will be music. What sculpture of sound cannot, what
cannot as a fluid token words, that nothing else cannot." 

						-Wyndham Lewis

Ok, so far I have several DJs and a variety of music. However, it was
brought to my attention that if I let you all decide who the DJ's should
be, which would be cool to do, BUT, it MIGHT turn to a popularity contest
and that's not what I really want to happen.  So I'll just list the main
styles of music that the DJ's spin without the names, and go from there.
I'll put the names in a hat and pick them.  I think that's fair enough and
it get you involved with what you want to hear and it keeps it from being a
popularity contest.

If you have any comments or suggestion let me know. This will be the last
public post about this until further info comes about. If you want to know
the latest info or want to help and contribute to this, please email me
privately.

Thanks for all the help.

Tim (knucklehead)

     It was a dark and warm Sunset at 4 mile
     
     Spun was playing some old skool acid beats.

OK, my last words on this subject:
[snip]
> This list starts to annoy me a whole lot.
> The way everybody joins in to flame some kid that simply refuses to voice
> in your choir of boring new age vibe sending conformity (yeah THATS
> courage, you fucking coward sheep),

Although I understand and respect your willingness to fend for those who
speak their minority opinion (like Jeff or Wowser in the past) I think
the list's response was not born out of a "boring new age vibe" but
basically because people feel pretty upset about his viewpoints. Although
I don't care much about the flaming that's been going on, Jeff hasn't
really clarified his point besides stating that he still has to kick
women off his God-like body. I find it kind of encouraging to see so
many people actually caring about womens personal freedom and all that,
given that they're still the "niggers of the world" as John Lennon put
it. Just because Jeff's opinion differs from that of most on the list
(but not from many people in the real world maybe) still doesn't mean
he is right. Just take a look at salaries of men and women in similar
jobs, domestic violence, date rape etc. and I guess you'll agree with
me that some people still need to be educated about the equality of all
people. Unfortunately, that was not the kind of attitude some people have
shown on the list by bluntly flaming away.

> the self declared righteousness of mr.
> moonpup, just to name somebody whose contribution struck me in an especially
> unpleasant manner, the joy and satisfaction  you people seem to get out of
> suffocating every attempt to utter a free, playful, uncensored, un-pc thougt,
> the entire TOTALITARISTIC attitude of this list definitely SUCK.

I like that one, "a free, playful, uncensored, un-pc thought". In that
respect one also could consider Moonpup's posting the same thing, i.e.
being pretty rude. And I wouldn't consider Jeff's way of thinking playful,
just plain stupid and people have to right to say so. It's only words, like
you said. And besides, totalitarianism requires an organization and the
people here all send their e-mails as individuals. I guess it means that
a lot of people have the same (respect-women) mindset on this list.

> people you mistake words for actions. you are desperately wrong in your
> infantile belief that the world would change in any way if you just
> succeded in your cruisage to suppress every uncorrect word. thanks god you
> won't, and thanks god there are other parts of the world where people are not
> as lame as you are.

Ofcourse people have the right to state their opinion but this particular
one is part of an ongoing battle for equal rights. If nobody had spoken
out about women's rights in the past, you probably would sit at home
right now, taking care of 12 kids and not being able to vote, go to a
university etc. I'm not surprised people react strongly to this kind of
stuff.

> it was said more than once by himself, let me say it again:
> jeff baby was just using WORDS. he didn't grab one single womans butt.

Exactly, and people are sending words back to him, they don't kick his
butt. I only wished the discussion would have been more intelligent
(which it is becoming slowly after the emotions have died down a bit)

> i am a woman. i don't feel offended in any way. i could even think of
> circumstances where i would possibly maybe enjoy it to have my butt
> grabbed a tiny little bit.

That's a different thing then when it just happens to you unexpectedly
and without your consent.

> however, when it happens to me and i don't
> like it (barely ever where i am btw) i don't make a fucking drama out of it.

You accept it as a normal part of life, I guess. That's a pretty sad thing
I'd say. And where do you draw the line? Fondling your but is OK, attempting
to kiss you not? When you allow one, is there a reason to not allow the
other?

> i still feel perfectly respected in any way. i don't need some kind of stupid
> vacuum tent around me. life's diverse.
> so where's the problem guys.

It's not about diversity, it's about your body being yours.

> jeff i don't know you and i'm not sure if we have anything in common, but
> the couraged and CHEERFUL way you defend your person and your right of free
> speech has all my respect and my utmost sympathy.

Personally I haven't seen much of a clearly worded defense or explanation
from him (which would have been interesting).

> i'm very sorry to piss you people off, and i'm especially sorry for myself
> cause i thougt i had some, well, like, friends there overseas, but i really
> had to say that.
> sorry, ulrike

Friends should be able to speak their mind to each other.

The Frying Dutchman

WOW!  I've been thinking a lot about this whole issue and it seems (from
some of the postings and emails I got) that other people have too...

shamini said:
One thing that we women should think about, is that we shouldn't take
advantage of the social stigmas for our benefit.  Sure, chances are if we
without warning grab a guy's butt or "stick our tongue down his throat"
;-) that he's not going to tell you he feels violated.  Maybe most  won't
feel violated.  But there ARE some guys who will feel lame about it, but
would never  admit it, perhaps even to themselves, because they'd feel
like a ween because they're "supposed" to want that as a "man"
>>>

Really good point.  And I certainly wasn't saying that I walk around
randomly inserting my tongue into strangers' mouths.  In the situations I
was refering to, there was generally a lot of talking and body language
going on, and when I "made my move" (ew, what a PIMP this makes me
sound like!) I was pretty damn sure it would work out.  Although it has
NOT worked out a few times.  I've gotten the "oh, you ridiculous little
etard" look and a hug and had to tuck my tail and slink away, but I've
never had anyone be OFFENDED.

What I'm saying is that as a woman, I can make assumptions men can't. 
Worst case scenario:  I attack some random man with my tongue, he
feels violated, he's 6 inches taller than me and weighs 50 pounds more
than me, pushes me off him and walks away disgusted and in need of
therapy.  We ALL know that the worst case scenario for a woman in
that situation is pretty different.

Brian Denny wrote:
If you want to _do_ something about that double-standard you can:
either (a) ask first before sticking your tongue in someones mouth, or (b)
don't get offended when some guy who thinks you're cute kisses you all
of a sudden. i think (a) is probably a better (more respectful) solution.
>>>

Hmm, yes, you're right here.  I want to have it both ways though!  I
mean...What's bizarre is that of the two I prefer the LATTER which I
know seems strange but let me explain.  I prefer it within the rave
community because it is an open expressive scene.  I would rather keep
that openess and spontaneity alive and keep a bottle of Listerine handy
for those random kissing-attack moments (which, don't get me wrong
here: THIS IS NOT SOMETHING THAT HAPPENS TO ME WITH ANY
FREQUENCY) than feel like I'm at that college where you have to say
"may I now untuck your shirt?  May I now touch your penis?  May I now
take off my shoes?"  I mean, what I'm saying could be taken out of
context and turned into "Ariel support date rape" which I really really
really vehemently (OBVIOUSLY) do not support...I'm just saying that
affection to some extent is a freedom of expression...

Ug, am I saying I'm in SUPPORT off A$$ GRABBING?  No.  I don't know
what I'm saying any more.  :S

BRIAN DENNY WROTE THIS, TOO:
i think that's true of some guys... personally i would be a bit, um,
surprised if a girl just kissed me totally out of the blue...  if she
_asked_ first, it would be no problem-- i like to kiss. by asking (or making
kissy gestures or something) i would feel more respected and wouldn't
be caught off-guard.
>>>>>

AH!  SEe, that's what I'm saying.  It's not OUT OF THE BLUE...Basically,
what I'm trying to say (in between tripping over my tongue and sounding
like a proponent of date rape) is this:

>I have no problem with spontaneity or making out in corners...show
>your love in whatever way you see appropriate :o) As long as it's a
>mutual thing, you know?  And if you're not sure it's a mutual wanting,
>it's probably a good idea to check first!!  :P

>what an idea... respect and open communication...

Words of Brian and Shamini.  Ah, they said it better than I could.   And for
anyone who is now worried: I PROMISE I DO NOT GO AROUND PARTIES
KISSING RANDOM PEOPLE.  Although...hee hee hee.  The first time I
kissed Timothy (my sweetheart/partner in crime) was at a Beautiful
People and I just interupted him mid-sentence and kissed 'im.  Thank god
he wasn't offended! See, it does work out, SOMETIMES.

:)

Ok I promise I'll be quiet now.
Ariel

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Oct 16 13:49:08 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id NAA25315; Wed, 16 Oct 1996 13:49:08 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from acergw3.acer.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with ESMTP id NAA25306; Wed, 16 Oct 1996 13:49:05 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from smtplink.acer.com ([204.160.139.137]) by acergw3.acer.com (8.7.3/8.7.3) with SMTP id NAA06465 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 16 Oct 1996 13:44:53 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from ccMail by smtplink.acer.com (SMTPLINK V2.11.01)
	id AA845499230; Wed, 16 Oct 96 13:49:38 pst
Date: Wed, 16 Oct 96 13:49:38 pst
From: "Andy Wyszkowski" <awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com>
Message-Id: <9609168454.AA845499230@smtplink.acer.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Planetarium Review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     
     First... 
     
     If you didn't go, don't feel bad.  It was only totally 
     unfuckinbelieveable, had some kill DJ's, best outdoor location I can 
     remember, cool promoters, and great people showed.
     
     Started in patented "Andy's in a good mood" mood, making dumb jokes so 
     bad people were just laughing at how lame I am.  Got a call from a 
     certain DJ (who's remaining unnamed but has certain luna-canine 
     affiliations and is going back to England soon *maximum respect!*) who 
     couldn't make it as my copilot, so I kinda got a little sappy... I 
     might have to go alone in the Samurai of Death to where the kindest 
     kind comes from... a two-three hour drive.  Ick.
     
     Fortunately, I found a ride from some enthusiastic newbies (heh heh 
     heh...) named Sabrina and Greg and took off about 7pm.  The road was 
     classic, and reminded me of why I love outdoor parties (the harder to 
     get to, the harder they rawk!).  I get there... and there's not a lot 
     of people there, the directions seem a little off, and some guy tells 
     us to follow the planets down the mountain about 9 miles... uh, 
     astrological driving?  Oh, little pictures of Saturn with arrows.  
     Okay.  I felt safe anyway... we were in a Volvo (which I think means 
     indestructible family style tank sans gun in Swedish).
     
     Two DJ areas, maybe 200 people.  So intimate.  Took care of the 
     newbies, made sure they started off right and got to the business of 
     partying.
     
     (+)
     I met nice people exclusively.  Nobody sucked.  Except me for running 
     out of cigarettes, and being a bum from about 4:00am on.  Oh, I was 
     the tallish guy with the doo-rag/F'd up hair, the pale blue and white 
     flannel with hood, black cords, and gratuitous KGB offerings.
     
     (+)
     Witnessed Deaks spin the best set I've heard in a long time... I love 
     hearing a DJ that throws it around like that.  And when's the last 
     time I heard "DILDO!DILDO!DILDO!" ... best use of happy hardcore I can 
     remember.  Buildups a mile long and a mile high.... Why were there 
     only a handful of people dancing... I'm still sore as hell (neck ouch, 
     back ouch, legs ouch).  Crazy crazy crazy crazy... 
     
     (+)
     Cloud never seems to spin the same stuff twice.  I vaguely recall 
     Gloria Gaynor's "I will survive" at Charity (disco... run away!)... 
     Didn't know he did trance.  Pretty trance.  Damn good trance.  Yay!  
     Also noted... pyrotechnic light show using only the mother of all 
     BBQ's and a lot of lighter fluid.
     
     (+)
     Stoney's tasty choices around sunrise.  Trees, mountains, hills, sun, 
     clouds, sky, fog, that peach to pink to blue fade that went halfway 
     across the heavens, you and me.  Damn.... Funny watchin people go 
     running out of their tents putting on clothes to dance to "Funk 
     Phenomenon".
     
     (+)
     Morning Junglism on the hill. I had to leave the area because 
     everytime I tried to dance I almost passed out.  You just can't stand 
     still to good jungle...
     
     (+)
     Maya's "oops!" face she does when things get chaotic at the 1200's.
     
     (+)
     Took a tip from Gilligan:
     Tikki Torches = Good Party
     
     (?)
     The shadowboxing dancer at like 5-6am on the hill.  Didn't hurt 
     anybody, but it was really weird feeling at one with the world with 
     all the angst and frustration gone from my mind body and soul, and 
     seeing this guy faking like he's tearing people's heads off and 
     pulping their skulls.  Maybe it was just me.  To each their own...
     
     (?)
     Kept thinking this one rock was a grizzly bear or something... I 
     wanted to go up and touch it or throw a rock at it or something, but 
     what if it really was a bear?  Maybe the bear just liked techno, or 
     found a baby Tylenol and was in the mood to hang with some cool folks. 
      Or maybe it was just a rock.
     
     And the moment of the evening goes to...
     
     Anonymous:
     After falling asleep on a haybale in the fetal position (it's the only 
     way a 6'2" person fits on a hay bale), some lovely person woke me up 
     to tell me they had pushed up another haybale up and that I was 
     welcome to stretch out.  That was soo nice... sorry if I seemed like 
     I'd just given birth, but Thank You.
     
     Oh... and I've been sick all week since.  I guess it was pretty cold 
     up there.  Howcome nobody informed me?
     
     8)
     
     AndyW

>I'm not going to participate in today's flame war, but I've got to say this:
>
>As Nancy pointed out, women (usually) feel safer at raves because there is a 
>(relatively) high respect level in that environment.  

>The question is simple: do you find it acceptable to have a stranger fondle 
>you at a party?


I've never given this much thought as in the aspect of "raving" because i
never thought harassment was that prevalent and it's not something me or my
friends do.  But when i read Nancy's post i got some insight as to what it
must be like for a woman, especially in her social life.  Men, i MOST
definitely admit, are not always gentlemen and i think if we make people
aware of this important issue and educate ourselves, then MAYBE we can
atleast cut down on it.  As attitudes change, so will people's actions.

My $.02...well actually i'm broke, so i owe everyone $.02.
Micron

He sees me come in and almost immediately puts on some of my favourite
records. It was good to be home.

> Brian Denny wrote:
> If you want to _do_ something about that double-standard you can:
> either (a) ask first before sticking your tongue in someones mouth, or (b)
> don't get offended when some guy who thinks you're cute kisses you all
> of a sudden. i think (a) is probably a better (more respectful) solution.
> >>>
> 
> Hmm, yes, you're right here.  I want to have it both ways though!  I
> mean...What's bizarre is that of the two I prefer the LATTER which I
> know seems strange but let me explain.  I prefer it within the rave
> community because it is an open expressive scene.  I would rather keep
> that openess and spontaneity alive and keep a bottle of Listerine handy
> for those random kissing-attack moments (which, don't get me wrong
> here: THIS IS NOT SOMETHING THAT HAPPENS TO ME WITH ANY
> FREQUENCY) than feel like I'm at that college where you have to say
> "may I now untuck your shirt?  May I now touch your penis?  May I now
> take off my shoes?"

I think I know exactly what Ariel is trying to explain.  I also like that 
bit of respectful sponteneity between two people.  You can tell it would 
be alright by reading each other body laguage and feeling the other's 
energy.

It's strange and rather difficult to explain, but when I am not in the 
mood to meet guys, somehow they can tell that.  Last year for about 8 
months I did not want to be physically involved with any guy.  Flirt was 
not a word in my vocabulary and I was totally happy being by myself - 
heck I didn't even want to be a part of a puppy pile or hand-orgy!  I 
just met lots of people and acquired friends of both genders.

When I was finally "ready", thinking it might be nice to share in some 
male company, I did that very night.  Guys can just tell if you are ready 
- at least the sensative ones do.  I think it is all in energy and body 
language - you just know how to tune in, that way you can act without 
asking and still remain respectful and non-offensive.  

That's this gal's 2 francs for this hump day...

love,
Amy

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Oct 16 15:01:56 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id PAA02580; Wed, 16 Oct 1996 15:01:56 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from netcom19.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with SMTP id PAA02575; Wed, 16 Oct 1996 15:01:53 -0700 (PDT)
Received: (from simitzis@localhost) by netcom19.netcom.com (8.6.13/Netcom)
	id PAA09310; Wed, 16 Oct 1996 15:01:52 -0700
Date: Wed, 16 Oct 1996 15:01:52 -0700
From: simitzis@netcom.com (Steve Simitzis)
Message-Id: <199610162201.PAA09310@netcom19.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: MC303 -- review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Well, I finally had a chance to play with the little silver box at
Guitar Center in SJ... And well, it was, er... not bad. Okay, I didn't
like the sound (at all), but I recommend checking it out.

My initial interest came from the possiblity of using it as a grab bag
of sounds, especially when I was looking for a 303 emulator. But the
TB303 sounds are terrible on the Groovebox. Roland really blew it on
this one, IMHO. Less like a 303, and more like a Casio harmonica with
filter sweeping capabilities.

The drum samples also were quite disappointing. I was expecting the
thump of a 909 and the "bwwwaaaauuuum" of an 808, but they weren't
there.

However, the pre-programmed loops are ultra cool, despite the cheese
factor of the patches/samples (I seriously did not find a single patch
that impressed me). And each instrument has a mute button, so during a
loop, you can insert a break by killing the kick and the snare, for
example. Neat stuff :)

For some reason, I found the MC303 very addicting, though, and I
finally was able to determine why it should exist. I see it as the kind
of thing that you keep in your backpack... for those moments on the
train... a tune comes in your head; you sing it all day in your head
and hope it'll still be there by the time you get to the sequencer.

But instead, you pull out your Groovebox and record those precious
moments before they escape... yes, I like the idea... I like it. Then
get home and do some real recording. A laptop for musicians? ;)

As a side note, I picked up a Bass Station, but I'd still like to
compare it to the Syntecno. Any comparisons?

Steve

>Hmm, lots of big names and big parties being mentioned in this thread.
>It's hard to choose though (even harder to acquire and remember the
>names of the people spinning when you're having a good time ;) )
>What makes a good DJ set? 

Well, IMO, what makes a good DJ set is which one is the most memorable.  
When I saw Spun spin at the 91 New Year Gathering, I had only been raving 
for a short time.  Listening to his set, was the first time I actually 
'got it'....the vibe, the experience, the people, the music, everything 
just kinda fell into place, and I remember dancing just to the right of 
the DJ booth, and thinking...."WOW!! I get it now!!  This is where I Need 
to be."  I even remember what track he was playing, "Nature" by Young 
American Primatives.

-M

                       ____                     ____
                                  !E.A.C!       
                       Electronic Artists Collective
                       ____     *Astronout*     ____

 My music prefs for BBQ&BEATS III ... ( no particular order )

 1. House! ( I usually eat too much to do trance effectively anyway! 
      ,and I realize that I haven't heard any soulful vocals coming out
      of a speaker bin in quite awhile. ) 
 2. Jungle/breakbeat/trip-hop/acid jazz  ( dub may be too much on the 
      ambient side for my taste - maybe REAL early in the day )
 3. Psychedelic trance ( after the food has digested! )

 Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

>For some reason, I found the MC303 very addicting, though, and I
>finally was able to determine why it should exist. I see it as the kind
>of thing that you keep in your backpack... for those moments on the
>train... a tune comes in your head; you sing it all day in your head
>and hope it'll still be there by the time you get to the sequencer.

Roland makes a pocket sized 8 track sequencer with about 300 or so sounds,
as well as some effects in it for this purpose.   It's a little bigger than
a walk man.

Rick

"Let me have silence always in the centre of the shouting, that is
essential. Let me have silence so that no pin may drop and not be
heard, and not a whisper. Escape us for all our spouting, nor the
needle scratching upon this gramophone of the circular cosmic spot.
Hear me, mark me, learn me, throw the mind's ear open. Shut up the
mind's eye, all will be music. What sculpture of sound cannot, what
cannot as a fluid token words, that nothing else cannot." 

						-Wyndham Lewis

Received: from scv3.apple.com (web.apple.com [17.128.100.121]) by mail-out2.apple.com (8.7.5/8.7.3) with ESMTP id PAA23018; Wed, 16 Oct 1996 15:26:53 -0700
Received: from [17.128.202.178] ([17.128.202.178]) by scv3.apple.com (8.7.5/8.7.3) with SMTP id PAA08898; Wed, 16 Oct 1996 15:28:54 -0700
Message-Id: <199610162228.PAA08898@scv3.apple.com>
Subject: Re: MC303 -- review
Date: Wed, 16 Oct 96 15:30:19 -0000
x-sender: camp@mail.apple.com
x-mailer: Claris Emailer 1.1
From: "Mark D. Camp" <camp@apple.com>
To: "Steve Simitzis" <simitzis@netcom.com>, "sfraves" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


>My initial interest came from the possiblity of using it as a grab bag
>of sounds, especially when I was looking for a 303 emulator. But the
>TB303 sounds are terrible on the Groovebox. Roland really blew it on
>this one, IMHO. Less like a 303, and more like a Casio harmonica with
>filter sweeping capabilities.

I just bought an MC303 on Tuesday.  I'll agree with you on the 303 
sounds, they suck.  Sounds nothing like a 303.

>The drum samples also were quite disappointing. I was expecting the
>thump of a 909 and the "bwwwaaaauuuum" of an 808, but they weren't
>there.

Have to disagree with you on this one.  I think the drums sounds are 
increadable.  Again, nothing like the real thing, But there's a ton of 
them, and they sound great when run thru the filters.  

>However, the pre-programmed loops are ultra cool, despite the cheese
>factor of the patches/samples (I seriously did not find a single patch
>that impressed me). And each instrument has a mute button, so during a
>loop, you can insert a break by killing the kick and the snare, for
>example. Neat stuff :)

Yes, really cool stuff.  By playing with the preset rhythm's I definatly 
see where they came up with the name "GrooveBox" (still dont know where 
the '303' name comes from.....I guess the Marketing Department).  The 
downside of all the cool preset loops is, people are going to be using 
them......to release records......Which, IMO, is really sad because its 
not their music, its some dude sitting in a cube at Roland creating the 
music for them.  

>I see it as the kind of thing that you keep in your backpack... for those 
moments on the
>train... a tune comes in your head; you sing it all day in your head
>and hope it'll still be there by the time you get to the sequencer.
>But instead, you pull out your Groovebox and record those precious
>moments before they escape... yes, I like the idea... I like it. Then
>get home and do some real recording. A laptop for musicians? ;)

That would be cool if it was battery powered, but its not, so you are 
limited to using it only near a power source.

Its a great tool for getting ideas down when you're sitting at home or at 
work (when your boss is not around, of course).  Still dont know how its 
going to work for me live, I'm not sure how much I can actually store in 
the sequencers memory.  I'd deffinatly recomend it if you're looking for 
an all in one portable techno box.

-M

oh ya, the head phone output is WAY too low.  You'll need to run it thu a 
mixer first.

                                  !E.A.C!       
                       Electronic Artists Collective
                       ____     *Astronout*     ____

Subject: Just somEthing fun

Precedence: bulk

     In the Monterey area, I have been seeing all of these signs everywhere
that say, "No On E". It had me quite distressed for a while I just would
think to myself, "What kind ao a place have I moved to?? Am I going to have
to rethink my place to settle in and go to school?"

Then, last night I found the answer to my question... A sign, bigger than all
of the others that said. "Urban sprawl costs us all...   -YES ON E" 

I began to smile and before I knew it, I was yelling to my roommate to "PULL
OVER NOW!! I'VE GOT TO GET THAT SIGN!" Soon I was dashing from the street and
over to the 2'x4' sign. Deeply buried in the soil, I had to pull on it with
all of my strength to make it mine. (Luckily, Monterey has nice sandy soil)

Now, mind you, I realize that what I did was probably a misdemeanor, and I'm
not condoning criminal behavior. But, now it decorates our livingroom,
clashing with everything we own. It's black letters on a yellow background
beaming its message from above the computer. "YES ON E."

From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: re: sexism at parties
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

To everyone who responded to my post privately: thank you! for all your 
kind words and consideration of the topic... I'm sorry I haven't written 
back personally, I have to sneak email at work at public monitors (a very 
tricky and risky business!!!)

I ALSO haven't been able to follow this thread totally (b/c of the work 
situation) but I am so heartened by the few I have read that show a lot 
of enlightened respect for women on behalf of the people on this list.

I did notice that the topic changed from the original objectifying 
treatment of women (the notorious "ass-grabbing") to a discussion on the 
gray area of how to appropriately approach people/signal attraction.  

There is a lot of confusion in our generation about this but I think this 
is GREAT because we are moving away from a more sexist paradigm (rude 
male behavior is "just being boys" or female clothing signaling 
availability) to figuring out a new paradigm based on new roles for men 
and women (hopefully more equal!).  Gender roles are in a state of major 
transformation - our discussions trying to figure out appropriate 
behavior is simply reflecting the positive transformation happening.  :) :)

As I think has been said, flirtation based on RESPECT for the person, 
paying attention to their signs and treating them like human beings is 
hopefully where we're headed.  

What I was initially upset about (actually, will always be upset about) 
is the lack of respect in objectification.  Leering, grabbing and 
generally being rude to women is NOT flirtation - it is behavior that 
dehumanizes the woman because it doesn't care about her response.  The 
whole point is that they can freely treat you in this manner; that they 
believe it is acceptable because you are female.  Whether you want it or 
not is totally immaterial.  It is a power differential exercised over 
women, thrusting them in to a sexual object role without their consent, 
and without any means of recourse. It happens whenever we walk down a 
street in public.

As for the "double standard," yes I agree women have a happier response 
from men when they approach them aggressively!  But it is not exactly 
reverse sexism; women grabbing guys' asses does not carry with it a 
legacy of thousands of years of domination based on a sexual definition and 
subordinate status of men to women; women do not constitute the physical 
threat to men and therefore the fear that a "little ass-grab" can 
instill; and I would bet that most women do it flirtatiously to a 
specific guy, not as an anonymous molestation in a crowd as most often 
happens to me.

Also, it could be true as was stated that women have a "sexual power" over 
men and use it.  But this "power" is based on the definition of women as 
sexualized beings to men, to wield power by accepting this definition and 
then trying to use it to her own advantage as much as possible.  The 
"power", in other words, is itself dependent on subordinated status.  
Then you get the stereotype of "whores" or "teases," women who use just 
about the only means of power available to them in patriarchal society - 
the definition imposed by hierarchy, that of sexualized object.  

Just as the "tease" is hounded by men, the aloof or playboy type of guy 
is sought after by a lot of women (as you "nice guys" have pointed out!)  
These types are a manifestation of the sexualized roles of patriarchy.  We 
have a system of patriarchy with which we are instilled from birth - 
being the horny creatures we are, we eroticize the roles associated with 
it.  

It is my hope that as our consciousness changes - as we move away from 
sexist thinking to a system of greater equality - that what is attractive 
to us will also evolve.  That "sexual double standards" and confusion 
will give way to relations based on equal human beings respecting each other.

It's a dream anyway!  

Feeling theoretical today,
Nancy
