On Wed, 16 Oct 1996, Nancy Shaw wrote:

> What I was initially upset about (actually, will always be upset about) 
> is the lack of respect in objectification.  Leering, grabbing and 
> generally being rude to women is NOT flirtation - it is behavior that 
> dehumanizes the woman because it doesn't care about her response.  The 
> whole point is that they can freely treat you in this manner; that they 
> believe it is acceptable because you are female.  Whether you want it or 
> not is totally immaterial.  It is a power differential exercised over 
> women, thrusting them in to a sexual object role without their consent, 
> and without any means of recourse. It happens whenever we walk down a 
> street in public.


	Except that to be objectified "whenever we walk down a street in 
public", "we" have to MENTALLY allow "ourselves" to be objectified. This 
line of reasoning bothers me for the simple reason that it is based on a 
you have no idea of what I go through line. I might make a similiar 
arguement that since there are women out there that will flaunt their 
sexuality, I am being objectified because, in this day and age, I have no 
means of recourse either. Now, am I really being violated in this case, 
or am I letting someone else get the best of me and placing the 
responsiblity for my own weaknesses on someone else? The case of 
ass-grabbing is a bit different because there, one's person is being 
violated.

> As for the "double standard," yes I agree women have a happier response 
> from men when they approach them aggressively!  But it is not exactly 
> reverse sexism; women grabbing guys' asses does not carry with it a 
> legacy of thousands of years of domination based on a sexual definition and 
> subordinate status of men to women; women do not constitute the physical 
> threat to men and therefore the fear that a "little ass-grab" can 
> instill; and I would bet that most women do it flirtatiously to a 
> specific guy, not as an anonymous molestation in a crowd as most often 
> happens to me.

	Let us look at this double standard a little more closely. Let us 
begin with the notion of a "legacy of thousands of years of domination". 
For the longest time, history has told us there has been a struggle 
between men and women that has centered around sex and power. Women had 
something men seemed to want, and it seems they still do. Now, since I 
was not around for most of the last thousand years (or if I have been, I 
surely do not remember it), I cannot say whether or not women have been 
dominated for that time. Looking at the stories that have made their ways 
through history, I know that either some cultures have allowed women to 
become sexual objects to be taken advantage of (an important distinction, 
because a sexual object such as goddess worship is still objectification 
though some forms of goddess worship supposedly came from matrical 
soceities).
	Anyway, bouncing through my memories of these stories, it seems,
when we look within the bounds of one soceity there has always been a
combination of behaviors, men raping women and women using sex to get what
they want (whether it be intercourse or clothing style or what have you). 
Each in itself is its own form of domination, one physical, one mental. 
But can we say which is worse? In today's standard's it seem obvious that 
the physical form of domination is far more voilating then the mental 
form of domination. But we have laws which restrict physical domination. 
Do we have equal laws under which someone can get legal recourse for 
mental domination? If you are a woman, yes, you do, it can be found under 
sexual harrassment, emotional abuse, and so on and so forth. Can men 
claim these as well? I would doubt it.
	Now let us take another look at mental domination. How many 
places does this enter our daily lives? How often do women bat their eye 
lashes to get a favor, play stupid to get out of something (or to get 
someone else to do it?). Let us ask how a male would go about doing the 
same things. Ok, now let us look through mainstream soceity as to what 
is expected of females and males. If you are female, you are now taught 
that when you grow up, you can either find a job and pursue it, have a 
family, or maybe be a housewife and just raise childs. Either way you 
are going to be working, and most likely, if you are working you will 
not be the sole wage earner in your family unless you are divorced. A 
male can look forward to growing up and supporting a family, maybe have 
a wife that works. (this all is based on "normal" growing up from what I 
understand it to be, howmany people have been raised in a different way 
- by both your parents and the rest of soceity). Here is a little theory of 
mine.
	Now, I personally could care less about who dominates who, or who
earns whose money... I try to stay away from those games, I have enough to
deal with with myself and my involvements, I have no time or energy to
waste on living someone else's life as well. Granted I slip up every once
in a while - ask anyone who has tried to drive my bus up a big hill and
has gotten stuck between gears. I just do not like being yelled at for
something I had nothing to do with. I also do not like being yelled at
people who want the best of both worlds... I shall go on to try 
to demonstrate: 

> Also, it could be true as was stated that women have a "sexual power" over 
> men and use it.  But this "power" is based on the definition of women as 
> sexualized beings to men, to wield power by accepting this definition and 
> then trying to use it to her own advantage as much as possible.  The 
> "power", in other words, is itself dependent on subordinated status.  

	Why is this power dependent on a subordinated status? Did these 
females perceive themsevlves to be subordinate, or did they play on the 
constructs of an inferior intellect to gain their own superiority? 
Abolsute status in a soceity only works if you buy into it... Why would 
you buyy into it? Most likely because it has something you want or feel 
you need. If you don't want to participate in the status struggle, then 
don't. If you still want things from soceity, than sharpen your wit, and 
take some self defense courses and most importantly, when something 
happens, follow through with your beliefs and don't sink into the 
background, because that is letting yourself be dominated. If you want to 
remain in the role of batting eyelases while being deamed equal, you have 
another thing to consider, at least in dealins with me.

> These types are a manifestation of the sexualized roles of patriarchy.  We 
> have a system of patriarchy with which we are instilled from birth - 
> being the horny creatures we are, we eroticize the roles associated with 
> it.  

	The same can be found in matrical soceities. Please, enough of 
the women are inheriently better than men shit. Power corrupts men and 
women equally, period. If you switched things around so that women were 
in charge, how different would things be? You might have men have 
revolutiuons from the tyranny and oppresion of females, because then, the 
cycles would just be reversed.

> It is my hope that as our consciousness changes - as we move away from 
> sexist thinking to a system of greater equality - that what is attractive 
> to us will also evolve.  That "sexual double standards" and confusion 
> will give way to relations based on equal human beings respecting each other.

	Which means no more bitching and name calling and I can't because
of my sex on everyone's part. I think in most places, relationships have
progressed quite a bit. Maybe not in business sectors like sales and
marketing, but overall, if you act like a human being, you will be treated
like on, if you act like a three year old who cannot do anything for
themselves, you will be treated like one, if you act like a sexual being,
you will be treated like one... What are you supposed to be? I don't know,
it's up to you to break through all of your cultural shit to figure it
out... So now all the women out there exclaim it is harder for women
because of all of the above mentioned reasons... Great, well, then maybe
you are bearing the weight of all the women in the 50s and previous who
fooled a generation into thinking men were dominate in all views and
forgot to pass on to the next generation the secret of manipulation, or
maybe we males have figured a little too much of it out, but if you want
to make a change for those who follow, your best bet would be to get your
shit sorted, right?! Which means I expect to see every "equalist" out there
helping break down the speaker stacks because although you might not be as
strong, you still can carry something ;)

dave

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Oct 16 21:41:09 1996

Dear Friends & Family,

My computer tells me that on Wed, 16 Oct 1996, Nancy Shaw shared:

> To everyone who responded to my post privately: thank you! for all your 
> kind words and consideration of the topic... I'm sorry I haven't written 
> back personally, I have to sneak email at work at public monitors (a very 
> tricky and risky business!!!)
> 
> I ALSO haven't been able to follow this thread totally (b/c of the work 
> situation) but I am so heartened by the few I have read that show a lot 
> of enlightened respect for women on behalf of the people on this list.
> 
> I did notice that the topic changed from the original objectifying 
> treatment of women (the notorious "ass-grabbing") to a discussion on the 
> gray area of how to appropriately approach people/signal attraction.  
> 
> There is a lot of confusion in our generation about this but I think this 
> is GREAT because we are moving away from a more sexist paradigm (rude 
> male behavior is "just being boys" or female clothing signaling 
> availability) to figuring out a new paradigm based on new roles for men 
> and women (hopefully more equal!).  Gender roles are in a state of major 
> transformation - our discussions trying to figure out appropriate 
> behavior is simply reflecting the positive transformation happening.  :) :)
> 
> As I think has been said, flirtation based on RESPECT for the person, 
> paying attention to their signs and treating them like human beings is 
> hopefully where we're headed.  
> 
> What I was initially upset about (actually, will always be upset about) 
> is the lack of respect in objectification.  Leering, grabbing and 
> generally being rude to women is NOT flirtation - it is behavior that 
> dehumanizes the woman because it doesn't care about her response.  The 
> whole point is that they can freely treat you in this manner; that they 
> believe it is acceptable because you are female.  Whether you want it or 
> not is totally immaterial.  It is a power differential exercised over 
> women, thrusting them in to a sexual object role without their consent, 
> and without any means of recourse. It happens whenever we walk down a 
> street in public.

	The ideal would be for everyone to be treated according to their wishes.
But even if everyone were willing to look upon each person exactly
as he or she wished to be regarded, they would not have the ability to
guess correctly every time.  Because we are not mind-readers, we must rely
on spoken and unspoken signals.
	I think it's important to recognize that being treated as sexually
desirable is in itself neither good nor bad.  Often we assume that this is
bad, that no one would want this, but when you think about it, that
assumption defies common sense and life experience.  There are lots of
times when people (both men and women) wish to be the recipient of
physical cues (not limited to physical contact) letting them know that
they are desired.
	The term "sex object" is usually used in a negative way, as if it
is impossible to treat someone as a sex object and respect them at the
same time.   A good example is the movie "Working Girl" where Melanie
Griffith's character says "I have a head for business and a bod for sin."
(I love that line!)  Clearly she wants men to appreciate her body, but not
only her body -- she wants to be a sex object, but she does not want that
to be the extent of how she is perceived.
	Agression and rudeness are one thing -- they're just plain wrong,
whether sexual or not.  But being politely appreciative, or making an honest
mistake in misreading signals, I don't see this as "a power differential
exercised over women" as Nancy puts it.  Just as plausible to complain
about being put into a *non-sexual* role without one's consent or any
means of recourse as to complain about being put in a *sexual* role!  
	Unless you really feel physically threatened, no one has power
over you unless you give it to them.  Feeling uncomfortable is not the
same thing.  Lots of guys feel uncomfortable when they are ignored by
women.  (Right now I can feel Gloria Steinem glaring at me).

> As for the "double standard," yes I agree women have a happier response 
> from men when they approach them aggressively!  But it is not exactly 
> reverse sexism; women grabbing guys' asses does not carry with it a 
> legacy of thousands of years of domination based on a sexual definition and 
> subordinate status of men to women; women do not constitute the physical 
> threat to men and therefore the fear that a "little ass-grab" can 
> instill; and I would bet that most women do it flirtatiously to a 
> specific guy, not as an anonymous molestation in a crowd as most often 
> happens to me.

	I agree, more is permissable for women right now...  Hopefully
we're moving toward men being less grope-happy and women being more so.
That would balance things out and make everyone in favor of equality
happier.

> Also, it could be true as was stated that women have a "sexual power" over 
> men and use it.  But this "power" is based on the definition of women as 
> sexualized beings to men, to wield power by accepting this definition and 
> then trying to use it to her own advantage as much as possible.  The 
> "power", in other words, is itself dependent on subordinated status.  
> Then you get the stereotype of "whores" or "teases," women who use just 
> about the only means of power available to them in patriarchal society - 
> the definition imposed by hierarchy, that of sexualized object.  

	Patriarchy is defined as rule by men, and I don't think that's
necessarily an apt description of social relations in our society.  The
balance between the genders is uneven in  many ways, but clearly men are
not "ruling."  (I know I'm going to get flamed for this one!)  In certain
countries like Saudi Arabia, that's another story.
	Again I do not think that being a sex object means being
subordinated in status.  It can, but the two don't go hand in hand.
Arnold Schwarzenegger and Tom Cruise are sex objects -- does that mean
they are "subordinate" in our society?  Madonna?  Clearly not!
Disrespected by some maybe, but not subordinate.
	The sexual power wielded by attractive women is not based on 	
a definition, IMHO, but on the biological reality of male sex drive.

> Just as the "tease" is hounded by men, the aloof or playboy type of guy 
> is sought after by a lot of women (as you "nice guys" have pointed out!)  
> These types are a manifestation of the sexualized roles of patriarchy.  We 
> have a system of patriarchy with which we are instilled from birth - 
> being the horny creatures we are, we eroticize the roles associated with 
> it.  

	Isn't this again assuming that sexualized roles are bad, by
associating them with a negative term like "patriarchy"?  Couldn't we have
a gender-equal society with sexualized roles for those who want them?

> It is my hope that as our consciousness changes - as we move away from 
> sexist thinking to a system of greater equality - that what is attractive 
> to us will also evolve.  That "sexual double standards" and confusion 
> will give way to relations based on equal human beings respecting each other.

	As long as we don't confuse "sexist" with "sexual," and we allow
people the freedom to be sexual and still give them the respect that we
give to the non-sexual, I think it will all work out eventually.

Much love (& sex),	;)-

				<<< Starchild >>>


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Oct 16 21:45:29 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id VAA12293; Wed, 16 Oct 1996 21:45:29 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from uclink4.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with ESMTP id VAA12288; Wed, 16 Oct 1996 21:45:26 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from uclink2.berkeley.edu (uclink2.berkeley.edu [128.32.136.72]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.7.6/8.6.12) with ESMTP id VAA31529; Wed, 16 Oct 1996 21:45:23 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from [136.152.74.237] (abrams2b.HIP.Berkeley.EDU [136.152.74.237]) by uclink2.berkeley.edu (8.7.6/8.6.12) with SMTP id VAA09595; Wed, 16 Oct 1996 21:42:36 -0700

>What I was initially upset about (actually, will always be upset about)
>is the lack of respect in objectification.  Leering, grabbing and
>generally being rude to women is NOT flirtation - it is behavior that
>dehumanizes the woman because it doesn't care about her response.  The
>whole point is that they can freely treat you in this manner; that they
>believe it is acceptable because you are female.  Whether you want it or
>not is totally immaterial.  It is a power differential exercised over
>women, thrusting them in to a sexual object role without their consent,
>and without any means of recourse. It happens whenever we walk down a
>street in public.


Nancy, Ariel, and others have provided a lot of insight into women's
perspectives on all this stuff. now i'd like to offer some insights into
how men's minds work...

i have spent a lot of time and thought observing women's reactions to men
in this regard...

i have seen innumberable examples of a female friend walking down the
street, and getting checked out by some guy, and she'll say either: (a)
"wow, he was cute!", or (b) "ewww, did you see that guy leering at my
breasts? yuck!"

i was confused for a very long time about this and i finally decided that
the response was based on 2 things: (1) how attractive she found the man in
question, and (2) how discreet he was being with his stare.

and it really seems to me that your comment "whether you want it or not is
totally immaterial" becomes an interesting problem at this point, because
women notice this behaviour by men, and if they happen to want it, the men
are rewarded, and if not, the men are accused of sexism.

some men are jerks and actually intend to objectify you. i make no defense
for this behaviour. but many, many men have NO CLUE about the way women's
feelings work. these men see women accepting some sexually aggressive
behavior and rejecting others, and they don't know what to do. what they
actually do depends on what type of guy they are.

the aggressive, insensitive ones get way too forward and behave rudely and
offensively, perhaps even grabbing asses. these guys aren't doing this out
of premeditated disrespect... they _are_ disrespecting you, but it's
because they don't see any other way to handle the situation. women's
practice of the "double standard" that ariel mentioned really contributes
to this problem because:

these guys are insecure inside, and seeing women exercise sexual power in
this "unfair" way actually seems oppressive to them.

and then there are the non-aggressive, sensitive (but not sensitive enough
to read women's social cues), insecure guys... i was one of these for a
long time and still am to an extent, so i can really provide insight here:

these guys do NOT get forward, do NOT grab asses, do NOT take or even ask
for kisses... they just make SURE to respect women's boundaries no matter
how unhappy they may be about doing so at that moment.

a story: i was at Harmony 3, around midnight, going up on E, feeling
physically affectionate-- not s*xual, mind you, just vEry physical (which
for me, as i've said, includes touching and kissing in ways that some
people _would_ consider sexual...)

anyway, i was also feeling particularly insecure and un-self-confident that
night, i was having trouble meeting people for plain ol' conversation, let
alone chill activities...

and i noticed some women (including one or two of my friends) kissing some
people, and observing how easy it was for them to find people to kiss, and
thinking "this is really unfair..."

and that feeling right there can really hurt, can really make you feel like
shit... i'm sure it's nothing so shitty as being physically violated, but
it's a very real, shitty feeling.

my point is that men who are more agressive than i am deal with that
feeling by being forward to the point of offensiveness.

so, to sum up:

1.      some men are complete evil assholes, but many just _act_ like
assholes because they're too unaware, hung up, and insecure to do anything
else.

2.      the paradigm i see is this: men have exercised physical sexual
power over women since the dawn of time. women have, in response, developed
ways of exercising psychological sexual power over men. (ariel's "double
standard" is a manifestation of this...). women's exercise of psychological
power makes things more "equal" on the surface, but it also helps promote
the exercise of physical power by men in some ways. thus i see it as a
self-perpetuating paradigm, and do not share Nancy's optimism about the
paradigm shifting towards a truer, more respectful equality.


--this has been a very long, rambling post... home some of you got
something out of it, and my apologies for the parts of it that seemed more
like a personal rant...

plurally,

brian

Dear Friends & Family,

My computer tells me that on Wed, 16 Oct 1996, Dave Bayer shared (in
part):

> 	Now, I personally could care less about who dominates who, or who
> earns whose money... I try to stay away from those games, I have enough to
> deal with with myself and my involvements, I have no time or energy to
> waste on living someone else's life as well. Granted I slip up every once
> in a while - ask anyone who has tried to drive my bus up a big hill and
> has gotten stuck between gears. I just do not like being yelled at for
> something I had nothing to do with. I also do not like being yelled at
> people who want the best of both worlds... I shall go on to try 
> to demonstrate... 

	I would agree with Dave that he is not at fault for actions
committed by others, but I would disagree regarding the historical status
of women.  In most societies, women have been treated as second class
citizens historically, because the idea of "universal human rights" is a
relatively recent Western concept.  As we have embraced this concept, the
mechanisms of aggression have become weaker, or less directed toward
groups based on race, gender, religion and the other traditional criteria
for which people have been mistreated.  Today minority women like Marian 
Wright Edelman and Maxine Waters enjoy more favor and protection from
society than do white men like Christian Martensen and Randy Weaver.
	Power in America is not based on sexual dominance, even if we do
have a sexual harrasser as President.  But because we still allow
aggression through government (some would say it's getting worse) we
haven't realized universal human rights either, and so it would be quite
easy to backslide to "might makes right" again, in which case power will
go to the strong, the aggressive, and the ruthless -- probably not a good
formula if you're a woman, or a sensitive man for that matter.  
	And in conclusion, that's why ass-grabbing at parties is bunk.  ;)

My $.02 (it was $20.00, but after inflation...)

				<<< Starchild >>>


P.S. -  Something else to consider:  Few people downgrade their social
	status voluntarily unless they are getting something they consider 
	more valuable in return.  What then to make of the fact that more
	men than women are getting sex changes, at no inconsiderable
	expense?  I doubt that you would see this in a truly sexist
	society like Saudi Arabia...

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----

Wow.  This has really given me a lot to think about over the last day or
so.  This post will probably get kind of long & turn into NRR land,
despite my best intentions.  Apologies in advance. 

I can't pretend to speak for men in general, by the way - and as a matter
of fact am always just a bit upset when someone claims to speak for me,
regardless of whether I agree.  In fact I know that I'm in a fairly small
subset of the male population as someone who, to put it bluntly, is
virtually asexual - so be it, what this all means is that this is all
merely one person's opinion.

In brief, I'm not happy with gender "roles".  One of the things that's
been pretty much taken for granted in virtually all of the previous rants
has been that all (or at least most) men can lose control of their own
actions, or be manipulated in other words, by another person's sexuality.
I'm really, really uncomfortable with this generalization; what's more, I
disagree.  Primal urges are all good, but in this world there are many
times when it is quite simply not acceptable for anyone, of either gender,
to allow themself to be ruled by their instincts.  Too many times have I
heard the "she was wearing a skimpy dress; I lost control" argument.
Truth or not, it's not a good enough excuse.  There's no such thing as
"asking for it" aside from literally saying "touch my ass, stranger."

Men, it is safe to generalize, tend to be larger & stronger than women. 
Obviously not in 100% of cases, but an overwhelming majority of the time.
In a world where we are trying to even the scales (not because they are
inherently even, but because we think it's *right*!), this gives men an
extra responsibility in being considerate & thoughtful of their actions.
My older sister (a very wise woman, BTW) once put me through an excercise
in understanding, for which I am very grateful.  For a month, I had to
alter my consciousness to some semblance of the female perspective -
almost every male who walked by on a dark street, I had to see as larger &
physically stronger, and as a potential assailant.  There was a lot more
to this excercise, but that's a general idea.  It really opened my eyes,
and (I hope) made me a bit more considerate.

A couple of people have proposed that women have the upper hand in the
mental arena, whereas men have the physical advantage.  I'm sorry, but
there are just as many manipulative men as there are women, if not more -
they may use different tools & methods, but both are equally nasty.  And, 
for the most part at any rate, there's no inherent advantage women have in
this area (it was implied that women are somehow more able to flaunt their
sexuality - I tend to disagree.)  Physical size & "superior" strength are,
sadly, biological differences that hinder true equality when flaunted.
Mental superiority or manipulative superiority are imagined.  Women do, in
general, tend to be more empathic - however I think (& am well supported
in thinking) that this is societal, not biological, in the same way as
men's tendency to be more agressive is.

And to those of you who think we are not living in a world/society where
women are subjugated & debased daily, bad news.  Girls are still
discouraged from certain subjects in schools at all levels, passed over by
employers, beaten by partners, raped by strangers and "friends", and so
on.  Yes, all of these things happen in the reverse as well, but the
numbers all point to the fact that the situation is considerably worse for
women.

Something else, and here I step into the realm of mere conjecture.  It
seems to me that women have much more clear & rigid societal expectations
to live up to.  Women's roles are significantly more pigeonholed than
those of men, it seems to me.  There is a beauty standard applied to women
that is not applied with equal force to men - not only that, but the
beauty standard applied to nowaday's women is *really* unhealthy.  Men are
still more free to explore their individuality in our society, sadly.

The rave scene is one place where women of all shapes, sizes, styles &
personalities are accepted for who they are.  They are free to dress &
talk & move & behave as they like, moreso than in everyday life.  For the
most part, they can expect to be free from harassment, sexual or
otherwise.  The above all applies to men as well, of course - it's just
more important for women because it's not like that all the time - in
daily life, there are more expectations (behavior & appearance) applied to
females than males.

I should try to justify that statement a bit, because I know it's going to
raise a few hairs.  Obviously (I think,) we are all - regardless of gender
- - free to be ourselves.  Women, however, are more likely to be treated
negatively if they don't conform to some relatively rigid standards of
behavior and appearance.  As a more concrete example perhaps: Men are
pretty free to eat what & when they want, with their weight varying
accordingly.  I've known many women who do the same - just eat what they
are comfortable with eating & are of whatever size is natural for them. 
But these women of any size above *sickeningly thin* can be called fat,
and are, regularly.  Several times I was within earshot when my
then-girlfriend was called fat - she was almost exactly my size & build,
and... well, I'm certainly not fat.  The insult-hurlers ranged from
strangers to family members.

Trying to come to some conclusion, here, I really want to make it clear
that the world is not yet equal (and if I hear anyone say anything about
white males being the most oppressed... I will have to scream!)  I would
really like to see the whole world be as safe for women as a rave can be.
There are many other positive & wonderful aspects of raving I strive to
bring into everyday life with me too, but this one is especially
important.  There are some inherent difference between genders, which need
to be worked at overcoming in the name of equality & fairness - this means
excercizing self control, when you're bigger & stronger (and when you're
not, for that matter :)

Okay, I'm almost done.  But I really want to add & expand on something I
said in my last post: RESPECT is a very, very important part of PLUR.  I
wanted to point out that without respect, there could be no peace love or
unity, and yet it is so often neglected.  It is to our credit, as a
(sub)culture, that we work towards this ideal - but we're not there yet.

I love you all, & implied in this is that I respect all of you as
individuals - including diverse views.  I hope this message says something
like what I want it to & isn't misunderstood... it's way past my bedtime,
so I hope I made sense... sweet dreams everyone!

: : J. David Lowe :: dlowe@best.com :: http://www.best.com/~dlowe/ : :
:"Time never started at all.  Chaos never died.  The Empire was never:
:  founded.  We are not now & never have been slaves to the past or  :
:       hostages to the future."         -Hakim Bey, /T.A.Z./        :

very clear...

"dirty word" in the rave scene.

it troubles me to see men groping women, and it troubles me to see women
using their "sexual power" over men, because all of these "power
relationships" in sexual matters just push us farther from a respectfully
sex-positive society.

OK..here's a little ditty about my experience at Ground Zero in relation to
the whole groping/sexual misunderstandings surrounding E.

While I was in line my friend spotted the incredibly hot brunette a little
further up in line and started pointing her out to me so we did the whole
<winky><winky> <smile><SMILE> <stare><stare> come here cutie..yeah you!
Game and coaxed them into stepping back two places in line to talk to us. 
We talked to them (Sara and Michelle) all the way throughout (sp??????) the
line and kind of split up once we got inside.  About a half-hour later we
bumped into them and Sara asked me to come sit down next to her.  The first
words out of her mouth were "My God, I am SOOOOO high off this E!"  I
thought to myself...great, what am I gonna do now?  I honestly didn't know
what she was trying to tell me, if anything at all.  So I decided to go get
some water for us while my big whopping stud of a friend (Shaun) talked to
them for a while.  I walked around a little bit (still completely sober)
and bought some water and one of those little glo stiks for my mouth (I was
tripping out on other peoples, so I figured I would be a part of tripping
out others!  :)  When I came back Sara saw the glo stik in my mouth and
just stared at it, then she just reached up, grabbed the back of my neck,
and kissed me!  She shoved her tongue down my throat and managed to wrestle
the glo stik out of my mouth and into hers!
At first I was amazed at her talent with her tongue, then I was appaled by
the fact that a complete stranger just kissed me in a way that I had only
been kissed by my most loved girlfriends!  It didn't take long for me to
say my goodbye's and make my dissapearance after that.

Not long after I was walking through the Robot Room, Dancing my skinny
little booty off when a girl with this incredibly cute braided pony tail
bounced past me and flashed a smile.  I started following her, just
tripping off this cure little bouncy wouncy pony tail in front of me! 
Oh...I had dropped by now and was feeling the E somethin' aweful!  I lost
track of her for a while and then I felt a pair of hands reach around my
back and tweak my nipples through my shirt!  Eeeek!  It's Sara again! 
Oh...no,...It's that cute little girl with the pony tail!  Ow...me nipples
are sore now!  then a few minutes later...this time she took aim for my
little boogeyin butt!  Which, I must say, took some talent to grab as I was
dancing so hard!  But she rightly managed to do so and properly offend me
in a small way.

Later that night I found a WONDERFUL woman by the name of Renee with which
I did end up going off to the chill room with and taking a right and proper
trip with...

The point of my story being, Men aren't the only ones that grab and fondle
at raves, it just seems like they are more easily offended by it.  Maybe
it's just a cheauvanistic male thing that is forcing me to post this...I
hope not....

Peace

	-Jason

>        Agression and rudeness are one thing -- they're just plain wrong,
>whether sexual or not.  But being politely appreciative, or making an 
honest
>mistake in misreading signals, I don't see this as "a power differential
>exercised over women" as Nancy puts it.  Just as plausible to complain
>about being put into a *non-sexual* role without one's consent or any
>means of recourse as to complain about being put in a *sexual* role!
>        Unless you really feel physically threatened, no one has power
>over you unless you give it to them.  Feeling uncomfortable is not the
>same thing.  Lots of guys feel uncomfortable when they are ignored by
>women.

well said, Starchild!

>        As long as we don't confuse "sexist" with "sexual," and we allow
>people the freedom to be sexual and still give them the respect that we
>give to the non-sexual, I think it will all work out eventually.

this point, too, i meant to imply in my last post but failed to make it
very clear...

i believe in sex-positivity, and think it's a shame that s*x is an un-PC,
"dirty word" in the rave scene.

it troubles me to see men groping women, and it troubles me to see women
using their "sexual power" over men, because all of these "power
relationships" in sexual matters just push us farther from a respectfully
sex-positive society.

AND...

Dave Bayer wrote:

"...if you act like a sexual being, you will be treated like one..."

which i think is something we all should think about for a little while.

love,

brian

OK..here's a little ditty about my experience at Ground Zero in relation to
the whole groping/sexual misunderstandings surrounding E.

While I was in line my friend spotted the incredibly hot brunette a little
further up in line and started pointing her out to me so we did the whole
<winky><winky> <smile><SMILE> <stare><stare> come here cutie..yeah you!
Game and coaxed them into stepping back two places in line to talk to us.
We talked to them (Sara and Michelle) all the way throughout (sp??????) the
line and kind of split up once we got inside.  About a half-hour later we
bumped into them and Sara asked me to come sit down next to her.  The first
words out of her mouth were "My God, I am SOOOOO high off this E!"  I
thought to myself...great, what am I gonna do now?  I honestly didn't know
what she was trying to tell me, if anything at all.  So I decided to go get
some water for us while my big whopping stud of a friend (Shaun) talked to
them for a while.  I walked around a little bit (still completely sober)
and bought some water and one of those little glo stiks for my mouth (I was
tripping out on other peoples, so I figured I would be a part of tripping
out others!  :)  When I came back Sara saw the glo stik in my mouth and
just stared at it, then she just reached up, grabbed the back of my neck,
and kissed me!  She shoved her tongue down my throat and managed to wrestle
the glo stik out of my mouth and into hers!
At first I was amazed at her talent with her tongue, then I was appaled by
the fact that a complete stranger just kissed me in a way that I had only
been kissed by my most loved girlfriends!  It didn't take long for me to
say my goodbye's and make my dissapearance after that.

Not long after I was walking through the Robot Room, Dancing my skinny
little booty off when a girl with this incredibly cute braided pony tail
bounced past me and flashed a smile.  I started following her, just
tripping off this cure little bouncy wouncy pony tail in front of me!
Oh...I had dropped by now and was feeling the E somethin' aweful!  I lost
track of her for a while and then I felt a pair of hands reach around my
back and tweak my nipples through my shirt!  Eeeek!  It's Sara again!
Oh...no,...It's that cute little girl with the pony tail!  Ow...me nipples
are sore now!  then a few minutes later...this time she took aim for my
little boogeyin butt!  Which, I must say, took some talent to grab as I was
dancing so hard!  But she rightly managed to do so and properly offend me
in a small way.

Later that night I found a WONDERFUL woman by the name of Renee with which
I did end up going off to the chill room with and taking a right and proper
trip with...

The point of my story being, Men aren't the only ones that grab and fondle
at raves, it just seems like they are more easily offended by it.  Maybe
it's just a cheauvanistic male thing that is forcing me to post this...I
hope not....

Peace

     -Jason

Well despite the fact that I got hundreds of dollors of stuff nicked
there; and despite the fact that nobody knows who I am  despite te fact
that I did the basement room and publlicised it like bitch on heat, the
215 party was a
complete success.  We had the most diverse crowd at an Sf rave that I have
seen in ages (even the hip-hop kids were there).  People played exellent
sets including Jonnah Sharp, Tracy (my favourite dj), Astrasl Matrix, a
blinding bit of live work by Chris-Cross and a quite simply
legendery set by Theatre-Blip.  Still can't get the hang of Ethan's music
but people seemed to be really into it.
But by far and away the best piece of news was that we raised $11,000 for
the campaign.
Thank you very much for all coming down and making it such a good party;
it just goes to show that there is no more unifying subject then the right
to smoke pot.
And don't forget to to vote for 215 on November 5th.
And don't forget to come to the next one in November which will be a
celebration of the proposition passing.

For ever encased in a cloud of KGB,
Tristan.

I would love to follow this discussion and answer all of these posts but, 
as I posted before, I have this really fucked-up work situation where I 
have to sneak email praying no-one will walk by and catch me.  <sucks>

In skimming,  I did see something about becoming a sex-postive society 
and no longer whining about sexuality.  Please don't confuse being 
treated respectfully with no longer being sexual!!  It's too bad that if 
women complain about being harassed, it somehow means they are not 
sexual.  I was simply trying to support a more respectful approach to 
people (arguing that the objectification in leering and grabbing is not 
flattering - something, thankfully, that does not seem to be too 
controversial here!)  It is the WAY it is done, the intention behind it.  
Not sex or male-female relations that are inherently bad (hey, I'm a 
Scorpio - you don't have to convince me sex is good!!!)

One other note: Dave said that being harassed walking down the street 
only bothers you if you "let" it.  I have tried for years to let it roll 
off of me.  But when I am alone on the street and I have to pass a group 
of frightening men who start leering and commenting, it is a scary and 
vulnerable feeling.  And people can violate you with their eyes and their 
words on you, just as with their hands.  

I would love to take the time to discuss whether or not men have more 
power than women in this society, whether there is sexism or not, what a 
more sex-positive society could possibly look like, how to achieve 
equality, etc., but there is a job for me to keep and a list to return to 
the topic of _raving_.

PEACE Y'ALL
(and special thanks to all the brothers out there
that showed such concern on this issue - I know it's
easy to feel attacked.  You all deserve - all of us deserve -
a great sexy one-night whirlwind chillroom affair!!)

N

so I'm skiing a few years ago and wipe out, landing on my *head* and my 
neck goes CRACK! and I can't really move the next day but I don't see a 
doctor because I don't have health insurance.  And then about once a year 
I do something and my back says NO and I can't really move the next day... 
and then it happens a little more often, and so finally I see a doctor who gives 
me drugs, and then I see a physical therapist who tells me I need to see 
a chiropractor because the accident knocked my spine out of alignment, but 
it's not covered by insurance so I don't go.

And then my back is hurting more and more, and I notice that the last few 
times after I've gone dancing I can't really move the next day.  So 
yesterday I finally DO see the chiropractor, and two doctors plus a 
massage therapist are leaning over me and asking, is there anything I do 
that really exacerbates it?

And I have visions of sweaty swirling nights of drugs and lights and 
people and going absolutely CRAZY on the dancefloor, and I tell them, 
well, I kinda like to go out dancing sometimes.  And the three of them 
start clucking at me and shaking their heads and they tell me

you can't dance anymore

if you want to get better
that is

but but but, I want to sputter at them, you don't understand - I'm a 
RAVER!  Dancing is what I DO!  It's what I live for!  It's like an 
addiction - the insane excitement, the anticipation, the incredible 
release in the dazed otherworld of raving.  I LOVE it you can't tell me to

just stop

That just doesn't make sense! There must be some kind of dancing that
would HELP your spine/back. You could always just lay on your back and
wiggle your arms and legs in the air. I had a boss who used to do that
at meetings because she had back problems. Who knows, you might just
start a new fad! Wouldn't it be cool to see a dance floor with
everyone laying on their backs wiggling their limbs? It would look
like sea urchins in the tide pools. I guess the music would have to be
oceanic/dolphin drum'n'bass. :)

Date: Thu, 17 Oct 1996 12:34:45 -0800
From: Pengo! (Blake Merriam) <blake@luna.tenetwork.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU
Cc: pengo@ten.net
Subject:  But I'm a Raver! -Reply
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

How many times have you heard those stories about sport athletes who
have some tragic accident, are told that they will never play again, but
triumph nevertheless and return to the field?

It's all about MIND OVER MATTER.

Now I'm not suggesting that you go right out and dance anyway. You are
likely to cause yourself more harm. But I'd look in to things like yoga, other
forms of therapy, simple exercises that can strengthen your back
muscles, ect. Build yourself back up to where you are able to safely
dance again!

I don't want to see you putting your self in a wheelchair, so please don't
be carless with your body. But there are many options still un-explored
so don't throw in the towel on your passion. 

-=Pengo=-


>>> Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU> 10/17/96 10:42am
>>>

so I'm skiing a few years ago and wipe out, landing on my *head* and my 
neck goes CRACK! and I can't really move the next day but I don't see a 
doctor because I don't have health insurance.  And then about once a
year  I do something and my back says NO and I can't really move the
next day...  and then it happens a little more often, and so finally I see a
doctor who gives  me drugs, and then I see a physical therapist who tells
me I need to see  a chiropractor because the accident knocked my spine
out of alignment, but  it's not covered by insurance so I don't go.

And then my back is hurting more and more, and I notice that the last few 
times after I've gone dancing I can't really move the next day.  So 
yesterday I finally DO see the chiropractor, and two doctors plus a 
massage therapist are leaning over me and asking, is there anything I do 
that really exacerbates it?

And I have visions of sweaty swirling nights of drugs and lights and 
people and going absolutely CRAZY on the dancefloor, and I tell them, 
well, I kinda like to go out dancing sometimes.  And the three of them  start
clucking at me and shaking their heads and they tell me

you can't dance anymore

if you want to get better that is

but but but, I want to sputter at them, you don't understand - I'm a 
RAVER!  Dancing is what I DO!  It's what I live for!  It's like an  addiction -
the insane excitement, the anticipation, the incredible  release in the
dazed otherworld of raving.  I LOVE it you can't tell me to

just stop

I am breaking the mold this weekend (in more ways than one) and going
to at LEAST one bigger, brightly-colored flyer party, and MAYBE even
TWO!  I'm sorry, but I simply cannot pass up seeing Dubtribe & Donald
Glaude tomorrow night at Common Ground.  I know, I know, I know.  No
vibe, right?  Well, this time I DON'T CARE!  With good music like that (aw,
come on: Donald is my boy from Sea-town!) I can manufacture my OWN
vibe!  Honestly, I will just lose my shit if I go to another TRANCE party.  I
know I've bitched about it before, and I LIKE trance...a LOT!  It's just that
I've heard SO much of it lately that I'm actually missing house!  EEK!  ME?! 
Missing cheezy house?

Then Saturday I'm either going to a private party in Berkely or GET DOWN
GET DOWN GET DOWN.  Steve Loria reduced me to speaker-licking once
in Portland, I want to see if he can do it again! :)

SO!  We'll see!  This is my big experiment...I haven't EVER attended one of
the flyered parties here in SF...even when I was here in May I went to
MADNESS, which was reletively small (hey, by the way, did anyone on
the list go to that party?  It was down by potrero hill...)

Ariel

right drumroll and or fresh ass sample, one cannnot help but groove right
down to the bone.  jungle will never die, it just keeps permeating in the
most unexpected places, i.e. kpfa radio? and a guy called gerald remix for
david bowie's  lateset effort?  go figure.........

> Date: Thu, 17 Oct 1996 11:42:11 -0700 (PDT)
> From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>

> 
> you can't dance anymore
> 
> if you want to get better
> that is

I don't know if this would apply to your situation or not, but...

After I injured my back recently (blame it on jungle!), I was faced
with two options: (1) stay at home, rest, get better (2) rave. (1) of
course was out of the question, so I tried to think of ways I could
dance and not make things worse.

Here are some suggestions: 

(1) Take a moment to think about the parts of your body that are
injured. Try to locate which muscles, joints, etc are causing you
problems. Identify other muscles that support or connect to these
trouble spots. So when you dance, you'll know which parts of your body
to keep perfectly still or supported, and which other parts can be
used to dance with.

simple example: if your legs hurt, move your arms
another example: if your neck hurts, use your hips to pivot your head
etc.

(2) Dance in half time. There's nothing written that you have to
bounce up and down uncontrollably to the beat [although sometimes it
can be uncontrollable ;)]. Groove slowly to something fast... if you
do it in half time, you'll still get a chance to move to the music,
but you won't be killing yourself in the process.

Also, slow movements might be good for resistance strengthening if
there are any weak muscles that are troubling you (can be the cause of
back problems).

Anyway, that's what I do when I'm having problems, and it seems to be
a good compromise.

Steve

	id AA845594312; Thu, 17 Oct 96 16:05:38 pst
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 96 16:05:38 pst
From: "Andy Wyszkowski" <awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com>
Message-Id: <9609178455.AA845594312@smtplink.acer.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, Jeff Croop <jeff@uai-mhs.utron.com>
Subject: I could keep quiet..RE: to re gangster evil scene (racist?)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     
     I think we agree, but I wanted to clarify some area from my 
     perspective.
     
     About gangsta ravers...
     
     Nobody is being cast out by anybody, but might I note:
     
     I just like the diversity of (in my opinion) a "good" rave.  I like to 
     see costumes, funky shit and people who look like a crowd of wierdos, 
     freaks and deviants (oh-my).  Sailor clothes, platforms, Birkenstocks, 
     Feather Boas, chucks, big smiles, goa freaks, tie dyes, people wearing 
     foil, sports jackets, hamstas, handmade jewlery, assorted TH garb, 
     batique prints, funky hats, pants big enough for three, embroidered 
     2nd hand dresses, Docs, plaid socks, day glo, and vinyl clad bondage 
     ninja turtle armor are all badass and they ALL belong because of the 
     smiles and openness of the people wearing them.
     
     Nothing is scarier than when I went to Eon and found...
     
     4000 people wearing the same black three stripe Addidas, baggie blues 
     and white shirts.  I'm sure it's comfortable, I'm sure it's great to 
     dance in, but massives look more and more like an army and less like a 
     party every time I go.  Some people were having a great time.  Props 
     to them, regardless of what they are wearing... But there's some 
     people who I am convinced were looking for a fight.  I don't consider 
     myself a very evil or wicked person, but somehow I managed to get 
     verbally/physically threatened or totally looked down at by people 
     several times.
     
     Sorry...
     
     As for giving gangsters a little credit, I went to high school in a 
     neighborhood where gangs had been around for generations, not the 
     bullshit COLORs wannabe 'cap in yo ass' bullshit I sometimes see at 
     parties (or on MTV, but I won't go there).  Gangs were for some, a 
     choice between living in fear and knowing somebody else was looking 
     out for you, not a bunch of bored kids with rich folks like a lot of 
     the people I see.
     
     I give EVERYBODY (except the guy who cut me off and then flicked a 
     cigarette into my open convertible this morning) respect because 
     that's all I ever wanted from anybody.  Sometimes I get it, sometimes 
     I don't.  When I don't get it from a group of people that are hanging 
     out dressed alike who threaten me or make me feel like I'm at THEIR 
     house, I write it off as territorial gangsta bullshit.  It has nothing 
     to do with social status, race or anything except for people who fuck 
     with me and make me feel like a stranger who has to watch their back.  
     I came to have fun, I paid just like you did... what the fuck?  Smile, 
     it's a party.
     
     Let it go...
     
     We're all beautiful people.
     
     And finally...
     
     Please don't start throwing race/racism labels around.  It looks like 
     you're trolling for something that I don't honestly think you're going 
     to find on this list (yes, I'm assuming but it keeps me sane).  
     There's not a lot of members of the Nazi party too into dancing to a 
     rippin set from Carl Cox, Cesar or Juan Atkins (FUCKIN Cesar & Juan @ 
     Space Children!!!!!!).  I should hope partyers/ravers are waaaay past 
     that, and I think it's an alarm you didn't need to set off.  Gangsters 
     and non gangsters come in all sizes shapes creeds and colors.  We're 
     talking about a mindset, nothing else.  I don't even mind people who 
     run with clubs or gangs, just leave any negative vibe or attitude at 
     the door.  That goes for everybody, I think it falls under being fair 
     and respecting everybody as if the slate was all around clean.
     
     Embrace misfit power!
     
     I love not knowing what I'm going to see when I open my eyes when I'm 
     dancing.  I don't want it to be people who all look the same, or 
     people making me feel intimidated or uncomfortable.
     
     +
     
     Peace:     I leave my spears and slings and fears at the door.  I come 
     to make friends and meet friends, and strive to find joy in all those 
     who are gathered here.
     
     Love:      If you smile at me, I will understand.  If you ask me, I 
     will try.  If you embrace me, I will hold you with my eyes closed in a 
     world where none of this can find us.  I open myself to you.  My 
     energy is your energy.
     
     Unity:     My past affiliations are nothing in the face of what WE 
     could do together.  I come with empty hands ready to create and an 
     open heart ready to understand.
     
     Respect:   I choose to be with you tonight, rather than my mother or 
     father or friends or those I labor with.  I know you have made a 
     similar decision.  And for this decision, you have already earned my 
     respect.
     
     AndyW

On Thu, 17 Oct 1996, Steve Simitzis wrote:




> (2) Dance in half time. There's nothing written that you have to
> bounce up and down uncontrollably to the beat [although sometimes it
> can be uncontrollable ;)]. Groove slowly to something fast... if you
> do it in half time, you'll still get a chance to move to the music,
> but you won't be killing yourself in the process.
> 
> Also, slow movements might be good for resistance strengthening if
> there are any weak muscles that are troubling you (can be the cause of
> back problems).

Hi!

 As many of you know (cause I whine a lot ;) I tore a tendon in my 
shoulder a while back and still went raving (and setting up H3's ambient 
arena amongst other theraputic activities). I found that my shoulder still 
felt better than expected after each party. Of course I was REALLY 
careful. I put my sore are/shoulder in a sling one night when I couldn't 
feel anything due to my pain killing cocktail =)

 I believe some movement is beter than none as long as you are careful 
not to aggravate the old injury (too much) or create new ones as your 
body tries to do what you ask it and tries to protect the injured area. I 
feel that if you immobalise (sp?) an area too long it will heal that way 
so that it will not want to move in the future. But it is certainly a 
question of balance and sensitivity to the unique structure and concerns 
of your body.

 BTW my shoulder still has some pain and weakness in certain directions 
but it is doing really well. I think I have the rave community here in 
the Bay Area to thank for a significant portion of my healing.



                      !!!!!THANK YOU EVERYONE!!!!!


                                 =)(=



Ran

                                 -=*=-
                                   ~

Subject: NRR: YLEM @ Open Studios - SF, 10/19 & 10/20
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 1996 17:56:00 -0700
X-Mailer:  Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.993.5
Encoding: 30 TEXT
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Seven members of the YLEM Artists Using Science & Technology group will
exhibit on October 19th and 20th, from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. at 3140 22nd
Street (at S. Van Ness), San Francisco.  The site's historic Victorian
church will be filled with the artists' works in futuristic technologies
and contemporary synthetic media.

The YLEM Artists participating are:
   ELEANOR KENT, a fabric artist using fractals and mathematical
progressions;
   PAT MARKOVICH, a sculptural painter now manipulating light and
shadow;
   MYRRH, the founder of YLEM and painter in translucent acrylics on
plexiglas;
   MIKE MOSHER showing computer figuration, prints and "social science"
paintings;
   KIT MONROE PRAVDA, who produces poetic computer photomontages;
   PATRICIA TAVENNER, award-winner cited in Albright's _Art in the San
Francisco Bay Area_;
   and MARY TEETOR, a needlework artist using tesselation patterns.

A part of that weekend's San Francisco Open Studios, their experimental
art
explores a diverse range of digital graphics, art-science
synchronicities,
sociopolitical imagery, fractals and tessalations, cosmology, light,
motion
and time.  There will be some demonstrations and presentations by the
artists as well.

For further information please contact Pat Markovich, (510) 655-5076.

Now that this Subject has had time to get my attention!


   I must say....  At FUSION, "Psycho Bitch & Miss Thing on six turn
tables" defonetly played my favorite set of all time.

   Right before they played I walked out side only to see my friend Wayne,
and his newly found friends smoking a doobie.. Of course I managed to find
a gap in there circle. When that tiny joint got to me, I sucked on that
thing for dayz with no luck at all. I just could not get a hit.        So I
wipped out my own fat sack of skunky doobie stuffagez and twisted up a
fatty. Needless to say. EVERYOne got stoned.
   While I was taking my last intended hit off my blunt, I felt my second
hit Oh <E> kick in..
   I am sitting there baked! My left hand is starting to fall asleep while
the bay door across from me is jerking around speraticaly. I look at the
people in our little circle and think.. "No time for conversation. I am so
F'in baked!!!  It iz time to DANCE!!!!
   I walk back in the warehouse at Pier 17. And the music sounded really
good.. Most of the time when the music gets this progressive, I will end up
walking towards the Dj to see who it iz. I get there and it ends up being
to girls. One really fat, and one really skinny, both totally cool and
having a great time.            I like, was all     Yea!!!  Wooooo!!!
   I did not once stop dancing through there whole set. It was like they
were playing everything that sounded good, one on top of the other for
three hours straight..

   For more reasons than this.....     I will never forget that ravE



Jeff

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench. Varied techno sub-genres, noise, spoken word, world
       music. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
   For a _search_ interface to the calendar, see the Late Train club
   section (http://www.latetrain.com/clubs/).
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

Date: Thu, 17 Oct 1996 21:51:00 -0700
From: Roy Feague <rfeague@starfishsoftware.com>
Subject: NRR: sexism (was: sexism at parties)
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
X-Mailer: Worldtalk (NetConnex V3.50c)/MIME
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Holy Cow!
 It's easy to see from the last few posts on this topic that it's fairly   
highly-charged and brings up a lot of feelings and personal baggage.

It can be really frustrating being a man in modern society.  This is not   
to say that it's not frustrating to be a woman, but I can relate to the   
frustrated tone of Dave's post.  I would like to put in a word on Nancy's   
behalf; I think she got vented at a bit, when her post wasn't really   
endorsing eyelash-batting or sexual double-standards.

That being said, if you're a Caucasian male in our society, you find   
yourself in the unfortunate position of belonging to the only group that   
can't point a finger at Caucasian males for past wrongs that are still   
lingering today.  Doesn't matter what group was wronged, it's your fault   
(so some say).  That can get burdensome.

It became clear sometime in the sixties-seventies that some changes were   
needed, and it was driven by the frustration women felt about being kept   
out of "men's roles".  That's been the steady context of gender dialog   
for quite a while, that things needed to change to correct wrongs against   
women.  Recently, there's been a men's movement that has surfaced, that   
has recognized that men are suffering today from a loss of masculine   
identity.

What's it about to be masculine?  It's not supposed to be about being   
strong and tough, that's old-school thick-headed jockspeak, right?  It's   
not about being successful in a career; now that women are right there   
alongside men in the workplace, it's no longer a "masculine" domain.  Is   
it about being the head of a household?  No, that's old school too, and   
really folks, how many of us grew up in a house where Dad was official   
family pants-wearer, but as a practical matter, mom ran the show?  I know   
I did.

The old roles have been thoroughly assaulted, denounced, condemned, but   
what has been offered as a new direction?

Modern men grew up with the idea that things were changing, and many grew   
up with a resolution not to be like all those brutish, oppressive men of   
the past (isn't that what we've learned our fathers were?).  But in   
trying to be different, to change, to listen to what women say they want,   
to try to chart a new course, we get laughed at as "sensitive new-age   
guys", mocked for retreating to the woods to beat on drums and try to   
re-evaluate what masculinity means, as some men's groups have done.  And   
sooner or later, a well-meaning guy gets _angry_, and lashes back at a   
society that sometimes seems to be saying that every way he turns, he is   
wrong, and offers little new guidance.

It's been a personal issue for me in the last couple of years that I've   
been trying to explore.  One thing is clear; one doesn't get very far   
asking others what one's identity ought to be.  At some point, you have   
to retreat from what the rest of the world has to say, and commune with   
one's self and other men to try to reshape masculinity, not in an   
obsequious way, but in a whole, strong, and healthy way.  I have a lot of   
respect for men who've formed men's groups to address these issues; I   
personally haven't joined one yet, but I'd like to look into it.  There's   
also some good literature on the topic that's appeared in the last   
decade, such as "Fire in the Belly" and "Iron John".

I'm also grateful for the many wonderful women I've met who've offered   
understanding and support instead of feeling that addressing men's issues   
somehow undermines women's issues.  I believe there is healing that needs   
to happen on both sides before we can come out a more whole society.

Thanks for taking the time to read this; it feels good to put these   
thoughts out there.  I'd be very interested to hear any and all thoughts   
back on this, publicly or privately.  I'd be especially curious to get   
some feedback from the men out there: can you relate to this?  Can anyone   
suggest other good books?

 -Roy

Hey y'all!

After 3 weeks of haggling with the owners, we finally got a space for a
jungle party.

What's up with these bar owner's anyway?

The owner said they heard about jungle a while ago, but always wondered
why it never got played out more. Then they give us TONS of shit with
gettiing ONE night. I'm finding more and more that the venue owners in
this town are whacked. 

Oh well, guess we'll just have to buy a few warehouses, have one of us
run for mayor, and set this town straight!  ;)

oh yeah...

Wed. Nov 6th, Hunab Ku has teamed up with the B.A.S.S. crew to bring an
all ages event to a nice sketchy part of North Beach. Puurrfect for
Jungle!

We'll be going from 9p - 3a.
tix are 5 bux

no alcohol will be served, so we encourage everyone to buy some
softdrinks and help pacify the management.  ;)

lineup, in no particular order:

Jason Mouse (Emocean Records, Boston Mass.)
UFO
Flux
Thad
Tomas

We'll be having free mix tapes for the first 30 people, plus promotional
giveaways from Island and Quango records, celebrating Alex Reece's US
debut.

We'll also be celebrating the anticipated passing of Prop 215. So fire
up your blunts and come on down!

We might be able to get this into a weekly, but things are conditional
with the management. Again, they're whacked, so who knows?

For more info, call the BASS crew's number:

415-332-5800 ext. 247


See you on the dance floor!


Jonas J.

Precedence: bulk

i first heard of 420 -- where else -- at Dead shows . . . here is the entry
in Skeleton Key, a Dictionary for Deadheads (by sometime raver Steve
Silberman of HotWired):

        Said to be police radio or civil statute code for a bowl of
marijuana "in progress."  Used as a justification to smoke pot at 4:20 in
the afternoon (or morning).  The term has become so widespread that hats
and bumperstickers have appeared in the parking lot reading, "It's 4:19 --
you're late!"


I've heard the story that 420 = the number of active ingredients in
cannabis, but this was just some urban myth ... i try to avoid the
california penal code or police lingo, but the 420 as the L.A./California
code seems to be the true origin.

At 4:20 a.m. at the Gateway 420 party, everyone else seemed to have
already, um, consumed their special party treat, but I had made sure that
my glass "object"  Rose's predecessor was well fed all evening, and my
distinctive cone-shaped party treat (thanks Ben) was still intact and much
enjoyed.

420 24-7

leftjab

My computer tells me that on Thu, 17 Oct 1996, Andy Wyszkowski shared (in 
part):

>      Peace:     I leave my spears and slings and fears at the door.  I come 
>      to make friends and meet friends, and strive to find joy in all those 
>      who are gathered here.
>      
>      Love:      If you smile at me, I will understand.  If you ask me, I 
>      will try.  If you embrace me, I will hold you with my eyes closed in a 
>      world where none of this can find us.  I open myself to you.  My 
>      energy is your energy.
>      
>      Unity:     My past affiliations are nothing in the face of what WE 
>      could do together.  I come with empty hands ready to create and an 
>      open heart ready to understand.
>      
>      Respect:   I choose to be with you tonight, rather than my mother or 
>      father or friends or those I labor with.  I know you have made a 
>      similar decision.  And for this decision, you have already earned my 
>      respect.

	Beautifully said, Andy.  As the Christmas carol says, it's been
said many times many ways, but it only becomes a cliche if we treat it
like one.  Keep it real!

plurally yours,
				<<< Starchild >>>

Precedence: bulk


You might also get into swinging those glowsticks on the end of a string 
(space permitting, of course).  I've seen many folks "grooving" in this 
manner and you don't have to really move the rest of your body much.  
plus it provides entertaining visuals for everyone.

(One glowstick memory to share) Remember at Burning Man how someone 
strung glowsticks up on some kites and took them up?  For those who 
weren't there, it was at night at the rave camp and I saw what looked 
like hovering fireflies in the sky - it was the most unusual spectacle.  
I was too far away to see the figures of the kites, all I saw was the 
faint glow.  That's when someone told me what it really was.  Ingenius!

love,
Amy

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

It is really important to build up your muscles. If your therapists have 
given you exercises to do, DO THEM. It will give support to the whole 
structure.
It is also important to work on your movement gradually- it is hard to 
restrain impulsive strenuous dancing. Watch out that you don't favor 
anything too much because you will build subconscious dependencies on 
certain ways of moving that could throw the rest of your body out of 
whack even more than it is now, grinding up other joints.
So- emphasis on time and self-restraint and you'll get there in a very 
good way.

Here's something for all you to think about.

Your in the forrest and you come up to a cliff with a log crossing to the
other side. Your traveling with a fox, rabbit and a bag of lettuce. You
need to get all three across, but can only take one at a time. You can't
leave the rabbit with the lettuce because it will eat the lettuce and you
can't leave the fox with the rabbit because the fox will eat the rabbit.

How do you do it?

Tim (knucklehead)

"Let me have silence always in the centre of the shouting, that is
essential. Let me have silence so that no pin may drop and not be
heard, and not a whisper. Escape us for all our spouting, nor the
needle scratching upon this gramophone of the circular cosmic spot.
Hear me, mark me, learn me, throw the mind's ear open. Shut up the
mind's eye, all will be music. What sculpture of sound cannot, what
cannot as a fluid token words, that nothing else cannot." 

						-Wyndham Lewis

Precedence: bulk

> 
> Here's something for all you to think about.
> 
> Your in the forrest and you come up to a cliff with a log crossing to the
> other side. Your traveling with a fox, rabbit and a bag of lettuce. You
> need to get all three across, but can only take one at a time. You can't
> leave the rabbit with the lettuce because it will eat the lettuce and you
> can't leave the fox with the rabbit because the fox will eat the rabbit.
> 
> How do you do it?
> 
> Tim (knucklehead)
> 

1. Bring the rabbit from side 1 to side 2.
2. Go back to side 1.
3. Bring the fox from side 1 to side 2.
4. Take the rabbit back to side 1, leaving the fox at side 2.
5. Bring the lettuce from side 1 to side 2, leaving the rabbit
at side 1.   
6. Go back to side 1, leaving the lettuce and the fox at side 2.
7. Bring the rabbit to side 2. 
8. Bring the lettuce, rabbit, and fox to F-8 and dance the
night away =)

Smiles,
     Chin

>(One glowstick memory to share) Remember at Burning Man how someone
>strung glowsticks up on some kites and took them up?  For those who
>weren't there, it was at night at the rave camp and I saw what looked
>like hovering fireflies in the sky - it was the most unusual spectacle.

>faint glow.  That's when someone told me what it really was.  Ingenius!

glosticks and putting the on a string with helium ballons. That was fun to
watch. The first time I saw them they were in the air and I thought a UFO
was coming.

Precedence: bulk


(1) using advanced tantric methods and shiatsu massage, induce an extreme
    state of relaxation in the rabbit and fox.

   (note) head of lettuce is already sufficiently relaxed.

(3) walk across log, juggling the trance-induced rabbit and fox and the
    head of lettuce.  you will only need to touch one of the three at any 
    given moment, although you may feel a sense of psychic one-ness with 
    all three during the crossing.

   (note) you will feel especially as one with the lettuce.

(5) to revive rabbit and fox, serve odwalla and bagels with accompanying
    goa soundtrack.

   (note) head of lettuce does not consume odwalla or bagels, but may
          vibrate satisfyingly to goa sounds.  consider hugging lettuce
          while sticking head in speaker.

=)
matthew.

| it's as much as _I_ can do to see real people, by this light!"       |

>Your in the forrest and you come up to a cliff with a log crossing to the
>other side. Your traveling with a fox, rabbit and a bag of lettuce. You
>need to get all three across, but can only take one at a time. You can't
>leave the rabbit with the lettuce because it will eat the lettuce and you
>can't leave the fox with the rabbit because the fox will eat the rabbit.
>
>How do you do it?

"Let me have silence always in the centre of the shouting, that is
essential. Let me have silence so that no pin may drop and not be
heard, and not a whisper. Escape us for all our spouting, nor the
needle scratching upon this gramophone of the circular cosmic spot.
Hear me, mark me, learn me, throw the mind's ear open. Shut up the
mind's eye, all will be music. What sculpture of sound cannot, what
cannot as a fluid token words, that nothing else cannot." 

						-Wyndham Lewis

Knucklehead wrote:
>Your in the forrest and you come up to a cliff with a log crossing to the
>other side. Your traveling with a fox, rabbit and a bag of lettuce. You
>need to get all three across, but can only take one at a time. You can't
>leave the rabbit with the lettuce because it will eat the lettuce and you
>can't leave the fox with the rabbit because the fox will eat the rabbit.
>
>How do you do it?
>
>Tim (knucklehead)

1)  Carry rabbit to side B
2)  Walk back to side A
3)  Take fox to side B
4)  Bring rabbit back to side A
5)  Take lettuce to side B
6)  walk back to side A
7)  Take rabbit to side B
8)  eat lettuce and watch fox devour rabbit with side A as a beautiful 
backdrop
9)  clean teeth with rabbit bones and throw fox over the cliff
10) Walk back to side A and find some new pets
11) go back to step 1

>>The New Priest
>>
>>    A new priest at his first mass was so nervous he could hardly
>>speak. After mass he asked the monsignor how he had done.  The
>>monsignor replied, "When I am worried about getting nervous on the
>>pulpit, I put a glass of vodka next to the water glass.  If I
>>start to get nervous, I take a sip."  So the next Sunday he took
>>the monsignor's advice.
>>
>>    At the beginning of the sermon, he got nervous and took a
>>drink. He proceeded to talk up a storm.  Upon return to his
>>office after mass, he found the following note on his door:
>>
>> 1. Sip the Vodka, don't gulp.
>> 2. There are 10 commandments, not 12.
>> 3. There are 12 disciples, not 10.
>> 4. Jesus was consecrated, not constipated.
>> 5. Jacob wagered his donkey, he did not bet his ass.
>> 6. We do not refer to Jesus Christ as the late J.C.
>> 7. The Father, Son, and Holy Ghost are not referred to as Daddy,
>>    Junior, and Spook.
>> 8. David slew Goliath, he did not kick the shit out of him.
>> 9. When David was hit by a rock and knocked off his donkey,
>>    don't say he was stoned off his ass.
>>10. We do not refer to the cross as the Big T!
>>11. When Jesus broke the bread at the Last Supper he said, "Take
>>    this and eat it, for it is my body", he did not say, "Eat
>>    me."
>>12. The Virgin Mary is not referred to as the, "Mary with the
>>    Cherry."
>>13. The recommended grace before a meal is not: "Rub-A-dub-dub,
>>    thanks for the grub, yeah God."
>>14. Next Sunday there will be a taffy-pulling contest at St.
>>    Peter's, not a peter-pulling contest at St. Taffy's.
>>
