	below is a story from the /chronicle/ that ran today.  officer
	haggett is the man that i and many of my friends witnessed
	betaing a friend of ours at a party raid.  her "crime" was
	that she was observing the officers beating other partygoers
	from a respectful distance and then taking photographs of
	the police officers actions.

	hagget has repetedly flaunted the law and violently violated
	citizens rights.  we waited two years for our turn at justice
	for his actions on new years 1994.  we thought we had some
	sembelance of justice recently, but the police power establishment
	has ruled against the citizens.  i urge you to take whatever action
	you think you can in this matter - letters to the police
	commisioner, board of supes, mayor willie brown and the media.
	how can we, as citizens, feel safe in san francisco if the systems
	that are here to protect us *and* the systems to watchdog
	them send us a clear message that we are not the priority,
	rather the systems themselves are.

	haggett's actions are patterned: violent outbursts against
	citizens and then completely lying in inquiry as to what caused
	his unwarranted actions.  i know this for *fact* because i
	observed one of these incidents first hand and his subsequent
	explanation of my friend "yelling and inciting the partygoers
	to riot" as a warrant for her beating, false imprisonment and
	mysterious disappearance of the film in her camera while
	in police impound.  i know what she was doing - standing and taking
	pictures, which is not illegal in the least.  in fact, it is
	within the law to observe police action without interfering.
	she was attacked for this, and it is reasonable for some of
	us who were there to assume that this attack was an effort to
	prevent those pictures from existing.

	there are plenty of good, valuable police officers out there
	who are doing their best to to serve and protect our citizens.
	those who are clearly out to commit violence and violate rights
	should be imprsoned, not employed at the taxpayers expense.

	most of us will not settle for anything less than his badge
	at this point.  please do what you can to help.  hopefully
	our leaders will be strong and advocate for us citizens, who,
	so far, have been ignored and taunted with false hopes,
	promises, and lies.  thank you for your time.

from  Friday, October 18, 1996 =B7 Page A1 =A9 1996 San Francisco Chronic=
le

http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/chronicle/article.cgi?file=3DMN65503.DTL&di=
rectory=3D/chronicle/archive/1996/10/18:



Cop's Suspension May Violate Rules

Susan Sward, Bill Wallace, Chronicle Staff Writers

     The San Francisco Police Commission's decision
     last week to allow Sergeant John Haggett to
     remain on the force after finding him guilty of four
     firing offenses appears to violate the department's
     own guidelines for disciplining officers convicted of
     misconduct.

     After finding the 38-year-old officer guilty of falsely
     arresting three people, using excessive force and
     filing a false report in connection with a 1995 New
     Year's Day police raid on an AIDS benefit, the
     five-member commission voted to suspend
     Haggett for six months.

     The commission and Police Chief Fred Lau said
     they decided not to fire Haggett because they
     did not want to impose the department's most
     severe penalty on him for an incident in which
     many other officers made mistakes.

     Lau did not return The Chronicle's call for
     comment, and John Keker, chairman of the
     commission, was out of town and could not be
     reached. Haggett's lawyer, James Lassart, also did
     not respond to a Chronicle request for comment.

     Department guidelines adopted by the
     commission in 1994 stress the need for
     ``progressive discipline.'' They call for an officer's
     disciplinary history to be used in evaluating an
     officer's current misconduct charge.

     Haggett has one of the most extensive misconduct
     records of any member of San Francisco's
     2,000-member force. In 14 years on the force, he
     has had two previous 90-day suspensions for
     excessive force, the maximum suspension at the
     time; has been named in six lawsuits with more than
     $70,000 in damages against the city so far; and he
     has been the target of dozens of complaints from
     citizens.

     Critics say the department's apparent failure to
     act according to its own guidelines shows it lacks
     the will to discipline rogue cops.

     ``An explanation is owed as to why the
     department's own disciplinary guidelines were
     abandoned in this case,'' said John Crew, an
     attorney with the American Civil Liberties Union
     who monitors the Police Department.

     Lawrence Sherman, chairman of the criminology
     department at the University of Maryland and an
     expert on police misconduct, said that while he
     does not know the details of Haggett's record, he
     has never encountered a case in which an officer
     with such a substantial prior disciplinary history was
     not dismissed from the department upon the next
     substantiated incident.

     ``I have looked at a lot of police departments,
     and I can't recall a case with that much prior
     discipline against an officer who was still on the
     force,'' Sherman said.

     Here are some of the major incidents in Haggett's
     career:

     -- James Tahsini was 19 years old when he
     encountered Haggett in May 1987. The officer
     approached him at midnight outside the Diamond
     Heights Safeway and asked to look in the duffel
     bag in which Tahsini was carrying two six-packs of
     beer. Tahsini says that when he told Haggett ``you
     have no reason to look in my bag,'' the officer
     ``grabbed me by my throat, slammed me against
     the hood of his car and started hitting me.''

     ``At first, I thought he was psychotic -- the way he
     slammed me against his car and hit me with his
     pistol and pointed it at my face,'' said Tahsini.
     Tahsini later testified that Haggett told him, ``I'm
     not in the mood for this s--.''

     The 150-pound Tahsini found himself lying on his
     back with his hands handcuffed underneath him. At
     that point, ``He (Haggett) stepped on my throat as
     if I was some sort of animal. It was just the way he
     was standing on me. You know when you see a
     movie where the hunter kills the wolf and steps on it
     to pose for the picture? It was sort of like that.''

     All charges against Tahsini, including resisting arrest
     and assaulting an officer, were subsequently
     dropped. Haggett earned a 90-day suspension in
     this case.

     At the end of the police commission hearing on
     the Tahsini case, then-Police Chief Frank Jordan
     called the allegations ``very serious'' and
     recommended that Haggett be suspended for 90
     days and fired if he engaged in another act of
     misconduct.

     Police Commission President Lou Giraudo was
     equally stern.

     ``Under no circumstances could I possibly sit here
     and believe that that which occurred in the
     parking lot . . . was reasonable behavior on your
     part,'' Giraudo said in imposing the suspension.
     ``We are saying 90 days because that's the
     maximum short of termination that this commission
     can do, to let you and your fellow officers know
     that we do consider it a most serious matter.''

     -- Later that year, Haggett appeared before the
     same commission and the same chief -- this time
     charged with smashing another teenager in the
     face with his walkie-talkie after the youth failed to
     sit down fast enough for him.

     According to police commission records, Haggett
     hit the teenager, Matthew O'Leary, at least twice
     with the heavy metal-and-plastic radio, breaking
     O'Leary's nose. During an investigation of the
     incident by the Office of Citizens Complaints,
     Haggett told investigator Araceli Matus that he
     did not know the department's general order
     governing the use of force on suspects. Haggett
     dismissed the departmental regulation as ``an
     opinion written by people that don't work in the
     street anymore.''

     In November 1988, the commission found Haggett
     guilty of using excessive force on O'Leary. But
     instead of firing him as Jordan had suggested four
     months earlier, the commission suspended
     Haggett for another 90 days.

     Police Commissioner Jose Medina, who was on the
     commission at the time Haggett received both
     suspensions, said the commission's hands were
     tied in those cases by the recommendation of the
     chief. The commission followed Jordan's
     recommendations by imposing the longest
     possible suspensions -- three months without pay.

     Medina said that even though Jordan had
     recommended that Haggett be fired for any
     further misconduct after the Tahsini case, Jordan
     did not ask that Haggett be terminated for
     beating O'Leary.

     ``He failed to follow his own recommendation,''
     Medina said of the former police chief. ``What he
     recommended was a suspension, and we
     imposed 90 days, the maximum that was allowable
     at the time.''

     Attempts to reach Jordan were unsuccessful.

     -- Court documents filed in connection with a
     police brutality lawsuit in 1989 showed that at that
     time Haggett had been named in 27 complaints
     ``which contain allegations that officer Haggett
     either falsely arrested a person or used excessive
     force in the course of the arrest.''

     The suit also indicated that Haggett had been
     named in 16 other complaints alleging conduct
     unbecoming an officer, neglect of duty or
     discourtesy toward citizens -- and 13 other
     complaints of various types of misconduct,
     including three that were still under investigation.

     -- In addition to the dozens of citizen complaints
     that have been filed against Haggett, he has also
     been named in six lawsuits that have cost city
     taxpayers more than $72,000 in jury awards and
     settlements.

     In a 1986 suit, Christopher Torres, an Ingleside
     District man, claimed he was dragged from his car
     and beaten by Haggett and other officers after he
     cruised through a stop sign on his way home. It
     later turned out that the officers had mistaken him
     for another man with a similar name who was
     wanted on a $160 warrant.

     During the incident, ``Haggett jumped me from
     behind and put a lock on my neck and grabbed
     my hair and threw me on the ground,'' Torres said
     during his testimony about the incident in Superior
     Court.

     ``I was screaming, telling my neighbors to stop
     him,'' Torres said. ``I yelled out that he was hurting
     me . . . (then) he choked me so tight I couldn't
     yell.''

     One of Torres' neighbors, Marie Louise Fernandez,
     confirmed Torres' story in her own sworn testimony.
     ``I remember thinking that he must have robbed a
     bank or murdered somebody because they
     (police) were not treating him as an ordinary
     citizen,'' Fernandez testified. ``He was being
     treated as a criminal.''

     Shortly after a Superior Court jury began hearing
     the testimony in Torres' case, the city settled his
     lawsuit for $35,000.

     -- FBI agents are conducting a federal civil rights
     investigation into Haggett's fatal shooting last year
     of parolee Edwin Sheehan, 40, who had a long
     string of convictions for drug abuse and one for
     armed robbery.

     Haggett shot Sheehan after the parolee drove
     into several vehicles in the Tenderloin while
     attempting to flee from police. Haggett said he
     thought Sheehan had a gun and made furtive
     movements. Investigators at the scene searched
     Sheehan's body and found he had been
     unarmed.

     Kenneth Quigley, an attorney for Sheehan's family,
     said at the time: ``All he did was run. He didn't fight
     them, and he didn't shoot them. All he did was try
     to get away.''

     As for Tahsini, putting his 1987 encounter with
     Haggett behind him has been a difficult ordeal, in
     part because lawyers keep seeking him out to
     testify in cases they have pending against the
     officer.

     ``I know a lot of cops who are good cops,'' said
     Tahsini, who collected a $35,000 jury award for his
     encounter with Haggett.

     ``There are a few bad apples who make it worse
     for everyone else (and put) a bad rap on the
     whole department,'' Tahsini said.

     ``With Haggett's record, once, twice, three times
     maybe you let it go. But when it's continuous, it's
     getting out of hand. Obviously something is
     wrong.''


-- =

"Let me have silence always in the centre of the shouting, that is
essential. Let me have silence so that no pin may drop and not be
heard, and not a whisper. Escape us for all our spouting, nor the
needle scratching upon this gramophone of the circular cosmic spot.
Hear me, mark me, learn me, throw the mind's ear open. Shut up the
mind's eye, all will be music. What sculpture of sound cannot, what
cannot as a fluid token words, that nothing else cannot." 

						-Wyndham Lewis

	id KAA17442; Fri, 18 Oct 1996 10:50:07 -0700 (PDT)

From: Steve Shah <sshah@cs.UCR.edu>

Subject: The Gabba Times Virus (humor)
To: socal-raves@ucsd.edu
Date: Fri, 18 Oct 1996 10:46:17 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL24]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Mozilla-Status: 0001

Dear all,

This message is extremely important.  This is no JOKE!  Really its
not.  It's completely true and you'd better read it and beleive it or
suffer the consequences. Honest, I wouldn't joke about something this
serious.  It is about a very highly intelligent virus that is being
spread worldwide called "Gabba Times".

Once you have read this message, please forward to fellow musos you
care about.  Thanks.

SUBJECT: [Very Important  !!! ]

There is a music virus that is being sent across the Internet. If you
receive an email message with the subject line "The Gabba Virus", DO
NOT read the message, DELETE it immediately, do not RESEND it and
immidiately backup your MIDI files, CD's (both Audio & ROM) and take
casts of all your precious vinyl.

Please read the messages below.  Some miscreant is sending email under
the title "The Gabba Virus" worldwide, if you get anything like this,
DON'T DOWN LOAD THE FILE! It has a virus that rewrites your hard
drive, obliterating all SMF, MID, RA, WAV, in fact *any* audio related
file, replacing them with a Gabba Mix version.

Not only that but if you store your CD's within the same room as your
harddrive the virus will emit a special magnetic field, which will
compress the data on your Audio CD's causing them to play back at
anything up to twice the normal bpm. Worse still, if your CD's have
not been mastered using a special 'Anti-Quantize Tampering' technique,
recently developed in the US to guard against such viruses, you will
find that the CD plays back to a viciousley quantised banging gabba
rhythm. Even jungle!! Or Enya!!  Remember, CD's contain only 1's and
0's. By altering the spacings between these it is quite a simple task
for the virus to alter the rhythm of a track.

Even vinyl is not safe. By downloading "The Gabba Virus" an electrical
pulse transmitted through the household mains will manifest itself in
the stylus of record deck causing irreversable damage to your
favourite platters, next time you put one on.

Unfortunately, most novice computer users will not realize what is
happening until it is far too late. Luckily, there is one sure means
of detecting what is now also known as the "Gabba Times" virus. It
always travels to new computers the same way in a text email message
with the subject line reading "The Gabba Virus". Avoiding infection is
easy once the file has been received simply by NOT READING IT! The act
of loading the file into the mail server's ASCII buffer causes the
"Gabba Times" mainline program to initialize and execute.

The program is highly intelligent- it will send copies of itself to
everyone whose email address is contained in a receive-mail file. It
can search all your HTML files for any reference to music or links to
music sites and transmit itself too all email addresses listed within
these files.  It will then proceed to trash all music of the unlucky
recipient.

The bottom line is: - if you receive a file with the subject line "The
Gabba Virus", delete it immediately! Do not read it!  Rest assured
that whoevers' name was on the "From" line was surely struck by the
virus and will die a horrible amphetamine/poppers overdose death.

Warn your friends and local sound system users of this newest threat
to the Music World! It could save them a lot of pain and anguish.
Could you pass this along to your global music mailing lists as well?

Oh, also if you receive a file called GABBAZIP300 be equally aware.
This is merely a ZIP file version of the virus, cleverlry and cunninly
renamed.

Please be careful and forward this mail to any muso you care about.

REPEAT: DO NOT DOWNLOAD ANY FILE NAMED GABBAZIP300 REGARDLESS OF THE
EXTENSION AND DO NOT READ ANY MAIL WITH THE SUBJECT "The Gabba Virus"

Oh and PS. Gabba fans - Beware the Ambient virus!! It's just like the
Gabba one but it will convert everything into an Orb stylee remix.

------------------------ End of forwarded message ---------------------

they have live music/djing.  definitely  one of the best restauraunts in the 
city, and a perfect place to relax and get some eats before going out...

Date: Sat, 19 Oct 1996 07:11:11 -0700 (PDT)
From: David Lowe <dlowe@best.com>
To: SF-Raver Family <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Frequency 8 review -> pre-sleep
Message-ID: <Pine.SGI.3.95.961019065002.10726A-100000@shellx.best.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----

I love it when a spur of the moment decision comes together & turns out to
be really fun.  I was kinda planning on taking it easy this weekend,
but... well, at 10:30 I suddenly got excited about the prospect of
*dancing*, so I trundled up to F8 & got me a ticket and ride up there with
some friendly folks.

I have no regrets, though I'm gonna be sore as hell tomorrow.  Only rarely
do we get to hear four flawless sets as I did last night.  I got there in
time for the last half-hour or so of Ethan's set.  Gorgeous.  Then DRC was
up - she never lets up!  Hard, hard, hard!  It was exactly what I was in
the mood for.  Mars, with his tuneful, melodic but very hard set, and
finally Mystr-E with a fantastic set.  The music was hard all night long,
which is normally a bit much for me... but it was just right last night.

The lighting & decorations were very minimal, which was not so great. 
I've always preferred a bit of actual light, so I could see what was going
on - and lots of pretty things to stare at.  But somehow, the giant
glowing pyramids & tons of blacklights were enough.  Barely.  That's
pretty much my only complaint, though. 

It's always a relief and a joy to rediscover the beauty of raving after a
bad rave experience (as I had last weekend.)  I did.  Hugs were plentiful,
smiles were even moreso, beautiful people were everywhere I looked... and
the music (clearly the number 1 priority of the night) was phenomenal.  I
spent quite a lot of time on the dance floor, particularily during DRCs
and Mystr-Es sets.  Yummy! 

There were a couple of really pleasant surprises for me, people-wise.
Ariel showed up, despite her intentions of going to a larger party and
*avoiding trance*.  Looked like you had a good time anyway, Ariel!
*smile*... and Shamini, it was really great to see on the dance floor,
finally!  Yippee!  There were of course many wonderful, friendly people
there (both familiar & unfamiliar) - too many to list, I'm afraid.  I do
have to thank Jay for giving me a lift home though!

So, that was my Friday.  How were you alls'?  What's up tonight for you
folks?  I'll be seeing some of you, I am sure.

'Till next time.... take care & have fun!  (quack quack!)

: : J. David Lowe :: dlowe@best.com :: http://www.best.com/~dlowe/ : :
:  "I will not play at tug o' war. / I'd rather play at hug o' war.  :
:   Where everyone hugs / Instead of tugs. / Where everyone giggles  :
:           And rolls on the rug, / Where everyone kisses,           :
:  And everyone grins, / And everyone cuddles, / And everyone wins." :
:                                -Shel Silverstein, "Hug 'O War"     :
 :: fingerprint: 1F E7 D3 24 04 18 72 67   CC E6 66 1B 79 79 CB 3A ::

Subject: DJ CD Player for sale $350
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Brand: Stanton Vestax
Model: Top Loading Dual Varispeed CD Player
Condition: Mint
Price: $350
Features: *joystick* cueing and pitch bend, +/- 8% pitch control with super long faders
Size: fits in 8x19" rack spaces.
Shipping: I will deliver to any SF bay area address

This is a first generation DJ CD player which I bought a few years ago
before I moved to Brazil. It never made it to Brazil and sat in a storage
space here in a rack unused until I came back a few months ago.

It handles two CDs with full transport/pitchbend/cueing on each side.
It sits *flat* and is about the size of a large dj mixer. It has 19"
rack-ears.

The technology is clearly first generation. It works but is not as accurate
at keeping a constant pitch as the newer DJ CD players. It has really cool
clear plastic space-bubble top loading CD transports and is much nicer
to control than those teeny weeny rackmount jobs of the modern era.

It does NOT have looping or cue memory features.

This is a fine unit for DJs who need to play CDs with beatmatching/varispeed
but not quite good enough for super accurate professional use.

This unit works as perfectly as it did when purchased since it was almost
never used. However, this is an "as-is" sale. Once you buy it, its yours.
No returns. No complaints. If you have cash in hand you can come over and
try it out if you want.

email:

sjlerner@netcom.com




From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Oct 20 14:22:17 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id OAA08597; Sun, 20 Oct 1996 14:22:17 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from cats.ucsc.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with SMTP id OAA08575; Sun, 20 Oct 1996 14:22:12 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from ese.UCSC.EDU by cats.ucsc.edu with SMTP
	id OAA06796; Sun, 20 Oct 1996 14:22:10 -0700
Received: by ese.UCSC.EDU (8.6.13/4.7) id OAA04343; Sun, 20 Oct 1996 14:22:08 -0700
Date: Sun, 20 Oct 1996 14:22:08 -0700 (PDT)
From: Randy C Cone <randream@cats.ucsc.edu>
Subject: Psychedelicatesen/Death of Acme (long)
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9610201317.A1138-0100000@ese.UCSC.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hi,

 I hope everyone can excuse my lack of cheerfulness here. The death of a 
location is never very inspiring.

 Dionysus Dreams was hired by the folks at Get Down to provide lighting. 
I was very excited at first as I have always heard good things about 
their parties. Came to find out that the folks using the name were not 
the original creators of Get Down. 

 At the VERY last minute it was decided that Get Down would be at Acme 
along with Psychedelicatesen (and Goa Gil!!). I was all stoked on being 
at what would essientially be a micro-massive.

 I get to Acme at 7pm and start setting up. The Acme event 
(Psychedelicatesen) was the most unorganised event I have ever worked on. 
At 10:00pm the stage on the main floor was still being disassembled, JK 
Sound had not arrived yet, the upstairs and the basement were still 
completely unready as was the dance floor for Get Down.

 Eventually word gets out that the police are outside. Eventually the 
police come inside (all doors were open to the building) demanding to know 
who is in charge. The cops hang out for a good 45 minutes and then the 
Fire Marshall shows up. In the meantime the individual who rents out Acme 
is taken away to jail for not identifying himself to an officer (refused 
to give his birthdate). The Fire Marshall walks through the building 
yelling out that the building is unsafe for human occupation and that 
everyone must leave. Then an officer walks through a minute later saying 
those with equipment can stay to pack up their equipment. 

 It is interesting to note that the promoter for Get Down shows up right 
after the Fire Marshall shuts us down (about 5 to 6 hours late!!!). 
However, despite the implication, I believe the fact that Acme tried to 
do this as an open art showing and had LOTS of people milling about and 
was obviously open for buisness is what drew police attention.

 I had heard that the lease for the current occupant at Acme was up in a 
day or two. This was probably meant to be the last party there anyway.

 Psychedelicatesen was okay (as an art show, I was at the opening the 
night before) but there was a lot promised on the flyer that didn't 
happen and would not have happened even if the next nights party had gone 
off. Also I had heard that the individual taken to jail by the police had 
done this double booking before (one party rents the building, can't fill 
all the floors and then another party gets rented the available space 
despite the wishes of the first promoter) which is kinda tacky I think.

 What did I learn? Trust my intuition (it had been screaming at me not to 
work with Get Down), the SF police department doesn't always mind being 
videotaped (someone got some GREAT footage that night!), to listen to the 
advice of my more experienced friends, Never EVER to work with Get Down 
again.


peace ya all,


Ran @ Dionysus Dreams


                             -=*=-
                               ~

Forwarded message:
From:	ishtaar@interport.net
To:	rockers@medisg.stanford.edu (rockers mailing list)
Date: 96-10-20 23:56:12 EDT


Hi, I would like to introduce myself, my names is Lisa, and I 
just relocated to Boston.  I spent this evening
at a gay bookstore for a book signing, and I noticed a severe lack of
literature for the bisexual  community.  Now the first thing that pops
into my mind is what would I want to read?  And the second question that
pops to mind is what would I write?  Now I have not completely answered my
own questions, but a spark of inspiration did happen.  I am quite sure
that I could not fill an entire book of ramblings of bisexual experience  
and I am sure that I would not want to read it, but, there
are many of you out there that have some things that you might be
interested in sharing.  Such as guidelines, experiences, questions, and
random tid bits.  I have decided to start an adventure of writing a book,
or more to the point compiling a book.  I may not get enough entries to
complete a book but I think this could be a lot of  fun trying.  What I am
asking of all of you is to send me information stories guidelines, hints
tips, questions, thoughts, and random tid bits. anything that you would
like to share with the known bisexuals, curious, and general populous.
Submissions can be anonymous, but I would like to know where you are
writing from.  Just so that someone reading this book does not think that
this is the Boston view on Bisexuality.  Please remeber that  this could
in fact be published, this entirely depends upon how many submissions I
receive, and if there is a company out there willing to print it.
Submissions can be one sentence or go on for as long as you feel
necessary.  If I end up with 100 coming out stories, I will edit  and
make a request submissions on other topics to even things out.  

I am also interested in what people would entitle the book.
The first thing that pops into my mind is "End the confusion: Bisexual
people speak out".  

Please pass this message on to your friends,
acquaintances, relatives, or anyone that you feel is interested in saying
something on their view of  bisexuality.  
I am currently in the process of moving, so I do not have a reliable snail
mail address,  but a PO Box is in the making, but for now, please respond
by e-mail, for this account will remain active.  

As I had stated before that submissions will remain anonymous, but I am
not sure of the laws regarding printed material,  I will be checking in to
that next week, so a way of contacting you may be necessary, if your
submission is to be printed.  Thanks for taking the time to read this
message and for passing it along to all interested parties.

Thanks again talk to you soon

Lisa

 My widfe Mary and I drove up to San Francisco today (Sunday) in large part 
to check out the Psychedelicatesen art show. When we got there, it was locked
up, and there was a sign in the window "Closed By The Police". Sheesh!

 As we were driving away, I speculated that maybe it was the exhibition of
blotter acid art that got them busted - I guess not.

 Does anyone who was there notice if they actually had any of Alex Grey's
or Paul Mavrides' art up on the walls? It seems to me that would have been 
too packed to entrust originals to errant elbows or hands.

that the promoters of Get Down knew that Terry Mullin, Steve Loria, and Mark
Farina would not be able to play at their party BEFORE the teasor flyer was
even released. This word comes straight from the very DJ's who will soon be
dealing with these cheeky promoters. Feel ripped off now? I suggest that no
one buy presale tickets UNLESS....1. It is being sold by an establishment
(i.e. Wicked, Housewares, BPM, etc.) or the event is being thrown by an
established promoter with a good reputation. Major props to Dionysus Dreams

                         -=*=-
                           ~


		    SCIENTISTS DISCOVER NEW ELEMENT!

  The heaviest element known to science was recently discovered by
  university physicists.  The element, tentatively named
  "Administratium", had no protons or electrons and thus has an atomic
  number of 0.  However, it does have one neutron, 15 assistant
  neutrons, 70 vice neutrons, and 161 assistant vice neutrons.  This
  gives it an atomic mass of 247.  These 247 particles are held together
  in the nucleus by a force that involves the continuous exchange of
  meson-like particles called morons.

  Since it has no electrons, Administratium is inert.  However, it can
  be detected chemically as it impedes every reaction it comes in
  contact with.  According to the discoverers, a minute amount of
  Administratium added to one reaction caused it to take over four days
  to complete.  Without the Administratium, the reaction occurred in
  less than one second.

  Administratium has a normal half-life of approximately three years, at
  which time it does not actually decay but instead undergoes a
  reorganization in which assistant neutrons, vice neutrons and
  assistant vice neutrons exchange places.  Studies seem to show the
  atomic number actually increasing after each reorganization.

  Research indicates that Administratium occurs naturally in the
  atmosphere.  It tends to concentrate in certain locations such as
  government agencies, large corporations and universities.  It can
  usually be found in the newest, best-appointed and best-maintained
  buildings.

  Scientists warn that Administratium is known to be toxic, and
  recommend plenty of fluids and bed rest after even low levels of
  exposure.

---End of forwarded mail from "Sean Castro Contra" <scastro@xsvr2.cup.hp.com>

--

According to the people who put on xntx the  main player was a guy
called Migel (probabbly wrong spelling).  They said that he had done this
sought of thing before: recieved booking money and pre-sale tickets, sold
the tickets, pocket the money and not shown up to do his room.  In short,
he ripped us (S.P.A.Z.) off the old fashioned way: he signed a contract
and then ran out on it profiting from the tickets and his hiring fee in
the process.  I personally know the people at ACME and can say that, apart
from stoner style organization, no wrong doing was done on their part.
In short, we were ripped by Miguel who, IN NO WAY WHAT-SO-EVER,
represented Get Down or anyother sound system or promoter.  He lied to us,
ripped us off and was the one who probably called the police on us and
then told them that he was calling from xcntrx! (an abvious complete lie
on his
part!).  If anyone knows this person tell him he is a wanted man by both
us and xcntx possie and that if he ever shows his face at one of my
parties he will be punished accordingly.  This guy is a complete scum-bag
and I heartily reccomend that no-one has anything to do with this
individual in the near future; in short, he's dodgy as fuck.
Tristan.
PS.  Despite the fact that I thought that Stacy and her boyfriend were
really nice good people, and the fact that DJ Dan played (i missed him
owing to the fact that I did not get there until 4.20) XCNTRX really
sucked as a party.  I don't think I have ever seen so many generic looking
people at an SF party ever.  Very dissapointing!

hello all-

tonight,  the monday night dinner will be at matt's house!  here's
directions to my house:

i'm at 16 loyola terrace in san francisco (loyola terrace is off fulton,
near the intersection of fulton and masonic).

i just realized that's its very difficult to to give directions to my
place without knowing where you're coming from, so, when you rsvp, i shall
give you directions.

it's a potluck dinner with everyone bringing something commensurate with
your cooking time/ability.  so far, we have a vegetarian lasagna (susan)
and a cool salad (diana greer).  i encourage anyone who plans to come to
post to the list what you're bringing so we don't get duplications.

the monday night dinners  have been going off for the past coupld weeks,
to anyone who hasn't been to one, come!!!!!!!!!

we shall eat at 8 pm, and i encourage people to get there at that time or
earlier if they can!  (my house is always open!)

e-mail me if you have any questions!  (mdpkl@best.com)

i look forward to seeing many of you!!!!

love-

matt

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Oct 21 10:44:01 1996

Date: Mon, 21 Oct 1996 10:26:42 -0700
From: Ariel Stallings <ASTALLINGS@gcwf.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject:  Ariel's Weekend Review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Ok, Ok, Ok...for those who saw me at F-8 on Saturday, yes I bit the bullet
and swallowed another night of trance.  *sigh*  Despite ALL my bitching I
had a great time (who knew those Marin kids could party so hard?) and
don't have any regrets.  ALTHOUGH: mark my words!  If Common Ground
had been less than a 2 hour drive away (who's idea was it to throw that
amazing party in Sac?) I would have been there in a second.

But, despite all my reservations, I went to F-8 and it *was* in fact
wonderful.  Mars was REALLY amazing...even though I'd been to parties
that he'd spun at before, I don't think I'd ever actually been AWARE that it
was him spinning and damn!  He really rips that shit up!  And he appears
to be damn into what he's doing, which gets me all the more riled up.  (I
swear, if I have to look up from dancing and see a dj doing the "this is my
job" half-assed head-bob over the turntables ONE MORE TIME I'm going to
go up to the tables and kick some ASS!  HONESTLY!  ;)

The space was really nice too...as exciting as a multi room party is, it's
really nice to have the dancing energy centered in one big room.  I
appreciated that a lot.  Chill rooms were nicely decorated.  Bathrooms
were quite nice (always an important part of the whole party
experience).  My biggest disappointment:  The lights turning on at..what
time was it?  5:30?  WAY WAY too early.  I mean, I KNOW there was
only 4 djs playing but it was so weird to get home and have it still be dark
out...did the promoters want to insure that we were all asleep by 7am or
something?

Anyway, all 'n' all a good time (even if it was trance...hee hee hee).  Hey
to all the folks I saw there...Steve, David, Dhiren, Libby, others who I for
some reason cannot remember their names...

Ariel

ps: for anyone who's interested, I didn't make it to Get Down Get Down
Get Down either...I heard they lost their space or something.  But the little
housE partE I went to in Berkeley was THA BOMB!  It was SO much fun
and, not that this is a forum for discussing drugs, but can I just say that
was the BEST e I have had since I moved down here?!  DAMN!  That,
combined with the fact that the music was progressive house (meaning
slower than trance) meant that I was dancing for over 5 hours
non-stop...slower music means I can get that "marathon runner" rhythm
going which I can't maintain to trance.  Ok, ok, ok: enough bitching about
trance.  :)  --Ariel

 Hallelujah!

Yes, the death of a location is usually a sad thing, but in this case, 
I'm celebrating. ACME was a death-trap, and should have been shut down 
years ago. It's also been a crutch for promoters who don't want to bother 
trying to find anyplace else, and have NO concern for the safety of their 
paying customers. Not to mention it always required a map point (which 
never seemed to be on-the-way to a MUNI rider like myself).

Sorry, folks got burned in the aftermath, but the risk of using ACME 
was obvious. (1) downtown, (2) constant use, (3) overcrowded, (4) totally 
unsafe. It was only a matter of time before it got shut down. I'm just 
glad it got busted before someone died there, because one of the two was 
bound to happen sooner or later.

good riddance ACME.
jmar!

|  D S G N E T C  |  JOHN-A MARTINKO, w. desk chief  martinko@netcom.com  |

WOW!  Cool party even if it ended a little early for me.  I had to sit in my
car for a little bit and relax before I drove home.  I still had a lot of
energy built up and wish I could have kept dancing for another hour or so at
least.

All the DJs had great sets but for some reason DRC sticks out in my mind.  
Maybe because there was that short pause in the music before she started.  She
has some killer records.  Definately a collection I wouldn't mind owning. 

Glad I got to see some familiar faces and glad I met quite a few new ones. It
was only Libby and I one the way up, but my car was full on the way home.
Pretty cool.  And your welcome David.  Anytime.

j 

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Oct 21 11:40:39 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id LAA17321; Mon, 21 Oct 1996 11:40:39 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from netcom17.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with SMTP id LAA17315; Mon, 21 Oct 1996 11:40:36 -0700 (PDT)
Received: (from simitzis@localhost) by netcom17.netcom.com (8.6.13/Netcom)
	id LAA09630; Mon, 21 Oct 1996 11:40:35 -0700
Date: Mon, 21 Oct 1996 11:40:35 -0700
From: simitzis@netcom.com (Steve Simitzis)
Message-Id: <199610211840.LAA09630@netcom17.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: another great weekend (F-8 and more!)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


It no longer makes sense to do "party reviews". For me, the weekend is
just one long event, broken up by periods of sleeping (or not!) and
transitions from place to place. And before I go any further, I just
wanted to say that I have the *best* weekends!

The weekend started off with a trip to Raw (one of my favorite grazing
places) to hear Tom spin some Goa. I met up with some other friends
quite randomly (apparently they had gone for the same reason) and
enjoyed a healthy dinner to some great music. Too bad the food there
is so damned expensive; I would be there every night otherwise.

I had been wanting to go to a Frequency-8 party for some time, and I'm
really happy that this one happened. The space (a recording studio in
San Rafel) was very cool. The first thing that I noticed was that it
was completely sound-proofed! 

I personally enjoyed the decorations and the lighting. It was, true,
minimal; however, there was enough light to see everything, and there
were just enough black-lights to make everything glow. Really, though,
the F-8 party wasn't about the visuals, it was about the *music*.
(The red light in the chill/smoking room was a bit too agro for my
taste. A nice blue light might have been better... details, details :)

Although I only caught the tail end of Ethan's set, it set the stage
very nicely for the Frequency-8 sound. DRC spun some excellent music
during her set (despite the fact that it began with her wrestling with
an unruly DAT player); really hard dance music, at times with a german
industrial flavor. Mars spun the best set that I had ever heard from
him (w0w!), and Mystr-E pumped up the crowd and then brought them back
down at the end with a phenomenal choice of music.

Mars and Mystr-E seemed to be the most comfortable I had ever heard
them spin, quite possibly because it was *their* party. As a result, I
spent somewhat little time socializing... the music was just too good
all night. Even though it ended early (5:30), I had no regrets. Any
longer, and it would have dragged out a good thing. Okay, I was a bit
miffed that I didn't get to see the sunrise as I drove back over the
Golden Gate bridge... :) but oh well!

Saturday was spent at a house party in Berkeley, hosted by Brian and
Susan... hey, thank you *so* much for the party on Saturday!!!
I had a woooooonderful time :) :) :)

Tom spun some more Goa (Tom needs to spin out more; he's probably SF's
best kept secret... can't wait for 2012!), followed by Jon Logan
spinning ambient for the rest of the night. Jon spun an incredible
assortment of tracks; ambient, IDM, trip-hop. But, Jon, where was the
BK crown? ;)

I *almost* went to the Pacific boat party, but bailed out at the very
last minute (like, at the docks). Which was fine. Instead, I went home
(imagine that!) and went to bed at 11. Besides, it would have been
hard to top the incredible night that I had at Brian's party, so I
enjoyed staying at home, relaxing and reflecting...

well rested,
Steve

--

having only been there once, and also sensing the fear in peoples post
after every party that was held there over the past year or so...(how many
times have we seen this sentiment on sfraves?-->"if there was a fire or
other emergency I would fear for the lives of my friends and myself" I can
only say that it seems like a good thing...I know it sucks to lose a place
for our parties, but obviously we need to use safe spots to avoid ruining
our scene...food for thought, what would happen to the scene if there were
a major tragedy? is the media on our side? 
	
     On a brighter note...happy monday!!!!!!smile everyone!! ;-0 ;-() ;-)

From: "Andy Wyszkowski" <awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com>
Message-Id: <9609218459.AA845918063@smtplink.acer.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Sorta F8 Review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     
     Location > San Rafael
     Missed Ethan & DRC (DOH!)
     
     (+)
     Generally spiffy location, GREAT people, smiling faces, dark and 
     simple looking without 'evil' overtones, hard trance!!!, KGB, the way 
     the dance floor felt (little slippy but not too much so)
     
     (-)
     Smoky chill space with screwy Lower Hades lighting scheme {my eyes 
     were red enough ;) }, oppressive smoking policy, nothing but hard 
     trance, had to take it Easy because of new job this week, Anne got a 
     speeding ticket on the GG.
     
     Overall had a really good time that somewhat expanded my idea of what 
     a good party could be.  Different is good.  Too bad the music wasn't 
     more varied (I'm pretty sure DRC would have taken care of that aspect 
     actually - I really like her style).
     
     It wasn't the DJ's, or the people, or the herbs and spices, or the 
     vibe.
     
     David Lowe's monkey made the party for me.
     
     Some might ask "Andy, you seem like your life is somewhat full (an 
     illusion I've been working on since childhood).  How could you be so 
     needy as to find pleasure in platonic contact with a toy monkey?"
     
     And to you I say... "You don't know this monkey".
     
     It's funny that almost every rave I go to, I get there, and I'm not 
     quite there.  I spend some time kicking back, or dancing until IT 
     comes over me.  Usually something is affiliated with IT.  Sometimes 
     it's a song, or a smile, or something I ate.  I can understand that.

From: Cami Edwards <cami@netcom.com>

Subject: Mark Farina on the Boat
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Precedence: bulk


I just had to post a review of Sunset's last boat party of the year.  I 
really contemplated not going, because the last two I have been to seemed 
to lack the usual boat party energy.  Not so last night.  

The one bummer about it was that we started out kind of late.  We were at 
the dock for one of the most beautiful sunsets; had we left on time, we 
would have had a pretty full view of it.  Not that the party didn't start 
while we were waiting to leave.  It was going off way before we left 
port.  Solar was spinning a high energy, funky ass set almost immediately.  

The group of people and the energy on the boat was amazing.  It sold out 
(as opposed to the last 2 that didn't) and was a perfect size crowd.  
Everyone was smiling and chatting and grooving.  I didn't run into one 
attitude the whole time.  

Mark Farina had people wooping it up with smiles all around.  He played 
his usual technically awesome, soulful, phunky house set.  I love hearing 
Mark spin because he not only helps you get a groove on, but he brings so 
much positivity to his music.  He must be a really happy, cool person. 

I am sorry that I didn't get to meet any new sfravers, but I saw some I 
already knew and met some really cool non-sfravers (hey maybe they were and 
it just didn't come up).  

Looking forward to next weekend's last Sunset of the year at a new location:)

Cheers***
Cami

On Mon, 21 Oct 1996, Adam Guevara wrote:

> Hmm... this post echos some minor fellings about burning man for me... 
> (however, despite the death of one and the crtical injuring of one of
> ours, I believe BM will still contenue...)

Although I agree Bman is dangerous (i spent a rather sleepless night 
friday as cars whizzed within 25 feet of my tent), i think it's a 
different story. Burning Man *is* about survival. The desert's a rough 
place. That's made clear up front. Safety is a personal responsibility.

Of course that doesn't take into account the cars. That was a problem not 
created by the promoters or the location, but by the attendees. I was 
dissapointed to discover that most of the offending vehicles were driven 
by people from the rave crowd instead of the regular bman crowd. The tent 
accident was a tragedy, but we (the attendees as a whole) can only blame 
ourselves for it. The lack of respect and responsibility that caused the 
dangerous driving is something only we (again, the attendees) can remedy, 
not the promoters. Hopefully, Omar will not have to pay the price for all 
of us.

As unfortunate as it was, the motorcycle death Tuesday night was just 
naked stupidity. Drunk + motorcycle + no lights = death. period. He made 
a choice, and sadly, took the consequences. It was an empty and selfish 
act that could very well be the final blow to the event he and the other 
artists tried to create.

Though I have no direct source anymore, I have heard of changes the 
promoters are considering (as opposed to ACME) to minimize the effects of 
our stupidity, including: some sort of shuttle between the camps, more 
clearly defined roads, pre-sale tickets only, &c. This is of course 
assuming there *will* be another.

At ACME, I have seen *no* effort to remedy a dangerous situation, caused, 
not by the attendees, but by the space itself and the constant 
overselling of tickets. If the ex-tenants of ACME or any promoters who've 
used the space are here, I'd like to know something.

Just what was your plan in case there was an emergency? 
Did you even have one?

Hell, even Kommotion made some changes to make their space safer. 

jmar.

On Mon, 21 Oct 1996 Jondabomb@aol.com wrote:

> God knows how promoters have so many available locations, and they use ACME
> becuase it just has so many fond memories. I think your statemant was a
> little narrow minded. I really dont think people used the ACME cause they are
> to lazy to find a better location, but because there are no other
> locations (or they have yet to be found)!
            ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

Interestingly, though you disagree with me, your last seven words made my 
point exactly. I do not accept that there aren't other spaces. There are. 
It's just that the mindset and lack of responsibility that is evident in 
throwing parties at ACME is keeping us out of them. Owners of property 
are ultimately responsible for accidents and complaints. Why would 
they put themselves at (a very real) risk of fines and lawsuits and 
property damage just to make a few dollars. Answer: they won't. 

Yes there is more to promoting than just finding a space. It's called 
taking responsibility and promoting (here's that word again...) 
sustainability. And yes, as has been seen, those are easier said than 
done as well.

This isn't an attack on anyone in particular. Just an observation. 
Parties used to be all over the place. Seemed like everyone was 
advertising "virgin warehouse space, blah, blah." Then about three years 
ago, most parties began to consolidate into a few spots, used repeatedly. 
Now these places are closed off to us, largely due (in my opinion) to 
irresponsible over-use and over-crowding. That's the real reason why 
"there aren't any other spaces." Promoters have been shooting themselves 
in the foot with their actions. So now ACME's gone. What'll be the next 
place to get burnt? Bets anyone?


jmar.

hehe, oops! I sent this to the nw-raves list!  heh

uhm...

====================
I read some of the noise about the Acme location, and I didn't make it to
this party so I don't have anything to say about it, but I did want to say
that with the _vast_ resources I see here in the bay area, we should
definately be able to have new spaces often.  I recently moved here from the
Seattle scene, and we had pretty good luck with spaces.  As a promoter you
have to CALL call call, talk to everyone that might have resources.
Sometimes if you have to deal with permits, it can slow you down pretty fast
-  but still this is a big area, and I don't know about you guys, but I've
driven my _ass off_ over the hills and through the woods even to get to a
good rave.  In Seattle it got to a point where you could put 'in a virgin
warehouse' or 'new space!' on your flyer or by word of mouth and it was just
the shit before you even saw it... there is something about a fresh space.
oops, I delurked.

Max
====================

peace!

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

	warnings and previous punnishments.

	below is a story from the /chronicle/ that ran today.  officer
	haggett is the man that i and many of my friends witnessed
	betaing a friend of ours at a party raid.  her "crime" was
	that she was observing the officers beating other partygoers
	from a respectful distance and then taking photographs of
	the police officers actions.

	hagget has repetedly flaunted the law and violently violated
	citizens rights.  we waited two years for our turn at justice
	for his actions on new years 1994.  we thought we had some
	sembelance of justice recently, but the police power establishment
	has ruled against the citizens.  i urge you to take whatever action
	you think you can in this matter - letters to the police
	commisioner, board of supes, mayor willie brown and the media.
	how can we, as citizens, feel safe in san francisco if the systems
	that are here to protect us *and* the systems to watchdog
	them send us a clear message that we are not the priority,
	rather the systems themselves are.

	haggett's actions are patterned: violent outbursts against
	citizens and then completely lying in inquiry as to what caused
	his unwarranted actions.  i know this for *fact* because i
	observed one of these incidents first hand and his subsequent
	explanation of my friend "yelling and inciting the partygoers
	to riot" as a warrant for her beating, false imprisonment and
	mysterious disappearance of the film in her camera while
	in police impound.  i know what she was doing - standing and taking
	pictures, which is not illegal in the least.  in fact, it is
	within the law to observe police action without interfering.
	she was attacked for this, and it is reasonable for some of
	us who were there to assume that this attack was an effort to
	prevent those pictures from existing.

	there are plenty of good, valuable police officers out there
	who are doing their best to to serve and protect our citizens.
	those who are clearly out to commit violence and violate rights
	should be imprsoned, not employed at the taxpayers expense.

	most of us will not settle for anything less than his badge
	at this point.  please do what you can to help.  hopefully
	our leaders will be strong and advocate for us citizens, who,
	so far, have been ignored and taunted with false hopes,
	promises, and lies.  thank you for your time.

from  Friday, October 18, 1996  Page A1  1996 San Francisco Chronicle

http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/chronicle/article.cgi?file=MN65503.DTL&directory=/chronicle/archive/1996/10/18:



Cop's Suspension May Violate Rules

Susan Sward, Bill Wallace, Chronicle Staff Writers

     The San Francisco Police Commission's decision
     last week to allow Sergeant John Haggett to
     remain on the force after finding him guilty of four
     firing offenses appears to violate the department's
     own guidelines for disciplining officers convicted of
     misconduct.

     After finding the 38-year-old officer guilty of falsely
     arresting three people, using excessive force and
     filing a false report in connection with a 1995 New
     Year's Day police raid on an AIDS benefit, the
     five-member commission voted to suspend
     Haggett for six months.

     The commission and Police Chief Fred Lau said
     they decided not to fire Haggett because they
     did not want to impose the department's most
     severe penalty on him for an incident in which
     many other officers made mistakes.

     Lau did not return The Chronicle's call for
     comment, and John Keker, chairman of the
     commission, was out of town and could not be
     reached. Haggett's lawyer, James Lassart, also did
     not respond to a Chronicle request for comment.

     Department guidelines adopted by the
     commission in 1994 stress the need for
     ``progressive discipline.'' They call for an officer's
     disciplinary history to be used in evaluating an
     officer's current misconduct charge.

     Haggett has one of the most extensive misconduct
     records of any member of San Francisco's
     2,000-member force. In 14 years on the force, he
     has had two previous 90-day suspensions for
     excessive force, the maximum suspension at the
     time; has been named in six lawsuits with more than
     $70,000 in damages against the city so far; and he
     has been the target of dozens of complaints from
     citizens.

     Critics say the department's apparent failure to
     act according to its own guidelines shows it lacks
     the will to discipline rogue cops.

     ``An explanation is owed as to why the
     department's own disciplinary guidelines were
     abandoned in this case,'' said John Crew, an
     attorney with the American Civil Liberties Union
     who monitors the Police Department.

     Lawrence Sherman, chairman of the criminology
     department at the University of Maryland and an
     expert on police misconduct, said that while he
     does not know the details of Haggett's record, he
     has never encountered a case in which an officer
     with such a substantial prior disciplinary history was
     not dismissed from the department upon the next
     substantiated incident.

     ``I have looked at a lot of police departments,
     and I can't recall a case with that much prior
     discipline against an officer who was still on the
     force,'' Sherman said.

     Here are some of the major incidents in Haggett's
     career:

     -- James Tahsini was 19 years old when he
     encountered Haggett in May 1987. The officer
     approached him at midnight outside the Diamond
     Heights Safeway and asked to look in the duffel
     bag in which Tahsini was carrying two six-packs of
     beer. Tahsini says that when he told Haggett ``you
     have no reason to look in my bag,'' the officer
     ``grabbed me by my throat, slammed me against
     the hood of his car and started hitting me.''

     ``At first, I thought he was psychotic -- the way he
     slammed me against his car and hit me with his
     pistol and pointed it at my face,'' said Tahsini.
     Tahsini later testified that Haggett told him, ``I'm
     not in the mood for this s--.''

     The 150-pound Tahsini found himself lying on his
     back with his hands handcuffed underneath him. At
     that point, ``He (Haggett) stepped on my throat as
     if I was some sort of animal. It was just the way he
     was standing on me. You know when you see a
     movie where the hunter kills the wolf and steps on it
     to pose for the picture? It was sort of like that.''

     All charges against Tahsini, including resisting arrest
     and assaulting an officer, were subsequently
     dropped. Haggett earned a 90-day suspension in
     this case.

     At the end of the police commission hearing on
     the Tahsini case, then-Police Chief Frank Jordan
     called the allegations ``very serious'' and
     recommended that Haggett be suspended for 90
     days and fired if he engaged in another act of
     misconduct.

     Police Commission President Lou Giraudo was
     equally stern.

     ``Under no circumstances could I possibly sit here
     and believe that that which occurred in the
     parking lot . . . was reasonable behavior on your
     part,'' Giraudo said in imposing the suspension.
     ``We are saying 90 days because that's the
     maximum short of termination that this commission
     can do, to let you and your fellow officers know
     that we do consider it a most serious matter.''

     -- Later that year, Haggett appeared before the
     same commission and the same chief -- this time
     charged with smashing another teenager in the
     face with his walkie-talkie after the youth failed to
     sit down fast enough for him.

     According to police commission records, Haggett
     hit the teenager, Matthew O'Leary, at least twice
     with the heavy metal-and-plastic radio, breaking
     O'Leary's nose. During an investigation of the
     incident by the Office of Citizens Complaints,
     Haggett told investigator Araceli Matus that he
     did not know the department's general order
     governing the use of force on suspects. Haggett
     dismissed the departmental regulation as ``an
     opinion written by people that don't work in the
     street anymore.''

     In November 1988, the commission found Haggett
     guilty of using excessive force on O'Leary. But
     instead of firing him as Jordan had suggested four
     months earlier, the commission suspended
     Haggett for another 90 days.

     Police Commissioner Jose Medina, who was on the
     commission at the time Haggett received both
     suspensions, said the commission's hands were
     tied in those cases by the recommendation of the
     chief. The commission followed Jordan's
     recommendations by imposing the longest
     possible suspensions -- three months without pay.

     Medina said that even though Jordan had
     recommended that Haggett be fired for any
     further misconduct after the Tahsini case, Jordan
     did not ask that Haggett be terminated for
     beating O'Leary.

     ``He failed to follow his own recommendation,''
     Medina said of the former police chief. ``What he
     recommended was a suspension, and we
     imposed 90 days, the maximum that was allowable
     at the time.''

     Attempts to reach Jordan were unsuccessful.

     -- Court documents filed in connection with a
     police brutality lawsuit in 1989 showed that at that
     time Haggett had been named in 27 complaints
     ``which contain allegations that officer Haggett
     either falsely arrested a person or used excessive
     force in the course of the arrest.''

     The suit also indicated that Haggett had been
     named in 16 other complaints alleging conduct
     unbecoming an officer, neglect of duty or
     discourtesy toward citizens -- and 13 other
     complaints of various types of misconduct,
     including three that were still under investigation.

     -- In addition to the dozens of citizen complaints
     that have been filed against Haggett, he has also
     been named in six lawsuits that have cost city
     taxpayers more than $72,000 in jury awards and
     settlements.

     In a 1986 suit, Christopher Torres, an Ingleside
     District man, claimed he was dragged from his car
     and beaten by Haggett and other officers after he
     cruised through a stop sign on his way home. It
     later turned out that the officers had mistaken him
     for another man with a similar name who was
     wanted on a $160 warrant.

     During the incident, ``Haggett jumped me from
     behind and put a lock on my neck and grabbed
     my hair and threw me on the ground,'' Torres said
     during his testimony about the incident in Superior
     Court.

     ``I was screaming, telling my neighbors to stop
     him,'' Torres said. ``I yelled out that he was hurting
     me . . . (then) he choked me so tight I couldn't
     yell.''

     One of Torres' neighbors, Marie Louise Fernandez,
     confirmed Torres' story in her own sworn testimony.
     ``I remember thinking that he must have robbed a
     bank or murdered somebody because they
     (police) were not treating him as an ordinary
     citizen,'' Fernandez testified. ``He was being
     treated as a criminal.''

     Shortly after a Superior Court jury began hearing
     the testimony in Torres' case, the city settled his
     lawsuit for $35,000.

     -- FBI agents are conducting a federal civil rights
     investigation into Haggett's fatal shooting last year
     of parolee Edwin Sheehan, 40, who had a long
     string of convictions for drug abuse and one for
     armed robbery.

     Haggett shot Sheehan after the parolee drove
     into several vehicles in the Tenderloin while
     attempting to flee from police. Haggett said he
     thought Sheehan had a gun and made furtive
     movements. Investigators at the scene searched
     Sheehan's body and found he had been
     unarmed.

     Kenneth Quigley, an attorney for Sheehan's family,
     said at the time: ``All he did was run. He didn't fight
     them, and he didn't shoot them. All he did was try
     to get away.''

     As for Tahsini, putting his 1987 encounter with
     Haggett behind him has been a difficult ordeal, in
     part because lawyers keep seeking him out to
     testify in cases they have pending against the
     officer.

     ``I know a lot of cops who are good cops,'' said
     Tahsini, who collected a $35,000 jury award for his
     encounter with Haggett.

     ``There are a few bad apples who make it worse
     for everyone else (and put) a bad rap on the
     whole department,'' Tahsini said.

     ``With Haggett's record, once, twice, three times
     maybe you let it go. But when it's continuous, it's
     getting out of hand. Obviously something is
     wrong.''



--

From: Rebecca Klassen <rdk4@axe.humboldt.edu>
Subject: some more f-8 if you feel like hearing it
To: beat and ravish eaters <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-id: <Pine.PMDF.3.91.961021152454.26325A-100000@axe.humboldt.edu>

Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Ok maybe everyone's getting sick of reading reviews for the same party. 
However, I am -VERY EXCITED-  because this was my first city party in two 
months and i just wanted to share that excitement with you all.

The vibe was great the music was great it was all damn great.
I loved the circle pictures in the red room and the one of the gears in 
the entrance hallway. Red was a good offset to the blue of the main room. 
i also -loved- the circle laser thing where the water was. It was 
probably the simplest, most repetitive laser pattern ever but it was so 
neat and trippy like that.

DRC rocked my world! She played some of her own new tracks and let me 
tell you... Unh! Power!

We drove five hours to get to that party and it was worth every drawn out 
minute of that crusty exhausting drive.

I met some rad enthusiastic people and even saw some people that I knew 
when I lived in Monterey. It really makes me want to go to school in SF; 
I feel so isolated up here, even though it is very beautiful.

Had wonderful randomly deep conversations with random people.
I had hoped to meet more SFR people but I did meet Andy (hello to you!).

Decided to let go of the scene for a little while, at least until I move 
down there. Making the trip to often I could get crispy burnt. But I 
definitely want to go down again this semester sometime.

zippety doo da!

rebecca

Subject: Ambient tip
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey all,

for those of you with an interest in ambient music and who are willing to
look beyond what's on the shelves in Ameba I can recommend the CD with
the music of the movie "Jacob's Ladder". I picked up the last copy from
Virgin records this weekend and am very happy with it. It took a while to
locate the CD but the movie is available on video and definitely worth
watching. Although it's in the horror section and containes some bad trip-
like footage it is in fact a very fascinating movie about life and death
and what is just in between (that was a clue, in fact it may take a while
before you get an idea of what is actually going on). If you rent it, check
out especially the music accompanying the scenes where Jacob is running
a high fever up to the point where he returns to the moment where he is
back on the stretcher in Vietnam and taken to the chopper. ("High fever"
on the CD, at t=1:50 and further on...).
Enjoy.

The Frying Dutchman

--

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Oct 21 16:21:43 1996

	id QAA01452 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Mon, 21 Oct 1996 16:21:37 -0700
From: "Ronald Knegtel" <knegtel@horatio.ucsf.EDU>
Message-Id: <9610211621.ZM1450@horatio.ucsf.edu>
Date: Mon, 21 Oct 1996 16:21:37 -0700
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.0 26oct94 MediaMail)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Sunset boat party short review
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey all,

Being Dutch, and therefore supposed to have a thing with water, fingers in
dikes and all that, I couldn't refuse my friends invitation to join them
to the Sunset boat party. This was a first for me and I have to say I wasn't
dissapointed. Although we left about 1.5 hours behind schedule (apparently
somebody got kicked off the boat because of being too fucked-up and
aggressive as I was told) we cruised for a few hours through the bay.
Interestingly, the boat had a full bar and those who keep insisting that
alcohol has no place at raves stood corrected. Everybody was real friendly
and relaxed which goes to show that it's really _the people_ and not the
drink that make the difference.

The scenery was great and floating under the GG and Bay bridges was quite
a sight. The music on the lower deck was a little bit too house oriented
and monotonous for my taste, although it definitely had the crowd moving.
It was a bit crowded though and the way the speakers were set up required
everybody to stand near the DJ to really feel the bass so I decided to
alternate a lot between dancing and wandering aimlessly through the ship.
The music on the upper deck went from ambient to jungle. Got into
conversations with two different people completely at random, only to find out
later they were both friends/co-worker of another friend of mine and
I'm still wondering what the chances of that were. Found that dancing
with the boat moving underneath you yields interesting effects (and
masks any incompetence actually).

Anyway, I had a great time, although I would have liked a bit more variation
in the kind of music being played. Definitely worth checking out in the
next season, which unfortunately I will not be able to enjoy in SF...

The Frying Dutchman

--

Thanks for the tip Dutchman!  I know that there are tons of great
soundtracks lurking around out there.  Ten years later and I still love
listening to the soundtrack of The Last Temptation of Chritst.  Any other
suggestions?

>Hey all,
>
>for those of you with an interest in ambient music and who are willing to
>look beyond what's on the shelves in Ameba I can recommend the CD with
>the music of the movie "Jacob's Ladder". I picked up the last copy from
>Virgin records this weekend and am very happy with it. It took a while to
>locate the CD but the movie is available on video and definitely worth
>watching. Although it's in the horror section and containes some bad trip-
>like footage it is in fact a very fascinating movie about life and death
>and what is just in between (that was a clue, in fact it may take a while
>before you get an idea of what is actually going on). If you rent it, check
>out especially the music accompanying the scenes where Jacob is running
>a high fever up to the point where he returns to the moment where he is
>back on the stretcher in Vietnam and taken to the chopper. ("High fever"
>on the CD, at t=1:50 and further on...).
>Enjoy.
>
>The Frying Dutchman
>
>--

Hi all!

 Well, I have called the promoter (from Get Down) twice asking for _half_ 
of my agreed upon fee (to be paid irregardless of whether the party was 
busted or not) and to no one's surprise he has not called back. In the 
interest of giving an idiot a break I have withheld certain info but no more;

 My intuition knew from the start that this was a slimey operation by the 
way I was approached; Madvi (sp?), the girlfriend of Miguel the promoter 
basically approached me, at the CCC party with Goa Gil, asking me if I 
would be interested in working Get Down. As she was talking to me she 
essientially was rubbing her breasts on me and getting really close (in a 
semi hot n heavy way). I sorta dug it as I was EssiEntially in a warm 
friendly mood.

 The next clue was that I never again talked to her again, only to Miguel. 
This guy didn't have a clue on how to do anything and was constantly asking 
me for names, phone #s, and advice on how to do things. Then he would 
take the info and lie to venue owners/operators about who he knew so he 
could get a space. Did I listen to my intuition then? NOOOOOOOOOOOOO. Yeesh.

 Well Miguel was always promising me to call at some time and took at 
least two days to accomplish that at any given moment. And oh man was he 
a fast talker.

 The final straw was him not showing up to his own party until AFTER it 
was shut down; about 12:30 am - 6 hours after he said he would be there. 
Yea, I think he called the cops on his own party.

 Anyway, whatever. If anyone wants to call this ass and his slutty 
girlfriend here are the numbers;

VM 		800-731-1557
VM/Pager	888-361-2779
Home		510-644-8308
 
 I mostly put these #s up so those that bought presale tickets could 
bother the guy (at least untill he changes all his #s) and to also show 
him (and other despoilers of the vibe) that this shit will not go 
unchallenged. This guy has done more to fuck the scene than anyone in a 
long time.

    !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!FUCK MIGUEL AND HIS SLUT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!


 My apologies to the list for the vulgarity. I also relise that 
disclosing this info may make promoters less likely to want to work with 
me... oh well.



peas,

Ran

hi folks,

i've really got the energy and the vibe to do it right now and i want to
send you all lots of *love* right now.

the following are my opinions...

everywhere we go and everything we do we've got the opportunity to learn
from our situations and and use our free will as a magic wand to do the
karmically correct thing, we should keep this in mind and also keep in
mind that what we percieve is only our perception, i.e., the folks
posting, the folks reading the posts, the promoters, the partiers, ect.
i'm saying, we all attract experiences to ourselves at times that may seem
painful, that may make us angry.  we learn and grow, especially in the
rave scene or whatever you want to call it, this stuff will still come up
as long as we need it for our growth.

i wasn't there, but it sounds like there was an intention that wasn't made
clear.  always be clear of the intentions.  always be clear about your
intentions.

i say this because being faced with a scene here in Portland that can be
utterly vibeless at times and racked with odd intent, i have had to ask
myself, how have i contributed to this?  besides the music, the ideal of
the love vibe is what has me hooked on this shit.  the only way i'm going
to have it is taking care of my shit, taking care of myself, loving myself
and then loving those immediately around me so that when i go to a party
my karma is clear.

i know this from personal experience and i just wanted to share it.  also,
i hope to say hi to many of you at Tigger.  i didn't get a chance to say
hi (because i didn't know who you were!) to many from the list, 'cept i
did meet a guy in the bathroom (?) (i had shoulder length dreds).  but
i'll be singing in the ambient room at tigger so please say hi.

extra special warm, vibey hugs to randy...

love,

brenda

hhhhhhmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm


 Well the chances I shot off my mouth again are pretty high. I really 
hate it when that happens. :(

 I was just contacted by Miguel from Get Down. He is unhappy about what 
he heard from me on the message phone (and I can't wait till he hears 
about my "get even" post =(  ). But he says he wants to pay me qnd 
everyone else he owes money to. He then wants to throw a free party to 
make up for this past fiasco.

 If he does this (and pay back the presale tix bought) I'm going to be 
looking for an awefully damn big bottle of catsup. The fact that he 
called me back and says he wants to take care of his incurred debts 
already raises my respect for him immensly (sp?). I really hope he does 
make me eat my words!! It will only help the scene. Only time will tell. 
I'll keep you folks posted from this end.

 If there are any people connected with Get Down I would like to say that 
I won't apologise now, but I'm starting to feel humbled again.

potentially in shame,

"Let me have silence always in the centre of the shouting, that is
essential. Let me have silence so that no pin may drop and not be
heard, and not a whisper. Escape us for all our spouting, nor the
needle scratching upon this gramophone of the circular cosmic spot.
Hear me, mark me, learn me, throw the mind's ear open. Shut up the
mind's eye, all will be music. What sculpture of sound cannot, what
cannot as a fluid token words, that nothing else cannot." 

						-Wyndham Lewis

hi all,

within the next few days, we will have installed our RealAudio 3.0 server
here at x-radio.  Once this happens, we would like to start a weekly
netcasting program.  To make it simple, we are planning on just netcasting
mixtapes at first (and at some point, possibly netcasting live).

So, if you've got mix tapes that you'd like us to netcast, get in touch with
me.  All mix tapes should have the playlist so that we can credit the
original artists.  We will, of course, credit you for supplying the tapes.

Thanks all, and have a great day1

pauly

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 10:19 PM -0700 10/21/96, mr. x wrote:

>Irregardless is not a word.

While I agree that Irregardless is redundant and the combination of two
words, your response that it IS NOT a word is not accurate.

Websters Collegiate Dictionary - Tenth Edition:
Irregardless - adv. - [prob. blend of irrespective and regardless] (ca.
1912) nonstand: regardless
USAGE  Irregardless originated in dialectal American speech in the early
20th century.  Its fairly wide spread use in speech called it to the
attention of usage commentators as early as 1927.  The most frequently
repeated remark about it is that "there is no such word."  There is such a
word, however.  It is still used primarily in speech, although it can be
found from time to time in edited prose.  Its reputation has not risen over
the years, and is still a long way from general acceptance.  Use regardless
instead.

FYI
Tony

Subject: oh, the Mad-ness!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

Although I missed the pre-Mad dinner, I was (contrary to popular
belief) still in the Bay Area ;). But I promised myself last night,
that even though I was going to Mad, I wasn't going to dance... In
fact, I even went in disguise: *no* glitter, *no* flashing lights, not
*even* any laminates... I was just going to take it easy and recover
from the weekend.

But when Drenalin played that slow acidy/trip-hop track that grooooved
and grooooved, and got faster and *faster* and *FASTER* until it
exploded(!) --- w0w! 

Okay, I gave in :)

It was the first time I had heard Scott, and you can really tell that
he's an ambient DJ at heart: tracks with long, lush beatless breaks -
but then it surprises you with a sudden build-up, and (wham) you're
pounding the dance floor again. very cool :) I'd like to hear him and
Joe Rice spin back to back some night...

But being the grumpy old raver that I am, I left (reluctantly) during
Sho's set to get some sleep. I'm really getting to like Sho a lot; too
bad he spun last.

As always, worth my $2 :)

Steve

(Apologies to anyone intimately involved with creating this party - it 
was the best pun I could come up with on the spot)

Anyone else endure the last Funky Tekno in May, the one in the gigantic 
warehouse close to HomeBase?

For those who didn't go, let me synopsize:

$25.  HUGE warehouse, one room only.  (Well, one TINY room off to the 
side).   Speakers surrounding half of it for a dancespace.  The other 
half of the room was barren, milling people, bad sound, dark.  No chill area 
at all.  No decorations to speak of.  Uneven vibe, decent at times.  A few 
lasers.  A large Flinstones-like/rock-constructed stage for the dj.  Paid dancing 
women.  DJ Dan, Chris Flores from LA.  Several special acts/attractions 
advertised that did not materialize. But cool firedancers in the morning.

That's it.  That's all there was to it.  Worth $25?  Not a chance in hell.

I still had fun.  I ALWAYS have fun at raves.  But I DID NOT see where 
this money went at all.  It certainly didn't show in the party.

It was the last massive I ever went to.

Hopefully more is going into the Halloween Tribal MASSIVE.  We'll see.
