Message-Id: <199610221958.MAA16789@dfw-ix9.ix.netcom.com>
From: shawna-@ix.netcom.com (Shawna McGourty)
Subject: Re: Stinky Tekno Tribe
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>Anyone else endure the last Funky Tekno in May, the one in the gigantic 
>warehouse close to HomeBase?


Yes, unfortunately after finding that Chrysalis (which had been planned for 
that same night) had been canceled, I found myself with a group of friends 
waiting in an hour-long line for that same silly party, finding out *after* 
waiting that hour that it was $25 at the door when it was advertised as $20 
beforehand, watched drunken idiots swill down as much JD as possible before 
falling into a window and breaking it to be hauled away by the police 
afterwards, watched bottles get smashed onto the pavement, helplessly observed 
large groups of people cut into the already long line, found myself in an 
enormous empty space almost entirely devoid of decoration, found that half the 
promised dj's were nowhere to be found, found a kick-ass system with kick-ass 
music blaring out of it, danced my ass off all night, and somehow had a really 
killer time in spite of it all.  Then I went outside after the party to find 
that our car had been broken into and my purse stolen. :(  I will not bother to 
attend another massive, with the possible exception of The Gathering in 
December.  I've certainly been able to hear kick-ass music even for free at 
times!  I do not need to make these other sacrifices for it.  But of course, 
this is all IMHO. :)

I hope all who attend have a fabulous time! :)


Love,
Shawna

>
>
>(Apologies to anyone intimately involved with creating this party - it 
>was the best pun I could come up with on the spot)
>
>Anyone else endure the last Funky Tekno in May, the one in the gigantic 
>warehouse close to HomeBase?
>
>For those who didn't go, let me synopsize:
>
>$25.  HUGE warehouse, one room only.  (Well, one TINY room off to the 
>side).   Speakers surrounding half of it for a dancespace.  The other 
>half of the room was barren, milling people, bad sound, dark.  No chill area 
>at all.  No decorations to speak of.  Uneven vibe, decent at times.  A few 
>lasers.  A large Flinstones-like/rock-constructed stage for the dj.  Paid
dancing 
>women.  DJ Dan, Chris Flores from LA.  Several special acts/attractions 
>advertised that did not materialize. But cool firedancers in the morning.
>
>That's it.  That's all there was to it.  Worth $25?  Not a chance in hell.
>
>I still had fun.  I ALWAYS have fun at raves.  But I DID NOT see where 
>this money went at all.  It certainly didn't show in the party.
>
>It was the last massive I ever went to.
>
>Hopefully more is going into the Halloween Tribal MASSIVE.  We'll see.
>

I agree with Nancy all the way!  This party sucked!  I made the decision
never to go to a massive again after that party.  They pissed a lot of
people off... including me.

> 
> >Anyone else endure the last Funky Tekno in May, the one in the gigantic 
> >warehouse close to HomeBase?
> 
> 
> Yes, unfortunately after finding that Chrysalis (which had been planned for 
> that same night) had been canceled, I found myself with a group of friends 
> waiting in an hour-long line for that same silly party, finding out *after* 
> waiting that hour that it was $25 at the door when it was advertised as $20 
> beforehand, watched drunken idiots swill down as much JD as possible before 
> falling into a window and breaking it to be hauled away by the police 
> afterwards, watched bottles get smashed onto the pavement, helplessly observed 
> large groups of people cut into the already long line, found myself in an 
> enormous empty space almost entirely devoid of decoration, found that half the 
> promised dj's were nowhere to be found, found a kick-ass system with kick-ass 
> music blaring out of it, danced my ass off all night, and somehow had a really 
> killer time in spite of it all.  Then I went outside after the party to find 
> that our car had been broken into and my purse stolen. :(  I will not bother to 
> attend another massive, with the possible exception of The Gathering in 
> December.  I've certainly been able to hear kick-ass music even for free at 
> times!  I do not need to make these other sacrifices for it.  But of course, 
> this is all IMHO. :)
> 
> I hope all who attend have a fabulous time! :)
> 
> 
> Love,
> Shawna

Hey, you know what?  CT has a group photo of a bunch of SFR people 
(including you, of course =)  )  waiting in line for this party!  It's
labelled as being a picture from Freedom, and I remember thinking 
"Hey, I wasn't at Freedom, was I?"  But I wasn't sure.  But when you
said "watched drunken idiots swill down as much JD as possible before
falling into a window" it all came back to me.  "Oh yeah, it was
FTT!" =) 

I remember that party pretty well...  I had decided to go sober, which
had turned out to be a good idea as a bunch of my friends ended up
with bad dosEs and had a not-so-good time.  But I did meet a lot of
people that night who are friends to this day, so there are quite a
few fond memories!  It's certainly a bonding experience to have a
kick-ass, happy time together, but strangely (or perhaps not so
strangely) it can be just as bonding to have a so-so time, but
have it together! 

The picture can be found at:
"http://www.cyborganic.com/people/ctdzine/photo/src/free0796.002.jpg"

And CT: update the caption!  =)

Smiles, 
     Chin

Ramirez, Christian P wrote:

>What does NRR mean???

>From the home office in Sioux City, Iowa,
THE TOP TEN MEANINGS FOR "NRR":

10. Nasty Rave Rhymes
9.  Note: Ranting Reindeer
8.  Not Reading Right
7.  Need Real Ravers
6.  New, Righteous, Right-on!
5.  Non-Rave Related
4.  Non-Related Ribosomes
3.  Nissan Road Ravioli
2.  Now RLunatic Rocks!

and the number one meaning for "NRR":

1.  Nasty, Raunchy and Red-hot!


S


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Oct 22 15:39:37 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id PAA29353; Tue, 22 Oct 1996 15:39:37 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from mailhub.Stanford.EDU by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with ESMTP id PAA29345; Tue, 22 Oct 1996 15:39:33 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from voyager4.Stanford.EDU (voyager4.Stanford.EDU [36.34.0.104]) by mailhub.Stanford.EDU (8.7.5/8.7.3) with SMTP id PAA05837; Tue, 22 Oct 1996 15:39:29 -0700 (PDT)
Date: Tue, 22 Oct 1996 15:39:30 -0700 (PDT)
From: David Richardson <suprdave@stanford.edu>
To: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Stinky Tekno Tribe (revisited)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9610221233.A2026-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.95.961022151909.14309B-100000@voyager4.Stanford.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi everybody. I've been lurking for a while, but Nancy has given me the
perfect occasion to introduce myself. (For those of you who were at Mad
last night, I was the skinny-ish guy with red-blonde hair, about 6'1",
with flourescent fingernail polish, nikes, and a striped thrift-store
shirt).

In defense of Stinky Tekno Tribe, I consider it the best night of my life.
When I got there, the line was ridiculous, so I climbed a couple of
fences, walked along the train track, uncovered a secret entrance to the
warehouse by moving a board, evaded a security guard, and snuck in.

During the night I danced as hard as I could. The music was
amazing, I really liked the lasers, and (this is the big one) I fell
in love.
 
(for those of you snickering: no, I was not on e -- I was completely
sober, except for a mini-thin or two. :) )

I admit the vibe was a bit weird; people kept coming up to me and Cindy
(the girl I fell in love with) and refused to believe we weren't on
crystal or speed. The line was absurd. And a good chill space was sorely
missed.

Even so, FTT (as one of my first raves) really got me into dancing,
electronic music, and the whole scene. that's why I have to come to it's
defense.

-dave

ps. (although, if BASS is selling tickets to the upcoming one, there's
nothing that can be said for that)



On Tue, 22 Oct 1996, Nancy Shaw wrote:

> 
> 
> (Apologies to anyone intimately involved with creating this party - it 
> was the best pun I could come up with on the spot)
> 
> Anyone else endure the last Funky Tekno in May, the one in the gigantic 
> warehouse close to HomeBase?
> 
> For those who didn't go, let me synopsize:
> 
> $25.  HUGE warehouse, one room only.  (Well, one TINY room off to the 
> side).   Speakers surrounding half of it for a dancespace.  The other 
> half of the room was barren, milling people, bad sound, dark.  No chill area 
> at all.  No decorations to speak of.  Uneven vibe, decent at times.  A few 
> lasers.  A large Flinstones-like/rock-constructed stage for the dj.  Paid dancing 
> women.  DJ Dan, Chris Flores from LA.  Several special acts/attractions 
> advertised that did not materialize. But cool firedancers in the morning.
> 
> That's it.  That's all there was to it.  Worth $25?  Not a chance in hell.
> 
> I still had fun.  I ALWAYS have fun at raves.  But I DID NOT see where 
> this money went at all.  It certainly didn't show in the party.
> 
> It was the last massive I ever went to.
> 
> Hopefully more is going into the Halloween Tribal MASSIVE.  We'll see.
> 
>

Hello everyone!!

        Well, I bring good news!!! I talked to Omar!!! Yes that means that
he is speaking and can hold a, well, relatively good conversation. He has
only been takling for a little while now, and his vocab. is tremendous!! He
uses words that I don't even know the meaning of!! (Not saying that I am an
English wiz, which I am not) He remembers a lot, but some of his memory is
patchy. He remembers certain parties. He can remember certain things about
Burning Man. But he has a bad time with dates, and numbers. Slowly but
surely his memory will come back!

        I told him about the party we are doing for him (A Wrinkle in Time)
and he got really excited. He said,"I'm ready to go!!" I said, "Omar, you
are going to miss this one unfortunatly, but maybe next time!" He agreed...
He is really excited about all of us coming together to help him get through
these hard times. He knows of, and feels everything we have done for him so
far, and is very grateful....

        So with this in mind, I ask that all of you come out to this very
special healing party!! Bring your best, most positive vibes, and send them
in Omar's direction!! This will prove to be a very intense night for Omar,
as well as the rest of the Harmony Family. We have been shaken up and really
hurt for a long time because of this tragedy. There has been an ungodly
amount of emotions (good and bad) bouncing to and from each of us. Well now
it's time to come together to create positive energy from this awful
negative occurance!!!

        Tigger Productions (Omar and Harmony) proudly present... 

                                (Drumz Please)

                             "A Wrinkle In Time"

        DJs = Matt - (The other) Matt - Ethan - Minor Minor - Jason + mtba

        
        Ambience provided by = Dionysus Dreams

                        (415)263-4885   (408)450-3044


        The party will be in S.F. and will go from 9:30pm - 6am. Admission
will be $15 - $20 strickly depending on how much you can give. We want to
charge a lot for this party, so that we can make some $ for Omar. But we
don't really want to charge an arm and a leg, so this is what we have come
up with. But hey if you have a spare arm or leg laying around, bring it!!!
Now, remember this is a benefit party, so, for Omar bring what you can! If
that means, "get well" cards, stuft animals, or just a big giant mental hug,
bring it!! Anything that will brighten his day is what we want!!!

        Also, our ambient room will be totally interactive. Which means that
you guys can play on the keyboards, drums, etc. (sorry no djing though) Also
we will have a full VIRTUAL REALITY machine!!!! You all have to try this!!!!
(mmmmmm...) There will be a whole separate room set aside for a healing drum
circle, as well as group/or singular meditations. So BRING YOUR DRUMS!!!!!!!
(if you don't have a drum, borrow one, buy one, build one!!! Just bring one!!!) 

        Also, if you have anything that you would like to bring to add to
our chill rooms or even our dance room, write to me or call the info
lines!!! Also, for those of you that are interested, there will be a meeting
for this party on Thursday Oct 24th. It will be at City Espresso on Stevens
Creek Blvd, in San Jose. Starting @ 7:30pm So you should come if you're
interested in helping with this party!!! (And that means YOU!!)

Peace, love and harmony to all,

Greg =)
Peace, love and harmony to all!!!

Greg =)

> soundtracks lurking around out there.  Ten years later and I still love
> listening to the soundtrack of The Last Temptation of Chritst.  Any other
> suggestions?
> 
> >Hey all,
> >
> >for those of you with an interest in ambient music and who are willing to
> >look beyond what's on the shelves in Ameba I can recommend the CD with
> >the music of the movie "Jacob's Ladder". I picked up the last copy from
> >Virgin records this weekend and am very happy with it. It took a while to
> >locate the CD but the movie is available on video and definitely worth
> >watching. Although it's in the horror section and containes some bad trip-
> >like footage it is in fact a very fascinating movie about life and death
> >and what is just in between (that was a clue, in fact it may take a while
> >before you get an idea of what is actually going on). If you rent it, check
> >out especially the music accompanying the scenes where Jacob is running
> >a high fever up to the point where he returns to the moment where he is
> >back on the stretcher in Vietnam and taken to the chopper. ("High fever"
> >on the CD, at t=1:50 and further on...).
> >Enjoy.
> >
> >The Frying Dutchman
> >
> >--

Subject: Costume Ideas for Halloween!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 22 Oct 1996 16:21:30 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]

Some Tuesday afternoon humor for y'all! M'be we'll see some of these
as regular rave-wear!

Enjoy ;)

- martin

===========================================================================


A Bunch of Low-Budget-Yet-Still-Fly-As-All-Hell Costume Ideas for Halloween
'96:

Knock several of your own teeth out, light a candle, swallow it whole and go
as one helluva slammin' jack-o'-lantern.

Dip yourself into a huge vat of saliva and go as a giant tongue.

Paint a big star on your face, throw on a blue-white-red striped Izod tennis
shirt and be your Texan roommate's Lone Star State flag.

Dress in all green, keep a leaking thermos of Kool-Aid in your front pants
pocket and go as Kermit the Vehemently Incontinent Frog.

Inflate four or five extra-large condoms, staple them to the crown of your
scalp and go as that satanicHamburger Helper hand thing.

Get naked, cover your body with bees and go as honey.

Put on a pretty red bonnet, have one of your good friends inadvertently
plunge a meat cleaver into your spine and go as Strawberry Shortcake After
One of Her Good Friends Inadvertently Plunged a Meat Cleaver into Her Spine.

Dip yourself into a huge vat of saliva, slap on a grass skirt and go as a
giant tongue that hails from the beautiful state of Hawaii.

Magic-marker your eyebrows together and go as Bert.

Set someone's house on fire and pretend you're an arsonist.

Shove your head straight through a Casio TK-1200 electronic keyboard and go
as An Organ of Very Impressive Size.

Spit on anyone who comes within a four-foot radius of you and be a human
water pick.

Club yourself in the face several times, safety pin your upper lip to the
tip of your nose and go as Donna from "Beverly Hills 90210."

Slap on a cape, vomit profusely and be Count Dracula After He Got That
Horrendous Gastrointestinal Problem That One Time.

Get naked, cover your body with bees and go as just a normal run-o'-the-mill
person who's not at all afraid to experiment with new somatosensory
endeavors.

Put on a big wig, big nose, big collar, big shoes and go as a big dork.

Coat your entire face with White-Out and go as The Noxema Girl After A
Really Cruel Hoax.

Whenever you converse with someone, scream as loud as you possibly can "No,
I don't want to talk with Helmut!" and go as A Horrendously Unproductive
Telephone Call to Germany.

Grab a turkey baster, a bucket full of cheese wiz and a circus midget, and
then--oh sorry, wrong list.

Thumbtack some Xerox paper to your chin, flap your arms incessantly and go
as a paper airplane.

Don a witch's hat, smother your body in ground beef and chili and go as a
Wicked Burrito.

Purchase a well-greased-down pair of mouse ears, slap 'em on, jam several
hypodermics into your arm and call yourself Mickey Mouse, Trying
Ever-So-Desperately To Kick a Hardcore Smack Habit.

Dye your hair green and go as broccoli.

Put several shoes of sundry sizes in your mouth and go as
Super-Insensitive-No-Sense-Of-Tact-Guy.

Annoyingly repeat everything that people around you say, using slightly
different terminology, and be Roget's thesaurus.

Stick both of your arms straight out in front of you and constantly yell,
"Hey, somebody come and sit on me, you bunch of stupid jerks!" and be the
spitting image of a rocking chair.

Stand completely straight, arms taut at your side, tilt your head slightly
to the right and go as a stunning Jack Nicklaus Classic Edition 5-iron.

Draw whiskers on your face, jump up and down on a pogo stick, cough
incessantly, refuse to talk to anyone and go as an anti-social,
hyper-excited bunny rabbit with bronchitis.

Find a small boy named Isaac, tie him up, brandish a knife above his chest
and go as Abraham.

Tie yourself from head-to-toe in bakery string of some sort and be dental
floss.

Wrap yourself completely in red wax paper and go as Herman The Mutant
Kielbasa Boy.

Shove a lot of sliced bananas and strawberries down your shirt and pants and
go as one of those crazy jello molds with the whole
colloid-suspension-fruit-effect goin' on.

     ha ha!  that happened to me at ComeUnity last month.  some girl came 
     up to me and asked me what i had taken tonight, as if it were a 
     prerequisite to entering the party.  i responded "nothing" because it 
     had not occurred to me to take anything.  it's funny how people's 
     perceptions of the world can be.  A lot of people have pretty funky 
     control dramas they have to work through.

From: rayvonie@ix.netcom.com (Ray Vonie)
Subject: The Spirit of Halloween (upcoming event info)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

What is the spirit of raving all about???
What is the spirit of Halloween all about??

To me, Halloween is like the biggest rave-like holiday of all time.  It 
reminds me of youth and the playfulness of my childhood.  Its like 
being young and getting all dressed up and having everybody smile at 
you.  You can dress goofy, weird, odd, strange, scary, or anyway, and 
nobody judges you because its Halloween.  And on top of it they give 
you candy and love for being the special person you are.  It seems like 
Raving has adapted many of its most positive virtues from the SPIRIT of 
Halloween.  For this reason I like to think of Halloween as the 
Birthday or NewYears of Raving.

This Halloween: Thursday, October 31st;  Come and rejoyce the Beautiful 
spirit of raving by escaping into a celebration for the SPIRIT of 
Halloween.

In 1992, Feel Good E., and others introduced you to CASPER.   Now we 
are going to regress even furthur down the evelutionary ladder, and 
start from scratch.  SPIRIT will be a diferent type of Halloween rave.  
We will have  Lots of candy, free stuff, many surprises, toy and prize 
giveaways, games, and a MaskaRave costume contest, and an incredible 
decorative haloween production, with special guests and surprises 
throughout the night.  

There will be a huge haunted house chill room amd 2 rooms of sound.
The dj's for the night will be:

In the Spiritual Dreamscape:
Dj's:  Jin, Tayco, Garth, Simon, Kimo, & Jazz-E

In the ThurZdaze Beat Chamber:
Dj's:  Ghost, Frank Nitty, Essence, Tripnotix, Paucus, Spinner, & Chad

The party will go all night long,  from 9pm til 6am.  We hava a ton of 
safe and secured parking.  Its a real relaxing feeling to be able to 
party and know that your car will be there when you are ready to go 
home.  We are also very close to public transit for those of you that 
don't drive.

THIS is going to be a REAL Halloween Rave for REAL Halloween Ravers.  
Admision is only $10 if you wear a costume and bring toys or 
Trick-or-Treat candy to share.  Door prizez will be given for the best 
and most creative costumes.

The SPIRIT of Halloween is all about FUN.  You can dance like a freak 
to great music all night long, while surrounded by all your friends, 
dressed up all crazy, and feel like more than just being at a party, 
but feel like YOU ARE A PART OF THE PARTY.  Your spirit, and positive 
attitude are the key ingredients that are going to make this such a 
memorable Halloween Rave.  Hope to see you there.

For all information call:   415-915-1704   or    510-340-9401

PS:  There are no flyers for this event, It is mostly word of mouth.  
Please help out by spreading the word to all your friends.
We will have more information to follow in the next few days.  

PLUR

Bad spelling is my trademark.  Ray Vonie

> (Apologies to anyone intimately involved with creating this party - it 
> was the best pun I could come up with on the spot)
> 
> Anyone else endure the last Funky Tekno in May, the one in the gigantic 
> warehouse close to HomeBase?
> 
> For those who didn't go, let me synopsize:
> 
> $25.  HUGE warehouse, one room only.  (Well, one TINY room off to the 
> side).   Speakers surrounding half of it for a dancespace.  The other 
> half of the room was barren, milling people, bad sound, dark.  No chill area 
> at all.  No decorations to speak of.  Uneven vibe, decent at times.  A few 
> lasers.  A large Flinstones-like/rock-constructed stage for the dj.  Paid dancing 
> women.  DJ Dan, Chris Flores from LA.  Several special acts/attractions 
> advertised that did not materialize. But cool firedancers in the morning.
> 
> That's it.  That's all there was to it.  Worth $25?  Not a chance in hell.
> 
> I still had fun.  I ALWAYS have fun at raves.  But I DID NOT see where 
> this money went at all.  It certainly didn't show in the party.
> 
> It was the last massive I ever went to.
> 
> Hopefully more is going into the Halloween Tribal MASSIVE.  We'll see.
> 
>

Hey all!

You may not of missed me but I mis all you in SF.  I moved to San Luis 
Obispo last October and yes it's SLOW!  This town is so concervative but 
it reminds me of Pleasanton, my home town.

First thing I did was look for the local clubs, bard, and any rave 
scene.  And yes they have one.  A small one but it's hear.  There is no 
really good clubs.  They have the Grad on Wed. which is a country club 
every other night and Tortia Flats has a disco night on Tuesday.  Every 
thing else is traditional top 40 or country.

A couple of cal poly student throw parties here.  A total of 5 I believe 
in the past 2 years but this is going to change.  Last Saturday they had 
the biggest party here yet.  
The group goes by the name Urban Generation.  Some local dj's.  Santos 
from SF was suposed to be here Sat but I showed up late to the party to 
see if he spun.  Javier spun (one of the promoters who's origianly from 
LA) and Morgan and Spark-e.  The last two I heard were good.  I got to the 
party at 1 am (I work as a waiter and intraining to be the "sound guy"/mobal 
banquet dj at The Forum {a very financially stable banquet hall).  They 
had problems with the sound (pushing the level, bad amp or something and the 
power cut out too many times) 

The party was at a roller rink in Morro Bay.  10 pm - 3 am. Permits are 
scarce in this conservative area.  Morgan was on when I arrived.  Tight 
security, Club style lighting (search lights - don't know a better name), 
Lots of stuffed animals in the chill area.  About 80 people when I got 
there but I heard there was about 400 - 500 earlier.  Mostly hardcore 
raver types at this point.  Morgan spun some acid trance/break and 
Spark-e was more hardcore with hard trance and goa with a couple good 
breaks thrown in. (huge responce to Loose Caboose many DAN fans here - I 
know I've been makin copies of his tapes for people).  

At the end everyone (25ppl or so) joined in a circle huging, screaming, 
smiling and dancing to the last traks.  Great little family vibe.
After the party I helped break down a little and went back to Spark-e's 
place to continue dancing, listing to music and meeting many of the last 
people to leave the party.  Many friendly people.

I've been to 2 other HOUSE parties since I've been here including 
Jordan's bE-day party in SB (hi Sarvi) and met many 
local dj's including 2 who just moved here from Chicago to train to be 
firemen.  One is purchacing a sound system.  I've met many practicing 
dj's and some students that even design rave flyers.  

I'm hopin to help out and pull resources for a DIY down here.  I also met
Marious or is it Marcus (it was loud and I'm bad with names) The guy that 
threw Seismic parties in SF.  Well, he moved here too this summer and is 
throwing a party this November 2nd!!!

BP to follow *****  Seismic  *******
      ******* Something Kind For the Mind *****
Straight off the flyer-
          November 2nd
Djs-
Thomas Michael (LA)           805.639.3953
Radley Marx (SF)             atmosphere of ease and relaxation by Sputnik
Kimo (SJ)                    Tribal Drummers        Body Painting
Spark-E (SLO)                  Free Sm:)es and candy

If your down in the area please come out and support or if your not 
planning on doing anything come on down and you can crash with me or my 
friends.

Hope everythings great at home.  I'll be up this weekend and am 
planning on going to the Full Moon at Mission Rock and Sunset maybe 
even FTT. 

Well, back to Diff EQ! Yeah-

PLUR

Austin

Although I haven't *bitched* about a massive yet, I resent being told not
to.  I am one of those people who think massives generally suck.  I won't
go into the sordid details, but I'd rather stay home and, uh, pick my nose
before I patronize most massives.  Yeah, a party is what you make it, but
then again some people aren't very choosy.  So, you like massives.  I
don't.  Bitch? Certainly I will if I feel passionately about something.
I usually don't get into the massive attack, but this time it was worth
wasting the time at my computer.

Over and Out,

KaySEE

        "Mission Rock hints?" (Oct 22,  8:30pm)
References: <199610230330.UAA12166@netcom17.netcom.com>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.1 10oct95)
To: larryc@netcom.com (Larry Ching), sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Mission Rock hints?
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Been there many times.  It's basically an old marina tavern/hangout that's
been used for years by the club side of the house music scene.  There
are two floors and an outside deck.  It's kind of a funky picturesque
place, definitely a dockside deal, no downtown flashiness.  I can't
say I've ever had a great time there but it's always enjoyable.  

Do be careful where you park.  Also, I've heard some reports of smashed
windows and so on in the vicinity.

One of my sources indicates that Mission Rock
has an uncertain future due to various legal disputes with the Port --
not that they've done anything wrong, more like the same old bureaucratic
hassles.  So check it out before it's history (or even if it doesn't 
vanish :)

phred

Dear Friends & Family,

=09I remember a number of you before the last election were quite
enthused about voting for Willie Brown, and how he was going to make the
city a better place for ravers.  I still don't believe it, but I'd love to
be proved wrong.
=09This is an excellent chance to find out what the man's colors are.
If Brown cares about human rights, he will use his considerable political
clout to nail this creep Haggett and see that he never wears a badge in
this town again.
=09Give "Da Mayor" a call at 554-6600.

My computer tells me that on Fri, 18 Oct 1996, Rocky Mullin shared:

>=20
> =09below is a story from the /chronicle/ that ran today.  officer
> =09haggett is the man that i and many of my friends witnessed
> =09betaing a friend of ours at a party raid.  her "crime" was
> =09that she was observing the officers beating other partygoers
> =09from a respectful distance and then taking photographs of
> =09the police officers actions.
>=20
> =09hagget has repetedly flaunted the law and violently violated
> =09citizens rights.  we waited two years for our turn at justice
> =09for his actions on new years 1994.  we thought we had some
> =09sembelance of justice recently, but the police power establishment
> =09has ruled against the citizens.  i urge you to take whatever action
> =09you think you can in this matter - letters to the police
> =09commisioner, board of supes, mayor willie brown and the media.
> =09how can we, as citizens, feel safe in san francisco if the systems
> =09that are here to protect us *and* the systems to watchdog
> =09them send us a clear message that we are not the priority,
> =09rather the systems themselves are.
>=20
> =09haggett's actions are patterned: violent outbursts against
> =09citizens and then completely lying in inquiry as to what caused
> =09his unwarranted actions.  i know this for *fact* because i
> =09observed one of these incidents first hand and his subsequent
> =09explanation of my friend "yelling and inciting the partygoers
> =09to riot" as a warrant for her beating, false imprisonment and
> =09mysterious disappearance of the film in her camera while
> =09in police impound.  i know what she was doing - standing and taking
> =09pictures, which is not illegal in the least.  in fact, it is
> =09within the law to observe police action without interfering.
> =09she was attacked for this, and it is reasonable for some of
> =09us who were there to assume that this attack was an effort to
> =09prevent those pictures from existing.
>=20
> =09there are plenty of good, valuable police officers out there
> =09who are doing their best to to serve and protect our citizens.
> =09those who are clearly out to commit violence and violate rights
> =09should be imprsoned, not employed at the taxpayers expense.
>=20
> =09most of us will not settle for anything less than his badge
> =09at this point.  please do what you can to help.  hopefully
> =09our leaders will be strong and advocate for us citizens, who,
> =09so far, have been ignored and taunted with false hopes,
> =09promises, and lies.  thank you for your time.
>=20
> from  Friday, October 18, 1996 =B7 Page A1 =A9 1996 San Francisco Chronic=
le
>=20
> http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/chronicle/article.cgi?file=3DMN65503.DTL&di=
rectory=3D/chronicle/archive/1996/10/18:
>=20
>=20
>=20
> Cop's Suspension May Violate Rules
>=20
> Susan Sward, Bill Wallace, Chronicle Staff Writers
>=20
>      The San Francisco Police Commission's decision
>      last week to allow Sergeant John Haggett to
>      remain on the force after finding him guilty of four
>      firing offenses appears to violate the department's
>      own guidelines for disciplining officers convicted of
>      misconduct.
>=20
>      After finding the 38-year-old officer guilty of falsely
>      arresting three people, using excessive force and
>      filing a false report in connection with a 1995 New
>      Year's Day police raid on an AIDS benefit, the
>      five-member commission voted to suspend
>      Haggett for six months.
>=20
>      The commission and Police Chief Fred Lau said
>      they decided not to fire Haggett because they
>      did not want to impose the department's most
>      severe penalty on him for an incident in which
>      many other officers made mistakes.
>=20
>      Lau did not return The Chronicle's call for
>      comment, and John Keker, chairman of the
>      commission, was out of town and could not be
>      reached. Haggett's lawyer, James Lassart, also did
>      not respond to a Chronicle request for comment.
>=20
>      Department guidelines adopted by the
>      commission in 1994 stress the need for
>      ``progressive discipline.'' They call for an officer's
>      disciplinary history to be used in evaluating an
>      officer's current misconduct charge.
>=20
>      Haggett has one of the most extensive misconduct
>      records of any member of San Francisco's
>      2,000-member force. In 14 years on the force, he
>      has had two previous 90-day suspensions for
>      excessive force, the maximum suspension at the
>      time; has been named in six lawsuits with more than
>      $70,000 in damages against the city so far; and he
>      has been the target of dozens of complaints from
>      citizens.
>=20
>      Critics say the department's apparent failure to
>      act according to its own guidelines shows it lacks
>      the will to discipline rogue cops.
>=20
>      ``An explanation is owed as to why the
>      department's own disciplinary guidelines were
>      abandoned in this case,'' said John Crew, an
>      attorney with the American Civil Liberties Union
>      who monitors the Police Department.
>=20
>      Lawrence Sherman, chairman of the criminology
>      department at the University of Maryland and an
>      expert on police misconduct, said that while he
>      does not know the details of Haggett's record, he
>      has never encountered a case in which an officer
>      with such a substantial prior disciplinary history was
>      not dismissed from the department upon the next
>      substantiated incident.
>=20
>      ``I have looked at a lot of police departments,
>      and I can't recall a case with that much prior
>      discipline against an officer who was still on the
>      force,'' Sherman said.
>=20
>      Here are some of the major incidents in Haggett's
>      career:
>=20
>      -- James Tahsini was 19 years old when he
>      encountered Haggett in May 1987. The officer
>      approached him at midnight outside the Diamond
>      Heights Safeway and asked to look in the duffel
>      bag in which Tahsini was carrying two six-packs of
>      beer. Tahsini says that when he told Haggett ``you
>      have no reason to look in my bag,'' the officer
>      ``grabbed me by my throat, slammed me against
>      the hood of his car and started hitting me.''
>=20
>      ``At first, I thought he was psychotic -- the way he
>      slammed me against his car and hit me with his
>      pistol and pointed it at my face,'' said Tahsini.
>      Tahsini later testified that Haggett told him, ``I'm
>      not in the mood for this s--.''
>=20
>      The 150-pound Tahsini found himself lying on his
>      back with his hands handcuffed underneath him. At
>      that point, ``He (Haggett) stepped on my throat as
>      if I was some sort of animal. It was just the way he
>      was standing on me. You know when you see a
>      movie where the hunter kills the wolf and steps on it
>      to pose for the picture? It was sort of like that.''
>=20
>      All charges against Tahsini, including resisting arrest
>      and assaulting an officer, were subsequently
>      dropped. Haggett earned a 90-day suspension in
>      this case.
>=20
>      At the end of the police commission hearing on
>      the Tahsini case, then-Police Chief Frank Jordan
>      called the allegations ``very serious'' and
>      recommended that Haggett be suspended for 90
>      days and fired if he engaged in another act of
>      misconduct.
>=20
>      Police Commission President Lou Giraudo was
>      equally stern.
>=20
>      ``Under no circumstances could I possibly sit here
>      and believe that that which occurred in the
>      parking lot . . . was reasonable behavior on your
>      part,'' Giraudo said in imposing the suspension.
>      ``We are saying 90 days because that's the
>      maximum short of termination that this commission
>      can do, to let you and your fellow officers know
>      that we do consider it a most serious matter.''
>=20
>      -- Later that year, Haggett appeared before the
>      same commission and the same chief -- this time
>      charged with smashing another teenager in the
>      face with his walkie-talkie after the youth failed to
>      sit down fast enough for him.
>=20
>      According to police commission records, Haggett
>      hit the teenager, Matthew O'Leary, at least twice
>      with the heavy metal-and-plastic radio, breaking
>      O'Leary's nose. During an investigation of the
>      incident by the Office of Citizens Complaints,
>      Haggett told investigator Araceli Matus that he
>      did not know the department's general order
>      governing the use of force on suspects. Haggett
>      dismissed the departmental regulation as ``an
>      opinion written by people that don't work in the
>      street anymore.''
>=20
>      In November 1988, the commission found Haggett
>      guilty of using excessive force on O'Leary. But
>      instead of firing him as Jordan had suggested four
>      months earlier, the commission suspended
>      Haggett for another 90 days.
>=20
>      Police Commissioner Jose Medina, who was on the
>      commission at the time Haggett received both
>      suspensions, said the commission's hands were
>      tied in those cases by the recommendation of the
>      chief. The commission followed Jordan's
>      recommendations by imposing the longest
>      possible suspensions -- three months without pay.
>=20
>      Medina said that even though Jordan had
>      recommended that Haggett be fired for any
>      further misconduct after the Tahsini case, Jordan
>      did not ask that Haggett be terminated for
>      beating O'Leary.
>=20
>      ``He failed to follow his own recommendation,''
>      Medina said of the former police chief. ``What he
>      recommended was a suspension, and we
>      imposed 90 days, the maximum that was allowable
>      at the time.''
>=20
>      Attempts to reach Jordan were unsuccessful.
>=20
>      -- Court documents filed in connection with a
>      police brutality lawsuit in 1989 showed that at that
>      time Haggett had been named in 27 complaints
>      ``which contain allegations that officer Haggett
>      either falsely arrested a person or used excessive
>      force in the course of the arrest.''
>=20
>      The suit also indicated that Haggett had been
>      named in 16 other complaints alleging conduct
>      unbecoming an officer, neglect of duty or
>      discourtesy toward citizens -- and 13 other
>      complaints of various types of misconduct,
>      including three that were still under investigation.
>=20
>      -- In addition to the dozens of citizen complaints
>      that have been filed against Haggett, he has also
>      been named in six lawsuits that have cost city
>      taxpayers more than $72,000 in jury awards and
>      settlements.
>=20
>      In a 1986 suit, Christopher Torres, an Ingleside
>      District man, claimed he was dragged from his car
>      and beaten by Haggett and other officers after he
>      cruised through a stop sign on his way home. It
>      later turned out that the officers had mistaken him
>      for another man with a similar name who was
>      wanted on a $160 warrant.
>=20
>      During the incident, ``Haggett jumped me from
>      behind and put a lock on my neck and grabbed
>      my hair and threw me on the ground,'' Torres said
>      during his testimony about the incident in Superior
>      Court.
>=20
>      ``I was screaming, telling my neighbors to stop
>      him,'' Torres said. ``I yelled out that he was hurting
>      me . . . (then) he choked me so tight I couldn't
>      yell.''
>=20
>      One of Torres' neighbors, Marie Louise Fernandez,
>      confirmed Torres' story in her own sworn testimony.
>      ``I remember thinking that he must have robbed a
>      bank or murdered somebody because they
>      (police) were not treating him as an ordinary
>      citizen,'' Fernandez testified. ``He was being
>      treated as a criminal.''
>=20
>      Shortly after a Superior Court jury began hearing
>      the testimony in Torres' case, the city settled his
>      lawsuit for $35,000.
>=20
>      -- FBI agents are conducting a federal civil rights
>      investigation into Haggett's fatal shooting last year
>      of parolee Edwin Sheehan, 40, who had a long
>      string of convictions for drug abuse and one for
>      armed robbery.
>=20
>      Haggett shot Sheehan after the parolee drove
>      into several vehicles in the Tenderloin while
>      attempting to flee from police. Haggett said he
>      thought Sheehan had a gun and made furtive
>      movements. Investigators at the scene searched
>      Sheehan's body and found he had been
>      unarmed.
>=20
>      Kenneth Quigley, an attorney for Sheehan's family,
>      said at the time: ``All he did was run. He didn't fight
>      them, and he didn't shoot them. All he did was try
>      to get away.''
>=20
>      As for Tahsini, putting his 1987 encounter with
>      Haggett behind him has been a difficult ordeal, in
>      part because lawyers keep seeking him out to
>      testify in cases they have pending against the
>      officer.
>=20
>      ``I know a lot of cops who are good cops,'' said
>      Tahsini, who collected a $35,000 jury award for his
>      encounter with Haggett.
>=20
>      ``There are a few bad apples who make it worse
>      for everyone else (and put) a bad rap on the
>      whole department,'' Tahsini said.
>=20
>      ``With Haggett's record, once, twice, three times
>      maybe you let it go. But when it's continuous, it's
>      getting out of hand. Obviously something is
>      wrong.''
>=20
>=20
> --=20

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Oct 23 06:18:35 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id GAA13699; Wed, 23 Oct 1996 06:18:35 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from upsmot02.msn.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with SMTP id GAA13694; Wed, 23 Oct 1996 06:18:33 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from upmajb02.msn.com (upmajb02.msn.com [204.95.110.74]) by upsmot02.msn.com (8.6.8.1/Configuration 4) with SMTP id GAA06521 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 23 Oct 1996 06:16:13 -0700
Date: Wed, 23 Oct 96 12:59:24 UT
From: "Funky Tekno Tribe Sound System " <FunkyTekno@msn.com>
Message-Id: <UPMAIL03.199610231318150835@msn.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: long: Reply from Funky Tekno Tribe to Stinky TeknoTribe, Halloween 
	Tribal Massive, FTT?, etc
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi everyone,
This is in reference to the postings regarding our last big party in May 
(2049:The Dune Kings). We realized that the missing 2nd sound system at our 
party dissapointed many. In particular it caused great distress to us because 
we knew we had let everyone down. I have reprinted (with permission) a public 
apology that appeared in last month's issue of XL8LR magazine from my partner, 
Kevon Banks, regarding what transpired that night. 
Our overriding mission in the 4 years that we've been in existence has always 
been to provide the best music and the best production at a reasonable price. 
We realize that not everyone can afford to pay the $25 charged at our larger 
parties, which is why we have always thrown free parties. To make up for the 
Dune Kings party, we threw the free afternoon LTJ Bukem gig infront of City 
Hall, followed later in the evening with another free gig at Mission Rock. A 
couple of Sundays ago, we also did the 'Organic in the Park'. Many shun 
massives for various valid reasons. FTT hopes that our Halloween Tribal 
Massive this coming Saturday would maybe change their minds. 
We have gone through great lengths to get the best DJs in their respective 
genres. DJ Rap, Nightmares on Wax, Wamdue Kids, Josh Wink and Springheel Jack 
are some of the artists that we are flying out just for this occasion. 
Springheel Jack (my favouriite) will be performing a full live drum and bass 
set. The Quango Music Group crew (Jason Bentley, Bruno Guez, Jun) will also be 
doing their down tempo thing that Quango is well regarded for. We feel that 
musically, Saturday night will be one of eclectic quality. As for your typical 
massive crowd and 'massive' lines, we are going out of our way to keep it to a 
minimal. 
As for the $25 we are charging for the party, we felt it was fair when the 
costs of the space, 4 sound systems, flying the artists here (most from the 
UK) and putting them up in hotels, etc were taken into consideration. The fact 
that there is also a major national surgeon's convention (which jacked up 
hotel prices 3-fold!) in town this weekend did not help our budget.
In closing, I'd like to thank everyone who voiced their opinions about our 
parties, and if you still feel dissatisfied with this lengthy response, feel 
free to email me at this address. The response from Kevon is below.  We 
guarantee you'll have a good time this Saturday. Take care, drive safely and 
see you at the party!!!

Mohan
Funky Tekno Tribe

"The producers of Funky Tekno Tribe would like to apologize to you, and to 
everyone who attended 2049:The Dune Kings event for the absence of the second 
sound system. It is not our intention to advertise an artist or any aspect of 
our shows that will not appear. Although we have been producing events in the 
SF/Bay Area for many years, unfortunately chaos ruled that Saturday May 25th. 
Artist cancellations, power limitations, miscommunications and equipment 
failure seemed to plague this particular event, culminating in what we feel 
was not a typical Funky Tekno Tribe production. Even with all of the mishaps 
that occurred during pre-production no one's sorrow could have matched my own. 
By the time we finally opened, only half of the second sound system had showed 
up.  I hurried back to San Francisco and immediately began calling everyone I 
knew with a sound system.  After several unsuccessful attempts I finally made 
my way back to the warehouse feeling tired and a bit let down. As always the 
music and the crowds energy replenished my spirits and what I felt would be a 
disappointment turned out to be a memorable experience.  In closing Denise, we 
would like you to know that perhaps no one takes their job more personal than 
us.  We feel that it is our responsibility to create an enjoyable dance 
experience for all who attend our events and your disappointment is ours.  By 
the time you read this Denise, the free make-up party will have been scheduled 
and you will be happy to know Darkhorse will be performing. I might also 
suggest attending our annual Halloween Tribal Massive as I can assure you 
maximum time and effort will be expended with hopes of making this year's 
event the best ever.  If anyone would like to contact us for questions or 
comments please e-mail us at Funkytekno@msn.com or write to: Funky Tekno 
tribe, 1388 Haight St. Suite 57, San Francisco CA 94117

Kevon 
Funky Tekno Tribe"

"Let me have silence always in the centre of the shouting, that is
essential. Let me have silence so that no pin may drop and not be
heard, and not a whisper. Escape us for all our spouting, nor the
needle scratching upon this gramophone of the circular cosmic spot.
Hear me, mark me, learn me, throw the mind's ear open. Shut up the
mind's eye, all will be music. What sculpture of sound cannot, what
cannot as a fluid token words, that nothing else cannot." 

						-Wyndham Lewis

On Wed, 23 Oct 1996, Fred Heutte wrote:

> Been there many times.  It's basically an old marina tavern/hangout that's
> been used for years by the club side of the house music scene.  There
> are two floors and an outside deck.  It's kind of a funky picturesque
> place, definitely a dockside deal, no downtown flashiness.  I can't
> say I've ever had a great time there but it's always enjoyable.  
> 
> Do be careful where you park.  Also, I've heard some reports of smashed
> windows and so on in the vicinity.
> 
> One of my sources indicates that Mission Rock
> has an uncertain future due to various legal disputes with the Port --
> not that they've done anything wrong, more like the same old bureaucratic
> hassles.  So check it out before it's history (or even if it doesn't 
> vanish :)
> 
> phred

At 12:49 AM -0700 10/23/96, Fred Heutte wrote:
>Been there many times.  It's basically an old marina tavern/hangout that's
>been used for years by the club side of the house music scene.  There
>are two floors and an outside deck.  It's kind of a funky picturesque
>place, definitely a dockside deal, no downtown flashiness.  I can't
>say I've ever had a great time there but it's always enjoyable.
>
>Do be careful where you park.  Also, I've heard some reports of smashed
>windows and so on in the vicinity.
>
>One of my sources indicates that Mission Rock
>has an uncertain future due to various legal disputes with the Port --
>not that they've done anything wrong, more like the same old bureaucratic
>hassles.  So check it out before it's history (or even if it doesn't
>vanish :)
>
>phred

From: Adam Guevara <aguevara@rely.com>
To: "'Sfraves@hyperreal.com'" <Sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Why Massives are needed...
Date: Wed, 23 Oct 1996 09:24:48 -0700
X-Mailer:  Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.837.3
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hello everyone,

I'd like to post this because... well, because I can.  I

Allthough Im just a DJ, not a promoter or anything, I feel that we're
all sorta missing the concept of "Rave" and "Massive" .  People say, " I
don't go to massives anymore " and I think that's good, it's
progressive.  Our culture are intoduced into the scene by two ways, 
either through friends or massives.  Only those that are "in" hear of
the Sunsets, Friends and Family, F-8, FMR, CCC ect al... Thus it's a
smaller circle (ie. 500-600) that knows of such events.  To be brought
into via friends is great, but, not everybody can come in through this
path...  
The next path is the massive, it's how I was introduced and several of
you out there have posted fond memories of your early rave experiences
through massives...  I go to massives only once a year and try to keep
it varied: Gathering in 95', Cool World in 94', Toon Town (I think) in
93' @ the cow palace, Casper (and Labrayth) in 92'. 91 and 90 were my
years of introduction of the scene so I was constantly going to massives
(it was my only connection to the scene @ the time, and I got in free
most of the time too :) 
The reason I keep on going once a year is to see the "newbies"  and
reaffirm that our vibe is still alive.  
Yea, there are "heads and hoods" but even they can change... It's about
acceptance.  
	And time.  
		And patience.
But, we're in the scene for different reasons wiether it be drugs, sex,
good times, expression, or waking people up...
I love my family and all you belong here, I don't really associate with
you outside of the list mainly because, in a way, many of you are on the
right path.  I focus moreso on those that are looking.  And I know some
are looking @ Massives.  I was.

--Adam
" The sheppard focuses most on the sheep that strays from the flock" 

"Stay Connected..."

     Food for Thought:
     
     Maybe next time some of the advertised entertainment doesn't come 
     through, let people know at the door, and consider cutting the cost of 
     admission accordingly.  All of the people who I heard were pissed 
     about it were pissed because they didn't know till after they paid.  
     
     Sometimes people would have stayed home if it wasn't for that one 
     obscure DJ that they've always wanted to see.  That DJ may be just 
     another DJ to you, but it's what made the $25 expense tolerable to the 
     person who went.
     
     Disneyland posts right at the front gate when a particular ride 
     doesn't work.  You might want to consider following suit.
     
     Peace,
     AndyW

out in the 80's. It's an excellent movie with a twisted sense of humor

Ramirez, Christian P wrote:
>Could someone please give me the 411 on NRR???:)

Non-rave related.  Used to signify topics that are not directly rave 
related.  Some members of our illustrious list have expressed extreme 
displeasure at receiving posts that did not have to do with raving, so this 
prefix was created to allow them to filter out the offending messages.

S


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Oct 23 11:16:58 1996

From: KaySEE <scarab@value.net>

To: Funky Tekno Tribe Sound System <FunkyTekno@msn.com>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: long: Reply from Funky Tekno Tribe to Stinky TeknoTribe, Halloween  Tribal Massive, FTT?, etc
In-Reply-To: <UPMAIL03.199610231318150835@msn.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.95.961023105433.8848A-100000@value.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> musically, Saturday night will be one of eclectic quality. As for your
> typical massive crowd and 'massive' lines, we are going out of our way
> to keep it to a minimal. 

Out of curiousity, I'd like to know how this is possible when the Tribal
Massive is advertised on Live 105?  In the add they say it will be "the
Bay Area's foremost underground experience."  How can something that is
advertised on the biggest commercial radio station in the Bay Area be
called "underground."  Might that not be a misnomer?  But, that's what
marketing is about--using "cool" buzzwords to perpetuate an attitude of
"coolness" so we will all want to buy, buy, buy to conform to an image.

Anyway, this may sound more caustic than I actually mean to be.  Massives
certainly have a clientele that they cater to, and I have no disrespect
for that.  I'm sure the music will be excellent and the party will go off
and tons of people will have a blast.  I've had fun at massives
before, and I'm sure FTT will be a good party for many.  However,
advertising on Live 105 will not keep "the typical massive crowd" to a
minimum.  If anything it perpetuates the "gimme" spectator attitude.  This
happens to be something that, IMO, subtracts from a good vibe.  

Thanks,
Kirsten

I am so F'in stoned right now. You don't even know.


I will defonetly date a Funky chick.
I might see a Stinky chick. (for awhile)
But a Stinky Funky chick. Not gonna do it.


       Anyone reading this, ever think about throwing a ravE?
       Do you want to throw one for the money? Or for the people?


If you want to throw a bigger party for the people. 
Your going to need more money from the people.


If you wanna spend your whole life making parties.
And if you want to spend your whole life broke/bankrupt.

Thats all fine and dandy but. Some people have to make a living.
Just think of the money you spend as if it were your half of the price it
took to get you, and your friends, and everyone else together.

We can't expect these people to just dish out all there money, and except
our thanx.
   I don't have the time to get my own 100,000 square foot harehouse, 30
Dj's from around the world, a huge fat sound system with visual
inneractivity. Just so all of us can be together. "I need to make money!"

Sh!t   My buzz is wearing off... 
I need to find something alittle more interactive quick like.

Later skaters.
Peace out scouts.
Jeff

Hi all- I've been trying to convince my SO about the wonders 
of techno music, and he just refuses to give it much of a chance.  
Unfortunately I don't have any good music to prove my point with, I know 
what I like when I hear it, but I don't know anything about it.
 
I know that if I found the right stuff he would love it....He's really into 
rap, especially Tribe, diggable planets- stuff with a good groove to it..- 
and he loves funk- so I need to find some tapes that will pull
 in some of those elements.. He loves a good beat and goes crazy for a 
thumping base, so once I get our stereo system pumping and the walls 
shaking  I know he will be in the kitchen dancing in his socks with me.

thanks ahead of time!
-jess


p.s. One last question- Halloween is Thursday and after a little bit of a 
dry spell, I'm going to get out and party...so, where is everybody going 
to be?

	Very well put.  I see what you mean...my first rave was a
	massive in SF and was with only 2 of my friends.  Just recently,
	I have entered the "family" raves.  


On Wed, 23 Oct 1996, Adam Guevara wrote:

> 
> Hello everyone,
> 
> I'd like to post this because... well, because I can.  I
> 
> Allthough Im just a DJ, not a promoter or anything, I feel that we're
> all sorta missing the concept of "Rave" and "Massive" .  People say, " I
> don't go to massives anymore " and I think that's good, it's
> progressive.  Our culture are intoduced into the scene by two ways, 
> either through friends or massives.  Only those that are "in" hear of
> the Sunsets, Friends and Family, F-8, FMR, CCC ect al... Thus it's a
> smaller circle (ie. 500-600) that knows of such events.  To be brought
> into via friends is great, but, not everybody can come in through this
> path...  
> The next path is the massive, it's how I was introduced and several of
> you out there have posted fond memories of your early rave experiences
> through massives...  I go to massives only once a year and try to keep
> it varied: Gathering in 95', Cool World in 94', Toon Town (I think) in
> 93' @ the cow palace, Casper (and Labrayth) in 92'. 91 and 90 were my
> years of introduction of the scene so I was constantly going to massives
> (it was my only connection to the scene @ the time, and I got in free
> most of the time too :) 
> The reason I keep on going once a year is to see the "newbies"  and
> reaffirm that our vibe is still alive.  
> Yea, there are "heads and hoods" but even they can change... It's about
> acceptance.  
> 	And time.  
> 		And patience.
> But, we're in the scene for different reasons wiether it be drugs, sex,
> good times, expression, or waking people up...
> I love my family and all you belong here, I don't really associate with
> you outside of the list mainly because, in a way, many of you are on the
> right path.  I focus moreso on those that are looking.  And I know some
> are looking @ Massives.  I was.
> 
> --Adam
> " The sheppard focuses most on the sheep that strays from the flock" 
> 
> "Stay Connected..."
>

From: branka@sirius.com (*B*)
Subject: Diversity is good
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

        By reading this list some people would think that people on the
list are the most sex deprived individuals ;P...

RELAX :) and don't take everything so seriously...

Some people like massives, some people like small parties....
Some people like hugz and sticker, some people get annoyed by them....
Some people like to dress up and pay lost of $$ for designer clothes,
others like used stores clothes....

        Can you imagine how *boring* it would be if all of us were exactly
alike?  Just think about it and don't hit that reply so soon.  We are here
to learn from each other and learn how to respect each other's opinion.  If
*we* (who claim are so concentrated on PLUR) can't do it, how can we expect
other people in the world to do it and make this a pleasant place to live.

Just my thoughts :) (I guess I really don't feel like working today)
*B*

To: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: riddle you this (NRR)
Date: Wed, 23 Oct 96 14:48:16 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> Here's a really cool puzzle to play with on a Monday afternoon--
> what's the only word in the english language that contains the
> letters u-f-a, in that order, somewhere in the word?  
>    (guaranteed to drive you mad for at least 10 minutes, possibly days :)

Using webster(1), xwebster(1) [BSP -- see
http://ftp.sterling.com/usenet/comp.sources.x/volume17/], or telnet...

netcom23-4-~> telnet 128.100.1.105 2627
Trying...
Connected to 128.100.1.105.
Escape character is '^]'.
define *ufa*
WILD
1 calc-tufa
2 chufa
3 manufactory
4 manufacture
5 manufactured gas
6 manufacturer
7 tufa

define calc-tufa
DEFINITION 0
calc-tu-fa or calc-tuff n. A porous or spongy deposit of calcium carbonate 
  found in calcareous mineral springs.[calc(areous) + tufa]

define  chufa
DEFINITION 0
chu-fa n. A sedge, Cyperus esculentus,  native to the Old World, having 
  edible, nutlike tubers.[Sp. chufar,  to make fun of <VLat.* sufilare,  
  var. of Lat. sibilare,  to whistle at]

 define tufa
DEFINITION 0
tu-fa n. 1. The calcareous and siliceous rock deposits of springs, lakes, 
  or ground water. 2. Tuff .[Obs. Ital. <Lat. tofus]-tu-fa'ceous adj.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==

>         Actually it's ADAM, not ATAM.

Or is it ATM? ;)

> There's also and EVE drug somewhere.

That would be the ethyl-derivative of MDMA, i.e. MDEA

> I think E is shit because it covers up all reality with a pretty puffy soft
> little blanket.

So? As long as you are aware of that I don't see the problem.
There are few evil recreational drugs, but there are many evil ways
to use them. It's the people, not the drugs. Perhaps I should make a
sig out of this, I keep repeating it on the list. And by the way,
people don't need drugs to cover up reality with pretty puffy soft
blankets, there are enough people in perfect denial of their actual
situation without the use of chemicals.

> I have a theory on the drugs I've tried, but no need to
> waste time explaining it to whoever, private mail me if you're curious, I
> love explaining things.

Oh don't tease us. I'd say this list is an approriate place for topics
like this. In case of doubt, insert the NRR in front of the subject to
please the netgods.

>
> Aryck
>-- End of excerpt from Aryck

The Frying Dutchman

>The next path is the massive, it's how I was introduced and several of
>you out there have posted fond memories of your early rave experiences
>through massives...  I go to massives only once a year and try to keep
>it varied: Gathering in 95', Cool World in 94', Toon Town (I think) in
>93' @ the cow palace, Casper (and Labrayth) in 92'. 91 and 90 were my
>years of introduction of the scene so I was constantly going to massives
>(it was my only connection to the scene @ the time, and I got in free
>most of the time too :) 


I too was introduced through MASSIVES..and i still like to go to them every
once in a while.  I don't see anything wrong with the size of the event if
it has something to offer that i want. i.e. a dj i can't otherwise see, cool
visuals, to meet some people that don't normally go to "small" parties, etc.
etc.

I also have fond memories of most of the massives that i've gone too.  I
really have had very few bad experiences at massives.  Some of my FAVORITE
parties have been massives, ie all the freedoms, gatherings and candyland at
the drive in movie complex.  I too have really gotten into the smaller party
scene..but i don't particularly have anything against the
massives...well...against most anyways...there are some promoters' (who
shall remain nameless) parties that i won't go to.

How is everybody doing??????

I also want to know who is going to go to the BBQ 3.  Looks like it'll be
FUN and we'll all finally get to meet.

AND...finally.....
I am getting REALLY psyched for the snow thing...i LOVE tahoe, cabins, the
snow, music, snuggling up to warm fires, tearing it up...etc. etc.
OH, and i can offer my dj'ing services for...well...a hug or two or ten. :P
I also have some equipment that i might be bribed into taking up.

much PLUR
Micron

Here is some humor yall.

Ran

>
>
>An old farmer decided it was time to get a new rooster for his hens.
>The current rooster was still doing an okay job, but he was getting on
>in years.
>
>And the farmer figured getting a new rooster couldn't hurt anything.  So
>he buys a young cock from the local rooster emporium, and turns him
>loose in the barn yard.
>
>Well, the old rooster sees the young one strutting around and he gets a
>little worried. So, they're trying to replace me, thinks the old
>rooster.  I've got to do something about this.
>
>He walks up to the new bird and says, "So you're the new stud in town?
>I bet you really think you're hot stuff, don't you?  Well I'm not ready
>for the chopping block yet. I'll bet I'm still the better bird.  And to
>prove it, I challenge you to a race around that hen house over there.
>We'll run around it ten times and whoever finish's first gets to have
>all the hens for himself."
>
>Well, the young rooster was a proud sort, and he definitely thought he
>was more than a match for the old guy.  "You're on," said the young
>rooster.  "And since I know I'm so great, I'll even give you a head
>start of half a lap.  I'll still win easy," said the young rooster.
>
>So the two roosters go over to the hen house to start the race with all
>the hens gathering around to watch.  The race begins and all the hens
>start cheering the roosters on.  After the first lap, the old rooster is
>still maintaining his lead.  After the second lap, the old guy's lead has
>slipped a little but he's still hanging in there. Unfortunately the old
>rooster's lead continues to slip each time around, and by the fifth lap
>he's just barely in front of the young rooster.
>
>By now the farmer has heard all the commotion.  He runs into the house,
>gets his shotgun, and runs out to the barn yard figuring a fox or
>something is after his chickens.  When he gets there, he sees the two
>roosters running around the hen house, with the old rooster still
>slightly in the lead.  He immediately takes his shotgun, aims, fires,
>and blows the young rooster away.
>
>As he walks away slowly, he says to himself........"Damn, that's the
>third gay rooster I've bought this month.

-------------------------------------------------------
Debbie Atwater
Learning Communities, Apple Research Labs
Apple Computer, Inc.
1 Infinite Loop, MS: 301-3E, Cupertino, CA  95014
(w) 408-974-0016, (f) 408-862-6430
atwater@taurus.apple.com

At 05:10 PM 10/23/96 -0700, Dan Capriles wrote:
>
>>The next path is the massive, it's how I was introduced and several of
>>you out there have posted fond memories of your early rave experiences
>>through massives...  I go to massives only once a year and try to keep
>>it varied: Gathering in 95', Cool World in 94', Toon Town (I think) in
>>93' @ the cow palace, Casper (and Labrayth) in 92'. 91 and 90 were my
>>years of introduction of the scene so I was constantly going to massives
>>(it was my only connection to the scene @ the time, and I got in free
>>most of the time too :) 

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

Hey.....My first party was a Massive too...the Let Freedom Rave..July 94...
A fire breaks out on the hillside...Lasers everywhere...and the biggest,
loudest, baddest collection of speakers I had ever seen in one
place..Simon,Josh,Doc Martin, GArth....A Gagzillion WAtts of
power...thump,thump humpin together...the bass lines take over my
heartbeats...clods of earth turn into powder under my feet..

....For me,  Massives are what some of the most ass-kickin' music was
designed to be played on...Big.Bass lines that shake the ground and
vibrations that run down and through and including your pubic hairs...let me
feel those speaker winds blown out by cone forces..I wanna sit on the
speaker cabinets for another butt shakin......

..In front of  BIG BLACK BASS bins...all lined up in a row.(such a pretty
sight).and the hum hum of generators and little blinky lights everywhere...

..I'm dancin all night and I feel like I'm in the Startrek transporter room
getting ready to be beamed up,( I didn't know where)...the sound...the sound
takes me apart atom by atom,...uh,.....I've got myself droolin'.....

Did i say I like it LOUD??????????????Turn it Up..             SpinSilver

At 11:32 PM 10/23/96 -0700, SpinSilver--'Robertj@Monterey' wrote:
>Hey.....My first party was a Massive too...the Let Freedom Rave..July 94...

That was my second.  My most recent massive was the Gathering last winter
(the one with Alex Patterson in the DJ lineup).  Both excellent parties.
There seems to be a pattern here.
Props and other assorted kudos to Martin!

And more props, hugs, and kudos to Brian B, et al, for this list,
which makes it possible for us to find a lot of the smaller parties too.

Harmony 3 may have had enough people to qualify as a massive,
but it sure didn't feel like one, so I don't think any of us are counting it
in this discussion.  Anyone who can put on a party like that has truely
mastered the art of putting on raves.  Lotsa hugs to all @ Harmony!

The Tie-Dyed Side of the Force

Subject: Re: MDMA.  The worst gateway drug?
To: knegtel@horatio.ucsf.EDU (Ronald Knegtel)
Date: Thu, 24 Oct 1996 10:03:41 -0700 (PDT)
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <9610231656.ZM6560@horatio.ucsf.edu> from "Ronald Knegtel" at Oct 23, 96 04:56:08 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL17]
Content-Type: text
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Ronald Knegtel writes...
> So? As long as you are aware of that I don't see the problem.
> There are few evil recreational drugs, but there are many evil ways
> to use them. It's the people, not the drugs. Perhaps I should make a
> sig out of this, I keep repeating it on the list. And by the way,
> people don't need drugs to cover up reality with pretty puffy soft
> blankets, there are enough people in perfect denial of their actual
> situation without the use of chemicals.

i put drugs in two categories

pleasure-producing, habit forming and body harming
	class 1 - harmful if abused over a long period of time
		alcohol, tobacco, pot
	class 2 - use only in moderation - damages brain, etc.
		ecstacy, speed, cocaine
	class 3 - extremely habit forming & damaging - avoid
		opiates

psychedelics
	use in moderation.  bad trips & longterm use can cause psychological
	problems.

the problem is, how do you tell a high school kid, "use in moderation?"
i think that kids should stay away from the harder stuff until college.

Cue for awful joke....

Bill Gates, Andy Grove, and Jerry Sanders are in a high-powered
business meeting.  During the serious, tense discussions, a  beeping
noise suddenly is emitted from where Bill is sitting.  Bill says, "Oh, 
that's  my _emergency_ beeper.  Gentlemen, excuse me, I really need to 
take this call."  
 
So Bill lifts his wristwatch to his ear and begins  talking into the end 
of his tie. After completing this call, he notices the others are staring 
at him. Bill explains, "Oh, this is my new emergency communication
system. I have an  earpiece built into my watch and a microphone
sewn into the end of my tie. That way, I can a take a call anywhere."
The others nod, and the meeting continues.  
 
Five minutes later, the discussion is again interrupted when Andy starts
beeping. He also states, "Oh, that's my emergency beeper.  Excuse me, 
gentlemen, this must be an important call."  So Andy taps his earlobe
and begins talking into thin air. When he completes his call, he notices
the others staring at him and explains,  "I also have an emergency
communication system. But my earpiece is actually implanted in my
earlobe, and the microphone is embedded in this fake tooth. Isn't that
neat?" The others nod, and the meeting continues.   
 
Five minutes later, the discussion is again interrupted when Jerry emits
a thunderous fart.  He looks up at the others staring at him and says, 
"Uhh, somebody get me a piece of paper... I'm receiving a fax."

- --

could get them to go at least as low as $499 (using Guitar Center's price)

Genius Inventor "Dr. Kurono"

experiment after another, just to give an astonishing impact to those

warped. The Time Keepers rush to the spot to find that young people are
sparkling their "minds" with vivid expression and bright laughter. An
entirely new form of communication has emerged.

"GALBO" has been created at ATC, OSAKA MINAMI PORT. "GALBO" is an
utterly new world in a different dimension that one genius inventor
