Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Aryck <mxman@illuminati.heald.edu>
Subject: Aryck's Theories of Expanded concious learning techniques.
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

        Ok, so, please, everyone, whoever has an opinion. . . EXPRESS IT! I
don't want to be the only DORK who thinks that he knows something.

Well, I'm a big thinker. In a past life I was probably a wise man or an
intellectual. I'm constantly thinking of everything that happens to me, or
that goes on in my life.
I don'tt think that I've always been this way, damn, I can recall many many
times where people would tell me to "Think before you act". Now, that's kind
of my rule (actually I can't help it). I like the way I've turned out, and I
owe a lot of it to certain diffirent keys to our conciousness (drugs, but I
don't really call em that).

        Many of you might be more qualified than me to speak of this, but I
did have pschology classes in school, have read a few books on diffirent
drugs, thoroughly searched through drug archives on the web, and have read
any article I could possibly get my hands on. Does that make me qualified?
The chemicals I've experienced are just few, but I've only tried the ones
that I felt I could gain knowledge from, and a couple just to get fuc***
when I was young and stupid. Mushrooms, Acid, MDMA, Alcohol, Marijuana,
Crank, Crack, That stuff from the Robitussin DM, Speed, GHB, and probably
some other stuff. But I'm still looking to try a couple things (just to
expand my knowledge).

        Most drugs are basically useless. These drugs rarely give anything
to you. They just fuc* you up, speed you up, or just make you feel funky
without teaching you anything or giving you asny type of benefit at all. I'd
put Crack, Robitussin, Alcohol, GHB, Speed, Crank, and similar drugs like
Nicotene in this catagory.

        My theory is that diffirent drugs open your mind up to a diffirent
level of conciousness. I think that certain aspects of drugs put you in a
state that makes you think or act a certain way. And most of these drugs,
after you've already come down, leave you with the knowledge of a new way of
thinking or acting. Let me explain.

Marijuana:
         Marijuana is basically just a recreational drug. But to those who
are open to what it does to you, you've probably noticed how it makes you
think when you're loaded. It makes you kind of analytical in a sense. It
makes you think more about people and what they do. Eg: If you and a few
people smoke a couple, when you're all stoned, you'll probably notice things
about these people that you wouldn't normally see, such as certain words
they say over and over, or if that person is a little weird, it accentuates
their strangeness and makes it more aparrent to you. Usually I'll watch a
person and study them, trying to look at the person behind all of the facial
hair, or piercings, or clothes. It makes me think sooo much about people
that I usually am able to seperate the people I really like from the ones
that I don't like too much. It makes me think about how stupid my girlfriend
acts sometimes. I think it brings out peoples annoying traits and makes them
more noticable.

Mushrooms:
        Whoa. . .now mushrooms opened up such a diffirent world to me, it's
impossible to explain exactly what the world is like unless that person is
there with you (y'Know). Mushrooms make you think more about your life, your
religion, your place in this world. I think that's why the native americans
used mushrooms in spiritual rituals. I made me realize everyone's
importance, or lack thereof. It told me who I was, who my friends were, and
who would be with me forever. I guess I could explain it as  being all
knowing, open to the world, and you could solve any problem with just a
couple words. When I ate them with my friends, every person had a charater
about them, and that's who they were from there on. Like, if someone was in
denial or whatever, that's all they would be stuck on, they couldn't get
away from their problems, and all of us others who ate knew it. The
mushrooms put you on a mission, you could travel forever without being
tired, you knew who to bring with you and who to not. And all of my friends
changed after the experience. I think that mushrooms put you on a religious
journey, finding yourself, your friends, and where you're going.

LSD:
        I guess I've had a few diffirent types of acid (or diffirent
strengths). Acid makes you innovative, productive, and kind of like an
inventor always coming up with a new idea  to make something better. It put
you in a diffirent world of thinking. It doesn't vring up new problems, but
it helps you repair existing ones. I've thought the most clearly on Acid,
and it's tought me how to think quickly, and solve problems easily. It makes
you smarter (without abuse), and helps teach you how to think. It brings out
the finest detail in anything, and makes you aware of that. It shows you
things how they really are, makes you realize how things are, and makes you
think about why they are. You'll probably say that "Then why does stuff
melt, and why is everything all so ugly". I guess I really don't have an
answer to that, but everything in the world, no matter how safe, has it's
side effects. It also opens up your creative side, allowing you to talk for
hours on end about a pencil (or whatever), or draw forever. It helps you
express yourself in a way you couldn't before, and it leaves what you've
learned with you after your experience.

MDMA:
        I don't like E too much. I'm usually frying when I see people on E
and it makes me think of how fake it makes you. The only good quality about
E is that it makes you very positive, it makes you love your lover even
more, it makes you sorry for every bad thing you've ever done, it makes you
happy to be who you are without any need for any type of change. These are
good things, but, I think that it covers up the reality of everything with a
soft pretty little blanket. It makes ugly people beautiful, it makes dirty
ass wherehouses the best place in the world, it makes people think that
they're a STAR in the biggest show on earth. I watched this girl intently
once, her name was Jenny, she was really nice n all, but she would go,
dance, then come back and act like the whole world was watching her, like
she was picturing roses flying up on stage, people kissing her telling "Good
show", it misled her into thinking that the Deli (upstairs) was this big
happy cloud in which everyone was kissing and hugging and there wasn't a
problem in the world. I guess that could be cool, but I just think that it's
too fake. I know most of us SFRAVERS E fairly often. Shit, thats where we
get most of our ideas of loving one another and all. But It just makes the
world too unreal, and doesn't teach you anything to deal with the real world
logically. But it can strengthen the love between people, and teach you to
be more compassionate towards others. I've eaten E many times (around 25 or
so) which in reality isn't much, I just don't like how it covers things up.
But I'm not saying that it's bad.


Others:
        I think that all other drugs like Alcohol are prettymuch useless. I
think that Alcohol is a seriously negative drug made to destroy families,
friends, and lives. Crank and Speed just make you get a lot done. Crack
tweaks you to the point to all you care about is you, and is just slightly
better than alcohol. And all that other stupid shit just gets you out of the
world for a certai amount of time and is completely useless and just a
destruction of perfectly good people.

        Again, this is just my personal thoughts on these things. You all
may have diffirent experiences because you're diffirent people, but when
I've talked to my friends, the ideas on the subjects stayed pretty
consistent. So tell me what you think. It's a big world and everyone can
think, so there's no reason to not be able to speak out.

        But without drugs, I wouldn't be as compassionate, thoughtful,
creative, innovative, or wise as I am now. Shit, when I didn't do drugs in
high school, I was an idiot, now I get straight A's in college.

Love ya all (and I'm perfectly sober) 
But even though drugs expand your mind, it doesn't mean that they're good
for you!

Aryck [The Boogie Man]

GRRRrrrrrrrOOOOOOoooowwwwwwWwWWw!

Ok, so, please, everyone, whoever has an opinion. . . EXPRESS IT! I don't
want to be the only DORK who thinks that he knows something.

Well, I'm a big thinker. In a past life I was probably a wise man or an
intellectual. I'm constantly thinking of everything that happens to me, or
that goes on in my life.
I don'tt think that I've always been this way, damn, I can recall many many
times where people would tell me to "Think before you act". Now, that's kind
of my rule (actually I can't help it). I like the way I've turned out, and I
owe a lot of it to certain diffirent keys to our conciousness (drugs, but I
don't really call em that).

        Many of you might be more qualified than me to speak of this, but I
did have pschology classes in school, have read a few books on diffirent
drugs, thoroughly searched through drug archives on the web, and have read
any article I could possibly get my hands on. Does that make me qualified?
The chemicals I've experienced are just few, but I've only tried the ones
that I felt I could gain knowledge from, and a couple just to get fuc***
when I was young and stupid. Mushrooms, Acid, MDMA, Alcohol, Marijuana,
Crank, Crack, That stuff from the Robitussin DM, Speed, GHB, and probably
some other stuff. But I'm still looking to try a couple things (just to
expand my knowledge).

        Most drugs are basically useless. These drugs rarely give anything
to you. They just fuc* you up, speed you up, or just make you feel funky
without teaching you anything or giving you asny type of benefit at all. I'd
put Crack, Robitussin, Alcohol, GHB, Speed, Crank, and similar drugs like
Nicotene in this catagory.

        My theory is that diffirent drugs open your mind up to a diffirent
level of conciousness. I think that certain aspects of drugs put you in a
state that makes you think or act a certain way. And most of these drugs,
after you've already come down, leave you with the knowledge of a new way of
thinking or acting. Let me explain.

Marijuana:
         Marijuana is basically just a recreational drug. But to those who
are open to what it does to you, you've probably noticed how it makes you
think when you're loaded. It makes you kind of analytical in a sense. It
makes you think more about people and what they do. Eg: If you and a few
people smoke a couple, when you're all stoned, you'll probably notice things
about these people that you wouldn't normally see, such as certain words
they say over and over, or if that person is a little weird, it accentuates
their strangeness and makes it more aparrent to you. Usually I'll watch a
person and study them, trying to look at the person behind all of the facial
hair, or piercings, or clothes. It makes me think sooo much about people
that I usually am able to seperate the people I really like from the ones
that I don't like too much. It makes me think about how stupid my girlfriend
acts sometimes. I think it brings out peoples annoying traits and makes them
more noticable.

Mushrooms:
        Whoa. . .now mushrooms opened up such a diffirent world to me, it's
impossible to explain exactly what the world is like unless that person is
there with you (y'Know). Mushrooms make you think more about your life, your
religion, your place in this world. I think that's why the native americans
used mushrooms in spiritual rituals. I made me realize everyone's
importance, or lack thereof. It told me who I was, who my friends were, and
who would be with me forever. I guess I could explain it as  being all
knowing, open to the world, and you could solve any problem with just a
couple words. When I ate them with my friends, every person had a charater
about them, and that's who they were from there on. Like, if someone was in
denial or whatever, that's all they would be stuck on, they couldn't get
away from their problems, and all of us others who ate knew it. The
mushrooms put you on a mission, you could travel forever without being
tired, you knew who to bring with you and who to not. And all of my friends
changed after the experience. I think that mushrooms put you on a religious
journey, finding yourself, your friends, and where you're going.

LSD:
        I guess I've had a few diffirent types of acid (or diffirent
strengths). Acid makes you innovative, productive, and kind of like an
inventor always coming up with a new idea  to make something better. It put
you in a diffirent world of thinking. It doesn't vring up new problems, but
it helps you repair existing ones. I've thought the most clearly on Acid,
and it's tought me how to think quickly, and solve problems easily. It makes
you smarter (without abuse), and helps teach you how to think. It brings out
the finest detail in anything, and makes you aware of that. It shows you
things how they really are, makes you realize how things are, and makes you
think about why they are. You'll probably say that "Then why does stuff
melt, and why is everything all so ugly". I guess I really don't have an
answer to that, but everything in the world, no matter how safe, has it's
side effects. It also opens up your creative side, allowing you to talk for
hours on end about a pencil (or whatever), or draw forever. It helps you
express yourself in a way you couldn't before, and it leaves what you've
learned with you after your experience.

MDMA:
        I don't like E too much. I'm usually frying when I see people on E
and it makes me think of how fake it makes you. The only good quality about
E is that it makes you very positive, it makes you love your lover even
more, it makes you sorry for every bad thing you've ever done, it makes you
happy to be who you are without any need for any type of change. These are
good things, but, I think that it covers up the reality of everything with a
soft pretty little blanket. It makes ugly people beautiful, it makes dirty
ass wherehouses the best place in the world, it makes people think that
they're a STAR in the biggest show on earth. I watched this girl intently
once, her name was Jenny, she was really nice n all, but she would go,
dance, then come back and act like the whole world was watching her, like
she was picturing roses flying up on stage, people kissing her telling "Good
show", it misled her into thinking that the Deli (upstairs) was this big
happy cloud in which everyone was kissing and hugging and there wasn't a
problem in the world. I guess that could be cool, but I just think that it's
too fake. I know most of us SFRAVERS E fairly often. Shit, thats where we
get most of our ideas of loving one another and all. But It just makes the
world too unreal, and doesn't teach you anything to deal with the real world
logically. But it can strengthen the love between people, and teach you to
be more compassionate towards others. I've eaten E many times (around 25 or
so) which in reality isn't much, I just don't like how it covers things up.
But I'm not saying that it's bad.


Others:
        I think that all other drugs like Alcohol are prettymuch useless. I
think that Alcohol is a seriously negative drug made to destroy families,
friends, and lives. Crank and Speed just make you get a lot done. Crack
tweaks you to the point to all you care about is you, and is just slightly
better than alcohol. And all that other stupid shit just gets you out of the
world for a certai amount of time and is completely useless and just a
destruction of perfectly good people.

        Again, this is just my personal thoughts on these things. You all
may have diffirent experiences because you're diffirent people, but when
I've talked to my friends, the ideas on the subjects stayed pretty
consistent. So tell me what you think. It's a big world and everyone can
think, so there's no reason to not be able to speak out.

        But without drugs, I wouldn't be as compassionate, thoughtful,
creative, innovative, or wise as I am now. Shit, when I didn't do drugs in
high school, I was an idiot, now I get straight A's in college.

Love ya all (and I'm perfectly sober) 
But even though drugs expand your mind, it doesn't mean that they're good
for you!

Aryck [The Boogie Man]

Been waitin for the details for this one, and I finally got them.

SAMHAIN 
(prounced Sow'en) (the Celtic Winter Solstice).  

This event will take place 1/2 hour outside Yosemite National Park on
November 2-3.  It will go from 2 pm Saturday through sunset on Sunday.
There will be Trance, Psychedelic Trance and Goa in a sound proof wearhouse,
and ambient/triphop/slow jungle/live music in an outdoor ampatheater.  The
location for the event is a hostile and the promotors have rented the entire
space.  There will be 80 beds available on a first come first serve basis,
and plenty of space for camping so bring tents and sleeping bags if you
got-um.  The owner of the site has required the promotors to rent the whole
space, and is limiting the attendance to 250 people.  Therefore the cost of
the party will be $25.  (They have found no way around this due to the cost
of the site and limit on the attendance, I do know they aren't making any
money off it)  Tickets are available at F8.  There will also be a chakra
expansion, light work ritual at sunrise on Sunday.   I am told that the site
of the event is incredibly beautiful. So:

Trance, Psychedelic Trance, Goa DJ's:

Adam (Ceiba Records)
Anon (Hunab ku)
Dutch (Inner Eye)
Ivo
Max Factor (Shyantra)
Jeremy Starseed

Ambient/idm/slow jungle/live:

Consciousness Lab Ambient Sound Research
RE: (performing live)
Felix the Cat (Black Diamand)
BioJeff
Neal
DE3
Todd (A.D.S.R.)

Lighting/Visuals: Astral Scapes
Sound: Chris Cambell

"Let me have silence always in the centre of the shouting, that is
essential. Let me have silence so that no pin may drop and not be
heard, and not a whisper. Escape us for all our spouting, nor the
needle scratching upon this gramophone of the circular cosmic spot.
Hear me, mark me, learn me, throw the mind's ear open. Shut up the
mind's eye, all will be music. What sculpture of sound cannot, what
cannot as a fluid token words, that nothing else cannot." 

						-Wyndham Lewis

I Picked up the Nov. issue of Wired Magazine with Burning Man on the 
cover.  Opened up to page 205, There's a picture smack dab in the middle 
of the page.  And I'm in it!!  Along with Robert Brown (used to be on the 
list), Jason Greene (on the list) and my buddy Neil!

If you look toward the top right of the picture, you'll see the profile 
of a guy with a blue bandana on his head, thats Robert, directly to the 
left of him wearing a brown jacket is Neil, and a little bit to the left 
of him you'll see half of my face, I'm wearing glasses and a green hat, 
and the head thats covering my face is Jason Green.

Quite a random picture.  This was when the man was burning and we were 
just cruzing thru the crowd.  One thing strange about this article is 
there is not one picture of the man burning......guess the photographer 
left before Sunday night. 

peace,

-M

"Let me have silence always in the centre of the shouting, that is
essential. Let me have silence so that no pin may drop and not be
heard, and not a whisper. Escape us for all our spouting, nor the
needle scratching upon this gramophone of the circular cosmic spot.
Hear me, mark me, learn me, throw the mind's ear open. Shut up the
mind's eye, all will be music. What sculpture of sound cannot, what
cannot as a fluid token words, that nothing else cannot." 

						-Wyndham Lewis


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Oct 24 15:51:21 1996

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Oct 24 15:59:34 1996

Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.95.961024151622.21660A-100000@value.net>

Not with much hesitation do I post the following.  Let me explain...  
This is a little story that I wrote.  I am posting it as a dedication to
the rave scene and in celebration of Halloween.  Raving sparked in me a
creativity that I knew existed, but never acted on.  I've always dreamed
of writing, not to be famous, but rather as a creative outlet.  The
following is a story that came to me while at the Harmony 3-Year.  It's a
bit fictional, a bit biographical.  Maybe you will see yourself in it.
I'm not saying it's great writing, but it was fun and it is the first
creative writing I've done since maybe elementary school!!  I have never
been a humanities major and all my writing has been technical science
writing, so that is a disclaimer.  I am posting it here after much
hesitation because most of my writing occurs on a computer and I started
putting a lot of thoughts down when I joined sfraves.  It isn't terribly
long, but not short either.  I apologize for the taking-up of so much
bandwidth, but it has been a slow day and I thought someone might enjoy
this.  (Nancy also gave me a gentle nudge to do this, otherwise I might
never have sent this)  I still don't believe I am sending this,
but here goes...........  ***(oshit)***

-KaySEE

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Children of the Night


As the sun sets, I come alive; awakened by the darkness, entranced by the
full moon.  I feel the hunger inside of me, calling me from afar,
sharpening my senses.  

I dawn my flashy apparel, my bright colors, making up in darkness for what
I miss in the light.  I truly shine.  I pick up the phone and call the
number, being drawn more and more by my hunger.  A beat heard over the
phone and some wispy directions teases the pain inside of me, churns it
until my viscera ache and my brain throbs.  I am restless, waiting,
pondering that moment of bliss.  The ache grows, the hunger I cannot
withstand any longer.

I leave my habitation quietly, leaving behind a small, almost unnoticeable
trail of glitter and the tic-tac of platforms on a stairwell.  No one
notices except for the boy at the corner store.  He sees me every night I
leave, the gleam of knowledge in his eye.  He shares my hunger as well and
often accompanies me on my excursions into the shimmering night.  But, not
tonight, material needs harken him now.

As I climb into my car, adjusting the seatbelt, I reach for the 
radio, desperately searching for a few beats. 
"Please," I say, "just one," I can't stand this hunger any longer.
Although, I know, to whet my appetite is to sharpen the pain.  Yet, I
can't hold back.  Almost shaking with worry that nothing will come
through, I find some sound glowing through intermittent static.
Good enough, it will assuage that empty hole in my gut temporarily.

I pull my dusty, run-down car out onto the city streets that are almost
empty at this time of night.  Gently, I accelerate and head towards my
destination, the place where I will be able to satiate my hunger for
the time being.  But, it will return with a vengeance, this  hunger
of mine.  I can never truly rid myself of it.  It calls to me from afar,
calling through the moonlit streets, sifting through the gutters with its
mechanical voice.

Turning the corner, I see the greenish light with its iridescent glow, a
beacon to us, the sons and daughters of the night skies.  I park and
head for the light.  The air about me hums with the presence of others of
my kind.  The bright colors of their clothing are clearly visible, an
announcement of their pride.  I move slowly, yet eagerly towards the light
with a determined step,  The movement of the air rustles through my hair,
sending shivers down my spine.  Coupled with the anticipation, my nerves
are electric.  I take a deep breath and enter the doorway below the green
light.

All of a sudden I've entered another world; passed through the Wardrobe.
As the Mad Hatter skims past me, Alice greets me warmly at
the door with a kind smile.  Overpowered by my hunger, I
hadn't noticed the mass of my kind surrounding me, pushing, desiring for
the ritual to begin.  I quickly pay for the trip into this alien landscape
that has become familiar to me in the past months.

Gliding through the entrance, my hunger pauses as I shift dreamily into
recollections of my initiation into this world.  I recall the fear of the
unknown being pushed aside by the desire to transcend my ordinary
existence.  My knowing friends had been savvy to these rites for months
and years.  It seemed so casual to them, like an extension of their aura.
Me, on the other hand, was I not a bumbling idiot?  What if I'm not
accepted?  They are so graceful in their movements, so blissful.  How can
I ever earn my rites of passage?  All of these memories swirl in my head
like a crisp autumn leave caught in a whirlwind.  "Funny," I think, "how
everything fell into place."  I was so ignorant to think I couldn't be one
of them, anyone can.  All you have to do is love yourself.

The walls are vibrating as they muffle the huge soundwaves passing
through.  Entering the main room, I am met by an overwhelming blast of hot
air, heavy with the breath and sweat of those joined here to become one.
The juxtaposition of an almighty heaven and a hedonistic hell.

The music is coming from the enormous speakers against the walls.  There
are bodies everywhere, twitching with incalculable delight.  I peer across
the undulating mass of human forms with a certain reverence.  My kind, my
brothers and sisters of the darkness.  With a silent woosh the lasers
sweep across the crowd, playing with the musky, smoky air; astounding even
the disbelievers.  The music is brilliant, generating an amorphous quality
that, once you grasp it, slips away only to be chased again.

The others are simply beautiful.  They are dressed in radiant colors and
lights, reminiscent of Monet.  There is a beauty to be found here in this
dilapidated warehouse.  We are at the turn of the century and technology
is used to its best to find beauty where nothing but decay exists.  Is
this the innovation of the young, of the next generation?  Or
is this the left-overs from the fore-fathers who have taken all and left
little?

I step onto the dancefloor to join the others.  As the music
pervades my body, I begin feeding.  Feeding off the beats. Manipulating
them with my body until they are mine.  The whole inside of me begins to
fill.  Every vein and artery, every nerve, sways with the power of my
nourishment.  Once my soul is replete, a profound happiness will settle
over my being and will last until, from sheer exhaustion, I can dance no
more.

Me, borne to the night, a raver, an intrepid vampire whose sustenance is
music.  My giddiness is contagious; it spreads to him and to her and back
again.  The magnificent infinitesimal circle of life; a crazy eight
filtering the minds of the masses.

In this existence I feel the pain of time passing.  I see the second hand
of the world before my eyes turning slowly, then quicker, then spiraling
until the future cometh.  The present becomes the past too quickly.  Thine
enemy of the dance world has come.  The hazy shades of early morning
arrive.  The sun pushes through the atmosphere with a persistence
unbeknownst to the night.

Glowing with a profound fullness, having made my special connection with
my fellow partners in crime, we end our night's journey in a stunned
satisfaction.  We dissipate with the last remaining shadows.  Back to our
houses, back to pretending we know what normal existence is.  The hunger
never leaves us, like the vampire of yore, we will be called again and
again.  For that inexplicable emptiness of our meager insides never
leaves.  Like a sieve, it empties before it fills.  As we pull the
blankets over our heads to ponder the memories of the night before, we
dream of our parallel existence.  But we are saddened.  For the universe
is endless, but the night is not.

Andy Wyszkowski wrote:

> Actually, I just called Guitar Center. They have a "sale" right now on new
> 1200s: $499.00.

Here's Top Secret info on Technics SL1200's:

The current cost to retailers is $374 or less per piece

The average cost of needles is 40 to 75 pts.

That means a Stanton 500el that costs $29 actually only costs the dealer
about $11 to $15. an Orthophon Night Club Kit at $225 retail only costs
the dealer about $100. Most sales people are out to get $$$comm and will
easily bend to price beats. In the South bay, use "SOUNDYNAMIX" on Tully
Rd., SJ,  as a source for a price beat.. There's not much of a profit
margin on the part of the 1200s (due to committed production in Japan),
but at least that gives you ammunition to use on the sales floor. If
this doesn't work, let me know and I'll conduct a seance to possess that
salesf@#%k with ultra-vibe!

NO raver deserves to pay full price for good music.

praying for FnF this Halloween,

Terry

Hi,
This is going to be a BLATANT plug, so don't read on if you don't want to...
Funky Tekno Tribe's Graeme remixed that particular single, so if you want to 
watch him play that single live... come this Saturday.... Here are some 
reviews of it....

Mohan
Funky Tekno Tribe

E.T.I vs Graeme
Baby Rise/Blue Dreamers
Oboro/US/12
Well, well, well Oboro number two is on its way to destroy a dance floor near 
you. This will be a massive summer party track that will outlive summer into 
Fall and beyond. Busybodies E.T.I and the other half of the Robbers of 
Antiquity, DJ Graeme are the perfect combination on this serious two track 
adventure. "Blue Dreamers" is the superfly, beatboxing, old school electro 
sounding jammie that is ooohhh sooooo fresh! "Baby Rise" is a slammin 
subsonic, backbreaking beat offering that is subsonic to say the least. 
Massive potential with this release, find this, buy this record, even if its 
your last five dollars, you will thank me later.
-Ryno XLR8R Magazine

Tori Amos Makes Her Way Underground
Anthem house bigwig BT and singer Tori Amos have collaborated on a single 
together to be out on Reprise/WEA. Big deal, right? Well, through the earlier 
success of the Robbers of Antiquity record Nocturnal, the San Francisco duo 
Graeme "La Paix" and Darin Marshall were asked to remix the track. Half of the 
Robbers, Darin decided to skip the project while Graeme hooked up with another 
local outfit currently slammin out the jams, ETI. So ETI and Graeme got 
together and pumped out their version of Blue Skies which in Graemes words 
isnt as pretty as BTs original, "its much more snappy, with an upbeat 
hardhouse feel to it, kinda funky and warmer with a breakbeat." ETI have also 
seen recent success with their collaboration with Wickeds DJ Garth on the 
track 7 Minutes of Disco Glory. Graeme and ETI have released Baby Rise/Blue 
Dreamers on Oboro together earlier this month and are sitting tight, waiting 
to hear when their remix will be released.
-XLR8R Magazine



----------
From: 	owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com on behalf of Todd Manley/Santa Clara/HDS
Sent: 	Wednesday, October 23, 1996 3:51 PM
To: 	sfraves
Subject: 	Any Tori Amos/BT fans out there?

Hi-

 I was listening to Live 105 last night and they played the new Tori Amos/BT 
song "Blue Skys".  Has anyone else heard it, and if so do you know where I 
could possibly get this on vinyl.  The release date is supposed to be sometime 

in November, but I know it's been getting some major play over in the UK.

-Thanks, Todd

There are a couple of full moon parties tomorrow night (hope it stops
raining by then), then a free park party on Saturday afternoon, then
the massive Funky Tekno Tribe.  There just might be something else
going on Saturday as well, if you keep your eyes and ears open ;).

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday morning 9am-11am - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon - Beats, Breakz
       and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford).
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench. Varied techno sub-genres, noise, spoken word, world
       music. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

   For a _search_ interface to the calendar, see the Late Train club
   section (http://www.latetrain.com/clubs/).
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

In <some_silly_message_id>, Eric Pederson wrote:


>	class 2 - use only in moderation - damages brain, etc.
>		ecstacy, speed, cocaine

	I can say nothing about the second two, but as for MDMA, your
characterization of "brain damaging" is a bit different from most of
the research that has been done (though no usuable data has been
collected from studies on humans since the FDA scheduled MDMA in 85 or
86, I forget which). So far, the results that have come from studies
on rats and monkeys is that MDMA causes nerves in the brain stem (I
believe) to form abnormally. Now, no one knows how the brain works,
so no one knows if this is damage or just a different formation. We
as humans, have not come to understand how the networks of nerve cells
in our brains map to thought processes or "normal" behavior, if there
is any correlation at all... Until that time, it will be difficult to
same whether these changes are harmful to us as humans, harmful to
maintaining the current society, or just harmful to someone's
wallet...


>the problem is, how do you tell a high school kid, "use in
>moderation?"
>i think that kids should stay away from the harder stuff until
>college.

	How do any of us know what "moderation" is? High school is
one of those arbitary lines that we can draw, but the real problem is
not age, but maturity or that lovely term for which everyone
seems to have a different definition - personal responsibility. Maybe
I should start using the term presonal accountibility. I had a talk
today with a cop who works with the DARE program in Nevada, and worked
with it in a form that I thought was the most responsible approach the
DARE program has taken yet. He had said their main objective was to
work with kids to increase their self esteem and commiunication skills.
This is suppose to curtail kids being pressured into drugs. He said
the old "Just say NO" campaign is out dated. So what distinguishes a
high school drug user from a college drug user? Nothing in a lot of
cases...

	Anyway, I have spewed on this topic often enough, as well as
others topics concerning personal responsibility for I deal it is
a quality everyone who goes out to parties must have (at least for the
type of parties that really go off which are the ones I want to
attend).
 
dave

Received: from aeternitas.cis.yale.edu (root@aeternitas.cis.yale.edu [130.132.143.31]) by janus.cis.yale.edu (8.7.6/8.7.3) with ESMTP id BAA16252; Fri, 25 Oct 1996 01:05:11 -0400 (EDT)
Received: from [130.132.160.24] (net160-24.student.yale.edu [130.132.160.24]) by aeternitas.cis.yale.edu (8.7.6/8.7.3) with ESMTP id BAA01598; Fri, 25 Oct 1996 01:05:06 -0400 (EDT)

At 4:23 AM +0000 10/25/96, Dave Bayer wrote:

>	I can say nothing about the second two, but as for MDMA, your
>characterization of "brain damaging" is a bit different from most of
>the research that has been done (though no usuable data has been
>collected from studies on humans since the FDA scheduled MDMA in 85 or
>86, I forget which). So far, the results that have come from studies
>on rats and monkeys is that MDMA causes nerves in the brain stem (I
>believe) to form abnormally. Now, no one knows how the brain works,
>so no one knows if this is damage or just a different formation. We
>as humans, have not come to understand how the networks of nerve cells
>in our brains map to thought processes or "normal" behavior, if there
>is any correlation at all... Until that time, it will be difficult to
>same whether these changes are harmful to us as humans, harmful to
>maintaining the current society, or just harmful to someone's
>wallet...
>

I don't post too much on the list, but i thought i would add my little 2
cents here just for information's sake :)

I would argue with you here Dave.   There have been a number of studies
done on human brains of people who have died in England of supposed E
overdoses, and they have found a degeneration of nerves in them, just as
was seen in the latest study by Ricaurte et al published last fall.  The
Ricaurte studies proved the MDMA caused serotonergic neurons in the brain
to degenerate, and although some did grow back, they never grew back to the
same location.  Because serotonergic neurons are known to have an effect on
mood and the like, it can be safely assumed that this restructuring of the
brain's connections would have some sort of affect on a person's mental
state.

There have also been a number of case studies where doctors have followed
kids who have claimed to have mood changes as a result of ecstasy
overusage.  Some of the people studied also had used large amounts of lsd.
Point is that they were overusing the drugs, and abuse of something like
that has its consequences.

The facts are out there.  Talk to anyone who uses e a lot, and they will
tell you they have noticed changes in their personalities as well....that
is unless they've gone crazy already :P

I am not saying here that one hit of e will totally change a person's life
forever, but i do think people ought to realize that it isn't the wonder
drug of the twentieth century either.  It has ups AND downs, and as long as
you realize that each time you take a hit, you put yourself on a coaster
ride that can go either way up or way down, then you're being a bit more
realistic.



>	How do any of us know what "moderation" is? High school is
>one of those arbitary lines that we can draw, but the real problem is
>not age, but maturity or that lovely term for which everyone
>seems to have a different definition - personal responsibility. Maybe
>I should start using the term presonal accountibility. I had a talk
>today with a cop who works with the DARE program in Nevada, and worked
>with it in a form that I thought was the most responsible approach the
>DARE program has taken yet. He had said their main objective was to
>work with kids to increase their self esteem and commiunication skills.
>This is suppose to curtail kids being pressured into drugs. He said
>the old "Just say NO" campaign is out dated. So what distinguishes a
>high school drug user from a college drug user? Nothing in a lot of
>cases...

Good point, i think that maturity is the key, not age.  Too bad one can't
easily tell who is mature enough to handle certain situations and who isn't
till after they get into them...

Oh, well, enough cheese.   Hope you're all having fun in california :P
cant wait till christmas :) :)

Peace,

Rob McCord

"Let me have silence always in the centre of the shouting, that is
essential. Let me have silence so that no pin may drop and not be
heard, and not a whisper. Escape us for all our spouting, nor the
needle scratching upon this gramophone of the circular cosmic spot.
Hear me, mark me, learn me, throw the mind's ear open. Shut up the
mind's eye, all will be music. What sculpture of sound cannot, what
cannot as a fluid token words, that nothing else cannot." 

						-Wyndham Lewis

Subject: Re: massives of the past...
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9610221031.A29063-0100000@saclink3.csus.edu>

I know what you mean.  To me, the parties that I help put on in England
with Spiral Tribe and Bedlam in
91/92 was the best time of my life. 2-3,000 people a week, E that makes E
round here seem like a sugar sweet, completely free and a vibe that was so
strong that it was like getting hit on the side of the head with a cricket
bat.  And then I came over here and started to go to the full-moon parties
on Bonny Dune Beach.  Man, those were really good parties: 1,000 people
and a beautiful vibe with beautiful music; exellent LSD as well.  It was
enough to impress me and I am very hard to impress.  Then the last
full-moon rave I went to only had about fifty people there and I thought
that was sad.  Where did all the people go?  Ah well, at least there are
still Sunset parties (which are beautiful in their own way) but some how
the massive of the vibe is not what it once was.  Although I felt that it
might be on it's way back when I done the Canibus Buyers Club.
But, while it may (sadly) be true that the vibe, for some of us, was not
the same as it was, this is actually a very negative view of the scene.
One should always have the attitude, whether it's about the rave scene or
indded any scene that one is involved in, that the best of it is always
just around the corner.
Tristan.

Dave Bayer writes...
> 
> In <some_silly_message_id>, Eric Pederson wrote:
> 
> 
> >	class 2 - use only in moderation - damages brain, etc.
> >		ecstacy, speed, cocaine
> 
> 	I can say nothing about the second two, but as for MDMA, your
> characterization of "brain damaging" is a bit different from most of
> the research that has been done (though no usuable data has been
> collected from studies on humans since the FDA scheduled MDMA in 85 or
> 86, I forget which). So far, the results that have come from studies
> on rats and monkeys is that MDMA causes nerves in the brain stem (I
> believe) to form abnormally. Now, no one knows how the brain works,
> so no one knows if this is damage or just a different formation. We
> as humans, have not come to understand how the networks of nerve cells
> in our brains map to thought processes or "normal" behavior, if there
> is any correlation at all... Until that time, it will be difficult to
> same whether these changes are harmful to us as humans, harmful to
> maintaining the current society, or just harmful to someone's
> wallet...

the monkey studies have shown that serotonin receptors get
damaged.  sure, there hasn't been a lot of conclusive proof in
humans, but you betcha that within 3-5 years there will be.  i'm not
saying don't take e. i'm just saying be careful, don't overdo it.
it *will* damage your brain and/or your liver.

i will repost an informative post someone did last year about
the hows and whys, and how you can possibly prevent such damage
(your mileage may vary).

> >the problem is, how do you tell a high school kid, "use in
> >moderation?"
> >i think that kids should stay away from the harder stuff until
> >college.
> 
> 	How do any of us know what "moderation" is? High school is
> one of those arbitary lines that we can draw, but the real problem is
> not age, but maturity or that lovely term for which everyone
> seems to have a different definition - personal responsibility. Maybe
> I should start using the term presonal accountibility. I had a talk
> today with a cop who works with the DARE program in Nevada, and worked
> with it in a form that I thought was the most responsible approach the
> DARE program has taken yet. He had said their main objective was to
> work with kids to increase their self esteem and commiunication skills.
> This is suppose to curtail kids being pressured into drugs. He said
> the old "Just say NO" campaign is out dated. So what distinguishes a
> high school drug user from a college drug user? Nothing in a lot of
> cases...

you're right of course, it's hard to draw an arbitrary line.  the
same goes for beer.  some high school kids are ready for it, some aren't.
in general i think they can and should probably live without "hard drugs"
until they are out of HS.

J&R Music and Computers in NYC is selling 1200's for $479.95. However,
if you know of a lower price, they will match it. If you're feeling
really cocky, make up some price, make up a store selling at that
price, give some friends's number who can pretend to be that store, and
give it a try :-). The big advantage is that J&R is in NYC, so you save
on the 8.5% sales tax (which is like $85.00 for $1000.00 o'
turntables). Of course, you have to pay 3% shipping for any "heavy"
items like turntables, but that still saves you 5.5% over what you'd
pay in CA. They also sell mixers (Gemini, Audio Technica, Pioneer),
phono carts,  headphones (Sony MdrV6 -- $69.95), etc. I bought my
Pioneer CDJ-500mkII and CDM-500 plus a road case from them at a price
that was many hundreds of $$$ less than any local shops, and cheaper
than that ProSound ripoff place in LA too, without the lame/rude LA
attitude (yes, it's true, i prefer NYC attitude to LA attitude!).
They're a reputable establishment and  they have a decent
return/defective policy as well. 1-800-221-8180

Precedence: bulk

***********************
Top ten reasons the "Wired" IPO ran into trouble

10. Investors discovered it was a publishing company
9.  HotBot: toy car or search engine?
8.  "Wired" too hip for NASDAQ and AMEX, wants to start
    own exchange
7.  Geeks and suits: not a happy mix
6.  Too many of Hotwired's cocktails
5.  A big mix-up: investors kept going to www.howtired.com
    instead
4.  Top investors spent all their money on snowboards;
    none left for stock
3.  Wired's ticker symbol, SUCK, turning people off
2.  Expected investors to pay with e-cash
1.  Nobody could read the prospectus: printed in blue
    ink on red paper

Apologies, and best wishes, to Wired (symbol: WWWW).

     http://www.hotwired.com/

***********************

Greetings Friends!

There will be a Friends & Family this Saturday. Before giving you the
details I just wanted to address the following.

  It is in no way our intention to be elitist, superunderground or whatever.

  It is however our firmest intention to manage our parties, and
expectations surrounding them
  responsibly.

Up until this morning, we did not have everything we needed (like
insurance) and hence the party was at best 50/50 for happening, which is
why, despite the fact that we continued planning for it, we did not
announce it publicly. This is also why tickets have not been available.

Two effects of having to pull this together on such short notice are

 a) due to space constraints, there will be less total tickets available
for this party and
 b) we will not be able to do mail order etc, ie tickets will be harder to get

This is not how we'd like it be, but simply How It Is given the
circumstances.  Once again our sincerest apologies to those who want a
ticket and don't end up with one.

So, roughly 300 tickets will be available in the east bay Saturday at 4pm.
They will probaly sell out in a half hour or less, so I'd plan on being
there at 4 on the nose or earlier. There will be a maximum of 4 tickets
sold per person. Suggested donation is $5 though if you care to donate more
you're certainly welcome, and truth be told we could use it this time. The
exact location will go on our VMs at 11am Saturday, however once again,
tickets will not arrive at the location until 4pm.

There will be no tickets at the venue, a map point will be used to check
tickets.

415.281.9432  415.985.7187

hope to see you there =)
ethan

----forwarded message----

Date: 25 Oct 96 08:39:42
From:"MEWONG.US.ORACLE.COM" <MEWONG.US.ORACLE.COM>

A friend forwarded this...thought you all might enjoy it. 
 
/marian 
 
************************ 
 
DILBERT'S LAWS OF WORK 
  
  
 If you can't get your work done in the first 24 hours, work nights. 
  
 A pat on the back is only a few centimeters from a kick in the butt. 
  
 Don't be irreplaceable, if you can't be replaced, you can't be 
 promoted. 
  
 It doesn't matter what you do, it only matters what you say you've 
 done and what you're going to do. 
  
 After any salary raise, you will have less money at the end of the 
 month than you did before. 
  
 The more crap you put up with, the more crap you are going to get. 
  
 You can go anywhere you want if you look serious and carry a 
 clipboard. 
  
 Eat one live toad the first thing in the morning and nothing worse 
 will happen to you the rest of the day. 
  
 When the bosses talk about improving productivity, they are never 
 talking about themselves. 
  
 If at first you don't succeed, try again. Then quit. No use being a 
 damn fool about it. 
  
 There will always be beer cans rolling on the floor of your car when 
 the boss asks for a ride home from the office. 
  
 Keep your boss's boss off your boss's back. 
  
 Everything can be filed under "miscellaneous." 
  
 Never delay the ending of a meeting or the beginning of a cocktail 
 hour. 
  
 To err is human, to forgive is not our policy. 
  
 Anyone can do any amount of work provided it isn't the work he/she is 
 supposed to be doing. 
  
 Important letters that contain no errors will develop errors in the 
 mail. 
  
 If you are good, you will be assigned all the work. If you are really 
 good, you will get out of it. 
  
 You are always doing something marginal when the boss drops by your 
 desk. 
  
 People who go to conferences are the ones who shouldn't. 
  
 If it wasn't for the last minute, nothing would get done. 
  
 At work, the authority of a person is inversely proportional to the 
 number of pens that person is carrying. 
  
 When you don't know what to do, walk fast and look worried. 
  
 Following the rules will not get the job done. 
  
 Getting the job done is no excuse for not following the rules. 
  
 When confronted by a difficult problem you can solve it more easily 
 by reducing it to the question, "How would the Lone Ranger handle this?" 
  
 No matter how much you do, you never do enough. 
  
 The last person that quit or was fired will be held responsible for 
 everything that goes wrong. 

----end of forwarded message----

--
Steve Simitzis | simitzis@netcom.com saturn5@cyborganic.net | "Hup!" - R. Crumb
 | simitzis /sim' - i - jees/ (n) an unpronounceable string of random letters |
     | Oracle Server Technologies - it's not just a job, it's a wardrobe |
            | operators are standing by : 415-626-5074 (H/VM->P) |

While everyone is talking about MDMA, I'd thought I'd slip this in.

A few months ago I had a very informative discussion about MDMA with my
doctor. One thing that I was not aware of that he mentioned was that
when people with ADD (like myself) have lowered Dophamine (sp?) levels,
their 'ADD like habits' are increased. 

MDMA is known to lower Dophamine levels as well as seritonin.

Consequently I haven't taken e scence then. 

-=Pengo=-
Blake "Pengo" Merriam

"Dosen't it seem ironic to anyone that life on Mars was discovered in a
Martian rock on earth; meaning that life on Mars made the voyage to
earth 1st?!?"

-Me

On Fri, Oct 25, 1996 8:11:46 AM  at TRISTAN BERNARD BLAUG wrote: 
 
>I know what you mean.  To me, the parties that I help put on in England 
>with Spiral Tribe and Bedlam in 
>91/92 was the best time of my life. 2-3,000 people a week, E that makes E 
>round here seem like a sugar sweet, completely free and a vibe that was so

>strong that it was like getting hit on the side of the head with a cricket

>bat.  And then I came over here and started to go to the full-moon parties

>on Bonny Dune Beach.  Man, those were really good parties: 1,000 people 
>and a beautiful vibe with beautiful music; exellent LSD as well.  It was 
>enough to impress me and I am very hard to impress.  Then the last 
>full-moon rave I went to only had about fifty people there and I thought 
>that was sad.  Where did all the people go?  Ah well, at least there are 
>still Sunset parties (which are beautiful in their own way) but some how 
>the massive of the vibe is not what it once was.  Although I felt that it 
>might be on it's way back when I done the Canibus Buyers Club. 
>But, while it may (sadly) be true that the vibe, for some of us, was not 
>the same as it was, this is actually a very negative view of the scene. 
>One should always have the attitude, whether it's about the rave scene or 
>indded any scene that one is involved in, that the best of it is always 
>just around the corner. 
>Tristan. 
 
My introduction to Raving and undergroud DJ'ing was in L.A. in 1990 and all
I used to hear was SF, SF, SF, it's the shit (as in good)......so I finally
came up to check out a full moon party at candlestick park (the one with
the violent ending.......) 
 
I was blown away by the tribal funky house sound that Garth played........
as L.A. was predominately Techno at the time, this was a new sound and vibe
for me....... I was never the same ever again........  
 
I actually decided that night to move to SF and it took about 6 months to
fully move my life......... I arrived in aug of 92 and for about 8 months I
was totally happy and inspired and everything seemed so good.......... 
 
but around summer of 93 things just seemed stale, weird, and got
strange........ for a while I thought it was the scene.........after a
while longer I thought it was me........ it turned out it was both........ 
 
I have spent 3 years searching for the vibe and every 3 months or so I
would find it........ but not with the regularity I was used to or happy
with. I actually gave up and "retired"from performing  but deep down
inside, I really wanted to be DJ'ing and I discovered it was a passion I
could not walk away from........ 
 
I went last year to the haight street fair and ran into greg & cindy (FnF),
and through them I worked with FnF and also worked with the new moon party,
and then I did a full moon, and I began to feel the vibe in SF was getting
better.......... and it has......the power structure seemed to be  moving
hands........as younger promoters began to throw parties.......... some
really cool parties and new vibes in S.F. has given me hope that the future
is in good hands. parties like Harmony, CCC, Cloud Factory, Gateway, Spaz &
Sunsets have taken over the vibe that Wicked used to have with there full
moon parties. 
 
I personally find most massives to be rather formula oriented and depending
on the promoters can be good or bad....... I have only attended one
gathering, DJ'd at one cool world, did a FTT (before they called it FTT),
and basically find I'm happier associating with parties no bigger than 750
people.......... 
 
since my return to S.F. after a summer in the UK, I found I was no longer
inspired by S.F. (after an insane & totally inspired visit to London), and
I decided after 2 weeks to move back to the UK. (I was originally born in
London), so I am legal there and it seemed a syncrinisitus place to be for
me at this time...... like a coming home, only better as I have developed a
lifestyle that is reminicent of rave culture UK circa 88/89. 
 
I found the vibe I was looking for in London this summer, and my heart &
soul is into moving there now.....I hope whether you are into small parties
or massives that you find the vibe you are all looking for.....  
 
I find travelling & moving from city to city (and now country to country)
seems to rejuvinate my sence of excitement and I find I am part of a bigger
family and picture than "the S.F scene" can offer me........ meeting fellow
clubbers & DJ's etc in other parts of the world and being invited to cool
vibe parties is the essence of what the music and scene is all
about......... to inspire others in other places, to be inspired by others
in other places, is what can I say ......inspirational..... 
 
I hope this puts to rest any rumors or attitudes people have of me that
reflect in a negative way.......I have always been my own worst enemy and I
find I mirror peoples emotions......if you are cool, calm, respectful and
kind, I tend to be the same........ 
 
...........if you are nasty, vile, and derogitory, I reflect back on you
that same negative energy......... it is a weakness I try to overcome, and
I try not to associate with people that take me down that ugly road.......
As I did a few weeks ago here on SFRaves........ 
 
I would like to close out by appologizing publically to Mr stuff and all
the other fine members of SFRaves. I have been under a lot of stress lately
and Mr Stuff just pushed my buttons.......... and I responded like a puppet
on a string........... 
 
If anyone comes to London, please look me up and I can help you to find the
vibe in London etc......I will be hopefully changing my e-mail address to 
 
 MOONPUP@CLUB.NET  
 
(I am just waiting for the official word from Wayne)...... I will post that
in the next day or two when it becomes official..........  
 
for those that want tapes, you need to call and sort it out..........like
now........ as I am running out of time......... there will be no tapes
made after Oct 31st and I leave Nov 2nd for London..........call me
@415-337-666 or e-mail me  
 
MOONPUP

Hey guys,
       (Just one last post before I log off of sfraves for another two
semesters.)

           This is a great post about how to stop E Neurotoxicity!

        After reading that thread about the reorginazation of neurons,
I thought I'd put in a little bit of my knowledge and opinion. I've 
basically spent most of my free time this summer reading the current 
journal articles on MDMA, and I'm a junior chemist at Harvey Mudd College 
(which btw, has a pretty cool scene here...), so I THINK I am somewhat 
reliable of a source (though I am always learning, just like everyone else)

        If you don't like boring scientific brain stuff, just skip to the
        end for answers on how to stop E neurotoxicity. There are actually a
        lot of really effective things you can do, and I've tried to list
        all that I know of (I'm sure there are more things...).

Q: What does E do?
A: It causes the massive release of serotonin from serotonergic presynaptic
neurons. Basically the neurons terminals that contain serotonin as their
neurotransmitter are caused to fire (ie. release serotonin into the synapse)
by MDMA. 
A very simplistic view of serotonin might describe it as the "happy
neurotransmitter," since low levels of it are associated with
depression. After this massive release your body probably cannot recollect
all of your serotonin (some gets degraded, some just floats away). Hence
your serotonin levels drop.

Q: What else does E do?
A: It inhibits TPH, tryptophan hydroxylase. This enzyme is the first of two
steps which transforms tryptophan (an amino acid) to serotonin. Hence new
production of serotonin is halted (or at least slowed down signifigantly).

Q: Is this what causes depression the next day?
A: Most likely, yes. After a night in which a chemical has caused the
massive release of serotonin into the synapse, and then significantly slowed
the new production of serotonin, your serotonin levels are likely to be
markedly lowered.

Q: Is MDMA neurotoxic?
A: Yes. It selectively degeneretes (note - it does NOT kill, as far as we
know) serotonin neuron terminals. In experiments on monkeys, after stopping
MDMA use for approx a year, the neuron terminals were found to
regenerate. 

MY THEORY - It's at this point that the serotonergic neuron terminals grow 
back to the wrong place, hence causing the abnormal connections we were just
reading about in the "Rave Drug May Damage Brain...." or whatever. But this
is just my theory on things...

Q: What causes the neurotoxicity?
A: This one's a doozy.....  After the serotonin has binded to the receptor
on the other side of the synpapse (the post-synaptic neuron), there is a 
reuptake pump (on the pre-synaptic neuron) that sucks back up the serotonin 
from the synapse. Every now and then the pump will suck up a dopamine
molecule (another neurotransmitter that isn't really related to the
"feel-good" effects of E). That dopamine doesn't have any business being
inside of a serotonin neuron, so MAO-B degrades the dopamine, IN THE 
PROCESS OF WHICH HYDROGEN PEROXIDE IS FORMED!!!!! 
        
Q: So what's the big deal about Hydrogen Peroxide?
A: Nothing normally. H2O2 (hydrogen peroxide) is toxic to animals because it
splits in two to form two hydroxyl free radicals, which are very reactive
and very damaging. Normally your body can handle these varmits just fine,
just by reducing them with anti-oxidants (like Vitamin C, E, or
glutathione).

Q: H2O2 and MDMA: so what's the connection?
A: MAO-B also degrades serotonin, but not as well as it degrades dopamine,
but there is usually so much serotonin as compared to dopamine inside of a
serotonergic neuron, that it has a hard time getting around to the dopamine,
so very little H2O2 is formed. HOWEVER, during an E trip, a whole heck of a
lot of your serotonin is outside in the synapse, not in the neuron, so the
MAO-B has a much easier time getting to the dopamine, and hence forming more
H2O2. (Also I think E causes a larger production of dopamine elsewhere in
your brain, and eventually some of that dopamine will get inside of the 
serotonergic neurons). Now there is a much higher level of H2O2 INSIDE of
your serotonergic neurons than your body can effectively get rid of, and
NOW we start seeing brain damage: specifically, selective serotonergic
neuron degeneration.

MY THEORY - The neurons form abnormal connections after being damaged, maybe
because they just hook up with the closet thing nearby. If you could stop
this degeneration damage somehow, there would be no way for the neurons to
grow back abnormally since they are already fine.

                        END OF BORING SCIENTIFIC STUFF

Q: So how do I stop this shitty neurotoxicity?
A: Many Many different ways. Below is a list of the ways I am currently
familiar with, though I'm sure there are probably more...


1) Stop the reuptake of serotonin (and hence the accidental reuptake of
   dopamine also which is the real cause of the neurotoxicity) by taking an
   SSRI (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor). So take:

                                Prozac 

   Take it 3-6 hours afters taking your E dose, and this will significantly
   reduce neurotoxicity. THIS IS A WELL DOCUMETNED EFFECT! This is not one
   of my other theories. If you do this your brain will love you for it. Any
   other SSRI will also have the same effect (Xanax? Zoloft? Are those SSRIs?) 
   This might even make your trip a bit better, because it will keep the
   serotonin in the synapse longer....

2) Stop the breakdown of dopamine by MAO-B. This is the ultimate step which
   produces the toxic hydrogen peroxide. The documented case I read about
   used:

                               L-deprenyl

   which I believe is a commonly prescribed anti-depressant, though when I
   think about it, maybe it's not since.... Well does anyone have any info
   on this or where to get it? It would be greatly appreciated.... Anyways,
   take it the same time that you take your E, cause that's what worked for
   the rats.... Other MAO-B inhibitors will also work (ask your doctor about
   this....)

3) Increase relative serotonin levels. If you eats lots of tryptophan at the
   same time you eat your E, this will overcome the inhibitory effects that
   E has on TPH (tryptophan hydroxylase), which will increase relative
   serotonin levels, which will decrease the degradative actions of MAO-B on
   dopamine (since all of the extra serotonin will be getting in the way),
   which will produce less H2O2, and hence less damage. So....

        Take something like 2-3 capsules of tryptophan with 1 capsule E.

   Unfortunatley, the FDA has taken tryptophan (an amino acid!!!) off of the
   market for what I believe is essentially political reasons (they found it
   later to be a contaminent in a Japanese pharmaceuticals tryptophan
   product that was causing the sickness, not the tryptophan itself.....)
   You can still probably get it in Mexico though and you probably can even
   mail order it for European Pharmaceutical companies. It's not like it's a
   Schedule I drug like E is....
   This might also make your trip a bit better because you will now be
   continually producing serotonin. IT WILL ALMOST DEFINITELY HELP WITH
   POST-E DEPRESSION....

4) Stop the free-radical damage. This is the easiest to do, since
   anti-oxidants are extremely easy to come by. Some suggestions:

        Glutathione - This a naturally occuring tripeptide in your body. I
                      THINK it is one of the chemicals your brain uses in
                      the process that gets rid of free radicals. And it
                      itself is an anti-oxidant....

        Vitamin C
        Vitamin E
        Melatonin (fairly good report in recent Newsweek on this)
        Many others....

   It would probably be a good idea to take some with your E, and then maybe
   about 3-6 hours later....



                 Summary

Prozac & other SSRIs                    3-6 hours after taking E
L-deprenyl and other MAO-B inhibitors   When you take your E
Tryptophan ***                          When you take your E
Anti-oxidants
    Vitamin C
    Vitamin E
    glutathione ***
    melatonin

*** - highly recommend

        Well, that's it.... Hope I haven't gone too overboard. I would like 
to give one last thanks to the SF scene for giving me what I believe was the
greatest summer I've ever had. Thanks much to all you out there who have
make it so special....

                                          lots and lots and lots o luv,

                                                Jason Sydes

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Oct 25 15:00:59 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id PAA26543; Fri, 25 Oct 1996 15:00:59 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from netcom17.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with SMTP id PAA26535; Fri, 25 Oct 1996 15:00:56 -0700 (PDT)
Received: (from simitzis@localhost) by netcom17.netcom.com (8.6.13/Netcom)
	id OAA01911; Fri, 25 Oct 1996 14:58:56 -0700
Date: Fri, 25 Oct 1996 14:58:56 -0700
From: simitzis@netcom.com (Steve Simitzis)
Message-Id: <199610252158.OAA01911@netcom17.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: too much trance?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hearing the same music all the time is boring. Lately, I've been
spending equal time in ambient rooms, going to jungle parties,
listening to trip-hop, listening to more ambient, going to different
*kinds* of trance parties (cyber-trance, goa trance, etc), etc etc...

All of this adds *variety*. It's out there; just look around. At
Charity, I spent most of my time in the breakbeat room, despite the
fact that two of my favorite DJ's (Deaks and Dutch) were spinning
downstairs.

I love trance more than any other music, and I don't ever want to get
sick of it. That's why I take time away from it as often as I can.

just some random thoughts from my cubicle,
Steve

--

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Oct 25 15:33:19 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id PAA29322; Fri, 25 Oct 1996 15:33:19 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from mom.hooked.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with ESMTP id PAA29315; Fri, 25 Oct 1996 15:33:16 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from also.hooked.net (moonpup@also.hooked.net [206.80.6.45]) by mom.hooked.net (8.8.0/8.7.3) with ESMTP id PAA25444; Fri, 25 Oct 1996 15:33:13 -0700 (PDT)
From: Milton Cecil <moonpup@hooked.net>
Received: (from moonpup@localhost) by also.hooked.net (8.7.3/8.7.3) id PAA13457; Fri, 25 Oct 1996 15:33:12 -0700 (PDT)

To: <sandoz@sfsu.edu>

Subject: Re: Re: massives of the past...
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

On Fri, Oct 25, 1996 8:11:46 AM  at TRISTAN BERNARD BLAUG wrote: 
 
>I know what you mean.  To me, the parties that I help put on in England 
>with Spiral Tribe and Bedlam in 
>91/92 was the best time of my life. 2-3,000 people a week, E that makes E 
>round here seem like a sugar sweet, completely free and a vibe that was so

>strong that it was like getting hit on the side of the head with a cricket

>bat.  And then I came over here and started to go to the full-moon parties

>on Bonny Dune Beach.  Man, those were really good parties: 1,000 people 
>and a beautiful vibe with beautiful music; exellent LSD as well.  It was 
>enough to impress me and I am very hard to impress.  Then the last 
>full-moon rave I went to only had about fifty people there and I thought 
>that was sad.  Where did all the people go?  Ah well, at least there are 
>still Sunset parties (which are beautiful in their own way) but some how 
>the massive of the vibe is not what it once was.  Although I felt that it 
>might be on it's way back when I done the Canibus Buyers Club. 
>But, while it may (sadly) be true that the vibe, for some of us, was not 
>the same as it was, this is actually a very negative view of the scene. 
>One should always have the attitude, whether it's about the rave scene or 
>indded any scene that one is involved in, that the best of it is always 
>just around the corner. 
>Tristan. 
 
My introduction to Raving and undergroud DJ'ing was in L.A. in 1990 and all
I used to hear was SF, SF, SF, it's the shit (as in good)......so I finally
came up to check out a full moon party at candlestick park (the one with
the violent ending.......) 
 
I was blown away by the tribal funky house sound that Garth played........
as L.A. was predominately Techno at the time, this was a new sound and vibe
for me....... I was never the same ever again........  
 
I actually decided that night to move to SF and it took about 6 months to
fully move my life......... I arrived in aug of 92 and for about 8 months I
was totally happy and inspired and everything seemed so good.......... 
 
but around summer of 93 things just seemed stale, weird, and got
strange........ for a while I thought it was the scene.........after a
while longer I thought it was me........ it turned out it was both........ 
 
I have spent 3 years searching for the vibe and every 3 months or so I
would find it........ but not with the regularity I was used to or happy
with. I actually gave up and "retired"from performing  but deep down
inside, I really wanted to be DJ'ing and I discovered it was a passion I
could not walk away from........ 
 
I went last year to the haight street fair and ran into greg & cindy (FnF),
and through them I worked with FnF and also worked with the new moon party,
and then I did a full moon, and I began to feel the vibe in SF was getting
better.......... and it has......the power structure seemed to be  moving
hands........as younger promoters began to throw parties.......... some
really cool parties and new vibes in S.F. has given me hope that the future
is in good hands. parties like Harmony, CCC, Cloud Factory, Gateway, Spaz &
Sunsets have taken over the vibe that Wicked used to have with there full
moon parties. 
 
I personally find most massives to be rather formula oriented and depending
on the promoters can be good or bad....... I have only attended one
gathering, DJ'd at one cool world, did a FTT (before they called it FTT),
and basically find I'm happier associating with parties no bigger than 750
people.......... 
 
since my return to S.F. after a summer in the UK, I found I was no longer
inspired by S.F. (after an insane & totally inspired visit to London), and
I decided after 2 weeks to move back to the UK. (I was originally born in
London), so I am legal there and it seemed a syncrinisitus place to be for
me at this time...... like a coming home, only better as I have developed a
lifestyle that is reminicent of rave culture UK circa 88/89. 
 
I found the vibe I was looking for in London this summer, and my heart &
soul is into moving there now.....I hope whether you are into small parties
or massives that you find the vibe you are all looking for.....  
 
I find travelling & moving from city to city (and now country to country)
seems to rejuvinate my sence of excitement and I find I am part of a bigger
family and picture than "the S.F scene" can offer me........ meeting fellow
clubbers & DJ's etc in other parts of the world and being invited to cool
vibe parties is the essence of what the music and scene is all
about......... to inspire others in other places, to be inspired by others
in other places, is what can I say ......inspirational..... 
 
I hope this puts to rest any rumors or attitudes people have of me that
reflect in a negative way.......I have always been my own worst enemy and I
find I mirror peoples emotions......if you are cool, calm, respectful and
kind, I tend to be the same........ 
 
...........if you are nasty, vile, and derogitory, I reflect back on you
that same negative energy......... it is a weakness I try to overcome, and
I try not to associate with people that take me down that ugly road.......
As I did a few weeks ago here on SFRaves........ 
 
I would like to close out by appologizing publically to Mr stuff and all
the other fine members of SFRaves. I have been under a lot of stress lately
and Mr Stuff just pushed my buttons.......... and I responded like a puppet
on a string........... 
 
If anyone comes to London, please look me up and I can help you to find the
vibe in London etc......I will be hopefully changing my e-mail address to 
 
 MOONPUP@CLUB.NET  
 
(I am just waiting for the official word from Wayne)...... I will post that
in the next day or two when it becomes official..........  
 
for those that want tapes, you need to call and sort it out..........like
now........ as I am running out of time......... there will be no tapes
made after Oct 31st and I leave Nov 2nd for London..........call me
@415-337-666 or e-mail me  
 
MOONPUP

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Oct 25 15:39:12 1996

Received: (from knegtel@localhost) by horatio.ucsf.EDU (940816.SGI.8.6.9/GSC4.24)
	id PAA11070 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Fri, 25 Oct 1996 15:39:08 -0700
From: "Ronald Knegtel" <knegtel@horatio.ucsf.EDU>
Message-Id: <9610251539.ZM11068@horatio.ucsf.edu>
Date: Fri, 25 Oct 1996 15:39:07 -0700
In-Reply-To: Shamini Jain <shamini@alois.icon.palo-alto.med.va.gov>
        "Re: MDMA...research, etc..." (Oct 25,  9:31am)
References: <199610251631.JAA28183@alois.icon.palo-alto.med.va.gov>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.0 26oct94 MediaMail)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: MDMA...research, etc...
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi all,

for those with an interest in the action and possible side effects of MDMA
I recommend visiting your neighborhood university medical library and
checking out the following recent review on MDMA:"Adverse reactions with
3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA; 'Ecstasy')" by U.D. McCann,
S. O. Slate and G.A. Ricaurte in Drug Safety 1996 (2), 107-115, which
summarizes everything that could acutely or in the long run go wrong
when taking E. Summarizing the conclusions MDMA can acute haert problems,
kidney failure, nasty blood clotting in occasional (acute) cases. Prolonged
use may lead to serotonin neurotoxicity resulting possibly in depression,
cognitive disturbance and anxiety disorders. Note that this review states
that neurotoxicity in humans has not yet been proven. Furthermore it states
that the number of reported complications of E use is low compared to the
number of users (which could be due to people not reporting them) and
that especially the neurotoxicity effects may be very subtle (involving
mood/sleeping/appetite/cognition disorders) and not be noticed until
a few years from now.

Oh, and while people are theorizing on the list regarding neuron terminals
growing back in the "wrong" place, I wonder what the wrong place is
exactly. The connections between neurons determine much of how our
brain/personality/intelligence works and I don't think the relation
between the exact composition of our brain neural network and
psychology is well understood. I guess we'll have to wait and see.

Still not feeling depressed,


The Frying Dutchman
of nerve


--

that same negative energy......... it is a weakness I try to overcome, and
I try not to associate with people that take me down that ugly road.......
As I did a few weeks ago here on SFRaves........ 
 
I would like to close out by appologizing publically to Mr stuff and all
the other fine members of SFRaves. I have been under a lot of stress lately
and Mr Stuff just pushed my buttons.......... and I responded like a puppet
on a string........... 
 
If anyone comes to London, please look me up and I can help you to find the
vibe in London etc......I will be hopefully changing my e-mail address to 
 
 MOONPUP@CLUB.NET  
 
(I am just waiting for the official word from Wayne)...... I will post that
in the next day or two when it becomes official..........  
 
for those that want tapes, you need to call and sort it out..........like
now........ as I am running out of time......... there will be no tapes
made after Oct 31st and I leave Nov 2nd for London..........call me
@415-337-666 or e-mail me  
 
MOONPUP
