__________________________________________________________________________
Here is a critique of the film independence day I recieved third or fourth
hand at my NASA account that originated from somebody who actually works at
area 51.  It is rather entertaining.

-Matt

>>
>>                      40 THINGS I LEARNED FROM ID4
>>                        That I Never Knew Before
>>                 By Dean Kanipe Area 51 Research Center
>>
>>  While viewing the film Independence Day, it became apparent that I was
>>  remarkably uninformed about several things related to Area 51, aliens,
>>  military operations, and America in general. Below is a quick list of
>>  a few important things I learned from the film that I never knew
>>  before, and a few lessons that were inferred from the plot. I wish to
>>  thank the creators of ID4 for making these facts much clearer to me.
>>
>>   1. Aliens like to blow up significant land marks first. Apparently
>>      the best way to destroy a city is to position your "Death Ray"
>>      over the most recognizable building.
>>   2. All pro-UFO people are morons who dance atop the building directly
>>      under the Death Ray.
>>   3. If alien "Destroyers" come to your city to blast it into oblivion,
>>      leave BEFORE they fire the Death Ray.
>>   4. If alien "Destroyers" come to your city to blast it into oblivion
>>      and you are caught in traffic at the last minute, make sure that
>>      you are travelling with a dog and a small child. The Law of
>>      Averages says you'll survive the Death Ray.
>>   5. If alien "Destroyers" come to your city to blast it into oblivion
>>      and you are caught in traffic at the last minute, make sure that
>>      you are NOT a raspy-voiced homosexual cable TV executive. The Law
>>      of Averages says you'll get waxed by the Death Ray.
>>   6. Stripping is a lucrative profession that allows one to "Pay the
>>      bills," "take care of one's boy," and own a nice house in a middle
>>      class subdivision.
>>   7. Strippers got moxie. When the going gets tough, they can drive
>>      California Highway Department utility vehicles, collect refugees
>>      and use their extensive survival skills to provide food and
>>      comfort to survivors.
>>   8. NASA sends out rejection letters, just like Harvard.
>>   9. Area 51 is an "Assault Base".
>>  10. A fleet of RVs can travel across the Nevada Test Site in
>>      line-abreast formation without the need of roads, thanks to the
>>      immense expanses of Salt Flats and the lack of impeding mountains.
>>  11. Area 51 has a big chain-link fence around it, and the guards at
>>      the gate wear black combat fatigues with white metal helmets in
>>      120 degree heat.
>>  12. Any bonehead with an RV can get to Area 51 by driving across the
>>      Salt Flat to the gate and flashing a captured alien to the guard.
>>  13. Standard operating procedure for the Air Force is to cluster all
>>      vehicles, aircraft, and ground personnel on a 200 meter section of
>>      tarmac in the middle of an Alien Invasion.
>>  14. The F-18 is the sole fighter in use by all branches of the
>>      service, including Marines and Air Force.
>>  15. From the assault scenes on the Alien "Destroyers', it appears that
>>      the F-18 must have had a 1000 unit production run.
>>  16. Both F-18s and B-2s must close to within 10 km of a target 20 km
>>      across before engaging with both air-to-air missiles and aerial
>>      launched nuclear cruise missiles.
>>  17. People too drunk to walk can still fly crop dusters and F-18s.
>>  18. Any bonehead with rudimentary aviation experience can be taught
>>      to pilot an F-18 in 5 hours.
>>  19. Any bonehead with F-18 flight experience can learn to pilot an
>>      Alien fighter in 5 minutes.
>>  20. Aliens with anatomy that includes tentacles and clawed feet use
>>      flight yokes just like ours.
>>  21. Aliens are wimps, even the ones in "Bio-Mechanical" armor. They
>>      have glass jaws and can be taken out with a punch by Will Smith.
>>      (He has had a lot of practice on photographers, though.)
>>  22. Aliens are stupid. When one of their fighters approaches the
>>      carrier, they don't bother to communicate with the pilot.
>>  23. Aliens are even more stupid. They pursue their targets into
>>      canyons walls and closing blast doors.
>>  24. Aliens are unbelievably stupid. While unarmed and unarmored,
>>      they do things to piss off people with hand guns.
>>  25. Aliens are just too stupid for words to express. An alien air
>>      traffic controller can look at a fighter that has been
>>      human-modified for 20 minutes and is only 50 feet away and not
>>      notice the welded-on missile rack until the missile is fired
>>      through his work station.
>>  26. Aliens are remarkably inarticulate. All they can say is, "Release
>>      me," "No peace," and "Die!"
>>  27. If you're President and your administration is faltering, an Alien
>>      Invasion might be a good way to boost your ratings in the polls.
>>  28. If you're President and your administration is faltering, manage
>>      to work into every other sentence the fact that you "flew in the
>>      Persian Gulf." No need to specify what branch of service.
>>  29. If you're President and your administration is faltering and an
>>      Alien Invasion occurs, relocate the V.P., the Cabinet, and the
>>      Joint Chiefs to one centralized location so that the Aliens can
>>      take them all out with one shot. You can always blame the problems
>>      of the past on them after victory is achieved.
>>  30. The President's Press secretary keeps her cell phone listed in the
>>      phone book "in case of emergencies."
>>  31. If your father abandons his Jewish beliefs after the death of your
>>      mother, always carry around a Torah and a Yarmulke. Aliens might
>>      attack and offer him a chance to renew his faith.
>>  32. If aliens abduct you and effectively destroy your life by making
>>      you the laughing stock of the community, never fear. When their
>>      "Destroyers" come, you will be vindicated to those who mocked your
>>      tale.
>>  33. If aliens abduct you and do unspeakable things to you, you can
>>      have revenge upon them by flying an F-18 into their Death Ray.
>>  34. If aliens abduct you and do unspeakable things to you and you have
>>      revenge upon them by flying an F-18 into their Death Ray, you will
>>      obtain redemption and your children will be proud of you.
>>  35. The best way to win back a former wife is to be very annoying,
>>      look perpetually vexed, and keep wearing your wedding ring for 4
>>      years after the divorce.
>>  36. In 10 hours, one man with a Macintosh Laptop can code a virus in
>>      C++ that will take down a completely alien computer system.
>>  37. Even though the Mac isn't compatible with most other Earthly
>>      operating systems, it can interface with an alien computer.
>>  38. Alien network security is nonexistent.
>>  39. Rather than attacking a planet when they first encounter it
>>      (i.e., 1940s), aliens wait until the planet has developed just
>>      enough technology to possibly defend itself.
>>  40. Scientists at Area 51 are a bit touched in the head, and "Don't
>>      get out much."
>>
>





From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Oct 28 12:34:06 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id MAA22731; Mon, 28 Oct 1996 12:34:06 -0800 (PST)
Received: from netcom17.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with SMTP id MAA22725; Mon, 28 Oct 1996 12:34:01 -0800 (PST)
Received: (from simitzis@localhost) by netcom17.netcom.com (8.6.13/Netcom)
	id MAA13874; Mon, 28 Oct 1996 12:33:54 -0800
Date: Mon, 28 Oct 1996 12:33:54 -0800
From: simitzis@netcom.com (Steve Simitzis)
Message-Id: <199610282033.MAA13874@netcom17.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: some final thoughts about the weekend
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I learned something new on Saturday at FnF:

It's Ernie Deaks' mission in life to kill me.
He is relentless.

Each time he finished with another *hardass* track, I would think,
"okay, it's time for a cool-down song now". No way. It just gets harder
and harder and higher energy... and then ends his set with what I can
only describe as acid-gabber.

Ouch. :) I'm still in pain...

But it wouldn't stop me from going to the last Sunset... and w0w! It
was beautiful. I had never been to the Berkeley Marina, but the view
is amazing. Hopefully, they'll use that location a bit more next year.

I had the same feeling as David Lowe when gazing out at the city, lit
up: "Damn, I *live* there!" It's so true what I had always heard
about the San Francisco skyline.

And looking back, it reminded me of a conversation Wayne and I had at
Sunset. We were reflecting upon why we like the DJ's that we do... and
it's not just the music that the DJ spins; it's the karma and the
energy that they project. Some DJ's, no matter how great their music
may be, have certain "arrogance issues"... ya know, lousy people with
groovy record collections.

And then there are those who truly love the people and the scene, and
love creating the energy and the vibe... the DJ's who will thank you
for thanking them for a good set. And I thought back to all of the
sweat dripping off of Deaks, the fat grin on Ethan's face when FnF
finally went off, and watching Astral Matrix smile and cheer with the
Sunset crowd as he tweaked the knobs of his 303...

And it reminded me of San Francisco, and the beautiful view at
Berkeley Marina. Living in SF is being part of this _energy_ that I
can't fully explain. All I know is that you can feel it when you're
there. And you can see it glowing from the city at night, from across
the bay.

It reminded me of the karma and the energy that our city projects.
Maybe that's why it's such a special place to live...

See you at Mad tonight (I'm not dead yet! :)

Steve

--

Received: from [205.178.41.41] ([205.178.41.41]) by mail1.sirius.com (8.6.12/960710) with SMTP id MAA08788 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 28 Oct 1996 12:34:05 -0800
X-Sender: branka@pop.sirius.com
Message-Id: <v02130500ae9ab56bac44@[205.178.41.41]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 28 Oct 1996 12:34:14 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: branka@sirius.com (*B*)
Subject: FTT review, energy - long
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

NOTE - if you don't feel like reading a party review, please read the way I
experienced the energy (if you are interested in that) - below the second
dotted line.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------

        Many of my best friends went to FnF, because FTT was going to be a
massive - there will be a lot of gangsters there and LIVE 105 ppl will show
up as well.  I have to admit I was really bummed, because at least one of
the people I really wanted to party with (from Seattle) got talked into
going to FnF....  Oh, well - there was nothing that was going to stop me,
because I was really looking forward to a big party with great DJs.  My
boyfriend Marc, some of our friends and I went to FTT, all of us psyched
about it.

        What can I say?  The party was a massive - there were thousands of
people, but that was to be expected.  I have been to Homebase once before
(The Gathering in April) and I have to admit that FTT made the space
magical.  There were 4 different rooms - some of them with great stage
settings, kick ass laser shows, chill-room looking like a cocktail bar,
killer sound systems.

        We got in pretty early and explored the space.  Tony was spinning
in one of the rooms and we decided to stay there (little did I know that I
will stay at the same place for 10 hours).  Tony was pretty good, although
it seemed like it was a little too early to really get into it (I wanted to
see everything and wanted to see how many of my friends were actually
there).

        I seriously started dancing around 11pm and was waiting for Dan to
come on.  Dan (as most of the times) really kicked ass.  People were
dancing like crazy and it was great to see all the energy that was created
on the dance floor.  The energy I am talking about is the energy that is
very different than energy at the small party.  It is energy of thousands
of people dancing their asses off to the killer music, who are there to
dance and hear DJs,  because they love the music and they want to be part
of thousands of people who feel the same.

        I stayed at that room for the most of the night beaus music just
kept me going (as well as great visuals).  Other highlights of the party:

- glow dancers (they had glow necklaces wrapped around them and dance in
couple rooms) - very entertaining

- fire show outside

- running into the astronaut from Burning Man

- getting help from the medical team (I manage to hurt myself, taking a
short cut to the bathroom, and needed some minor medical help to stop the
bleeding on my back)

- getting a plastic glow-bracelet from this guy who was dancing with his GF
close to us

- leaving a stuffed animal there (on purpose) and actually having this guy
pick it up and give it to somebody as a present

        Thanks FTT crowd, thanks all of you wonderful people who were there
and who brought the positive energy with you.  FTT was definitely my
favorite massive, and maybe my favorite party I went to so far.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

        Many times during the night, I though about you guys - many of my
friends, and just many people that had bad thoughts about the party.  I
wished you could have been there, to see with your eyes how great the party
was.  Many times while I was dancing I started writing this letter in my
head, so I could explain it better, but somehow all those thoughts are
scattered and I can't really put them on the paper.

        I was surrounded by hundreds of people, and never in those 10 hours
I was there, I felt the negative energy.  I had people come up to me and
introduce themselves just because they wanted to (not because I put the
description on the list).  I met people, because they were sharing the same
dance floor as I was and after dancing for hours we just wanted to know who
was the person next to us with whom we shared that amazing experience.  I
accidentally hit people while dancing with my eyes closed (one time I had
my fingers in somebody's mouth and almost ripped his upper lip), and
although they would have maybe passed as gangster types, they just smiled
and walked away. I saw people who were hungry for great music and who
wanted to be there for it and enjoy every minute of it.

        I didn't get many hugs and I didn't get stickers offered to me at
every corner, but that is not what I was looking for.  Reading other
people's posts and hearing that people did see the bad energy, makes me
wander if I was maybe at the right spot at the party the entire night.  But
then it also makes me wander if it is true when people say "if you do
something with negative expectations and just look for negative things -
you will see them".  IMO, taking "happy drugs" to get the negative energy
away from you and waiting for drugs to kick in to have fun is the most
ridicules thing.  You should have fun in the first place, otherwise it's
time to go home.

        Many people say how massives are not put together with love and
positive energy, how they are too expensive etc.  It cost $25, but that's
the money that went into the space, permits, stages, visuals, DJs etc...  I
didn't mind spending that money because I had one of the best times of my
life.  I am glad I gave FTT another chance and didn't blow them off,
although I had two good reasons - my last FTT party that I wasn't too fond
of and well as many people on this list "bitching" about how the party will
suck.  Once again I proved to myself that find out for yourself is the best
way, rather than listening to others.

        Sorry this is so long, I just want some of you to see how I felt.
I am glad people had fun at FnF, but I also hope some day, some of those
people who keep dissing massives will give than a change and see for
themselves how great  they can be.

Hugz to all,
Branka

P.S.  the most depressing moment of the night - one of the people I know
came up to me and asked me with a sad look on her face and pity in her eyes
"so, you didn't get tickets to FnF, ha?"

micron said...
>That was one of the lamest parties i've ever been to, especially coming from
>the killer vibe at FnF.  I have never been in such a cold space and around
>so many cold people before.  There was like 100,000 watts pumpin in the main
>room...actually the sound system was pretty nice.  And like 3 other rooms, 2
>jungle/trip hop and 1 house.  I was having no fun..so i decided to take my
>vitamin E.

jack said...
>Well, it must have something to do with the eye of the beholder.  My
>take was that friends and family couldn't have touched the massive I
>attended at funky techno.  As for cold people, I have to say, that unless
>your part of the "friends and family clique", friends and family events
>can often be pretty cold also.  In fact, I have had much better times at
>massives and have been welcomed with open arms by 17 year olds from
>Hayward, etc., while at a friends and family event, I couldn't even get
>an E to save my fucking life.  I guess if you're part of the sfraves

First off I think that in my case you pretty much discredit yourself
completely by relating that because you couldn't get drugs at F&F that it
is an unfriendly/unfamily event...this is not what you may have meant but
I'll bet it appeared that way to many...

>gang, and schmooze with people, then perhaps it's more fun, and people are
>more friendly, but the only people who have really been very welcoming to
>me at friends and family events are the people I already know.  On the other
>hand, like I said, I've been treated more warmly by youngsters I don't even
>know at bigger parties, and not just this Saturday, although this Saturday
>was a serious case in point.  I don't want to schmooze you people, I go to
>parties to dance, have fun, and go nuts.  I'm a 60 hour week hacker and I
>don't have time to go out often, and when I do, I don't want to have to run
>around meeting all the "right people" before I can get connected, have fun,
>have people to talk to, etc.  I've felt this way for a long time now, and
>have never said anything before about this, as I really don't want to be a
>downer, but when I saw this note, I simply had to respond.  I have also had
>other people tell me they feel similarly, but whatever the case, your mileage
>may vary.  It is my feeling, however, that these parties, while small and
>intimate, often aren't very friendly unless you know a significant number of

I've had some people tell me some similar feelings about the Cloud Factory
(of which i am somewhat of a founder) and I think that these kind of
experiences are common at smaller parties.  I think this happens because of
the reasons that people throw parties.  I wanted to start throwing parties
so my friends would have something fun to do, something they could afford
and someplace close to go (2 hrs to sf is a long ways).  So I suppose out
of that purpose we are intent on making our parties fun for ourselves, why
not we put all of the hard work into it.  I'm sure some of the massives
promoters like to make sure they are having a good time as well.  But when
you take the size difference, suppose we are having a party with 150
people, at the Cloud Factory likelihood is that about 100 of those people
would be friends.  Tendency of friends is to hang/chill with friends...some
people call this cliques...i call it natural.  Truth of the matter is it is
easier to approach those you know than a stranger.  I think that as someone
who considers themselves an outsider or a stranger to those who are the
core of friends is going to have make that effort to be involved in meeting
people and having conversations. At a massive it is easier to meet people
sheerly because of the amount of people (imho), there is somewhat of a
ratio...there are still only a certain core group of friends who throw the
event but then add 4000 people and you have an environment where it is
easier for starngers to meet and interact.

Because smaller parties are more friendly to friends does not make them
elitist or cliquish.  In my opinion it means that there are some of us who
want to go to a party where we know someone.  I don't get anything out a
some random 17 year old treating me like a friend/family for a half hour
and then never seeing them again...I'd rather have people treating me like
that that i can call next week and say hi to.  Just a matter of preference,
some people dont want that kind of relationships in their partying.

>people at the event.  Last Saturday at this giant warehouse in Oakland with
>some 4000 kids, I was treated like family by more kids than I can even
>remember.  Yes, it was crowded.  I like that anyway.  Yes, there were people
>there who don't know the scene, but everybody has to have a first time at
>any sort of thing, and raving is no different.  I also would like to mention
>that with even thousands of kids, from all over the place, I personally
>didn't witness even the slightest trouble with aggressive males (the folks
>you all call "hunters and gatherers"... that's pretty elitist, folks), or

I don't understand how that is elitist to call someone who is out looking
for action a hunter/gatherer.  Some people are obviously out to hunt and
gather...

>anything even remotely like that, although I can't say it didn't happen, as
>the place was much to large to see everything happening...
>
>That brings me to another point.  The parties you folks throw tend to have
>a rather homogeneous crowd, which isn't a bad thing per se, but the fact is,
>it's much more difficult to get a friendly happy environment when you have
>people there from radically different homes, races, socioeconomic backgrounds,

socioeconomic backgrounds...I'm sure there weren't too many poor people at
Funky Tekno Tribe this weekend.  Just couldn't resist that bait (sorry =)

>and the like.  Most brilliant of all was that funky techno tribe was attended
>by a *very* diverse crowd, a much more diverse crowd than you folks have ever
>attracted, and the vibe was still incredibly friendly, peaceful, and as
>Coolio says... "all the way live"....  I'm not saying that you should go out
>and try to attract a more diverse crowd, there is a place for both massives,
>and the parties you throw in this scene here in the bay area, but when I hear
>people capping like that, I'm likely to speak.   I don't want to rain on your
>parade, but I've been to alot of parties, and that massive was fucking rocking,
>in a most delightful way, so I felt your analysis needed a little
>counterpoint....

I'm glad you had a good time, it sounds like many did!  Those of us who
help throw smaller parties like to hear criticisms if they are
constructive...(your note wasn't really a criticism I didn't feel more a
reflection on your feelings which is also helpful).  If you have stuff you
want to say, say it!  It can only help people do things better (if the
criticism/comments are constructive not destructive)

love drenalin

On Mon, 28 Oct 1996, Steve Simitzis wrote:

> 
> I learned something new on Saturday at FnF:
> 
> It's Ernie Deaks' mission in life to kill me.
> He is relentless.
> 
> Each time he finished with another *hardass* track, I would think,
> "okay, it's time for a cool-down song now". No way. It just gets harder
> and harder and higher energy... and then ends his set with what I can
> only describe as acid-gabber.
> 
> Ouch. :) I'm still in pain...
> 
> But it wouldn't stop me from going to the last Sunset... and w0w! It
> was beautiful. I had never been to the Berkeley Marina, but the view
> is amazing. Hopefully, they'll use that location a bit more next year.
> 
> I had the same feeling as David Lowe when gazing out at the city, lit
> up: "Damn, I *live* there!" It's so true what I had always heard
> about the San Francisco skyline.
> 
> And looking back, it reminded me of a conversation Wayne and I had at
> Sunset. We were reflecting upon why we like the DJ's that we do... and
> it's not just the music that the DJ spins; it's the karma and the
> energy that they project. Some DJ's, no matter how great their music
> may be, have certain "arrogance issues"... ya know, lousy people with
> groovy record collections.
> 
> And then there are those who truly love the people and the scene, and
> love creating the energy and the vibe... the DJ's who will thank you
> for thanking them for a good set. And I thought back to all of the
> sweat dripping off of Deaks, the fat grin on Ethan's face when FnF
> finally went off, and watching Astral Matrix smile and cheer with the
> Sunset crowd as he tweaked the knobs of his 303...
> 
> And it reminded me of San Francisco, and the beautiful view at
> Berkeley Marina. Living in SF is being part of this _energy_ that I
> can't fully explain. All I know is that you can feel it when you're
> there. And you can see it glowing from the city at night, from across
> the bay.
> 
> It reminded me of the karma and the energy that our city projects.
> Maybe that's why it's such a special place to live...
> 
> See you at Mad tonight (I'm not dead yet! :)
> 
> Steve

        "FTT review, energy - long" (Oct 28, 12:34pm)
References: <v02130500ae9ab56bac44@[205.178.41.41]>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.0 26oct94 MediaMail)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, branka@sirius.com (*B*)
Subject: Re: FTT review, energy - long
Mime-Version: 1.0

Precedence: bulk

        Many times during the night, I though about you guys - many of my
friends, and just many people that had bad thoughts about the party.  I
wished you could have been there, to see with your eyes how great the party
was.  Many times while I was dancing I started writing this letter in my
head, so I could explain it better, but somehow all those thoughts are
scattered and I can't really put them on the paper.
------------
It definitely sounds like you were at the same party I was (i.e. funky
techno tribe).  I don't think I have EVER been to a party that had such
a nice feeling, so many cool people (as in something like 4000... anyone
know how many people actually attended that party?).

Also, like you, I saw absolutely nothing negative the entire night.  I also
bumped into people, as I don't always dance that well when I start getting
really tired, etc., and was merely smiled at...

I definitely agree there's something really cool about a good massive
party, as with so many people, there's just something kinetic that
happens... I also agree, that while small parties are cool, that this
thing that happens at a large party is unique to parties with many,
many people... I find it really cool that I simply couldn't have seen
everyone and everything, that no matter how hard I threw myself at this
rave, no matter how many dance floors I danced on, and how many people I
met, there were thousands upon thousands more I didn't manage to see or
experience.  Like I said earlier, that party was the *BOMB*, no doubt
about it, and while I've been to lousy massives, I have to say the funky
techno tribe definitely outdid themselves this time.  I also urge those
who think massives "necessarily suck" to reconsider, as while they are
definitely harder to throw and to keep everything groovy, when it works,
it's quite a spectacle to behold.

I might also add, that I did see alot of kids, dressed in many different
types of clothing, but I saw no one I would consider "a gangster".  I
did meet a bunch of kids from the South East Bay that I would not likely
have met at a smaller party, (as we don't run in the same circles), and
that was also very cool.

IMHO, raving is about being inclusive.  This party was inclusive on a
MASSIVE scale... maybe that's why they call them massives... anyway, if
it's simply the numbers involved (i.e. the number of attendants) that
puts you off of massives, then you probably won't appreciate them anyway,
but if you think that they "necessarily suck", this last Saturday definitely
proved that completely incorrect...

Like I said, it was the best party in three or four years, for me...

-=jack=-

(This text composed by voice)


-- 
========================================================
	      http://buchu.eit.com:8888/
========================================================

show
: up as well.  I have to admit I was really bummed, because at least one of
: the people I really wanted to party with (from Seattle) got talked into
: going to FnF....  Oh, well - there was nothing that was going to stop me,
: because I was really looking forward to a big party with great DJs.  My
: boyfriend Marc, some of our friends and I went to FTT, all of us psyched
: about it.
: 
:         What can I say?  The party was a massive - there were thousands
of
: people, but that was to be expected.  I have been to Homebase once before
: (The Gathering in April) and I have to admit that FTT made the space
: magical.  There were 4 different rooms - some of them with great stage
: settings, kick ass laser shows, chill-room looking like a cocktail bar,
: killer sound systems.
: 
:         We got in pretty early and explored the space.  Tony was spinning
: in one of the rooms and we decided to stay there (little did I know that
I
: will stay at the same place for 10 hours).  Tony was pretty good,
although
: it seemed like it was a little too early to really get into it (I wanted
to
: see everything and wanted to see how many of my friends were actually
: there).
: 
:         I seriously started dancing around 11pm and was waiting for Dan
to
: come on.  Dan (as most of the times) really kicked ass.  People were
: dancing like crazy and it was great to see all the energy that was
created
: on the dance floor.  The energy I am talking about is the energy that is
: very different than energy at the small party.  It is energy of thousands
: of people dancing their asses off to the killer music, who are there to
: dance and hear DJs,  because they love the music and they want to be part
: of thousands of people who feel the same.
: 
:         I stayed at that room for the most of the night beaus music just
: kept me going (as well as great visuals).  Other highlights of the party:
: 
: - glow dancers (they had glow necklaces wrapped around them and dance in
: couple rooms) - very entertaining
: 
: - fire show outside
: 
: - running into the astronaut from Burning Man
: 
: - getting help from the medical team (I manage to hurt myself, taking a
: short cut to the bathroom, and needed some minor medical help to stop the
: bleeding on my back)
: 
: - getting a plastic glow-bracelet from this guy who was dancing with his
GF
: close to us
: 
: - leaving a stuffed animal there (on purpose) and actually having this
guy
: pick it up and give it to somebody as a present
: 
:         Thanks FTT crowd, thanks all of you wonderful people who were
there
: and who brought the positive energy with you.  FTT was definitely my
: favorite massive, and maybe my favorite party I went to so far.
: 
:
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
----
: 
:         Many times during the night, I though about you guys - many of my
: friends, and just many people that had bad thoughts about the party.  I
: wished you could have been there, to see with your eyes how great the
party
: was.  Many times while I was dancing I started writing this letter in my
: head, so I could explain it better, but somehow all those thoughts are
: scattered and I can't really put them on the paper.
: 
:         I was surrounded by hundreds of people, and never in those 10
hours
: I was there, I felt the negative energy.  I had people come up to me and
: introduce themselves just because they wanted to (not because I put the
: description on the list).  I met people, because they were sharing the
same
: dance floor as I was and after dancing for hours we just wanted to know
who
: was the person next to us with whom we shared that amazing experience.  I
: accidentally hit people while dancing with my eyes closed (one time I had
: my fingers in somebody's mouth and almost ripped his upper lip), and
: although they would have maybe passed as gangster types, they just smiled
: and walked away. I saw people who were hungry for great music and who
: wanted to be there for it and enjoy every minute of it.
: 
:         I didn't get many hugs and I didn't get stickers offered to me at
: every corner, but that is not what I was looking for.  Reading other
: people's posts and hearing that people did see the bad energy, makes me
: wander if I was maybe at the right spot at the party the entire night. 
But
: then it also makes me wander if it is true when people say "if you do
: something with negative expectations and just look for negative things -
: you will see them".  IMO, taking "happy drugs" to get the negative energy
: away from you and waiting for drugs to kick in to have fun is the most
: ridicules thing.  You should have fun in the first place, otherwise it's
: time to go home.
: 
:         Many people say how massives are not put together with love and
: positive energy, how they are too expensive etc.  It cost $25, but that's
: the money that went into the space, permits, stages, visuals, DJs etc... 
I
: didn't mind spending that money because I had one of the best times of my
: life.  I am glad I gave FTT another chance and didn't blow them off,
: although I had two good reasons - my last FTT party that I wasn't too
fond
: of and well as many people on this list "bitching" about how the party
will
: suck.  Once again I proved to myself that find out for yourself is the
best
: way, rather than listening to others.
: 
:         Sorry this is so long, I just want some of you to see how I felt.
: I am glad people had fun at FnF, but I also hope some day, some of those
: people who keep dissing massives will give than a change and see for
: themselves how great  they can be.
: 
: Hugz to all,
: Branka
: 
: P.S.  the most depressing moment of the night - one of the people I know
: came up to me and asked me with a sad look on her face and pity in her
eyes
: "so, you didn't get tickets to FnF, ha?"
: 
: 
: 

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Oct 28 13:21:52 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id NAA27924; Mon, 28 Oct 1996 13:21:52 -0800 (PST)
Received: from twaxx.twaxx.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with SMTP id NAA27911; Mon, 28 Oct 1996 13:21:47 -0800 (PST)

	 id NAA12921; Mon, 28 Oct 1996 13:08:23 -0800
From: "-=jack=-" <jack@twaxx.twaxx.com>
Message-Id: <9610281308.ZM12919@twaxx.twaxx.com>
Date: Mon, 28 Oct 1996 13:08:20 -0800
In-Reply-To: drenalin@salinas.net (Scott Nelson)
        "Re: Fnf vs. FTT..went to both" (Oct 28, 12:54pm)
References: <ae9ab75b000210048fa5@[205.179.129.2]>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.0 26oct94 MediaMail)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, drenalin@salinas.net (Scott Nelson)

First off I think that in my case you pretty much discredit yourself
completely by relating that because you couldn't get drugs at F&F
-----------
I didn't draw that conclusion simply on that basis.  I have been around
a *very* long time, and I've had many experiences that have led me to tend
to feel this way.  I simply don't like the elitism.  It's present whether
or not one is looking for intoxicants...



 that it
is an unfriendly/unfamily event...this is not what you may have meant but
I'll bet it appeared that way to many...
------------
I really can't worry too much about what others think.  All in all, funky
techno tribe was such a BOMB ass party, that worrying that someone may
take my statements the wrong way is hardly a consideration.  But, for the
real possibility that I wasn't that clear, let me reemphasize.  Elitism
really sucks rocks, IMHO it's not what raving is about (although I would
never go as far as to say what raving should be for anyone other than
myself), and I'm afraid that even while I know many of the people that
started the whole sfraves thing, and while I'm very close to some of
these people, and certainly appreciate many (as in a great many) of you,
it's become very elitist as time has passed.  The example I gave was the
easiest to explain, required the least amount of text, and was based upon
fairly recent experience, but let me state clearly: IT'S HARDLY ABOUT GETTING
DOPE.  The thing that was so unbelievably righteous about the funky techno
tribe party was the completely insane number of people, and the incredibly
friendly way that this VERY diverse crowd treated each other.  It was quite
a sight.  I've really never seen such an inclusive, widespread vibe in all
my born days, with such cool people, and I was literally flabbergasted.

Since I don't get out that often, it's unclear when I'll next attend any
party, as I'm really quite busy at the moment, but I'm in no way saying
that friends and family sucks, but that I, for one, would really appreciate
people taking care to not play that elitist bullshit.  If I thought that
it was beyond hope, I wouldn't bother to mention it, but I know that a
number of you really care about these parties, and I think that's very
cool.  I feel that if I didn't tell you what I really think, then I'm
not really acting like friends *OR* family... honesty is a good thing, even
when it's not what you're hoping to hear.  So, perhaps I'll make the next
friends and family, or some event in the (hopefully not too distant) future,
and perhaps I won't feel "left out", but I could hardly even complain if I
did feel left out and didn't have the balls to say so.  Include *everybody*,
even if you think they "look like a gangster"... I really haven't met that
many gangsters ever, I'm not really even sure they exist.  Yes, there are
people out there who are completely fucked, and yes, they're less likely
to find your small hidden parties, but there are an immense number of very
cool people who you are also excluding, and I'd be very happy if friends &
family became a little more friendly to "unknowns"...


later,

-=jack=-

(This text composed by voice)

-=jack=- had this to say...

>>        Many times during the night, I though about you guys - many of my
>>friends, and just many people that had bad thoughts about the party.  I
>>wished you could have been there, to see with your eyes how great the party
>>was.  Many times while I was dancing I started writing this letter in my
>>head, so I could explain it better, but somehow all those thoughts are
>>scattered and I can't really put them on the paper.
>>------------
>It definitely sounds like you were at the same party I was (i.e. funky
>techno tribe).  I don't think I have EVER been to a party that had such
>a nice feeling, so many cool people (as in something like 4000... anyone
>know how many people actually attended that party?).

Well, someone mentioned 6500 yesterday, or was it 7500? =) I don't think it
was that many, but it was MASSIVE! =)

>Also, like you, I saw absolutely nothing negative the entire night.  I also
>bumped into people, as I don't always dance that well when I start getting
>really tired, etc., and was merely smiled at...

The vibe definitively not as bad as some people on this list kept telling us
it would be. Au contraire, the vibes I got from everyone were vibes of pure
happiness and friendship. If I'm allowed to compare it to a more "underground"
party, CCC w/ Goa Gil, the vibe was MUCH better on Saturday night.

>I might also add, that I did see alot of kids, dressed in many different
>types of clothing, but I saw no one I would consider "a gangster".

Although there were quite a few people in "gangster clothes" (which I really
don't have a problem with, they can wear what they want), I didn't see any
of the gangs that were all over the place at Ground Zero. Instead, the 
"gangsters" got into the music and experience just as much as anyone else at
HomeBase.

>Like I said, it was the best party in three or four years, for me...

Maybe not THE best party I've been too, but it was up there. And I'm not
just saying that cuz I got to see/hear Mr. Wink, this was a truly GREAT
party!

reespect, jonas

Truth of the matter is it is
easier to approach those you know than a stranger.
----------

What was so unbelievably cool about funky techno tribe was that people
who I had never met, and people who I may never meet again, took the
trouble to meet me, even though hanging with only their friends would have
been obviously "easier".  Like I say, yes, it's harder, but it also makes
that much more of an impression....  It's very cool to realize *how much*
harder it is to hang out with people you don't know, and to include them,
and then to actually see that happen.  To me, that's a real rave.

-=jack=-

"Let me have silence always in the centre of the shouting, that is
essential. Let me have silence so that no pin may drop and not be
heard, and not a whisper. Escape us for all our spouting, nor the
needle scratching upon this gramophone of the circular cosmic spot.
Hear me, mark me, learn me, throw the mind's ear open. Shut up the
mind's eye, all will be music. What sculpture of sound cannot, what
cannot as a fluid token words, that nothing else cannot." 

						-Wyndham Lewis


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Oct 28 13:45:02 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id NAA00330; Mon, 28 Oct 1996 13:45:02 -0800 (PST)
Received: from value.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with ESMTP id NAA00315; Mon, 28 Oct 1996 13:44:58 -0800 (PST)
Received: from localhost (scarab@localhost) by value.net (8.8.Beta.5/8.7.3) with SMTP id NAA16642 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 28 Oct 1996 13:44:56 -0800 (PST)
Date: Mon, 28 Oct 1996 13:44:56 -0800 (PST)
From: KaySEE <scarab@value.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Weekend-sunset
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.95.961028132542.14772A-100000@value.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, the only thing I made it to (after FnF getting busted) was sunset.
I have to say that this was my *first* sunset of the year besides the
first boat party.  I'm usually busy on Sundays, but I allowed my friends
to drag me out to the Marina after we went on a short bike ride in Tilden
Park.  Short because of rangers kicking us out due to extreme fire
danger which was disappointing, but understandable.  Anyway, I was
really looking forward to some gnarly hills that would beat me to the
ground and get rid of some of the anxiety, anger, and disappointment
that I've been in possession of lately.  I was hoping to dance really
hard at FnF, and maybe that would have done it, but it wasn't meant to be.

I was grumpy heading out to sunset, and I'm not sure why I went.  I had
other things to do, but part of me really wanted to go, especially after
FnF not happening.  We got there right as the sun was setting and Astral
Matrix was playing.  The crowd was truly impressive-the biggest sunset
crowd I've ever seen.  And everyone was so happy and *so* into the music.
Immediately I felt some of my tension loosening, and next thing I know I
am dancing like a fiend.  Astral Matrix really played some beautiful stuff
and ended with a tad of jungle.  I LOVED  it, and, most importantly, I
NEEDED it.  It is really amazing how you can let yourself sink into
laziness and then become bitter at the world.  

I have to say that I felt really good after dancing and being with such a
happy, exuberant crowd.  I watched the moon rise and everything go from
light to dark to light again.  It reminded me that to be happy one has to
work at it, something I forget from time to time.  

I danced so hard I got a blister on each foot!!  And my spirit returned,
or at least I was reminded of its existence.

I hope everyone had as much of a rewarding time as I did :)

-KaySEE

I've been on SFRaves for three months now, and I've not seen anything but 
welcoming arms.  I've been going to the parties, saying hello to people, 
talking to some, dancing alot, enjoying the vibe, getting hypnotized by 
the beat.

And just this last weekend, everything seemed to gel for me.  I started 
placing faces with names, meeting a lot of SFRavers with similar 
interests, and at Sunset yesterday, I  was able to go alone and find my 
newfound friends to hang out with!  That as cool; I haven't felt that 
since leaving college and dedicating my life to software.

Elitist?  Not at all.  Making GOOD friends takes time.  I like going to 
massives to see the diversity, to meet new people.  I like going to raves 
like FnF to be with people I know, if not by name, at least by sight.

I'm sorry you've felt "left out".  I hope we can meet sometime, maybe 
talk about snowboards, politics, or music?  In fact, of the near 500 (??) 
people on this list, I've only met a handful, and look forward to meeting 
more of you.

peace and love,

deeje

Sorry..this is kinda long...which is something i don't normally do.

Well...i hope i didn't start anything, though i'm not really sure i did.  My
post was about MY experiences and feelings and was not intended to upset or
embarass anyone.  

SOme background.......
I've been going to parties for like 6 years and truly hold a deep and strong
love for the scene( ALL of it).  But when i first started partying i went to
massives cuz that was all i knew and most of my friends went. I had a GREAT
time at those parties...it was strange to me to feel such positive energy
and to see so many happy and loving ppl., though i'm sure a lot of that was
due to drugs. ;) No really, it was really nice to feel all that positive
energy.  Whether it was the drugs or whatever, it still felt nice to have a
good time with so many ppl. and the MUSIC..WOW....but that's a completely
different story.

So i went to these massives and had fun..a LOT of fun.  But then i also
started to go to house parties and smaller events...and for one reason or
another i felt an EVEN better vibe at these parties.  They were much more
personal and that feeling of unity was much more present.  So i kept going
to both for a long time, but then my life began to change as well.  I
couldn't go to as many parties as before and now had to be much more
selective.  Not only was there a time constraint but my reasons for partying
began to change to one of self expansion and growth, not just having a good
time. Now i realize that both types of parties serve their purpose; the
massives introduced me to the scene and energy and the smaller parties
helped me find that energy in a purer form.  But it was the "smaller" ones
that gave me what i needed, don't forget i'm talking about ME and what i need.

So i began to go to more "small parties" and seemed to find what i was
looking for there. And as time progresses i guess i have become much more
content and comfortable with those parties. And, so, for several personal
reasons i now tend to be really selective about my parties.

Also..i don't have anything against massives and will still go if i believe
in what they are about.  AND i'm REALLY glad all u had fun at FTT....maybe i
was just looking for something different or maybe i was too blind to open my
eyes to what went on..but those were my experiences there and like anyone
else on the list i just wanted to share them with all of u.

I must admit that it felt better to give $5.00 to Fnf than $25 to FTT. And
it amazes me how ANYONE could do a good party for $5.00.

Glad everyone had a good weekend..wherever they ended up.

MUCHO PLUR -even to those that went to FTT.... =P  ;)

Micron

Date: Mon, 28 Oct 1996 15:12:09 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: lachim@uclink4.berkeley.edu (michal migurski)
Subject: FTT kwestions/komments
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

so, what was FTT like? I hear from the list that alot of people had fun.
However, my roommate ryan went (his first big rave) and although he had fun
as well, a few images stuck with him:

1) the bar outside. Selling alcohol at a rave? what the fuck???
2) the $2 water bottles. 2 bones is 2 much for water, esp. when the flyer
says it's free.
3) the brawl(s).
4) seeing a dodgy, speed-dealer looking type of guy walk up to one of the
ever-present cops and give him a phattie hi-five and a hug. hmmm...
5) getting kicked around and stepped on in the chill room, which apparently
had no beanbags, no couches, and no mattresses.
6) Too too many high school girls walking around in large groups clutching
their handbags tightly with that "fish-out-of-water" look on their faces.
7) having to walk through a line of hundreds of e-dealers on the way in,
all of them whispering "ecstasy... e... x..."

I don't even want to know how much FTT had to fork over to the Oakland PD
to get their approval for the shit going down there. There's no way I'd pay
$25 for a party where I was in any way doubtful of the crowd it was going
to attract. (see: radio ads, dodgy promotions, poster-sized flyers) My name
was on the guest list for FTT, but I CHOSE to pay for my FnF ticket, the
tickets of four friends, plus the toilet paper and trash bags that were
there. FTT went off because of the money involved, FnF went off because of
the love and energy and hard work involved!

smiles,
-m.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Oct 28 15:27:44 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id PAA10842; Mon, 28 Oct 1996 15:27:44 -0800 (PST)
Received: from xinet.COM by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with SMTP id PAA10829; Mon, 28 Oct 1996 15:27:40 -0800 (PST)

	 id PAA18574; Mon, 28 Oct 1996 15:26:23 -0800

 FTT..went to both" (Oct 28, 12:54pm)
 <ae9ab75b000210048fa5@[205.179.129.2]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 28 Oct 1996 15:26:18 -0800

        drenalin@salinas.net (Scott Nelson)
From: Tony Rotundo <tony@xinet.COM>

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Here's what I have to ask...

At 1:08 PM -0800 10/28/96, -=jack=- wrote:
>I didn't draw that conclusion simply on that basis.  I have been around
>a *very* long time, and I've had many experiences that have led me to tend
>to feel this way.  I simply don't like the elitism.  It's present whether
>or not one is looking for intoxicants...
Snip
>real possibility that I wasn't that clear, let me reemphasize.  Elitism
>really sucks rocks, IMHO it's not what raving is about (although I would
>never go as far as to say what raving should be for anyone other than
>myself), and I'm afraid that even while I know many of the people that
>started the whole sfraves thing, and while I'm very close to some of
>these people, and certainly appreciate many (as in a great many) of you,
>it's become very elitist as time has passed.  The example I gave was the
>easiest to explain, required the least amount of text, and was based upon
>fairly recent experience, but let me state clearly: IT'S HARDLY ABOUT GETTING
>DOPE.  The thing that was so unbelievably righteous about the funky techno
>tribe party was the completely insane number of people, and the incredibly
>friendly way that this VERY diverse crowd treated each other.  It was quite
>a sight.  I've really never seen such an inclusive, widespread vibe in all
>my born days, with such cool people, and I was literally flabbergasted.

>Since I don't get out that often, it's unclear when I'll next attend any
>party, as I'm really quite busy at the moment, but I'm in no way saying
>that friends and family sucks, but that I, for one, would really appreciate
>people taking care to not play that elitist bullshit.  If I thought that
>it was beyond hope, I wouldn't bother to mention it, but I know that a
>number of you really care about these parties, and I think that's very
>cool.  I feel that if I didn't tell you what I really think, then I'm
>not really acting like friends *OR* family... honesty is a good thing, even
>when it's not what you're hoping to hear.  So, perhaps I'll make the next
>friends and family, or some event in the (hopefully not too distant) future,
>and perhaps I won't feel "left out", but I could hardly even complain if I
>did feel left out and didn't have the balls to say so.  Include *everybody*,
>even if you think they "look like a gangster"... I really haven't met that

What are you suggesting short of me walking around a party and breaking
groups of people up, telling them "you're being too elitist.  Get out there
and meet more people."

What is it that the crew of FnF does that causes you to feel that we
practise elitism, and that FTT does that serves to negate it?  Are you
faulting FnF, the people that attend FnF, or are you just frustrated that
you haven't broken into an imaginary inner sanctum?

I don't want to come off harsh.  I completly understand the frustration of
not being part of what seems to be a big clique.  It's not.  What you are
seeing is a lot of people who see each other on a very regular basis,
meeting again.  When I began partying I went to four shows where I couldn't
get any candy either.  Most of them in the basement of 1015 Folsom.  I came
with one DJ friend, and of course he knew what seemed to be everyone.
Eventually, I started seeing some faces I remembered, through him, and
things started becoming more fun.  Then, at a free wicked at 1015 Folsom, I
blossomed.  I met no less than 20-30 people in one night, and that was all
it took.  From then on it seemed that I knew someone at most of the parties
I went to.

Jack, the bottom line is: only YOU can affect this kind of change.  You
can't expect me, as a crew member of FnF, to go around and make sure YOU
are being excepted into everyone's circle.  It's your responsibility to get
out and meet people, not mine.  All I do is invest huge hours of
back-breaking work, take financial and emotional risks, and try to provide
the best and safest environment for people to come together and listen to
quality music, and meet.  There is no way in hell we would practise
elitism, in fact I think you'll see more people from FnF practise
inclusionism than most other crews.  How many times at FnF have you seen an
exclusive DJ area behind the decks, where all the DJs hangout with their
others and never become part of the whole?  Never!

It sounds like you went in to FnF harboring ill feelings of elitism, and it
became a self-fulfilled prophecy.  You then went to FTT and let yourself go.

If there's one thing I can do well, Jack, it's getting strangers to meet
and converse.  I like that quality, it's contagious.  Next FnF, find me,
and I'll walk around with you and we can discuss instances where you are
seeing elitism practised...I'd really be interested in seeing the party
through your eyes.  Plus, I will introduce you to some of the greatest,
friendliest, selfless people you could ever hope to meet.

Peace and respect,

Tony Rotundo

>3) the brawl(s).

What's that???

>5) getting kicked around and stepped on in the chill room, which apparently
>had no beanbags, no couches, and no mattresses.

I have been to small, friendly parties (last Chrysalis for example) that
didn't have anything of that sort either - no beanbagsm, couches nor
mattresses, but you would always agree that Gateway parties are in the same
group as FnF

>6) Too too many high school girls walking around in large groups clutching
>their handbags tightly with that "fish-out-of-water" look on their faces.

I haven't see many of those - actually I saw many older ppl than at FnF and
Gateway parties....

>7) having to walk through a line of hundreds of e-dealers on the way in,
>all of them whispering "ecstasy... e... x..."

Where there are drugs, there will be dealers, some of them are quiet, some
are not, but that there were hundreds - little too much - maybe 20-30 (what
I saw).

>I don't even want to know how much FTT had to fork over to the Oakland PD
>to get their approval for the shit going down there. There's no way I'd pay
>$25 for a party where I was in any way doubtful of the crowd it was going
>to attract. (see: radio ads, dodgy promotions, poster-sized flyers) My name
>was on the guest list for FTT, but I CHOSE to pay for my FnF ticket, the
>tickets of four friends, plus the toilet paper and trash bags that were
>there. FTT went off because of the money involved, FnF went off because of
>the love and energy and hard work involved!

        I am not sure I agree with you that love and energy of the
promoters has to be what makes the party.  I think that love and energy of
people attending a party can make it as well.  And FTT didn't go off
because of the $$ involved, I agree it had to add some to the atmosphere,
but also the people there are people that made it.

        Also,  I can tell you for sure that some of the people that were
attracted to this party (at least the once I know) were as great as people
that were at FnF or smaller parties.

        The reason I am writing so much about FTT, is because I don't think
some of you are willing to listen at all.  You just go by what other ppl
say, which is wrong.  I have been to more small parties than massives, and
I do agree that they can be a lot of fun (I met many of you through them).
I chose last FnF over Theta, because I heard so much about their parties,
and I had one of the best times there.  I love majority of people I have
met through small parties, and I will continue to go to small parties when
I am up for a small party vibe, but I will also go to massives, with good
DJs to hear the music and be a part of the massive.

        Also, please think twice before you post ...  I am referring to
this comment:
"There's no way I'd pay
>$25 for a party where I was in any way doubtful of the crowd it was going
>to attract"

I was attracted to that party, as well as some of my friends?  What does
that make us?  I am also hurt (surprised) by reactions of *some* people who
went to FnF who keep bad things about FTT and people who went there.  Is
that really necessary?

Not really understanding where meaning of PLUR comes in play in some of the
posts,

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Oct 28 15:55:06 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id PAA13696; Mon, 28 Oct 1996 15:55:06 -0800 (PST)
Received: from twaxx.twaxx.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with SMTP id PAA13652; Mon, 28 Oct 1996 15:54:53 -0800 (PST)
Received: by twaxx.twaxx.com (940816.SGI.8.6.9/940406.SGI.AUTO)
	 id PAA13800; Mon, 28 Oct 1996 15:41:20 -0800
From: "-=jack=-" <jack@twaxx.twaxx.com>
Message-Id: <9610281541.ZM13798@twaxx.twaxx.com>
Date: Mon, 28 Oct 1996 15:41:17 -0800
In-Reply-To: lachim@uclink4.berkeley.edu (michal migurski)
        "FTT kwestions/komments" (Oct 28,  3:12pm)
References: <v0213050bae9aeb52415d@[128.32.160.61]>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.0 26oct94 MediaMail)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, lachim@uclink4.berkeley.edu (michal migurski)
Subject: Re: FTT kwestions/komments
Cc: geoffw@v-site.net
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

1) the bar outside. Selling alcohol at a rave? what the fuck???
---------
Actually, somewhere around 8 AM, a beer starts to sound like a damn
good idea, although I didn't have one while there.  They also were grilling
hamburgers and other stuff like that.  I wasn't particularly in the mood,
but it was cool that it was there.  As far as the alcohol goes, I didn't
see any problems as a result of it, and wasn't even aware that it was
available, but given that they were grilling burgers, it's not too far a
stretch.



3) the brawl(s).
---------------
Never saw anything akin to this all night, but, as I said, it was much
too large an event to exhaust (meaning, that even somebody on speed couldn't
get to/cover everything going on), so there might have been a brawl.  I
saw no such thing, but it's possible it did happen.  It must have been
over pretty damn quick, though, because I did scope out the entire venue,
and I particularly enjoy roaming around at these things, so I did see all
the rooms, and frequented nearly all of them throughout the night.



4) seeing a dodgy, speed-dealer looking type of guy walk up to one of the
ever-present cops and give him a phattie hi-five and a hug. hmmm...
----------------
Now that's plain creepy, I don't know what to infer.  However, I would say
that labeling someone a "speed-dealer looking type of guy" is quite possibly
inaccurate labeling... and I do know people like Geoff White think it's a
good idea to make friends with the cops, if at all possible (sometimes it's
obviously not possible... if so, usually best to give them a wide berth).
Perhaps this "dodgy speed dealer" was just some spun raver trying to include
the "stiff policeman" in the fun... it does happen, although I'm usually not
the one to take such risks.  If, in fact, there is collusion between speed
dealers and police, and that's what was happening, then I must agree that's
pretty sketchy situation, but it's entirely possible that what happened had
nothing to do with "speed dealing" whatsoever.  There were a ton of whispers
about X though... and lots of people looked pretty buzzed.  Being that I'm
"old", I often get treated to suspicion at times, and maybe what was seen
was somebody my age being friendly to a cop, as it does happen.  Or perhaps
not.  There's obviously a serious problem with both our drug laws and with
police corruption so it's not beyond the realm of possibility.  Did anyone
see anyone getting busted?  I didn't...



5) getting kicked around and stepped on in the chill room, which apparently
had no beanbags, no couches, and no mattresses.
--------------------
Yes, there were no beanbags, nor mattresses that I saw in there, which would
have been better.  However, rather than being kicked, some unknown person in
a pile of people on the floor played with my hair and gave me a quite nice
hand massage (not that kind of massage, silly, he/she massaged my *hand*!).  I
agree that beanbags would have been the shit, but nevertheless it hardly
detracted from the fun I had, although lying around in there certainly would
have been more comfortable.  The getting kicked part could also have been
somebody stumbling... I know I stumbled on *at least* one person, to whom I
apologized profusely... which apparently amused her no end, as judged by
her reaction.  There were times when it was hard to navigate through the
bodies...


6) Too too many high school girls walking around in large groups clutching
their handbags tightly with that "fish-out-of-water" look on their faces.
----------------
I did see lots of young girls, young boys, older girls, older boys... to
tell the truth, almost all ravers look pretty young to me, but like I said,
I'm "old"....  I didn't really see anyone looking like a "fish out of water",
but that's somewhat subjective also, and it's entirely possible I looked
that way myself somewhere around 5:30...


$25 for a party where I was in any way doubtful of the crowd it was going
to attract. (see: radio ads, dodgy promotions, poster-sized flyers)
------------------
I too was very doubtful from the outset.  Probably because of where it
was held, but as *B* mentioned, they did some really cool things with that
space that made it much better than the (only) other time I've been there.
As for the "Live 105 crowd", I really couldn't tell... what do they look
like?


FTT went off because of the money involved
---------------
That's complete horseshit.  It went off because the environment was good,
the music was slamming, the people wanted to party and everyone was really
friendly.  Yes, obviously that production took serious dollars to put on,
but I'd say your opinion is unnecessarily cynical.  It was a complete hoot,
and it looked to me like everyone there was having a great time.  I would
also say that it's very likely that the funky techno tribe people worked
rather hard also, as the evidence of it was everywhere.  Why do some folks
feel compelled to bag so hard?  It's unfortunate that your friend or whoever
it was had a lousy time, I would have been happy to hang out with whoever
it was that wasn't feeling too good about things, but like I said, I didn't
see really anyone fitting that description....  Just because the current
popular logic says that "massives suck" doesn't mean that they always do,
and to put on an event that large with that good a scene, and to keep it
raging the way it was for so long is akin to building a bridge in the 1920's,
in terms of what it takes to put on parties.  I can only begin to imagine
the insanely complicated logistics that must surely have been necessary to
put that party at the level it was.  For that, I have utmost respect, as
we have all seen what massives look like when that isn't done, and it
isn't pretty.  This was very pretty, very pretty indeed...

Are any of the promoters for funky techno on this list?  I would be
curious to know about some of the things they had to do to make that
thing go off successfully without the police, or any other unfriendly
entity screwing it up.  Whatever they did, it sure worked.  Besides, it
isn't a competition, we're not (or rather I'm not) in the "business" of
being cooler than thou, and the best thing about Saturday was that I
really didn't have to deal with any attitude whatsoever.  I was expecting
to endure hardships, as I've seen big raves turn out really bad, but
in retrospect, I think that I'll revise my thinking, as going with the
"current popular logic" that massives suck, was definitely proven wrong.
On the other hand, there are definitely shifty promoters around (I've
heard that the Acme place was pretty scary, for example, and that if a
fire or something happened, many would be injured or worse), but I
would say that this party was pretty solid evidence the funky techno tribe
promoters are into throwing good events, even though I once went to a
funky techno tribe party at Cesar's Latin Palace which wasn't anywhere
near as good.  This time around they rocked it right, boy...

-=j=-


--

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Oct 28 16:26:37 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id QAA16992; Mon, 28 Oct 1996 16:26:37 -0800 (PST)
Received: from uclink4.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with ESMTP id QAA16984; Mon, 28 Oct 1996 16:26:34 -0800 (PST)

From: "b. denny" <bdabrams@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
To: -=jack=- <jack@twaxx.twaxx.com>

Subject: Re: Fnf vs. FTT..went to both
In-Reply-To: <9610281308.ZM12919@twaxx.twaxx.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.ULT.3.93.961028154844.3911C-100000@uclink2.berkeley.edu>

On Mon, 28 Oct 1996, -=jack=- wrote:
> to find your small hidden parties, but there are an immense number of very
> cool people who you are also excluding, and I'd be very happy if friends &
> family became a little more friendly to "unknowns"...

i'm not going to be one of those ppl who says "massives suck!"... you had
a lot of fun, and i'm glad you did.

i'd like to say this:

i've been raving for 3 months. that's all. there have been times when i
felt like an outsider looking at a clique, there have been times when i
couldn't meet anybody...

but meet people i have. i've met a lot of people. at FnF i met more people
than i could count. how? by trying.

one way to meet people in this "clique" is just by asking. that's how i
went to my first rave. i emailed someone on sfraves who seemed friendly,
and asked if i could join him in going to a party he said he was going
to. he said to call him, i did, and the rest is history. first i met his
friends, then i met their friends...

now i know many people, including several who are involved with throwing
"underground" parties. i've become involved with one such group myself,
just by asking someone how i could help out.

because of the bust at FnF, i knew fewer ppl than i normally would. so i
met people. i met _more_ people at FnF than i have _ever_ met before in
one night. _especially_ hanging out in the parking lot waiting for the new
location. people came up and introduced themselves, hugged, gave out
candy...

i only wish i could remember the names of everyone i hugged.

i know i met at least 5 sfravers i hadn't met before: Deeje Cooley, Jay
Wiley, BlackAdder, Tony Rotundo, and Tony Rose. i met a huge number (a
couple dozen? that's huge for me) of non-sfravers, including a few who
i'll be keeping in touch with outside of raving.

some tactics used for meeting people:
introducing yourself randomly.
giving out candy/stickers.
offering water (or hugs or anything else).
smiling.

sound hard? (it can be. i'm usually really shy, and there have been times
when everything on the above list has seemed impossible. but it's really
not.)

my point is this: sfraves/friends&family/etc. IS, in a sense, a clique.

but it's the easiest clique to join that i've ever seen. all you have to
do is put out a little teensy bit of "friendly energy", and you'll be
welcomed with open arms.

i am a case in point: i've gone from knowing nothing about raves and
nobody who raved, to knowing dozens of awesome people. and i met them all
at "underground" parties and/or through eachother.

i hope to see you at a party someday. to me, these parties are more about
"friends and family" (ie, people) than anything else, so i usually stick
to the undergrounds. (on thanksgiving day, i'm driving to modesto to see
my blood relatives, then i'm driving back in the evening to party with my
_real_ "family". i'd never do this to party with 6000 people i didn't
know. but that's just me.)

love,

brian

> I seriously started dancing around 11pm and was waiting for Dan to
> come on.  Dan (as most of the times) really kicked ass.  People were
> dancing like crazy and it was great to see all the energy that was creat
> on the dance floor.  

			I was one of those people who went off the floor
			with engery from the power of Dan's set =)

						MHg


> 
> - running into the astronaut from Burning Man
> 
> - getting help from the medical team (I manage to hurt myself, taking a
> short cut to the bathroom, and needed some minor medical help to stop the
> bleeding on my back)
> 
> - getting a plastic glow-bracelet from this guy who was dancing with his GF
> close to us
> 
> - leaving a stuffed animal there (on purpose) and actually having this guy
> pick it up and give it to somebody as a present
> 
>         Thanks FTT crowd, thanks all of you wonderful people who were there
> and who brought the positive energy with you.  FTT was definitely my
> favorite massive, and maybe my favorite party I went to so far.
> 
> --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
> 
>         Many times during the night, I though about you guys - many of my
> friends, and just many people that had bad thoughts about the party.  I
> wished you could have been there, to see with your eyes how great the party
> was.  Many times while I was dancing I started writing this letter in my
> head, so I could explain it better, but somehow all those thoughts are
> scattered and I can't really put them on the paper.
> 
>         I was surrounded by hundreds of people, and never in those 10 hours
> I was there, I felt the negative energy.  I had people come up to me and
> introduce themselves just because they wanted to (not because I put the
> description on the list).  I met people, because they were sharing the same
> dance floor as I was and after dancing for hours we just wanted to know who
> was the person next to us with whom we shared that amazing experience.  I
> accidentally hit people while dancing with my eyes closed (one time I had
> my fingers in somebody's mouth and almost ripped his upper lip), and
> although they would have maybe passed as gangster types, they just smiled
> and walked away. I saw people who were hungry for great music and who
> wanted to be there for it and enjoy every minute of it.
> 
>         I didn't get many hugs and I didn't get stickers offered to me at
> every corner, but that is not what I was looking for.  Reading other
> people's posts and hearing that people did see the bad energy, makes me
> wander if I was maybe at the right spot at the party the entire night.  But
> then it also makes me wander if it is true when people say "if you do
> something with negative expectations and just look for negative things -
> you will see them".  IMO, taking "happy drugs" to get the negative energy
> away from you and waiting for drugs to kick in to have fun is the most
> ridicules thing.  You should have fun in the first place, otherwise it's
> time to go home.
> 
>         Many people say how massives are not put together with love and
> positive energy, how they are too expensive etc.  It cost $25, but that's
> the money that went into the space, permits, stages, visuals, DJs etc...  I
> didn't mind spending that money because I had one of the best times of my
> life.  I am glad I gave FTT another chance and didn't blow them off,
> although I had two good reasons - my last FTT party that I wasn't too fond
> of and well as many people on this list "bitching" about how the party will
> suck.  Once again I proved to myself that find out for yourself is the best
> way, rather than listening to others.
> 
>         Sorry this is so long, I just want some of you to see how I felt.
> I am glad people had fun at FnF, but I also hope some day, some of those
> people who keep dissing massives will give than a change and see for
> themselves how great  they can be.
> 
> Hugz to all,
> Branka
> 
> P.S.  the most depressing moment of the night - one of the people I know
> came up to me and asked me with a sad look on her face and pity in her eyes
> "so, you didn't get tickets to FnF, ha?"
> 
>

lachim@uclink4.berkeley.edu had this to say...

>so, what was FTT like? I hear from the list that alot of people had fun.

FTT was great, and I don't regret for ONE second not trying to get FnF tix.

>1) the bar outside. Selling alcohol at a rave? what the fuck???

No big deal. Some people like to drink to have fun, other prefer to take e
or smoke a bowl or two. They sell alcohol in most clubs I've been to. Why?
Because people want it, and isn't that what it's all about, giving the people
what THEY want?

>3) the brawl(s).

Didn't see a single one.

>4) seeing a dodgy, speed-dealer looking type of guy walk up to one of the
>ever-present cops and give him a phattie hi-five and a hug. hmmm...

Aren't we being just a LITTLE bit hostile and prejudice right here? Describing
someone as a "speed-dealer looking type" does NOT go hand in hand with PLUR,
or you think it does?

>7) having to walk through a line of hundreds of e-dealers on the way in,
>all of them whispering "ecstasy... e... x..."

Don't know why that would be a problem. It's not like one has to stop at every
dealer and talk to them about their merchandise.

>There's no way I'd pay $25 for a party where I was in any way doubtful of the
>crowd it was going to attract. (see: radio ads, dodgy promotions,
poster-sized
>flyers) 

Well, that's your point of view. Personally, I prefer to keep an open mind
towards events. Too bad a lot of people tend to swing from promoting Peace,
Love and all then to trying to discriminate some people. Does that make sense?
I think not.
(Yes, I know I bashed 6 in the Morning for Ground Zero, but their policy of 
letting girls ahead in the line is just another example of discrimation)

>My name was on the guest list for FTT, but I CHOSE to pay for my FnF ticket, 
>the tickets of four friends, plus the toilet paper and trash bags that were
>there.

And you had a great time, right? So did most of the people who went to FTT,
how about we leave it at that? =)

reespect, jonas

Well I read and read about everyone else's Point of view on FTT.  And to
add my bit, all I have to say is:

		-Never will I attend a Funky Tekno Tribe again.


I had a stellar time.  I danced all night long.  Broke into a few
circles.  Threw down some serious moves.  Heard some serious beats and
breaks. Smiled, chatted, and had an all around grande time.

However...  

I stabbed at _Lust for Life_ when they had Ethan and Dutch on the flyer
allthough they were not confirmed.  
I voiced my opinion at Planetarium when A band (10BassT) was scheduled
that I knew would not appear.
And I feel the same way when I had to pay 12$ worth of water (throughout
the night) when it was advertised as free...

C'mon leave the lies to the politicans and propisitions.  If someone
says it free, then it's free (ie. chrystalsis, a few of the F-8 's).  If
it's not, don't lie.

We are come into this world with our word and honor.  Hydration is a
very important thing.  FTT broke it's word.  

There are other productions.
There are always other massives...


---Adam
"Stay Connected..."

This is what I see as a very serious problem that can turn the massives vs
smaller parties thread even more negative...it is easy to feel resentment
towards the  people that attend massives and the promoters that throw
massives since through this sort of corruption they are allowed to get
away with blatant stuff while at FnF it was clear that there was nothing
but good vibes happening andFnF got shut down...but I think a really
important thing to remember is that that is a result of the police and
THEIR system, not the promoters or happy massive goers that just want to
have fun...just an attempt to identify the enemy...lets not let them turn
us on ourselves!

tony rose
