On Mon, 28 Oct 1996, b. denny wrote:

> my point is this: sfraves/friends&family/etc. IS, in a sense, a clique.
> 
> but it's the easiest clique to join that i've ever seen. all you have to
> do is put out a little teensy bit of "friendly energy", and you'll be
> welcomed with open arms.
> 
> i am a case in point: i've gone from knowing nothing about raves and
> nobody who raved, to knowing dozens of awesome people. and i met them all
> at "underground" parties and/or through eachother.

	I suppose what this argument is not really about elistism but
instead is how different cultures come together. The cliques that
exist in the smaller parties tend to not be very open to people who do not
use the same "standard" of communication - take all the threads on
gangsters as case in point. Then look at what happens when people from the
FnF lifestyle go to something like a Ghost tibe production - they feel
like the out siders at a G boy party, but those parties do not have very
vocal member of the sfraves community if they are present at all.
	Maybe this is not clear yet. My observations have benn each
culture has its own way of communicating. Things that in one cultures are
signs of respect may be interpreted as signs of aggression in the other
culture. An example, if you are waiting for the train in Glasgow, you
probably should not make eye contact with most of the people on the
platform because you must think you are some kind of hard ass to be eyeing
someone over there, even if they are standing by the Coke machine and you
are debating whether you want a soda for the train. The cliques of the
smaller party "elitist" community want everyone to be able to make eye
contact and smile, but that will get you killed in some parts of the
world. 

	So, as long as one is willing to communicate with the people at 
smaller parties on their terms, it is not an elitist community right? But 
wait, is it elitist to ask people to communicate with you based on the 
majority of people there will communicate with you in those terms? What 
if a certain cultures behavior brings the level of energy of the party 
down at a party where the majority of the people are aimed at pushing the 
energy through the roof (Ok, my personal thing)?!

	So how to reconcile the groups involved? How do we let people 
alone to do what they want without getting in the way of what we are 
trying to do? Which compromises do we make? How many compromises do we have 
to make? How many compromises are the other groups making in accepting an 
outsider? Do you know if the other person's silliness is an act or their 
hard ass stance is a front? Can you figure it out without talking to 
them? Do you want to figure it out? Are you an elitist if you don't?

	Somehow other parts of the world have worked this out because I 
have been to parties with more energy on the dance floor than 
almost any party I have been to here (although the Chyralis last December 
might have been about equal, especially if the needles wouldn't have been 
skipping due to everyone dancing so hard).

dave

Hello! This has been in the works for a while, and it's finally time
to announce it!

On Thursday, Novemember 28th 1996 AD, please join us for:
                    Thanksgiving!!!

This will be an evening to celebrate with good food and music, and
to give thanks for the wonderful people and things that we have in
our lives. :)

This party is especially dedicated to people who (like myself) are not
originally from the Bay Area, and have no family to see... or just
can't make it out to be with their families. Why have a boring night
alone, eating Ramen? Party with us instead!!! Let's make our *own*
family this Thanksgiving!

DJ's for the night:

Mystr-E (frequency 8)
John Carel (gateway systems)
Anon (look for her at mantra :)
Warren Parker (one track mind)
Jon Logan (ambiance during dinner)

Dinner will be provided by Raw, a restaurant in SF specializing in
raw, super-energizing foods, and of course will be 100% vegan :)

Dinner and ambient music will begin around 9pm-ish, with trance music
running until 7 the next morning. The party will be in San Francisco,
and due to the size of the location, we'll have room for only about
200 or so people, so come early! :)

voicemail: 415.248.1997 (saturn5)

from your favorite happy turkey, ;)

Steve

PLEASE HELP ME I CAN'T STOP LISTENING TO IT

- hooray!  wonderful decorations on walls and especially ceiling!  but!
i have never been in a more humid or muddier rave room - the pipes were
sweating before the room was half full ... i wonder why i didn't mind?

experiments in endurance dancing are HERE and AMONG US.  warning - hugging
them may result in enjoyable chromosome damage.

goa from 2 to 4 am?

In-Reply-To: <v02130500ae9ab56bac44@[205.178.41.41]>

Precedence: bulk


The part of your post that you had mentioned accidently hitting someone 
while dancing with your eyes closed particularily grabbed my attention.  

While on this general sfraves topic of comparing massives to more 
underground parties and how the "underground movement seems friendlier 
than massives", Branka's statement made me think of something that 
occured at the "very undergound" F&F party that happened Saturday night. 

I was dancing hard in the thick of the crowd right in front of the dj, a 
few people back from the tables.  The crowd was thick and in a dancing 
frenzy.  In that type of dancing crowd, getting bumped every now and then 
just happens and it is no big deal.  If I jab someone or step on their 
toes, I apologize.  

But there was this chick dancing in the thick of it with all of us and 
she was flailing her body around quite disrespectfully (to others).  She 
was taking up WAY too much room and she was right next to me, constantly 
bumping into me and not even acknowledging that she had done it.  Often 
her flailing hands would come within inches of my face and I was 
literally frightened that I would get seriouly scratched by her 
fingernails.  I really wanted to yell at her to knock it off, but 
didn't.  It did piss me off.

So my point is that this kind of behavior is not being reserved for 
massives.  It goes on in the most underground of small raves.

love,
Amy

Hi Matt and the 362 people who got the CD ,

The Cd is titled "The Language of Light" and is on Ceiba Records wich is
part of Hunab Ku. for all of you wondering what the track listing for the CD is.

1. Ceiba - Rainbow Warrior
2. Cyclics - Movement within the 4th dimension
3. UV 13 - The Pharm
4. Kode IV - Firestarter (RMX by Ceiba)
5. The Nommos - Po Tolo (B Sirius mix)
6. State of Trance - Alien Prophecy
7. Whirling Merkabas - Electric Moss
8. Ceiba - Pacal (Ahau mix)
9. Ceiba - 1+1=1

The Nommos is Goa Gil, Ariane, Peter Z.
Ceiba is DJ Caban (Adam) & Peter Z.
Cyclics is Guy Frenkel & Ran Pink
UV 13 & Whirling Merkabas are Jeffery and Carlo from C.C.C
State of trance is Ido loran

Thanks for all of your feedback on the party and the CD. Sorry I can't reply
to all of you, as I am inundated with a wealth of responses and I am the
slowest of typers.

Also a reminder about Samhain this weekend this should be one incredible party.

With DJ's 

Caban (Ceiba,Hunab Ku)
Anon (Hunab Ku)
Jeremy Starseed (C.C.C)
Dutch (Iner eye)
Max & Ivo (Sri Yantra)
Neal (C.C.C)
 plus more but I cant find the flyer right now and cant remember the rest.

Oh yeah and a sunrise Chakra ritual by Antara (Return to the Source)

Lots of love

Ayahuasca

Subject: fnf, elitism, parties, doleisms
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I read the littany of threads about all of the parties everyone attended.
It seems eeveryone had a good time.  To me, that is the good thing.

I just wanted to make note of some of jacks observations SINCE they are teh
same observations I've made about this list, and parties in general.

>From my view, we are all part of cliques.  ti cannot be helped.  I bleieve
someone said that everything is dependent upon the mode/method of
communication, and I agree.

I have not been to an fnf, ever.  I've wanted to go for years, but
something has always come up, I chock it up to karma, and the possible fact
I was not meant to go.  fnf isn't the only party I'm not to attend, burning
man is another...every year I plan, and every year something happens.  Oh
well.

Anyway I think Jack has some very good points as they relate to elitism and
cliques.  Sfraves, fnf, sandbox, and other small UG events are in many ways
cliques.  SFraves is a clique because you need a computer.  Fnf is becuase
it is an extension (to some degree) of SFRaves, sandbox is becuase you have
got to know one of the primaries to get in...and the list goes on.  In
other words, if you do not have access to the mode/method of communication,
you're automatically locked out.  Just a fact of dance culture (and believe
me, there are hundreads of thousands of people who have yet to rave, and
thousands who are looking for one to go to and STILL didn't find it DESPITE
four color flyers everywhere!).

Massives are massives and UG's are UG's.  The type of people forming these
groups will have a direct effect on the people in attendence.  FTT is all
about the brown, the guys who throw it are people of color, and it shows.
FnF has it's people, and it is refelcted in the crowd, it also shows.
Preston's parties have a mix, but homeboy is straight and his parties tend
to be a bit (if not totally) het.  And the list goes on and on.

I have come to accept the fact that if I want diversity, *I* have to throw
the dig myslef (like I used to, and yes, it showed), or just wait for
someone with my ideals to do it for me.  Some parties, due to the method of
communication etc. are exclusionary...not on purpose, but as a result of
said communication only being available or accessible by a very few.  And
those who are lucky enough to be in the communications chain will invite
thier friends, who are a reflection of themselves.  You get the idea.

So all in all, there is plenty in SF and the bay area for everyone and for
every type.  From the tech geek, to the circle dancer, there is plenty to
go around.  I'm pretty much through with pointing out the good or bad in
parties.  I mention it to close friends, but in general try not to rain on
anyones parade.  Since people are at least dancing and not killing each
other, I figure it's all good.  At least it's a small step in the right
direction.

As for breakin' into cliques, etc.  It just takes time, and a willing
guide.  Even *I*, with all my years of crackerjack socialization looks for
a guide before stepping into unfamiliar territory, no matter where it is.

With that, I'm glad everyone partied thier asses off.  I did mine a few
weeks ago, and it was all good.  Especially when I got home!

Take care all, and remember...don't call *me* a raver...instead, just call me,
John

Peace out.

P.S.  Bob Dole - nothing but a stinky pen, and a penchant for saying
"whatever" as he meanders toward defeat.  Pitiful...

Bill "George" Clinton - "I didn't inhale, but I slept with your wife."

H. Ross Perot - Just get under the hood and give me a lobotomy.

Harry Brown - just another pot smoking republican who wants to privatize
everything.

Ralph Nader - cheap bastard, and boy is he shrill.  The only enemy is a
corporation.

Natural Law Party - better living through meditation...I'll meditiate on it.

Taxpayers something or other - a not so cloaked ultra-right wing
bible-beating heretics out to make the world safe for fetuses everywhere.

Yep, I'm really proud to be an American...look at whose trying to represent
me, and not a female or person of color in the bunch.  Ys, as Dole ai,
we aredomd.
orseyt:  I'm voting for the MDnalds atin' ftby. At leas knw'm voig for a coplete hpocritews mde no os aboutis
hyocrs. Aea leader...h-huh...

>         I didn't get many hugs and I didn't get stickers offered to me at

> you will see them".  IMO, taking "happy drugs" to get the negative energy

From: Austin Woffington <awoffing@tuba.aix.calpoly.edu>
To: I_wanna_Dance! <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Weekend: Lunaseed...FTT...Sunset! :)
Message-Id: <Pine.A32.3.91.961028225643.35887C-100000@tuba.aix.calpoly.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0

Hey all!

Well I didn't expect to come up this weekend but unfortunatly my uncle 
and grandma both pasted away.  I came up to be with family and friends as 
well.  I thought...as long as I'm up here...

Well Friday I went to the Sound Factory.  I wasn't having a good time at 
the meatmarket so I decided to go find Russ street and check out Goa Gil.
I had trouble parking, forgot my tix at the map point and lost a friend 
but after all that I got to "spacestation" around 1am

I'd never heard Goa Gill before and I can't remember the last time I 
heard Adam but It was all good.  Great decor many black lights, very hot 
down stairs but I liked it - Everyone did!   Met some great interesting 
people (some I saw again at Sunset) and Caban got me movin'

Gil came on around 3 and WOW.  I tried my best to take a break and sit 
down but I couldn't doit. Something about that damn Goa just gets into 
your head, arms, legs, and body and you just can't stop moving.

I couldn't stay till the end because I danced the whole time I was there, 
and I left around 7am.  I was told that GG was to spin till 11 I couldn't 
stay that long.  Did he?   I had a great trip, Hunab Ku, C.C.C., Gil, 
Caban any every one else did a great job.  

Saturday was FTT but I am a broke college student and didn't have the 
money to pay for it.  I could have scamed it but I felt it wasn't worth 
it.  I tried to get on the guest list but ethan who was doing masage 
theropy had to pay as well so he couldn't get me in anyways.  My parent were 
gone so I had a few friends over and we just chilled and a friend brought over
 his tables.

I found out the next morning that another friend got me on the list but 
forgot to tell me and I could have gone for free anyways.  Doh!  Oh well 
there will be more FTT's and more massives to attend.  I'm glad you all 
had a great time.

Sunday I had to drive back to SLO but decided to go to the last sunset.  
And I'm Glad I did.  So many great faces, smiling, dancing and having a 
great time.  I saw so many people I hadn't seen in a while and Sunset 
made up for the missed evening at FTT.  I wish I could of stayed till hte 
end but it's a 3 hour drive home and I left at 6.30 to get home in time 
to finsh homework.  Believe me, I used some serious will power to drag 
myself out of the middle of all the grooving ravers to drive myself home.

If I come up again it might be on November 9th; other than that I won't 
come up till the Gathering.

Till the next~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PLUR

Austin

>There are a couple of full moon parties tomorrow night (hope it stops
>raining by then), then a free park party on Saturday afternoon, then
>the massive Funky Tekno Tribe.  There just might be something else
>going on Saturday as well, if you keep your eyes and ears open ;).

>   Prevention Studies

>Radio/TV Shows
>
>     * Sunday morning 9am-11am - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon - Beats, Breakz
>       and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford).
>     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
>       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
>       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
>     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
>       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
>       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
>     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
>       Monkeywrench. Varied techno sub-genres, noise, spoken word, world
>       music. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
>     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
>       (Berkeley)
>     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
>       available on Realaudio
>     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
>       90.3 (SF)
>     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
>       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
>     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
>       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
>       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
>     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
>       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
>     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
>       KMEL.
>     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
>     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
>       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
>     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
>       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
>     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
>       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
>     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
>       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
>       281-3377. flux@flux.net
>     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
>       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
>     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
>       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Oct 29 02:26:32 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id CAA11856; Tue, 29 Oct 1996 02:26:32 -0800 (PST)
Received: from upsmot01.msn.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with SMTP id CAA11849; Tue, 29 Oct 1996 02:26:30 -0800 (PST)
Received: from upmajb02.msn.com (upmajb02.msn.com [204.95.110.74]) by upsmot01.msn.com (8.6.8.1/Configuration 4) with SMTP id CAA17384 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 29 Oct 1996 02:25:28 -0800
Date: Tue, 29 Oct 96 10:22:55 UT
From: "Funky Tekno Tribe Sound System " <FunkyTekno@msn.com>
Message-Id: <UPMAIL03.199610291025420074@msn.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Thanks from The Funky Tekno Tribe - long
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi All,
Whew! What a weekend! We're still recovering. Four days of setting up the 
various rooms, dealing with missed flights, delayed baggage (containing 
records), pickups and returns of DJs from SF to Oakland and back, making sure 
a party of this size runs smoothly, running from room to room to catch a 
favourite DJ can take a physical and mental toll on one's body. First, I'd 
like to thank ALL who came out and supported FTT's four years of existence at 
our Halloween Tribal Massive. You were totally AWESOME! No serious incidents, 
a few minor bruises and scratches that our First Aid team professionally took 
care of, 7500 ravers in all shapes and forms... old schoolers, kids, freaks, 
suits, gangstas, metalheads, east bay, south bay, nerds, queens, kids from LA, 
Seattle, Portland ...were there with ONE purpose - to celebrate music and 
dance!!! And boy did we boogie down through the night!! My only regret was 
that I wasn't able to be in the Planet of the Drumz room for DJ Rap's and DJ 
SS's set... I heard it was legendary!!!
I would also like to make some apologies to all. Firstly, the lines WERE 
definitely too long and though we tried something different with the lines at 
Homebase this time... it didn't quite work. We're working on keeping that 
down. Secondly, the party started late, mainly due to last minute production 
set-ups. We're very into our production, so we wanted to make all the rooms 
just right, which ended up in last minute changes in set design.  And for the 
folks out there who did not have a good time for one reason or another, our 
personal apologies. Lastly, for someone who mentioned about alcohol being 
served, there wasn't any.
Massives cannot compete on the same level as smaller parties when it comes to 
that personal vibe. I go to a lot of parties talked about on SFRaves... and 
agree wholeheartedly. What we at FTT try to do is to try and create a 
compromise with the quality of music and production. We also want to spread 
the spirit of raving to the entire community of people who love music and love 
dance, which is why there was a diverse crowd last Saturday. It gave me a real 
good feeling when I saw some heavy-metal friends I forced to go last Saturday, 
actually standing up and grooving in their leathers and chains when Diesleboy 
pumped his thing!! And seeing rastas raising their hands when Springheel Jack 
played that totally wicked drum-and-bass raggae track!!  And when the circle 
dancers formed (one of them was actually a record company executive in a suit) 
and break-danced in the Quango Room to some excellent jungle that Tomas was 
spinning, I was totally blown away!!! Which is what raving is all about... it 
is for everyone because it is IN everyone... and massives are usually (though 
not always) the way to initiate the uniniated.
Anyway, I'd like to thank everyone once again for the support, encouragement 
and love we got. We've a few more events lined up before the year closes. On 
November 15th there is Funky Tekno Tribe vs Porno for Pyros aka rave vs 
alternative... we have a few interesting things lined up for this one. Come if 
you can. We'll also be throwing our last Organic in the Park for the year with 
a very special guest. Oh, for all of those who complained about how our web 
site sucked (yeah, yeah, I admit it did, but what do you expect when you use 
Microsoft's Frontpage wizards ;), check it out now...  
URL:http://www.funkytekno.com  Also, check out our new logo. Criticisms 
welcomed!!

love and regards,
Mohan
Funky Tekno Tribe

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Oct 29 05:14:05 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id FAA24147; Tue, 29 Oct 1996 05:14:05 -0800 (PST)
Received: from precipice.v-site.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with SMTP id FAA24141; Tue, 29 Oct 1996 05:14:02 -0800 (PST)
Received: from ecotopia by precipice.v-site.net (8.6.10/SM-8.6.4)
	id FAA20455; Tue, 29 Oct 1996 05:16:33 -0800
Message-Id: <199610291316.FAA20455@precipice.v-site.net>
From: "Geoff White" <geoffw@cybertribe.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Review:Funky Techno Tribe (long)
Date: Tue, 29 Oct 1996 05:14:23 -0800
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Priority: 3
X-Mailer: Microsoft Internet Mail 4.70.1155
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

It's rare that I bother to give reviews these days,  I'm mostly content to
lurk on the list
and observe all the foolishness that goes down from time to time. 
Sometimes things
get so outrageous that I'm almost pushed to post but then again I say "why
bother".
But I felt this time that I really needed to post about this party because
it seemed that
a lot of people had a good time (myself included) and it also seemed that
several whiners
felt compelled to dis a party (for various reasons and to compare it to a
failed FnF which
(IIMHO) totally disses FTT and FnF.  I know the promoters of both parties
personally,
all of them have the utmost respect for the partygoes that come to their
party and a deep
reverence for the music played whether it is Trance or Trip Hop.  It was my
intention to go to
both parties that night but (in usual fashion :) I didn't get out of the
house and to FTT till
2 a.m. and by that time I heard FnF had been busted.  I felt bad for Ethan
cuz I know how badly he
wanted to bring the house down and have a kick ass party.  There is no
question in my mind that 
Ethan will deliver the goods in due time and have one killer make-up party.
I admire his stamina
and dedication cuz I know the workload he must be under.  That is why it
really bother's me to
hear so called "ravers" dising and complaining about FTT that was fortunate
to go off. I don't
understand where these people are coming from at all with that kind of
attitude.

As Allways :) Maybe a little grand-pa raver story is in order:

The guys from Funky Techno Tribe have been throwing parties for about 4
years. I remember when
they were considered the "new kids on the block".  I must admit that in the
past, FTT has thrown
some legendary parties and some parties that were horrible.  A lot of
people dissed and made fun of them in the past because they weren't into
the "hands in the air, mystical raver"  clique back when that meme was
popular. but during the Malachy tragedy, these boys came through and
distinguished themselves with levelheaded solid production skills when they
were needed the most, they played a
key role in raising money for Mal when it was needed and some of us never
forgot that they were 
there for the Family regardless of the petty and trite squables that may
have gone on before.  I know Kevin, Jerry, Hector et al. Have their heart
and soul into throwing good parties that transform young people's lives and
despite popular belief on this list, many a "gangsta"
(why is it that it seems that this phrase is only used to describe people
of color on this list :)
Has had their heart opened and turned around by the music and vibe that has
happened at FTT.
It may not have happened for you or me but IT DOES happen for many AND THAT
IS THE IMPORTANT THING! Not whether FTT makes a lot of money (frankly if
they keep throwing parties like the one last Saturday I hope they totally
get Paid IN FULL!!) or whether they bought off the police
transformation happens on many levels, if out of 7000 people 500 See the
Light, then it's worth 
paying off the police.  Kevin and Jerry are good businessmen, (I mean that
as a compliment :) They are in the business of throwing parties for a
living, they have lasted the test of time allong with Wicked, Martin, and
Preston all of whom throw parties FOR A LIVING (as opposed to working as
highly paid knowledge engineers  as many people on the list)
Massives are just that, they are Massive, they are designed to bring
together a wide array of people mostly people who have never been to a
party.  For many this was their first
Rave experience, and for many that night, FTT changed their lives, I saw it
on their faces,  I 
haven't seen it happen a lot at parites for a while but I definitely saw it
on a lot of young people that night and it connected me with that feeling
in myself that I remember (once I set  aside the jaded
attitude from years of raving :)  that feeling of WoW! this is so
wonderful! and these people are so beautifull and I can't believe that this
is really happening to me! Feeling.  I knew I was in the right place when I
 went into the "Techno room" and saw speaker tweekers, boys, gurls of all
shades grooving to Jeno, Wink and Sneak.  You know your in the House when
you can get black drag
queens (Like Foxy Brown) to come to a Rave, (cuz you know how the Children
are :).  To me, this was a trigger that this was not just an ordinary
massive, and yes, I knew this was the place when i saw that guy in the suit
start bustin moves in the Jungle Room :)  I walked all around this massive
party and saw serious pockets of Vibe everywhere, I caught several grooves
both in the Techno room and in the House room and, being as i was
completely sober that night (I wanted to evaluate the party based soley on
"unaltered merits")  I really felt that what I was perceiving was real and
genuine.  In fact,
for the first time in 2 years have I been able to close my eyes and trance
out without worrying about some fool bumping past me or feeling self
conscious. I felt enough of a vibe to feel safe at this party,
It was so wonderful to see Little Red Raver Girls next to big bad gothic
girls, homeboys from oakland, cowboys from concord, techno geeks, black
drag queens (you know its safe when they show up) all under one House.  If
this keeps up, I'm going to have to start going out 3 times a week again :)
NOT!   

Now to address some comments that were made in this general direction:


> 1) the bar outside. Selling alcohol at a rave? what the fuck???

Umm dude, what party were you at? I didn't see this. Now selling MEAT at a
party ain't my thing
(the last thing I want to smell if I'm off my face is searing carcass, but
it's not my party :)


> 2) the $2 water bottles. 2 bones is 2 much for water, esp. when the flyer
> says it's free.

I must agrtee here, FTT needs to be on the free water tip, period, it's
unsafe not to have free water availabe, if it's only just a specket.

> 3) the brawl(s).

I  saw no brawls while I was there, I supoose they could have happened but
even the toughest
guys that I saw seemed to be off their face (in an eXtremely good way) so I
didn't pick up much aggrow in the crowd, (though I'm 6'5" 300 lbs, black
and almost 40 so...) but I have friends who
are little white guys and they didn't feel threatened either :)

> 4) seeing a dodgy, speed-dealer looking type of guy walk up to one of the
> ever-present cops and give him a phattie hi-five and a hug. hmmm...

Dude, unless you know what's up you are completely out of line here. You
don't know what the fuck
was going down.  Over the years I have talked to and with many "Cops" at
parites. Consider the following:
	1) The Cop wasn't born a Cop, they might be curious and want to talk to
someone about
	    the event since so many people seem to be having a good time.

	2) While the Cop is talking he's not looking for people to bust.

	3) Police are people too, sometimes a personal relationship with someone
in Law 
	    Enforcement can defuse or prevent ugly situations from happening
before they start.

Besides I know several of the upper staff of Lyons and I know they do their
job well and are there to keep everyone safe. The Homebase complex is a
hard place to police efffectively,  Lyons (and the
people in charge of the Lyons security for thies parties have been doing
this for years, some of them 
have been raving as long as I have :)

> 5) getting kicked around and stepped on in the chill room, which
apparently
> had no beanbags, no couches, and no mattresses.

Oh poor baby,  try bringing some next time!!
Back in tha day (tee hee) When Equinox threw undergrounds, you might be
lucky if the
abandonded wearhouse  had a clean place to sit :)



> 6) Too too many high school girls walking around in large groups
clutching
> their handbags tightly with that "fish-out-of-water" look on their faces.

A full on Massive to someone not used to it can be a scarey thing, did you
try to 
make them feel safe and welcome?


> 7) having to walk through a line of hundreds of e-dealers on the way in,
> all of them whispering "ecstasy... e... x..."
> 

Well, judging from some folks that I saw in the crowd, some of them must
have had The Shit!!


> I don't even want to know how much FTT had to fork over to the Oakland PD
> to get their approval for the shit going down there. There's no way I'd
pay
> $25 for a party where I was in any way doubtful of the crowd it was going
> to attract. (see: radio ads, dodgy promotions, poster-sized flyer
>My name
> was on the guest list for FTT, but I CHOSE to pay for my FnF ticket, the
> tickets of four friends, plus the toilet paper and trash bags that were
> there. FTT went off because of the money involved, FnF went off because
of
> the love and energy and hard work involved!

With this kind of attitude I'm glad you didn't come, too bad Ethan had to
put up with your bullshit.


Ethan works his ass off to throw good parties for the people that come, and
I know for a fact that
Ethan welcomes everyone who can hear about it and get tickets to his
parties. He has to limit the
number of people that would come to his party because he wants to keep the
prce low and affordable
and have a manageable underground party. He does that very well, but it
seems that some folks have
used the success of FnF to set up some sort of snooby FNF is kooler then
thou Vibe that a lot of people are perceiving, I KNOW this is not coming
from Ethan but I'm not sure about some of you 
who regularly attend FnF.  Massives are just that, they turn LOTS of people
on to the scene
all at once, when they are good they are evolutionary triggers. Small
Undergrounds like FNF
builds solidarity among the "families", it's  OK to go to both! They all
should be about the same thing which is connecting the goer to an intense
experience of Connectedness and Love.  Many people find
God/des on the dance floor both at tiny Undergrounds and at Massives, For
those who have
been so lucky to find a group of people that you can catch a groove and
explore with, please don't fall into the trap of thinking that your groove
is better then anyone else's if it works for you, that's
great but don't knock what works for someone else.

Kevin, Jerry, Hector. Mohan   NICE ONE!!

(Can't wait for the next )

( PLEASE Email replies to me, don't group reply either ... )

So.. as a 41 year old guy who doesn't quite have a handle on the young
folks terminology, I thought I'd ask this - what are folks meaning when
they describe "gangstas" at a party? 

 Reply to me, and I'll post a summary of the replies. Remember, I'm
only interested in what YOU mean by the term, not what you think 
others mean when they use the term. I feel I've been on SFRaves long
enough so that folks know I'm not going to "out" them just because they
may have an definition that not quite nice.

 Also, "gangstas" vs. "gangsta wanna-be's" ? 

 What I think the term means
 1. Guys who actually are in a violence-prone gang.
 2. Guys who want to look aif they belong in a gang.
 3. Guys who copy what rap artists are wearing.

 Larry "old fart" Ching / larryc@netcom.com

Hi Everyone!  I just watned to tell you all that I had a wonderful time 
at FTT event onSaturday.  My friend, Denise, and I roadtripped it down 
there in 4.5 hours (usual 5-6hr drive).  When we got there, that p[arking 
lot was full!  we just cruised around until we foundthat muddy spot next 
to the fence that everyone had to walk by to get to the back side ofthe 
ware house.  My tiny little beat up chevy sprint fit really nicely into 
that debris pile!  :0  I'm sure many of you walked by my car!  It had a 
"do not disturb" sign in the side windw.  


ANYWAY!  Even thoug the line was huge, and the dealers were lined up to 
offer us e, all Denise and I could do was smile!  I felt so happy to be 
there.  So many people with smiles on their faces all grooving to intense 
music in every room.  When I danced myself too hard, I just walked around 
observing people in their bliss!  It was soo nice.  I couldn't keep a 
smile off my face!   

So I'm thanking everyone who went!  I had a blast even if I didn't meet 
you, you were probably one ofthose people around me enjoying yourself 
with thousands of others.  I look forward to going to a smallerevent 
where I may meet some of you.  

Oh!  The scenery in any of those rooms!  Was that the shit or what?  
Roman statues, a fountain, netting hanging from the ceiling, a scafforld 
surrounded by trees, all the plants!!!  wow,   andthe columns of water in 
the small room.  Everything was groovy to me!  I am coming down again, soon!

			PLUR

			-Kevin-

--- begin forwarded text

From: "Bred" <bigshirt@earthlink.net>

----------
From: Michael Hauben <hauben@cs.columbia.edu>
To: nyc-raves@hyperreal.com
Cc: ne-raves@world.std.com; off-topic@dewline.com
Subject: (nyc) Report from information talk about E
Date: Wednesday, October 23, 1996 7:25 AM

Wow...someone went to the talk by columbia prof on E...and asked me
to post this report for him...glad someone went and was able to
do a nice type-up of it....and sounds like there might be some
more notes of the meeting forthcoming...

----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Ron Winchel, professor of Psychiatry at Columbia University,
addressed a crowd of about 150 people last night, October 22,
on Ecstacy, MDMA, and its potential for good and harm. He said
that as of today there is no conclusive proof that MDMA causes
permanent brain damage, but the latest research suggests this
is possible.

He spoke on the topic "Ecstasy: What Every User Should Know"
at the Lesbian and Gay Community Services Center at 208 West 13th
street. Professor Winchel is a consultant to "Project Connect",
the center's effort devoted to prevention, intervention, education,
and other activities related to drug usage.

Professor Winchel also maintains a private practice.

At the presentation, a handout was available which I included
below.

I was very impressed by Professor Winchel. He is knowledgeable,
speaks well, and illustrated his talk with pertinent slides.
He elaborated on the handout and the slides from memory,
and covered the issues which I have which are related to Ecstacy.

He stayed for a long time after the presentation answering
questions from the audience. In fact, he continued until there
were no more questions. I admire that approach.

He will speak again in the near future on the subject of K.
He also has studied other drug usage. He pointed out that
unlike most other drugs - marijuana, coke - which pretty much
have no measurable brain damage once they have left the system,
preliminary indications suggest ( but have not proved ) that
E does damage to the brain which continues after usage has
stopped. He said that research is under way right now to
finally resolve the question of brain damage in humans:
and that a final definitive answer can be predicted to be
available in two to three years.

I will comment futher after presenting
the two page handout here.

-------------------------------------------------------------------

Ecstacy (MDMA)

1. What is MDMA?

A chemical synthesized in 1914
In 1980s someone discovered its "psychotropic" (mind altering) properties.
It's a chemical similar to amphetamine. Its effects in the brain
are similar to - but not the same as - LSD.

2. What does it do in the brain when you take it?

First, a brief lesson in how the brain works:

   [[[Drawing of two pear or beaker shaped things called cells
   [[[with the bottoms facing each other, containing little
   [[[circles, labeled cell1 and cell2. There is an arrow
   [[[pointing from cell1 to cell2.

Almost everything the brain does happens
by one brain cell sending messages to other brain
cells. (Brain cells are called neurons.)

The first cell makes little packages of special chemicals.
The cell ejects these chemical packages into the space between
cells, and other cells pick up these chemicals that are floating
around.

After the 2nd cell picks up these chemicals, the chemicals set off
a whole chain reaction of other chemical processes. That is how
the brain does its jobs.

Most psychotropic drugs (including drugs that people use to get
high and medications like antidepressants) work by affecting
this process. Basically, they speed up, slow down, increase,
decrease, or otherwise modulate the process of a chemical
message being sent between cells (a process called neurotransmission).

3. What does this have to do with MDMA?

MDMA causes an immediate surge of secretion of one of these
neurotransmitting chemicals (serotonin) - causing a sudden
increase in serotonin neurotransmission. It has other effects
as well, but this is the primary one.

4. Is this responsible for the high?

Probably. It also causes some effects in another neurochemical
system - the dopamine system. But most of what we are talking
about today is probably related to serotonin effects.

5. Why is the serotonin system important?

The serotonin system is a major player in controlling the
function of multiple brain activities. These include the
regulation of mood, anxiety, sleep, memory, body temperature,
sexual function - the list is very long.

6. What are the immediate effects of MDMA?

Psychological Effect - Short Term                Physiological Effects
----------------------------------------------------------------------
elevated mood                                 |  inc. heart rate
"heightened sensual awareness"                |  inc. blood pressure
decrease in libido                            |  dry mouth
"closeness" with others                       |  decreased appetite
hallucinations - uncommon                     |  jaw clenching
from a self-report study of 20 psychiatrists: |  decrease in erectile
function
    inc. ability to concentrate               |  rats - inc. locomotor
activity
    dec. defensiveness                        |         inc. heart rate
    dec. fear                                 |         inc. temperature
                                              |  Probably same as in people
----------------------------------------------------------------------

7. So - what is the concern

There is mounting data which suggest - suggest rather strongly -
that exposure to MDMA may cause long term damage to the cells
which produce and secrete serotonin.

8. Is this different from other drugs?

Yes. By and large, most other drugs that people use to get high -
except for "crystal meth" - cause only transient changes in the
neurochemistry of the brain. Long-term changes in brain cellular
anatomy are uncommon with other mind alterning substances.
("Crystal" may also cause long-term effects. Other drugs may as
well, when used persistently.)

9. What is the specific nature of the potential damage?

Synopsis:
- Extensive studies with laboratory mice, rats, and monkeys demonstrate
that administration of MDMA leads to significant depletion of serotonin.
- This serotonin deficit is associated with destruction of the parts of
serotonin cells which secrete serotonin.
The damage may last for many months - or longer.
- Studies of this kind cannot be directly done with humans.
- But indirect evidence gathered with human MDMA users have provided
preliminary evidence that there may be prolonged deficits of
serotonin in the brain of some users.

10. But are the doses which are used recreationally likely to do this?

That may be the case. Recreational doses tend to range between one
and two milligrams per kilogram of body weight. Studies with different
laboratory species suggest that species higher up on the evolutionary
scale are more vulnerable to smaller doses. In studies with some
monkeys, single exposures of as little as 5 mg/kg have been associated
with serotonin deficits. Therefore, it is possible that a user may
come close to such doses if they do several "hits" at once, or in
close succession. Since humans are evolutionarily "higher", they may
be even more vulnerable. The longer a serotonin cell is, the more
vulnerable the cell may be. Since human brains are larger, serotonin
cells may be much longer.

11. So, if MDMA does cause this effect in humans, does that mean that there
is any actual harm being done?

We don't know. Such studies have not been done - and are not easy
to do. But several factors raise concerns:
- serotonin function is important in many brain functions
- some individuals may start out with vulnerable serotonin systems, e.g.,
people with mood and anxiety disorders.
- there are a fair number of clinical case reports which suggest that
some cases of unusual and severe disorders of anxiety may have been
precipitated by MDMA use.
- for people who may already have pre-existing depression, the benefits
of antidepressants are, in part, dependent upon intact serotonin
function, i.e., decreased serotoning may inhibit the benefits of
antidepressants.
- and, we may not see the effects of serotonin deficits for many years.
There is a normal decrease in serotonin as people age. The margin of
safety may decrease with time if serotonin deficits do occur and are
maintained over time.

12. Are there any special considerations regarding HIV?

Yes. HIV infection causes decreases in brain serotonin - as do some
other viral infections. This may reduce the margin of safety.

13. Given these concerns, can anything be done to reduce the potential
risk among users?

Maybe. It should be repeated that there is as yet no strong evidence
that there actually is a problem - but based on the existing animal
data, there is strong reason to be concerned.
The mechanism by which MDMA causes the serotonin changes in animals
is only partially understood. But, a leading possibility is that
certain chemical compounds, called "free radicals", may be produced
by MDMA action in the brain. These compounds can be quite toxic, and
may be the source of the long term cellular damage seen in lab
animals. It is possible that free radical accumulation can be diminished
by certain "antioxidant" vitamins, in particular vitamin E. It would be
reasonable for MDMA users to think of taking vitamin E, about 1000 i.u.,
international units - vitamin E is always labeled this way. It should
probably be taken for at least a week before and continue for a week
after exposure. This duration is speculative. NO ONE SHOULD READ THIS
AND CONCLUDE THAT IT PREVENTS POTENTIAL MDMA INDUCED CELL DAMAGE.
It may help. It should be said that the only definite way of preventing
the potential for damage is not to ever use it.

In addition, the potential risks for MDMA may be exacerbated by
dehydration and elevated body temperature - both are conditions
which are typical of dance clubs. One should pay careful attention
to drinking non-alcoholic fluids and cooling off in these environments.

14. Are there any other concerns regarding MDMA?

Yes. In addition to the - still speculative - concerns about serotonin
deficits, there are a number of case reports of other medical
complications. These include potential life threatening heart and
liver problems. There are a number of reports of death possibly
associated with MDMA use.

15. Bottom Line:

The evidence that MDMA causes meaningful damage to brain serotonin
cells is based on extrapolation from effects in laboratory animals.
There is some indirect evidence for long-term serotonin deficits in some
users. Definite evidence is still lacking. (But that is only because
few investigations have been done, as yet. There is also no evidence
that says it is safe.)

Certain individuals may be at increased risk. These include people
with depression, anxiety problems, and HIV.

------------------------------------------------------------

I want to suggest that anyone who has any specific concerns
about how this information applies to them should see Professor
Winchel in his private practice. I found him not to be harshly
judgmental, but rather understanding and compassionate.

He showed a slide and summarized the results of three
investigations into the neurotoxicity of MDMA. He said the
first study in the mid-1970s showed no brain damage. He
commented on a second study but I do not have those notes
available right now. He said, however, that the most recent
study in 1985 by McCann showed definite and permanent brain
damage. He said that there were two groups, one of 30 people
who had not used MDMA, and 28 who had, and the 28 who had used
MDMA showed permanent brain damage.

Professor Winchel showed a slide of a tree with lots of long
branches extending up from a root. He said that in some ways
this resembled a cell in the brain, and that the branches could
be thought of as being like axions which extend out from the
brain cells and communicate with other branches. He said that
MDMA research in animals shows that MDMA causes the branches
to wither and die, and that if they regrow after taking MDMA
is stopped, then they regrow slowly and usually in a pattern
which suggests chaotic growth rather than orderly growth.

He said that this effect had been observered to be stronger
in higher level phylums - creatures more like humans - than
in the lower levels, and could be shown to occur at dosages
of 5 mg of MDMA per 1 kg of body weight.

He elaborated on whether there was a level of use which might
be within a threshold of safety. He made it clear that he was
not recommending use of the drug, and that the only truly save
course would be not to use it. However, if someone were to use
it, he thought at a maximum of two or three times a year might
be a level of usage which would not a level of high risk. He also
recommended that any use be preceded and followed by a one week
course of Vitamin E.

He said that he is now taking Vitamin E and other antioxidents
as is virtually everyone at Columbia's neuropsychiatric unit.

He said that typical street dosage is reported to be between
75 and 125 mg. That the level of safety would be limited to
one "hit". Never do more than two hits at once at that could
exceed the 5 mg of MDMA per 1 kg of body weight dosage which
has been shown to be harmful in certain species.

He said that he thought that the reputed positive effects of
E in the nature of increasing empathy was more a function of
lowering peoples inhibitions. He said that he thought that most
people had an expectation that they would be rejected by others
which was probably wrong, and that when people got over their
inhibition in approaching a stranger they were able to form
a bond which was more a factor of starting the conversation with
them than a factor of improved bonding.

Humorously, he said that he thought empathy meant something
more than agreeing with someone at the end of the evening
that the dj played too much techno music.

He was asked about combining E with K or GHP. He thought it was
a mistake. He pointed out that a known side effect of GHP is coma.

He also said that a hallucinogenic reaction to MDMA was unusual,
and it is not a hallucinogen for most people.

--- end forwarded text

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Oct 29 13:58:04 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id NAA17741; Tue, 29 Oct 1996 13:58:04 -0800 (PST)
Received: from gcwf.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with SMTP id NAA17732; Tue, 29 Oct 1996 13:58:00 -0800 (PST)
Received: from SOCAL-Message_Server by gcwf.com
	with Novell_GroupWise; Tue, 29 Oct 1996 13:54:43 -0800
Message-Id: <s2760ca3.065@gcwf.com>
X-Mailer: Novell GroupWise 4.1
Date: Tue, 29 Oct 1996 13:54:26 -0800
From: Ariel Stallings <ASTALLINGS@gcwf.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject:  Ariel's Inevitable Weekend Report (longish)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Lessons of this weekend:

1.  Ariel has now *officially* burned out on filled-past capacity
trance parties.  No really, I mean it this time:  I fell asleep in a
corner at Lunarseed.  I woke up briefly, stood in line for the
bathroom for 40 minutes, and then JUST when it was my turn, Goa Gil
cut in line!  "Um, my name is Gil, and I'm djing next and I gotta pee
real bad...would you mind if I went in front of you?"  Yeah, yeah,
sure sure.  Then as he's in there, a nauseous partier asked if she
could go in front of me "I have to puke...please?".  Yeah, yeah, sure
sure...My kidney infection is only in the early stages.  No really,
The biggest lesson was Ariel Needs A Nap On Friday Evening Or She
Can't Go Out.  I know you all care.  Grumpy Gruvers & Goa Gil do not
mix well.

2.  Under-attended parties in the park can be fun!  I had the BEST
time at Space Children!  Yeah, tourists to gruvers were about 3 to 1,
but that was ok!  I danced and danced, and noticed two women who had
been standing there watching for probably close to an hour, and so I
hopped down and ran up to them and said "Hey!  If you think it's fun
to watch, you should try dancing to it!"  They then just WENT OFF
about how wonderful it was to see people dancing so freely and
happily...they were like "be glad you're young!"  Keep in mind these
women were in their late 20's MAYBE, so I'm like "well, some of us
are young, but not all!"  When I told them I was 21 they were in
shock and sheepishly admitted that they thought I was 16 because I
was smiling so much.  !  It was a neat afternoon though...educate the
tourists!

3.  Funky Tekno Tribe?  Lots o' lessons from that one:  Hmm, you can
cut your wait in line from 2 hours to 10 minutes if you are a girl by
yourself, you know how to flirt with drunk sophomores in highschool
("ooh!  Is that a 40 of old E you've got there?!  mm, yummy!  Can I
have a sip?  giggle giggle") and have no conscience, all of which I
was, did, and didn't have...much to my chagrin.  Next lesson?  Taking
a little 20 minute nap immediatly after taking one's e is QUITE a
weird experience when you wake up.  My first sensation?  "Wow.  My
feet are in my shoes.  Mmm.  My feet:  They're in my shoes. 
Feeeeeeeet....Shoooooooooes....."  Next lesson?  At least there's
LOTS of room to dance at massives!  Phil Smart was awesome, and the
little Quango (or whatever it was) room had awesome trip hop in the
morning.  Other lessons?  Journeez Jeans is making these awesome
SUPERPHAT >>FUR<< PANTS that have 30" cuffs!  NICE!  I stood and
chatted with those kids about rave fashion for a long time...HOW
WEIRD, yet enjoyable.

4.  Someone at Sunset stole my friend Dandilion's backpack from under
her feet while she was dancing.  That sucks.  At the last sunset,
where the vibes of love and community are the strongest, and her bag
got swiped and then looted (she found disks and papers in the
bushes...but not car keys, wallet or organizer.)  Sad sad thing.

Anyway, there's my weekend's lessons.  This weekend I'm heading back
up to Seattle for a few days!  FUN!  Show the ol' hometown kids how
it's done! ;)

Ariel

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Oct 29 15:25:17 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id PAA26674; Tue, 29 Oct 1996 15:25:17 -0800 (PST)

Received: from [198.97.35.13] by tapeheads.ednet.net
 with ESMTP (Apple Internet Mail Server 1.1); Tue, 29 Oct 1996 15:28:04 -0800
X-Sender: ambient@netcom13.netcom.com
Message-Id: <v03007802ae9c41318859@[198.97.35.13]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Tue, 29 Oct 1996 15:26:55 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Joe Rice <ambient@netcom.com>
Subject: F&F apology
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I'd like to apologize for a situation that occurred with F&F on
Saturday.

As you may know, about an hour and a half after the initial bust, we
ended up moving the party to a small space in Redwood City. We finally
decided this after unsuccessfully checking into several spaces in SF,
all of which could have at least accommodated 200-300. At the time the
decision was made to move, the only ones who knew about it were those
who had remained at the first location. I changed the voicemail to
reflect our decision and intended to post directions once we'd set up
and knew that the new space was viable. Honestly, I didn't feel there
would be many people willing to drive down to the new location.

Upon arrival at the new space about 2am (PST), a large crowd was waiting
and two police cars stopped to check the situation out. They thankfully
let us have the party, but it was obvious we had as many people there as
the space (basically a small commercial garage) could safely contain and
we feared that the arrival of any more people could result in a mob
scene and a completely demoralizing 2nd bust. I've been painfully aware
of the perception of exclusion that has been directed at F&F lately and
I felt that leaving a message on the voicemail to the effect that we
were continuing the party but couldn't let anyone else in would merely
reinforce that image - despite the fact that we had no way to open the
party to more people, as much as we wanted to. So I left a message
saying the 2nd location didn't work out, which has evidently led some to
believe we were being less than truthful and has led to some hurt
feelings. At the time, I felt that was the best way to handle the
situation, and still feel that there was no way that we could have let
anyone else into that space - and I certainly didn't want people driving
to Redwood City only to be turned away.

Once the space cleared out a bit, I changed the voicemail again and
posted directions, as we could then accommodate more people. This was
about 5am (PST) and the party continued until about noon.

In retrospect, I should have been more straightforward about what was
happening and given our reasons for not initially giving directions to
the 2nd space. The F&F crew is painfully aware of how difficult it is to
obtain tickets and we're always struggling with ways to sort out ticket
distribution in the most equitable manner. The fact is, there will never
be enough tickets for everyone. We have no intent of being elitist or
exclusionary, and I'm personally quite troubled that we're being accused
as such. We're open to any and all views and suggestions and we're
working on these issues constantly.

Thanks,

Joe


(:Joe Rice:____________:joe@psychoactive.com:____________:ambient@netcom.com:)

[ to sfraves ]

RE: Joe Rice's recent "F&F apology" post

 After the fact, I'm sure a lot of folks will have suggestions about how
the voicemail situation could have been handled differently. I've been
to that garage, and it's not designed for a large gathering at all. I 
didn't make it to the 2nd half party, but no hard feelings on my part!

 Friends and Family has always been mindful of maintaining a comfortable
match of dance space and crowd. The one exception that I can think of
( the "infamous" Acme warehouse bust ) was overcrowded due to non-FnF 
scalpers counterfeiting the tickets and the maps and selling them to
people that overcrowded the site. Lesson learned - ever since, FnF have
used tickets that can't be easily duplicated !

 Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

INTELLIGENT.  I have actually learned a lot by subscribing to sfraves.

I have posted a few things on here...some would probably fit in the stoopid
pile, but that's ok.  I have also seen a lot of feedback to both mine and
everyone elses posts and it amazes me how many good points ppl bring up(on
both sides of most issues).

It just makes me realize how different we really all are.....but...it also
makes me realize how much we ALL have in common and how so many of us are on
the right track to being happy.

From: lachim@uclink4.berkeley.edu (michal migurski)
Subject: Re: FTT kwestions/komments
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>        Also, please think twice before you post ...  I am referring to
>this comment:
>"There's no way I'd pay
>>$25 for a party where I was in any way doubtful of the crowd it was going
>>to attract"
>
>I was attracted to that party, as well as some of my friends?  What does
>that make us?  I am also hurt (surprised) by reactions of *some* people who
>went to FnF who keep bad things about FTT and people who went there.  Is
>that really necessary?

I'm not trying to disresect the FTT crowd (a GANG of my friends were there,
and they had a great time) but I tend to get REALLY suspicious when an rave
promoter feels the need to advertise on alterna-rock-radio to get a crowd.
Who exactly were they trying to attract??? I think if they were going for
"ravers" (draw your own conclusions on that term =) they would have let the
strength of their *unbelievably good* lineup attract people. However, the
promotion involved with this event reached and almost exceeded the type of
promotions I'd expect for a Lollapalooza or Kamp KOME or something tike
that... I'm not at all against massives, but I DO think the best way to be
introduced to any aspect of the scene is through friends who know what's
going on and can help "ease" you into it... I didn't have this benefit when
I first started going to parties, and I think that's why I didn't enjoy it
as much. But once I started meeting people and gaining friends who could
show me around and guide me a bit, I began to have a lot more fun and work
with th parties alot more.

take care,
-m.

>3) the brawl(s).
>---------------
>Never saw anything akin to this all night, but, as I said, it was much
>too large an event to exhaust (meaning, that even somebody on speed couldn't
>get to/cover everything going on), so there might have been a brawl.  I

apparently some of my friends were knocked around by a crowd of goons
bum-rushing another crowd of goons...

And when they were being stepped on in the chill room, no apologies followed.

>FTT went off because of the money involved
>---------------
>That's complete horseshit.  It went off because the environment was good,
>the music was slamming, the people wanted to party and everyone was really
>friendly.  Yes, obviously that production took serious dollars to put on,
>but I'd say your opinion is unnecessarily cynical.  It was a complete hoot,

*oop!* <sound of foot hitting back of mike's throat>

OK, what I meant was: This production went off because they had the dough
to pay off the Oakland PD, the Oakland permit crooks, the owners of
homebase, all those DJs, and everyone else. That's cool if you've got a
pile of cash to spend and blow it all on a kickin' party, but somehow I get
a much better, warmer, *fuzzier* feeling inside when I know that a crew
like frinds and family can do the same, except everyone's time is
donated... I seriously doubt that DJ Dan or Jeno or DJ SS were hanging out
in the morning pushing brooms around and thanking FTT for for *letting*
them play at that party. It's more of a professional money-involved
atmosphere that just doesn't attract me as much. It was more of a
production than a party, which isn't bad necessarily (see: martin's ragers
=) but it definitely wasn't as *pure* as what I've experienced at smaller
parties. From what I've heard about the way-early rave scene in england,
the UG trance scene in SF is alot more in touch with the beginning than
what I see at the big parties.

take care,
-m.

>Hi-
>
> I hope somebody on the list will know the answer to this:  Is it possible to
>take a discman and use it with your third channel on a mixer?  I feel like
>experimenting with a couple of different ideas while I'm mixing my vinyl,
>but I
>have no idea if plugging a cd player will allow me to hear a CD through the
>mixer.  Thanks!
>
>-Todd


Buy a plug that fits your headphone jack on one end(prolly either 1/4 inch
or 1/8 in male,) which turns into an RCA on the other end.  Plug the 1/4
inch or 1/8 inch side into the headphone jack, and the RCA side into the
mixer.

Presto.  You'd be surprised what you can run through a mixer.  I wired my
bellybutton once.

-b))merang

(you can get the  plug at radio shack for 3-4 dollars.)

lachim@uclink4.berkeley.edu had this to say...

>>>4) seeing a dodgy, speed-dealer looking type of guy walk up to one of the
>>>ever-present cops and give him a phattie hi-five and a hug. hmmm...
>>Aren't we being just a LITTLE bit hostile and prejudice right here?
Describing
>>someone as a "speed-dealer looking type" does NOT go hand in hand with PLUR,
>>or you think it does?
>I don't think prejudice goes with PLUR, but I think one has to have at
>least a bit of prejudice... e.g. learning from past experiences to judge
>possible future outcomes. It's the way our brains are wired, and it's how
>we learn. "If it walks like a duck and it looks like a duck and it quacks
>like a duck, then it's probably a duck." --when someone looks like a total
>pimped-out speed dealer then they obviously put alot of thought into their
>appearance, so why would they want to project that image? I don't think I'm
>being prejudiced in this case, I think I'm drawing a sensible conclusion.

No, when someone looks like a "total pimped-out speed dealer"to you, YOU are
the one who's putting thought into that image. It's YOU who perceive him/her
as a "total pimped-out speed dealer". When I wear a tee that says "DOPE" on
it,
people approach me and ask me for drugs. That's because THEY think I'm
selling,
not because I try to look like a dealer. It's all in the eyes and mind of the
beholder. =)

>>>7) having to walk through a line of hundreds of e-dealers on the way in,

essential. Let me have silence so that no pin may drop and not be
heard, and not a whisper. Escape us for all our spouting, nor the
needle scratching upon this gramophone of the circular cosmic spot.

mind's eye, all will be music. What sculpture of sound cannot, what
cannot as a fluid token words, that nothing else cannot."

feedback (positive or negative, as long as it's
constructive.. although I prefer positive for some reason :) 

>         Thanks to all you guys who made it really fun for me, (you know who
> you are), and I'm really glad I was introduced to all of you. 
>         I'm still not really straight on what beat is what type of music???

Well, I'm gonna take a stab at describing the kind of things I
like, but I know that I'm going to miss a lot.

Categories of music are useful in order to get within the
right ballpark, but to be any more specific, I often find
that the best way to talk about music is by knowing your
artists and record labels.

Techno (or Detroit Techno)
   Medium paced (130bpm or so, typically), with a beat
strongly influenced by chicago house. Dark and moody, but
with an underlying sense of beauty. Often minimal (drum
beats + one or two synth noises), but not always so. When
there is a melody, it tends to be repetitive and on the
subdued or atonal side. Like chicago house, there is an
emphasis on production which subverts traditional beat
structures, such as by sticking in an extra measure here and
there, putting in beat patterns on the half-beat, repeating
sections backwards and forwards, and adding synth lines
which repeat at odd intervals (such as 5/4).

   labels: M-plant (experimental, minimal, complex rhythms)
           +8 (2nd wave detroit, clangy, abstract)
           Phono (housey, upbeat)
           UR/Red Planet (jazz/hip hop influenced, dark, beautiful)
           Planet E (discoey, groovy, quirky)
           Reload (dark, hard)
           Communique (Warm groove, abstract and minimal)

   artists: Rob Hood, Derrick May, Richie Hawtin, Carl Craig,
            Cristian Vogel, Luke Slater, Steve Bicknell

Electro
   Originally a form of breakdance music, the recently
revived electro movement typically features round, fat kick
drums, squelchy analog synths, and, more often than not, the
808 cowbell arranged in a slower (120bpm? sometimes
slower?), hip hop-like pattern. Vocoded voices (i.e., human
voices processed through an effects unit and made to sound
like a synthesizer) are common.

   labels: Metroplex (classic)
           430 West/Direct Beat (electro + techno bass)
           Clear (offshoot of rephlex, experimental, melodic & quirky)

   artists: Ectomorph, Dopplereffekt, Will Web, Drexciya, Aux 88

Trance
   Strong four on the floor beat, usually around 135-140bpm,
emphasis on melody, often features at least one breakdown
per track with corresponding buildup. Hard trance tends to
be more repetetive, with less emphasis on melody.

   labels: Synewave, Hybrid, Loop

Acid
   This word can refer to the earlier acid house movement,
but more often just refers to any song with a predominant
303 sound, or other similar analog burble. Acid tracks tend
to have no melody except for the 303 (or multiple 303s), and
the drums tend to be an 808 or 909, often distorted.

   artists: Acid Junkies, Mike Ink

Trax
   A term for minimal chicago-style house, with a banging
somewhat off-kilter beat and often with a cut-up vocal
sample. I include this here because you hear it all the time
when people try to describe minimal music of any type. "Kind
of tracky," they might say, "but with a weird jazzy line on top."

   labels: Dancemania, Relief, Accelerate
   artists: Boo Williams, Dan Bell, Green Velvet


That's all for now. Let me know if you have comments.

-Sho

We've actually volleyed this about a bit in the past, but the main
contravening factor is the massive budget required to do a legal massive.
Just for location and permits, I wouldn't be surprised if the trade center
in Oakland (behind HomeBase) pushes $20,000. This is before security - I've
found to be legal you'll often be required to have licensed, bonded
security guards. And one thing we're not prepared to do is push the price
above $5.

I'll bet a 2000 person F&F would go off, though!

Hmmm... I'm going to have to think about this for awhile. I tend to get a
little wrapped up in my own "rightness" sometimes without thinking... but
to respond: there defintely are societal stereotypes about what certain
types of people look like. And when someone dresses/acts like the societal
stereotype for, say, a "speed dealer," they're either:

a) trying to break the restrictive bounds of stereotypical dress and the
conventions of modern urban society by affecting the mannerisms of the
stereotyped, while simultaneously commenting on the inherent stupidity of
labelling people based solely on their appearance and apparent membership
in a perceived clique

or:

b) a speed dealer.

I usually tend to believe (b). =)

Now that all the hype from FTT is passed, It's time to get raedy for a 
REAL Halloween rave, Not just a party on Halloween....You Know What I 
Mean?!?

I don't Know if I saw more than just a handfull of people dressed up in 
costumes or even trying to get into the Halloween Spirit at the FTT 
Massive.  Mabee All the COOL ravers that enjoy dressing up and having a 
REAL Halloween EXperience are saving their juices for this Thursday,  
At least I am.    

Let me ask you something?!?

What is the spirit of raving all about???
What is the spirit of Halloween all about??

To me, Halloween is like the biggest rave-like holiday of all time.  It
reminds me of my childhood.  Its It takes me back to a time of
being young and getting all dressed up and having everybody smile at 
you.  A day when being goofy, weird, odd, strange, scary, or anyway, 
and nobody judges you because its Halloween.  And on top of it, You get 
candy and love for being the special person you are. 
It seems like Raving has adopted many of its most positive virtues from 
the SPIRIT of Halloween.  For this reason I like to think of Halloween 
as the Birthday or NewYears of Raving.  Especialy for a city like San 
Francisco,  Also known of as "Halloween On The Bay".  Halloween around 
here is truely a special ocasion.

This Halloween: Thursday, October 31st;  Come and rejoyce the Beautiful
spirit of raving by escaping into a celebration for the SPIRIT of 
Halloween.

In 1992, Feel Good E., and others introduced you to CASPER.   Now we 
are going to regress even furthur down the evelutionary ladder, and 
start from scratch.  SPIRIT will be a diferent type of Halloween rave.  

We will have  Lots of candy, free stuff, many surprises, toy and prize 
giveaways, games, a MaskaRave costume contest, and an incredible 
decorative Halloween production, with special guests and surprises 
throughout the night.  

There will be an incredible Holistic Haunted House by NEXUS.  With tons 
of surprises and incredible decorations, and 2 rooms of Music.

The dj's for the night will be:

In the SPIRITual Mausoleum:
Dj's:  Garth, Simon, Kimo, Jazz-E, Tayco, Matthew, Jonathan, & Jin

In the ThurZdaze Beat-Crypt:
Dj's:  Ghost, Frank Nitty, Essence, Tripnotix, Paucus, Spinner, & Chad

The party will go all night long,  from 9pm till 6am.  We hava a ton of
safe and secured parking.  Its a real relaxing feeling to be able to 
party and know that your car will be there when you are ready to go 
home.  We are also very close to public transit for those of you that 
don't drive.

THIS is going to be a REAL Halloween Rave for REAL Halloween Ravers.  
Admision is only $10 if you wear a costume and bring toys or 
Trick-or-Treat candy to share.  Door prizez will be given for the best 
and most creative costumes.

The SPIRIT of Halloween is all about FUN.  You can dance like a freak 
to great music all night long, while surrounded by all your friends, 
dressed up all crazy, and feel like more than just being at a party, 
but feel like YOU ARE A PART OF THE PARTY.  Your spirit, and positive 
attitude are the key ingredients that are going to make this such a 
memorable Halloween Rave.  Hope to see you there.

For all information call:   415-915-1704   or    510-340-9401

PS:   Despite the fact that this event is being produced by Feel Good 
Entertainmnet, It is in no way a 'MASSIVE' along the scale of 
Megga-Buzz OnE, or Cool World, Or FTT or.......Etc.   There were hardly 
any flyers made for this event, and almost all the promotion is word of 
mouth.  We especialy would like to invite all of You who postulated 
that all our events are comercial and over-hyped, to please come out 
and eat your words.  
Feel Good E. has been throwing parties far longer than most of you have 
been going out.  If anybody knows how to throw an underground Halloween 
Rave, Well, Its probably Us.  For those of you who have never heard of 
a small underground thrown by us, well, its probably because the party 
is to underground for you, or you havn't been around long enough.  
This is your chance to check it out.   

PLUR

Bad spelling is my trademark.  Ray Vonie

The Lunatic Adam wrote:

>Shieeett.. I wish there were 7-11's at all raves.. Slurpees, coke, nachos,
>water.. all
>for under 5 bux.. That'd be pretty cool...
>
>Hmmm If anybody throws a party and has some sort of 7-11 inside with CHEAP
>ASS FOOD AND
>DRINKS.. I *WILL* give major props to.. Hehehe.. But that'll be in my dreams...

That's actually not hard to do. You just have to get something like those
food wagens you see and lunch time in parking lots or at street corners,
the RV sorta looking things. You need good people that won't jack up the
prices also. I've seen mobile taco bells when I worked at Moffett Field in
Mt. View. There also are Burgr King  and KFC ones. Why can't there be a
7-11 type. If I'm not mistaken, at Freedom 96 there was some kind of
trailer that had food and drinks. A little pricey, but it was cool. Hell,
I'd offer and have offered to bring my BBQ to whoever wants to use it. That
offer always stands, however I'm not going to sit over it like I do at BBQ
& BEATS.

So, if anyone wants to use it for a party, just ask.  I think by also
having that BBQ at a "rave" there would be a better chance of passing the
party off as something other then a "rave". But of course the party would
have to have an outside area or something.

Tim (knucklehead)



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Oct 30 07:36:52 1996

	id HAA22981; Wed, 30 Oct 1996 07:39:05 -0800
Message-Id: <199610301539.HAA22981@precipice.v-site.net>
From: "Geoff White" <geoffw@cybertribe.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Drugs and the Mass Media
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 1996 07:36:53 -0800
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Priority: 3
X-Mailer: Microsoft Internet Mail 4.70.1155
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



	With Williams Buroughs selling Nikes
	And Speed junkies selling Jeans, it seems to me that
	someone is pushing the notion that the cultures that form
	around these drugs are kool. I don't own a television so in certain
	ways I'm not influenced by the medium but I also miss out on whole
	cultural memes that float through culture (especially "youth :) culture"
	So TV for me is like a drug, when I go to a friends house, I usually 
	become transfixed for a while. So maybe my perceptions are way off
	base but if they aren't then I would ask the question,  why should we
	not push "Rave" or the more prepackaged anacronym P.L.U.R.?  It seem's
	that as far as selling jeans or sneakers, I'd rather have my baby sister think 
	that Tim Leary was kool as opposed to William Bouroughs. Now, don't get me 
	wrong, I'm not saying that Nike and Calvin Klein or whomever shouldn't run these
	ads, but I am wondering why all the PLUR spouting people (if that's your thing) aren't
	spouting it to Madison Avenue.   The bottom line is I'd rather see younger people
	who are coming up and looking for identification to identify with the cultural values
	of the "Rave" scene as opposed to the  "Junkie" scene.


	Questions?
	Comments?
	Flames?


						G

Subject: Re: CD/Mixer question
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Yes.  Go to radio shack or some equivalent, and get a cord with a stereo
headphone jack on one side that splits into two RCA jacks on the other.
Plug the headphone jack into your disk man and the RCA's into your mixer.
There ya go.

Rick

"Let me have silence always in the centre of the shouting, that is
essential. Let me have silence so that no pin may drop and not be
heard, and not a whisper. Escape us for all our spouting, nor the
needle scratching upon this gramophone of the circular cosmic spot.
Hear me, mark me, learn me, throw the mind's ear open. Shut up the
mind's eye, all will be music. What sculpture of sound cannot, what
cannot as a fluid token words, that nothing else cannot." 

						-Wyndham Lewis

"Let me have silence always in the centre of the shouting, that is
essential. Let me have silence so that no pin may drop and not be
heard, and not a whisper. Escape us for all our spouting, nor the
needle scratching upon this gramophone of the circular cosmic spot.
Hear me, mark me, learn me, throw the mind's ear open. Shut up the
mind's eye, all will be music. What sculpture of sound cannot, what
cannot as a fluid token words, that nothing else cannot." 

						-Wyndham Lewis

--=====================_846691744==_--

> 	The bottom line is I'd rather see younger people
> 	who are coming up and looking for identification to identify with the 
>       cultural values
> 	of the "Rave" scene as opposed to the  "Junkie" scene.
> 

I don't know... have you seen the ad for Gap's new fragerance, "Om"?
(which you can purchase in about 25 different varieties of perfume,
after-shave, shampoo, candles, incense, body lotion, deoderant ect.)

The marketing picture for that I see all over the place is a group of
young kids lounging on a couch looking pretty Eed out.  Plus, the
word "Om" instantly evokes images of tranquility and new-age-conciousness...
or something.

Granted, Calvin Cline ads still look like the opening shots to a low-budget
kiddy porn spread... whose models are doing such a thing to pay for their
smack/meth habbit.  But hey, it sells underwear and t-shirts, becuase every
time you see the big C and the little K you subliminally think of trashy
young people who are easy to have sex with.  Thats the whole marketing
hook of CK... associate CK with cheap sex in any way possible.

Where as Gap is looking more for a more cool, concious model of youth
to assoicate with its bright orange "Om" products.

"Ommmmmmmmmmmmmmm.....mmmmmmmmmmoney"

Personally, I want to be just like the clean-cut models in JCPenny ads :)

-troy

     Think about it... Burrough's work stands alone without an 
     understanding of his personality or his drug use.  I think fewer of 
     Timothy Leary's actions would fit in that category.  I appreciate the 
     contribution of both of these men, and I'm not sure I appreciate 
     Burroughs (author of Naked Lunch and Junkie, which opened up 
     literature to a new kind of storytelling) being compared unfavorably 
     to Timothy Leary (the Guy Who Brought LSD to American Pop Culture).
     
     I'm not sure I appreciate Leary claiming ownership or "invention" (as 
     he did in his last spoken word tour) of the Zippie and Rave cultures 
     either (not that he didn't have a significant influence, but modesty 
     baby, you were not the only one).  I'm not even sure I appreciate 
     being part of a identifiable culture.  I'll shut up.
     
     Besides... it would be difficult to get Timothy Leary to say anything 
     he hasn't already said... rest in peace ... respect.
     
     AndyW
