[ to sfraves list ]

For aspiring/active musicians -

 I was web surfing, and found a US dealer for the Syntecno T303
( known as the TeeBee 303 outside of the US ).

REUSE IT MUSIC
2 Roosevelt Ave.
   Suite 123cM
Mystic, CT 06355       1-860-536-9400 

http://www.reuseit.com/n_keybds.htm   http://www.reuseit.com/orders.htm
sales@reuseit.com  

$599.95 for a Syntecno T303 ( aka TeeBee 303 )

That's  all I know - call them for more details. 


For info about the product itself, there's Syntecno's web page:

http://www.xs4all.nl/~syntecno/     syntecno@dds.nl 

Last I heard, "Price for 1 TeeBee : FL 780,- ( Dutch Guilders )  
                                            (approx. US$ 470,-)"

 - plus customs ( no power supply , but price includes postage & handling )

 Note: A new model has just come out with analog input that mixes with
       the local oscillators or can be just the analog input alone, before
       the filter and voltage controlled amp.

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

PS - No, I don't own one, but I thought folks here might be interested.
I got some techncal info about the new model that just came out, and 
ordering info from Syntecno via email, and I can forward that to anyone 
who's interested.

came home yesterday to find a message from Martin on my machine
about someone finding a red backpack. called the guy back today and it
turns out it wasn't my old Trager after all but I go , "oh well, thanks
for the call anyway and good luck on your parties." and Martin goes,
"thanks, if you want you can be on the guest list for the Basics on Nov.
16" and I go, "you don't *have* to do that." and he goes, "I know I don't
*have* to do it, but your on it." so at least that part of the story
eventually had a happy ending.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Oct 30 11:49:12 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id LAA24173; Wed, 30 Oct 1996 11:49:12 -0800 (PST)
Received: from horatio.ucsf.EDU by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with SMTP id LAA24164; Wed, 30 Oct 1996 11:49:07 -0800 (PST)
Received: (from knegtel@localhost) by horatio.ucsf.EDU (940816.SGI.8.6.9/GSC4.24)
	id LAA21044 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Wed, 30 Oct 1996 11:49:05 -0800
From: "Ronald Knegtel" <knegtel@horatio.ucsf.EDU>
Message-Id: <9610301149.ZM21042@horatio.ucsf.edu>
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 1996 11:49:05 -0800
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.0 26oct94 MediaMail)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: A farewell to sfraves
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey all,

well, all good things come to an end and so does my stay in San Francisco.
We've been here for a year and it has been a wild ride (much wilder then
I anticipated when I left home). I just want to say a few things before
signing off.

There has been a lot of discussion about the (NRR) contents of the list
and its usefulness. Let me say this, I am still very impressed by it.
I came to SF as a total stranger and I have met so many great people
through the list, found out about the places to be, exchanged (weird) ideas
or just had fun. This is a very powerful medium, even if it is chaotic
or consumed by flamewars every now and then. You people are the best.

On raving in San Francisco, especially with all the controversy recently
about "massives" vs. "undeground" raves. In my opinion you should all be
very happy with what you have right now, a very much alive scene with
something (of quality!) for everybody. And I say this coming from a country
where house has become mainstream and infiltrated big time by the greedy and
clueless. The kind of parties you have here, almost every day of the week
and several to choose from in the weekends are nowadays hard to find back
home and I will miss them. Lots of what I've seen here reminded me of the
scene in the Netherlands, say, 4-5 years ago. Appreciate it while you have
it, free water may be the least of your worries.

So, the Frying Dutchman will become the Flying Dutchman next week wednesday.
I thank you all. I hope to be online again within a few months from now and
perhaps I'll drop by here once in a while.

And for those 2001 lovers (check out http://www.design.no/2001/ lots
of great soundfiles and pictures for the true geek!!)... the HAL 9000
signing off...

Dave...my mind is going...I can feel it...I'm afraid, Dave...Daisy, Daisy..."

Goodbye,

The Frying Dutchman


--

I along with many others made sure all the thirsty ravers got water at
Homebase for the Last Gathering and Organic and a few other parties....There
is one fawcett where one can get drinkable water. We had to fill up 5 gallon
water jugs the whole night, so we could fill cups, bottles, etc... there is
no water fountain or any bathrooms to fill up bottles and such... If people
where allowed to fill up from the ONE spigot then it would be pandimonium,
not to mention the fact that there would be a flood... there was when I was
filling up the containers... So that is the water situation at homebase and I
hope that this explains it...
though this does not have anything to do with the fact that FTT said there
would be free water... But I don't know about the situation. I was at home
praying to the toilet, sick with the flu!!!!:(

Black Adder wrote:
>> 	base but if they aren't then I would ask the question,  why should we
>> 	not push "Rave" or the more prepackaged anacronym P.L.U.R.?  It seem's
>
>Because it has all been done before, 30 someodd years ago, though in a
>slightly different flavor. It went from being a movement to a prepackaged
>mass-marketed trend. 

BA, I'll be the first to absolutely agree with you, in fact I've been saying 
something similar all along to friends of mine when the subject comes up, 
but I'd like to ask some questions: 

1. Would you say that the movement, albeit eventually prepackaged and 
mass-marketed, changed society for the good?  That elements of that movement 
still swirl through the miasma of our culture even today?

2. If yes to #1, then would you say that "pushing 'Rave' or the more 
prepackaged anacronym [sic] P.L.U.R." would validate certain elements of 
that original movement and even further them?

While some will slam me for the reference to PLUR, which they see as a 
mindless and constrictive dogma, the sentiment behind PLUR is a good one 
IMHO and could stand to be publicized...

(Ooooo... I'm going to get smacked for this post...)

S

Hey kids, just wanted to drop a note to say what a wonderfull time Lori
and I had down in SF.  This weekend was my second F&F party and it
completely surpassed all possible expectations.  I've never in my life
experienced such a concentrated vibe as we did in that little garage in
Redwood City.

I was nearly in tears when the cops busted up the first space.  So many of
my friends were there that I hadn't seen in a long time.  We tried to make
plans of meeting somewhere or heading to another party but everything was
just chaos.  As we were heading to the car we noticed that it was
approaching 1am (we had previously planned a cosmic love vibe connection
between us and our family in Seattle and Portland for 1am ;) so Lori threw
some tunes on in the car and we had ourselves a little mini-rave out in
the parking lot ;)  There were 20 or so of us out there gvooving away when
there came the rumors about a new space.  A half hour later we found
ourselves caravaning down to Redwood City not knowing what to expect. 

Once we got there though we knew we were home.  Wow, I can't even begin to
tell you all how good it felt to be there.  Everyone milling about with 
huge grins on there faces, hugging each other and making new friends.  And
then the sound system went on...

I haven't danced that hard and felt so connected to a group of people in
my entire life!!  There was so much love in the room!!  I want to thank
all of you who made that experience happen - each and every one of you are
beautifull beyond description!!  I look forward to seeing you all again.

And to those of you who got shut out or didn't find out about the new
space, I don't know what to say other than we will make this happen again.

Much Love,
Arlyn

--
        'C' is for cookie and that's good enough for me.

From: "Andy Wyszkowski" <awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com>
Message-Id: <9609308467.AA846723137@smtplink.acer.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, SDream@tgrigsby.com (SDream)
Subject: Re: Publicizing PLUR (was: "Drugs and the Mass Media")
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     
     2 cents on this thread...
     
     Raves look to me like a cross between the flappers of the 20's and the 
     hippies of the sixties.  The flappers seemed a little less 'hardcore' 
     and ended up having a longer impression because there was less 
     backlash... in fact, the harmless nature of the flappers resulted in a 
     public opinion that hippies were harmless at first which bought the 
     hippie culture time to unify USING the media as an aid.  Only when the 
     dangers of drug use, and the incredible stupid motto of "Don't trust 
     anyone over thirty", flag burning and other poorly selected slogans 
     started to enrage the majority of the country did they fuck up.  
     Hippies lost sight of the goal and got wrapped up in the methods.  At 
     best they are remembered as the nuts who drove the magic bus in the 
     summer of love, at worst, they are blamed for the decline of society.  
     In the grand assessment, hippies and hippie culture DID do a lot of 
     damage and we shouldn't look at the OD's, deaths and conflict of the 
     time through rose colored glasses.  We should benefit from their 
     lessons: Misfit power, alternative community, the power of art, music 
     and media, and a stronger emphasis on peace in our decisions.
     
     America isn't ready for the responsibility of a higher social, ethical 
     and life order.  We need to expand the sense of possibilities first.  
     That's where raving fits in.  If I could address a large group of 
     people that had all the same dream some hot summer night in a 
     warehouse years ago, I could make them feel something.  Too bad that 
     group is a minority of the population.
     
     Currently the only bond we share as a country is what flies out of a 
     box in the corner of our rooms, which may I add is a known emitter of 
     numerous types of radiation.
     
     As a "raver", I choose my own path and recommend everybody involved do 
     the same, in their OWN way.  If we are faceless, and nameless, and 
     agenda-less, we are not a target.
     
     We don't ALL do drugs.
     
     We don't ALL dance.
     
     We don't ALL go all the time.
     
     We don't ALL care about the same things.
     
     We're not all in the same political party (has anybody found one that 
     represents ALL their beliefs... or even most of their goals or ethics)
     
     Several years into this, we can see what works and what doesn't.  I 
     can say from my own experience that I have benefited greatly and 
     become a lot more open to questioning myself, without doubting my past 
     self.  I am prone to growth, regardless of whether I think the time is 
     right.  I try to enjoy the harvest of happenstance.  I like life more, 
     and I don't have to go to another party to benefit.
     
     I don't think we can get much done right now, except spread acceptance 
     to ideas, and a general sense that one person or group shouldn't 
     dictate the morals of an entire country.  As we age, we will watch our 
     children grow up.  We are the prototypes for their genius and power 
     and direction.  We need to make sure we hold the feeling that this is 
     possible deep in our hearts.  We need to stay focused.  The art of 
     storytelling is dying.  When we can't explain things to our children, 
     we leave it to someone else. 
     
     Teach your children well.
     
     and about publicizing anything... FUCK COMMERCIAL TV.
     You don't realize how sad it is till you walk away.
     
     "Just because the radar can't see us doesn't mean we're not bombing 
     the town"
     
     Peace,
     AndyW
     
     
     
     
     Post Script Crap Below
               |
               V
     
     Whatever it is, love it in all it's forms.  It's Juan Atkins driving  
     a dark room through space... it's Deaks blowing people up on a cold 
     mountaintop... it's looking around at the other dancers wondering if 
     this is really happening... it's going to three locations in one night 
     and never getting anywhere... it's driving the Marin headlands at 
     2:00am searching for a party that ceased to exist at 9:00pm with a guy 
     I HATED in the passenger seat and realizing he's not so bad after 
     all... it's dancing with people for three hours before asking their 
     name and feeling a little stupid... it's helping clean up... it's 
     missing the Acme a little bit... it's rockin back and forth in your 
     seat because your legs can't groove but you have to move... it's 
     waking up on a chill room floor still feeling buzzed... it's talking 
     to some of the nicest people I've ever met... it's watching somebody 
     freak out and dance like nothing I've ever seen... it's about going 
     back to your car in a blissful afterglow and finding it keyed... it's 
     about seeing a familiar face and not even trying to figure out their 
     name, but rather what rave you met them at... it's staying a couple 
     more minutes at a party because your friend/ride wants to when the DJ 
     just starts to go off, and then I'm the one who doesn't want to 
     leave... it's about being bored this weekend and having to choose 
     between two killer parties next... it's getting caught by your 
     roomates or parents dancing in your room with a big shit eating 
     grin... it's having somebody you looked at and already made up your 
     mind on approach you and prove you wrong with a smile and a hello... 
     it's about driving god knows where because the directions are a little 
     off... it's about uncertainty and surprise and happenstance and 
     synchronicity.
     
     It's about us doing it to ourselves, rather than them doing it for us.

>      and ended up having a longer impression because there was less 
>      backlash... in fact, the harmless nature of the flappers resulted in a 
>      public opinion that hippies were harmless at first which bought the 
>      hippie culture time to unify USING the media as an aid.  Only when the 
>      dangers of drug use, and the incredible stupid motto of "Don't trust 
>      anyone over thirty", flag burning and other poorly selected slogans 
>      started to enrage the majority of the country did they fuck up.  
>      Hippies lost sight of the goal and got wrapped up in the methods.  At 
>      best they are remembered as the nuts who drove the magic bus in the 
>      summer of love, at worst, they are blamed for the decline of society.  
>      In the grand assessment, hippies and hippie culture DID do a lot of 
>      damage and we shouldn't look at the OD's, deaths and conflict of the 
>      time through rose colored glasses.  We should benefit from their 
>      lessons: Misfit power, alternative community, the power of art, music 
>      and media, and a stronger emphasis on peace in our decisions.
>      
>      America isn't ready for the responsibility of a higher social, ethical 
>      and life order.  We need to expand the sense of possibilities first.  
>      That's where raving fits in.  If I could address a large group of 
>      people that had all the same dream some hot summer night in a 
>      warehouse years ago, I could make them feel something.  Too bad that 
>      group is a minority of the population.
>      
>      Currently the only bond we share as a country is what flies out of a 
>      box in the corner of our rooms, which may I add is a known emitter of 
>      numerous types of radiation.
>      
>      As a "raver", I choose my own path and recommend everybody involved do 
>      the same, in their OWN way.  If we are faceless, and nameless, and 
>      agenda-less, we are not a target.
>      
>      We don't ALL do drugs.
>      
>      We don't ALL dance.
>      
>      We don't ALL go all the time.
>      
>      We don't ALL care about the same things.
>      
>      We're not all in the same political party (has anybody found one that 
>      represents ALL their beliefs... or even most of their goals or ethics)
>      
>      Several years into this, we can see what works and what doesn't.  I 
>      can say from my own experience that I have benefited greatly and 
>      become a lot more open to questioning myself, without doubting my past 
>      self.  I am prone to growth, regardless of whether I think the time is 
>      right.  I try to enjoy the harvest of happenstance.  I like life more, 
>      and I don't have to go to another party to benefit.
>      
>      I don't think we can get much done right now, except spread acceptance 
>      to ideas, and a general sense that one person or group shouldn't 
>      dictate the morals of an entire country.  As we age, we will watch our 
>      children grow up.  We are the prototypes for their genius and power 
>      and direction.  We need to make sure we hold the feeling that this is 
>      possible deep in our hearts.  We need to stay focused.  The art of 
>      storytelling is dying.  When we can't explain things to our children, 
>      we leave it to someone else. 
>      
>      Teach your children well.
>      
>      and about publicizing anything... FUCK COMMERCIAL TV.
>      You don't realize how sad it is till you walk away.
>      
>      "Just because the radar can't see us doesn't mean we're not bombing 
>      the town"
>      
>      Peace,
>      AndyW
>      
>      
>      
>      
>      Post Script Crap Below
>                |
>                V
>      
>      Whatever it is, love it in all it's forms.  It's Juan Atkins driving  
>      a dark room through space... it's Deaks blowing people up on a cold 
>      mountaintop... it's looking around at the other dancers wondering if 
>      this is really happening... it's going to three locations in one night 
>      and never getting anywhere... it's driving the Marin headlands at 
>      2:00am searching for a party that ceased to exist at 9:00pm with a guy 
>      I HATED in the passenger seat and realizing he's not so bad after 
>      all... it's dancing with people for three hours before asking their 
>      name and feeling a little stupid... it's helping clean up... it's 
>      missing the Acme a little bit... it's rockin back and forth in your 
>      seat because your legs can't groove but you have to move... it's 
>      waking up on a chill room floor still feeling buzzed... it's talking 
>      to some of the nicest people I've ever met... it's watching somebody 
>      freak out and dance like nothing I've ever seen... it's about going 
>      back to your car in a blissful afterglow and finding it keyed... it's 
>      about seeing a familiar face and not even trying to figure out their 
>      name, but rather what rave you met them at... it's staying a couple 
>      more minutes at a party because your friend/ride wants to when the DJ 
>      just starts to go off, and then I'm the one who doesn't want to 
>      leave... it's about being bored this weekend and having to choose 
>      between two killer parties next... it's getting caught by your 
>      roomates or parents dancing in your room with a big shit eating 
>      grin... it's having somebody you looked at and already made up your 
>      mind on approach you and prove you wrong with a smile and a hello... 
>      it's about driving god knows where because the directions are a little 
>      off... it's about uncertainty and surprise and happenstance and 
>      synchronicity.
>      
>      It's about us doing it to ourselves, rather than them doing it for us.
> 
>

Many thanks to everybody who put on and came to FnF and FnF, part II. My 
trip in from Chicago for my anniversary FnF was so worthwhile because of 
YOU.

I had been to a few raves before last year's Halloween FnF. But something 
was very different for me that night and my follow-up email to everybody 
I met at that party was "Now I understand."

I guess I can say, "Now I truly understand." Last year wasn't just a 
freak one-time occasion. Warmth, compassion, and kindness do exist.

What I don't understand are the people who have trouble with the idea 
behind this small party. Elitism? I didn't see any; I met all kinds of 
people. One simply has to introduce themselves. A party and your 
perception of it are what you make of it. Show some warmth, compassion, 
and kindness, and people will reciprocate.

On Wed, 30 Oct 1996, SDream wrote:

> Black Adder wrote:
> >> 	base but if they aren't then I would ask the question,  why should we
> >> 	not push "Rave" or the more prepackaged anacronym P.L.U.R.?  It seem's
> >
> >Because it has all been done before, 30 someodd years ago, though in a
> >slightly different flavor. It went from being a movement to a prepackaged
> >mass-marketed trend. 
> 
> BA, I'll be the first to absolutely agree with you, in fact I've been saying 
> something similar all along to friends of mine when the subject comes up, 
> but I'd like to ask some questions: 
> 
> 1. Would you say that the movement, albeit eventually prepackaged and 
> mass-marketed, changed society for the good?  That elements of that movement 
> still swirl through the miasma of our culture even today?

No. The fact that it was mass-marketed and packaged destroyed whatever
hope the movement had at changing anything significant. It went from being
a movement, which encompasses a collective conciousness moving towards
certain goals, to a trend, which is composed of a group of sheep
wearing the right clothes, saying the right things, and hanging out
with the 'in crowd', all which becomes passe' over time. 

Have people stopped killing one another? Have people stopped hating one
another, for whatever pathetic reasons they might have, be they racial,
religious, political, etc.? Are people (legally)free to do what they wish
their own bodies? 

> 2. If yes to #1, then would you say that "pushing 'Rave' or the more 
> prepackaged anacronym [sic] P.L.U.R." would validate certain elements of 
> that original movement and even further them?

No. That is the mistake that has been made previously. You cannot "push." 
You can merely offer. How can you *force* peace? How can you *force* love?
How can you *force* unity? How can you *force* respect?

> While some will slam me for the reference to PLUR, which they see as a 
> mindless and constrictive dogma, the sentiment behind PLUR is a good one 
> IMHO and could stand to be publicized...

An overused simplification of an otherwise worthy ideal used as a selling
point for $25 parties.

                                             Black Adder

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Oct 30 21:28:19 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id VAA21402; Wed, 30 Oct 1996 21:28:19 -0800 (PST)
Received: from scruz.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with ESMTP id VAA21395; Wed, 30 Oct 1996 21:28:17 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [165.227.109.23] by scruz.net (8.7.3/1.34)
	id TAA10866; Wed, 30 Oct 1996 19:53:45 -0800 (PST)
X-Sender: anarch@mail.scruznet.com
Message-Id: <v01530501ae9d9ce04a0b@[165.227.109.23]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 1996 19:56:42 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: anarch@scruznet.com (Anarch)
Subject: Re: Publicizing PLUR (was: "Drugs and the Mass Media")
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

SDream@tgrigsby.com (SDream) wrote:
>Black Adder wrote:
>>Because it has all been done before, 30 someodd years ago, though in a
>>slightly different flavor. It went from being a movement to a prepackaged
>>mass-marketed trend.
 [...]
>1. Would you say that the movement, albeit eventually prepackaged and
>mass-marketed, changed society for the good?  That elements of that movement
>still swirl through the miasma of our culture even today?

Ah, I'm so glad you said this; it touches on a pet peeve of mine.  In
brief, yes.  To say more, first it seems to me that the great majority of
personal attitudes toward "the sixties" today fall into three broad
categories: one, a basic indifference of a sort widely applied to history
and historical moments of all kinds, seeing the past like a museum exhibit
of various exemplary or characteristic concepts (hippies, MLK, rock music,
drugs, etc) without any particular continuity or relation to the present;
two, the mixture of nostalgia and commitment to various ideas or ideals of
the period that can manifest itself in both new and unreconstructed hippies
and activists; three, the disdain and self-congratulatory "realism" that
replies to the perceived failure of anyone to achieve the many stated goals
of those pressing for change in the period: there was no revolution, we
have no world peace, racism lives, and so on.  Each of these views strikes
me as amazingly shallow.  I don't want to wander too far, but to quickly
summarize my feelings, "the sixties" (a grossly artificial category) were
an upwelling of ideas and actions that need to be considered as a natural
historical result of what came before and, most importantly, as a cause of
what came after, of what we are living with.  Hippies, Yippies, Black
Panthers, SDS may not have succeeded in creating the societies they claimed
as their results, but did they simply dissipate, with no effect?  No.  The
world we live in today unquestionably bears their marks, in the form of
every stride toward personal equality, moral freedom, democratic
participation, and individual liberty taken since, and probably most of the
strides taken in the other direction as well.

There was a great example of all this recently.  There was a piece, in the
SF Weekly I believe (maybe the Guardian), about the memorial for Timothy
Leary in San Francisco, a month or two after his death.  It appeared under
the headline "Fucking Hippies."  It's an epithet we've all heard, I expect,
usually with a combination of both derision and respect, the first for the
supposed failure of all that hippies have stood for, the second for their
willingness to commit to an admittedly admirable set of goals.  The report
reflected the title, with a fair bit of jibing at hippie idealism and
nostalgic reminiscence mixed with with real respect for the ideas that
Leary and followers had managed to put forth, and their results.  It was
basically positive, though definitely not lacking in mockery.  On the
mocking side, particular mention was made of the spectacle of Joe
MacDonald, of Country Joe and the Fish, leading the crowd in his famous
Woodstock war chant ("whoopee, we're all gonna die...").  A few weeks
later, a letter appeared in the Weekly (Guardian?) from Mr MacDonald.  It
combined (as I read it) a somewhat sardonic acknowledgment of the truths in
the piece with a comment to the effect that it was pleasant to observe that
a public paper could unconcernedly make use of the word "fuck," which in
the day of his and Leary's prominence was cause for investigation by the
FBI.  Exaggeration, possibly, but I doubt it.  In any case, it demonstrates
real changes that have occurred since the sixties.  Would they have arrived
without the activists, hippies, druggies, panthers, rockers, and so on?  I
don't think so.

The moral, if any, of all this is basically that idealism should never be
shunned.  People today tend to look at the sixties as a collection of
idealisms, either failed or still to be treasured, revered and immemorial.
But the lesson of the past ought really to be that ideals are indispensable
to change, though they might never be realized: ideals are the raw material
of history, producing through all their perversions and distortions the
growth and development of the human race.

>2. If yes to #1, then would you say that "pushing 'Rave' or the more
>prepackaged anacronym [sic] P.L.U.R." would validate certain elements of
>that original movement and even further them?

Could.  (Anacronym...I like that.)

anarch@scruznet.com

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: bdabrams@uclink2.berkeley.edu (Brian Denny)
Subject: re: promoting PLUR -- one person at a time
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

[this note has a cynical section and a constructive section. if you don't
want to hear me bitch about why mass media exposure won't work, please skip
to the second half of this post :) ]

do i think that Peace, Love, Unity and Respect are values to live by?

absolutely.

do i think we (whoever "we" are) should try to "push" these values through
the mainstream media?

no way.

first of all, the mainstream media does not believe in peace, love, unity,
or respect. they are experts in subverting, twisting, suppressing, and,
finally, "commercializing" and taking over such messages and using them to
their own advantage.

secondly, there is not enough Unity among us to begin with. we have all
sorts of different values, beliefs, etc. we bicker over these things all
the time. right now we can't agree on this very question. trying to access
the mass media would fragment us further.

third, PLUR and raving mean different things to all of us. i have seen far
too many un-PLUR posts on this list (and this list is one of the most
PLURry groups of people i've ever encountered.) to some people, raving is
an escape from "real life." to others, raving _is_ real life, and the rest
is just a recurring nightmare. other people think that raving is "the way
things ought to be", and want to try to integrate the rave and non-rave
worlds. many of us would like to live PLUR as everyday philosophy, but we
find the stresses of everyday life too much for us. i'm not denigrating
anyone for being "less-than-ideal", i'm just saying this:

if we could send a message to the world, what would it be? and would we be
up to the challenge of truly leading by example?

i don't think we could agree, and i don't think we are prepared to put
together any sort of unified example to lead by.

now, enough cynicism. i also hold some hope for these ideals.

LEADING BY EXAMPLE (take 2). we are individuals, the rest of the world is
made up of individuals. in our society, each individual gets a vote.

every time you introduce a newbie to the scene...
every time you smile at a stranger, or give someone directions on the street...
every time you give someone a much-needed hug...
every time you get someone to turn off their television...
every time you convince someone to register to vote...

you are promoting PLUR.

a story:

my roommate, Susan, was walking down Market St. the week after her first
rave (Beautiful People in September). a businessman walking near her
started to cross the street against a red, nearly getting hit by a taxi and
delaying some traffic. Susan asked him, don't you think if all the
pedestrians respected the cars and all the cars respected the pedestrians
(and eachother), the streets would be safer and less congested for both?
the businessman looked at her skeptically and said, but everyone's not
going to do that. Susan said, well it's gotta start with somebody, doesn't
it?

Susan watched the businessman as he approached the next intersection. he
waited until it was clear.

point: real change happens slowly, and it CAN happen _one person at a time_.

point: if you don't, who will?

point: the best way to spread PLUR is to _live it_ ourselves, every moment
of every day, not just when we're raving. until we all do that, talk of
reaching mass audiences is futile.

YOU are a beautiful person. YOU can bring out the beauty in other people.
if you don't, who will?

much love,

brian

pants.  next i have a long red plaid night shirt which will double today as
my tunic.  i have a plaid down vest over that.  (layers of clothes are key
both in the desert and in oaktown).  i have a little black shoulder case
with goodies and pens and paper and an ultima 5 map so i will never get

        plur is life. but you don't need to preach it.  just think of your
favorite religious icon. i.e. j.c. (no offense, cuz i luv him), buddah (not

atheist just think of the spirit of what these people were trying to
promote.  i think you'll find that they were not trying to convert their
enemies, rather, they were trying to educate them.  this is overly
simplistic, but that's what makes it beautiful.  we are not the first
ravers and we won't be the last. what this means to me is that since we
have nothing to lose (which is what janis called freedom) why not promote
plur by living it?  it comes back to you tenfold....and your raves are more
fun too.....

TOP TEN REASONS WHY TRICK OR TREATING IS BETTER THAN SEX

10. You're guaranteed to get at least a little something in the sack.

9. If you get tired, you can wait ten minutes and go at it again.

8. The uglier you look, the easier it is to get some.

7. You don't have to compliment the person who gave you candy.

6. It's okay when the person you're with fantasizes you're someone else,
   because you ARE someone else.

5. 40 years from now, you'll still enjoy candy.

4. If you don't get what you want, you can always go next door.

3. It doesn't matter if the kids hear you moaning and groaning.

2. Less guilt the next morning.

 AND the #1 reason....

1. You can do the whole neighborhood!!

To: Know 1 <knowoneness-l@teleport.com>

This may be a little out there for some but I felt it would be goods to 
share.

peas,

Ran
                           (Namasate)
                                /
                          -=*=-/
                            ~






   Greetings to all,
       
               I was just reading a book on eastern religions the other day,
when I happened across this passage. Now I know to some this may be nothing
new, but for myself it was reaffirming of my views and brought JOY to my
heart. So I'll share it with you all, in hopes of bringing you a smile.

                                     The Yoga of Music
                                   **********************
           ~ The yoga of music is directly related to devotion. Devotion is
inner attachment, love. =>   Without this psycological and spiritual
attitude, music cannot lead to salvation. Music is not regarded in India as a
means of diversion and pleasure but as a path to God-realization and is
called Nada-brahma-yoga or the Yoga of the Brahman as sound. This Brahman is
regarded by the philosophers of grammar as the Word. Music enables man to get
merged in the peace and bliss of the spiritual aspect of sound. (..YES!!..)
 The sense of music, when developed, enables us, like moral sense,
intuitively to distinguish between harmony and disharmony, right and wrong,
to realize the discordance of the worlds with the ideal reality or existence,
and the havoc caused by anger, and so on, on our being.

       
         In harmony with love,
                                         Chris.

> Black Adder wrote:
> >> 	base but if they aren't then I would ask the question,  why should we
> >> 	not push "Rave" or the more prepackaged anacronym P.L.U.R.?  It
seem's
> >
> >Because it has all been done before, 30 someodd years ago, though in a
> >slightly different flavor. It went from being a movement to a
prepackaged
> >mass-marketed trend. 
> 
> BA, I'll be the first to absolutely agree with you, in fact I've been
saying 
> something similar all along to friends of mine when the subject comes up,

> but I'd like to ask some questions: 
> 
> 1. Would you say that the movement, albeit eventually prepackaged and 
> mass-marketed, changed society for the good?  That elements of that
movement 
> still swirl through the miasma of our culture even today?


I was 10 in 1967 and though I was too young to go to Woodstock I remember
it clearly.
The "Hippie" movement was still kicking in 1971 when I took my first acid
in Central Park Manhatten.
I must say that the 60's and the associated counter-cultural movements have
had a clear,
profound and unmistakable effect on western culture (and thus the world).
Particularly in
silicon valley, you owe flex-time, no dress codes, no drug test (for most
large computer co.) to the
direct effect of "Computer Phreaks" (Hippies who programmed computers). 
The fact that even the
Pres can sday that he put the joint to his mouth (but did not inhale), and
the vice president went all the way
is a result of the memes exported by the 60's


> 
> 2. If yes to #1, then would you say that "pushing 'Rave' or the more 
> prepackaged anacronym [sic] P.L.U.R." would validate certain elements of 
> that original movement and even further them?
> 
> While some will slam me for the reference to PLUR, which they see as a 
> mindless and constrictive dogma, the sentiment behind PLUR is a good one 
> IMHO and could stand to be publicized...
> 
> (Ooooo... I'm going to get smacked for this post...)

Yes the media apparatus is completely self serving, this is well known, but
consider this that
the spin doctors of the 80s and 90s learned well from the tactics of the
Yippies from the 60s
and 70s. The Yippies sought to manipulate the media by feeding them a
poison pill, i.e. they knew
they would tend towards the sensational so they fed them stuff that was
sensational knowing that
the media would gobble up the sensational part and pull the sub-textual
message along with it.
This is what a meme is. The real goal is to bring the sub-textual message
through.

> 
> Geoff,  
>         Well, this is somewhat of a surprise to me that you guys (who are

> you guys BTW) somehow got a hold of that post I made.  I made that post
to
> SFRaves in September of 1995 (more than a year ago).  I learned a lot
that
> summer, though I've also learned a lot since then also.  All in all
though,
> I think you guys should know that I am by no means whatsoever a doctor,
nor
> am I in Med School.  All of this stuff I have learned just cause I'm
really
> interested in the molecular effects of drugs on our bodies and brains....
>         In general, MAOIs in general are not something to pop like candy
> because of their side effects.  The worst side effect that I know of is
the
> "cheese reaction."  MAO is an enzyme that oxidizes amines.   Tyramine is
an
> amine in cheese which is metabolized by MAO.  If MAO is blocked, tyramine
> does not get metabolized, and if excessive amounts of tyramine are
absorded,
> they can cause a "hypertensive reaction"... excessively high blood
pressure,
> etc.
>         However, L-deprenyl selectively inhibits MAO-B, that is, it
inhibits
> the B-form of MAO (which is found mostly in the brain).  The form found
in
> the stomach is MAO-A; L-Deprenyl does NOT inhibit this form IF TAKEN AT
THE
> RECOMMENDED DOSAGE.  If you take too much then yeah, it will cause
problems.
> 
>         MDMA is also an amine, though I can't remember if MAO metabolizes

> MDMA or not.  One part of me says yeah, because its an amine, the other
part
> of me says nah, because in MDMA the amine has a methyl group attached to
it
> and hence could be considered not to be "mono".  Anywyas, MDMA MAY also
be
> metabolized by MAO, in which case using L-deprenyl simulataneously may
lead
> to MDMA staying in your system for prolonged periods.  Of course ALL of
this
> is speculation; I haven't done any kind of laboratory research on this
> whatsoever.  My general opinion on this after another year of wisdom is
that
> 
>         1) anti-oxidants are great
>         2) prozac should be just fine
>         3) L-deprenyl shouild be ok, but.... 
> 
> 
> Well Geoff, could you forward this to whatever list you are subscribed
to,
> and tell what list it is...  I'm curious.  I got something like 13
responses
> directly to me and haven't had time to get to them all yet....  Tell all
> those other people who were kind enuf to say a few nice words that I will
> respond to their stuff sometime this week...  
> 
>                                                         lots o luv,
> 
>                                                            jason

Hi Guys,
Sorry I didn't get back earlier with the water fiasco. I was out of town on 
business. As everyone has pointed out, free water was going to be available at 
the party, and free water (55 tanks in all) were ordered from Alhambra. 
However, due to a mix-up, the delivery people from Alhambra came to the wrong 
gate that Saturday evening and left. By the time we found out, it was too 
late. 
Yes, water was sold at the party, but ALL the beverages sold that night were 
NOT from FTT. We did NOT make ANY money from the sale of beverages. Our deal 
with the owners of the space was that we could rent it on condition they 
handle and get to keep all proceeds from the beverages. We did however get 
permission to distribute a certain amount of free water until it ran out. 
I realize that this explanation will not satisfy everyone on the list, but its 
the truth. We had no control over the price that was charged for the water at 
the event, and we did not in anyway get a percentage of the profits. FTT 
apologizes for the misleading information on the flyer.  We are going to throw 
a free Organic in the Park soon with some very special guests (hopefully) 
playing live. 
Also, watch out for the Funky Tekno Tribe crew tonite at the Civic Center.... 
we'll be in drag ;) Happy Halloween!!!

Mohan
The Funky Tekno Tribe

From: Andy Thomas <andy@hyperreal.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: support for California prop 215 
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.95.961031164346.23392E-100000@taz.hyperreal.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Subj:  Rich Contribute To Pot Measure
Date:  Wed, Oct 30, 1996 7:51 PM CST


.c The Associated Press

      SACRAMENTO, Calif. (AP) -- George Soros and Laurance Rockefeller
are among the rich and famous who have contributed $1.4 million to
support a ballot measure to legalize marijuana for medical use in
California.
      With their help, supporters of Proposition 215 began airing TV
commercials over the weekend -- something the opposition couldn't
afford.
      Campaign spending reports ending Oct. 19 show that the wealthy
donors' contributions account for roughly three-quarters of the
$1.8 million raised. Opponents have raised $28,128 against the
measure, mostly from law-enforcement groups.
      Proposition 215 would allow Californians to grow and use
marijuana for medical purposes for cancer, AIDS and other ailments
if recommended by a physician.
      Soros, a billionaire currency trader living in New York, donated
$550,000. He advocates ``legalizing some of the less harmful drugs
and devoting the money saved from the criminal justice system to
treatment'' in his book ``Soros on Soros.''
      Rockefeller, brother of former Vice President Nelson
Rockefeller, donated $50,000 after a request from New Age guru Ram
Dass, aka professor Richard Alpert, who was exiled with Timothy
Leary from Harvard in 1963 after using students in psychedelic drug
experiments.
      George Zimmer, owner of the Fremont-based Men's Wearhouse
clothing store chain, donated $50,000 and loaned the Yes campaign
$210,000. Zimmer, whose mother died of cancer, said he had wanted
to give it to her to ease the pain of chemotherapy.
      Other donors include:
      Chicago commodities broker Richard Dennis, one of the nation's
leading advocates of legalizing drugs as a way to reduce crime and
save tax money, donated $100,000.
      John Sperling, president of the University of Phoenix, donated
$200,000.
      Peter Lewis, president of the Progressive Corp., the nation's
seventh-largest auto insurance company, donated $500,000.
      Other prominent donors include Gail Zappa, widow of rock
musician Frank Zappa, with $5,000; former Reagan administration
Secretary of State George Shultz, 1,000; Nobel-laureate economist
Milton Friedman, $150; and former California Sen. Alan Cranston,
$100.
            
      AP-NY-10-30-96 2048EST
      Copyright 1996 The Associated Press

>> >> Never read a book of demon summoning aloud, even as a joke.
>> >>
>> >> Do not search the basement, especially if the power has just gone
>> >> out.
>> >>
>> >> If your children speak to you in Latin or any other language
>> >> which they should not know, or if they speak to you using a voice
>> >> which is other than their own, shoot them immediately. It will
>> >> save you a lot of grief in the long run. NOTE: It will probably
>> >> take several rounds to kill them, so be prepared.
>> >>
>> >> When you have the benefit of numbers, *never* pair off and go it
>> >> alone.
>> >>
>> >> As a general rule, don't solve puzzles that open portals to Hell.
>> >>
>> >> Never stand in, on, above, below, beside, or anywhere near a
>> >> grave, tomb, crypt, mausoleum, or other house of the dead.
>> >>
>> >> If you're searching for something which caused a noise and find
>> >> out that it's just the cat, *leave the room immediately if you
>> >> value your life.*
>> >>
>> >> If appliances start operating by themselves, move out.
>> >>
>> >> Do not take *anything* from the dead.
>> >>
>> >> If you find a town which looks deserted, it's probably for a
>> >> reason. Take the hint and stay away.
>> >>
>> >> Don't fool with recombinant DNA technology unless you're sure you
>> >> know what you are doing.
>> >>
>> >> If you're running from the monster, expect to trip or fall down
>> >> at least twice, more if you are of the female persuasion. Also
>> >> note that, despite the fact that you are running and the monster
>> >> is merely shambling along, it's still moving fast enough to catch
>> >> up with you.
>> >>
>> >> If your companions suddenly begin to exhibit uncharacteristic
>> >> behavior such as hissing, fascination for blood, glowing eyes,
>> >> increasing hairiness, and so on, get away from them as fast as
>> >> possible.
>> >>
>> >> Stay away from certain geographical locations, some of which are
>> >> listed here: Amityville, Elm Street, Transylvania, Nilbog (God
>> >> help you if you recognize this one), the Bermuda Triangle, or any
>> >> small town in Maine.
>> >>
>> >> If your car runs out of gas at night, do not go to the nearby
>> >> deserted-looking house to phone for help.
>> >>
>> >> Beware of strangers bearing tools such as chainsaws, staple guns,
>> >> hedge trimmers, electric carving knives, combines, lawnmowers,
>> >> butane torches, soldering irons, band saws, or any device made
>> >> from deceased companions.
>> >>
>> >> Listen closely to the soundtrack; and pay attention to the
>> >> audience, since they are usually far more intelligent than you
>> >> could ever hope to be.

Subject: NRR: Hug quote of the day
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


"Hugging can be vital for your emotional well-being. Everybody

feels skin hunger throughout their lives, and unless that hunger

is satisfied by touching, there's a vital void in the emotional

make-up that's going to cause deep unhappiness. We all know that

babies thrive on frequent stroking. Well, adults are no

different. When they are not patted on the hand, embraced around

the shoulder or hugged, they withdraw into themselves. I

prescribe four hugs a day for survival, eight for maintenance and

twelve for growth. Dr. Virginai Satir in Homemade, March, 1990

Hugs are not only nice; ther're needed. Hugs can relieve pain and

depression, make the healthy healthier, the happy happier and the

most secure among us even more so. Hugging feels good, overcomes

fear, eases tension, provides stretching exercise if you're short

and stooping exercise if you're tall. Hugging does not upset the

environment, saves heat and requires no special equipment. It

makes happy days happier and impossible days possible."


--Kathy Tobin

<HUGS>

brian

     this reply is rather lengthy...it took me all day to type this.  i 
     tried to make it as understandable as possible.  If I left some 
     important information out that you'd like to know specifically, let me 
     know, allright?   Also, if you are going to flame me, please, please

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
============================================================================

i think the best things in life are always made hard to find unless you are 
truly looking for them.  I think these things are best left in the 
underground, but not chaotic like some people would like.  Good parties like 
Sunset would get out of hand if 5.5 million people in the Bay Area suddenly 
knew about it.  We wouldn't get fair coverage.  See my next note about this.

============================================================================
     
do i think that Peace, Love, Unity and Respect are values to live by?
     
absolutely.
     
do i think we (whoever "we" are) should try to "push" these values through 
the mainstream media?
     
no way.
=============================================================================

I would have to agree that the media, with a few exceptions, doesn't cover 
topics fairly.  They cover topics based on what they think the people want to 
see to be entertained.  A great example of this was the hard copy coverage of 
raves.  clearly they were simply trying to find only the negative aspects and 
front them to the American people so they may mainline it into their brains.  

Another experience I have had with inaccurate media coverage is a bit NRR, 
however it seems appropriate to bring up in this instance.  About 4-5 months 
ago, 20/20 did a story on Equinox International, an environmentally conscious 
company which markets over 300 environmentally sound products to consumers 
either directly or through catalog sales.  Perhaps some of you out there may 
have seen this show or heard of the company before.  I just found out today that
Equinox has listed #1 as the fastest growing company in the either inc or 
fortune 500.  

Fortunately, since I know people in the company and was able to hear the story 
before the story even happened, I can give sort of an inside story.  

About 5 weeks before 20/20 aired this fairly negative story interviewing 12 
people who were accusing Equinox and its founder, Bill Gouldd, of dishonest 
business practices.  

Now I don't want to go into too many of the details because they are not 
pertinent to our subject of the media, but the 20/20 people ONLY interviewed the
12 people (out of a company with over 300,000 representatives) and based their 
entire story on that.  They gave Mr. Gouldd 4 hours to respond.  Also, Equinox 
sent out some other representatives to 20/20 to give a different side of the 
story.  20/20 wouldn't even talk to them.  

some of the accusations made by these 12 people were that these people had lost 
all their savings and one person even claimed to lose his house because he got 
involved in the company.  Further research found that this person did not lose 
his house, but he actually sold it for more than they paid for it!  

now some of you may be asking what does equinox and 20/20 have to do with the 
mass media?  everything!  because this is a company that is doing a lot of good 
for our generation.  They make charitable donations to several organizations 
many of us are familiar with, such as greenpeace and save the whales.   the sf 
rave scene is doing a lot for our generation, too, such as greg from harmony's 
wonderful bid to donate money to omar's well-being.  but it constantly is being 
picked on because people use drugs.  That is so one-sided it is absolutely 
pathetic!

In closing about equinox and 20/20, the day after the show aired, Bill Gouldd 
responded in a rebuttal show that is approximately 1 hour on his private 
satellite network (how's that for underground?), and he said "we've got a hugh 
downs, a john stosle, and a barbara wa-wa, sitting back, criticizing one of the 
only opportunities that you will ever have to live the kind of lifestyle that 
they enjoy on a daily basis."  This may not be an exact quote, but if anyone 
wants to view the tape, I would be happy to set that up with them.  This is our 
future, and nothing is going to stop us from making some improvements to this 
appalling situation we have going on in our country.  

=============================================================================
     
first of all, the mainstream media does not believe in peace, love, unity, 
or respect. they are experts in subverting, twisting, suppressing, and, 
finally, "commercializing" and taking over such messages and using them to 
their own advantage.
     =====================================================================
     
     This is very interesting, but unfortunately I believe it to be true.  
     We seem to be, in my eyes, on the verge of a higher collective 
     consciousness that will unify at least a small group of minds that 
     truly want change.  
     ====================================================================
     
secondly, there is not enough Unity among us to begin with. we have all 
sorts of different values, beliefs, etc. we bicker over these things all 
the time. right now we can't agree on this very question. trying to access 
the mass media would fragment us further.
     
third, PLUR and raving mean different things to all of us. i have seen far 
too many un-PLUR posts on this list (and this list is one of the most 
PLURry groups of people i've ever encountered.) to some people, raving is 
an escape from "real life." to others, raving _is_ real life, and the rest 
is just a recurring nightmare. other people think that raving is "the way 
things ought to be", and want to try to integrate the rave and non-rave 
worlds. many of us would like to live PLUR as everyday philosophy, but we 
find the stresses of everyday life too much for us. i'm not denigrating 
anyone for being "less-than-ideal", i'm just saying this:
     ======================================================
     
     The best message might be to simply lead by example.  
     
     ======================================================
     
if we could send a message to the world, what would it be? and would we be 
up to the challenge of truly leading by example?
     
i don't think we could agree, and i don't think we are prepared to put 
together any sort of unified example to lead by.
     
now, enough cynicism. i also hold some hope for these ideals.
     
LEADING BY EXAMPLE (take 2). we are individuals, the rest of the world is 
made up of individuals. in our society, each individual gets a vote.
     
every time you introduce a newbie to the scene...
every time you smile at a stranger, or give someone directions on the street... 
every time you give someone a much-needed hug...
every time you get someone to turn off their television... 
every time you convince someone to register to vote...
     
you are promoting PLUR.
     
a story:
     
my roommate, Susan, was walking down Market St. the week after her first 
rave (Beautiful People in September). a businessman walking near her started 
to cross the street against a red, nearly getting hit by a taxi and delaying 
some traffic. Susan asked him, don't you think if all the pedestrians 
respected the cars and all the cars respected the pedestrians (and 
eachother), the streets would be safer and less congested for both? the 
businessman looked at her skeptically and said, but everyone's not going to 
do that. Susan said, well it's gotta start with somebody, doesn't it?
     
Susan watched the businessman as he approached the next intersection. he 
waited until it was clear.
     
point: real change happens slowly, and it CAN happen _one person at a time_.
     
point: if you don't, who will?
     
point: the best way to spread PLUR is to _live it_ ourselves, every moment 
of every day, not just when we're raving. until we all do that, talk of 
reaching mass audiences is futile.
     
YOU are a beautiful person. YOU can bring out the beauty in other people. 
if you don't, who will?
     
much love,
     
brian

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Oct 31 18:19:17 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id SAA09296; Thu, 31 Oct 1996 18:19:17 -0800 (PST)
Received: from emout16.mail.aol.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with SMTP id SAA09287; Thu, 31 Oct 1996 18:19:13 -0800 (PST)
From: Hughdhyana@aol.com
Received: by emout16.mail.aol.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id VAA15486 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Thu, 31 Oct 1996 21:18:41 -0500
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 1996 21:18:41 -0500
Message-ID: <961031211841_1214621459@emout16.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: My Problem With PLUR...
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I know that I may get blasted for this one, but it's a theory that I have
been brewing for quite a while, and I just can't hold it in anymore.

I just believe that we can do better than PEACE, LOVE, UNITY, and RESPECT
with one single word- COMPASSION. I just feel that the word "unity" doesn't
carry the weight of undescriminating inclusion that should be the goal of
every human on the planet. I think that it has the potential of sending a
message of exclusivity to those who don't necessarily think, act, dress, or
play the same way that we do. 

The under ground is always talking about vibe. I believe that we can take the
power that we create in terms of a good vibe to transform the world. It
doesn't have to remain within the confines of our particular sociological
strata. 

Personally, I try every day to lift the vibe of the people with whom I come
in contact. Whether it be the supermarket checker, the cop who pulled me over
(but didn't give me the ticket), the teachers and students I deal with at
school, or my roommate who is the single most important person in my life, I
have made it a function of my life to promote well being for anybody who may
cross my path. The only tool I need to do this is COMPASSION.

This world is a hard place to exist, for everyone. I'm not saying that it's
not enjoyable, just that every moment is a challenge to be something better,
more evolved. All that we have that can truly depend upon to ease the
struggle is ourselves and each other. In order to be truly helpful, you must
be able to empathize and live from a place of compassion, not unity.

The universe is made of one thing- energy. Any unity is promoting a
separation from that which has not yet been included, or has not yet been
exposed.duality On the other hand,  compassion is the unyeilding acceptance
of concepts, appearances, and emotion through understanding.

I realize that the concept of PLUR is better than what a lot of people are
living by today. I just feel that there is a greater potential for humans to
live by. The underground is closest to my ideal, which I have yet to reach
myself.

Thank you for listening!
Take care of eachother-
-hugh

>                                      The Yoga of Music
>                                    **********************
>            ~ The yoga of music is directly related to devotion. Devotion
is
> inner attachment, love. =>   Without this psycological and spiritual
> attitude, music cannot lead to salvation. Music is not regarded in India
as a
> means of diversion and pleasure but as a path to God-realization and is
> called Nada-brahma-yoga or the Yoga of the Brahman as sound. This Brahman
is
> regarded by the philosophers of grammar as the Word. Music enables man to
get
> merged in the peace and bliss of the spiritual aspect of sound.
(..YES!!..)
>  The sense of music, when developed, enables us, like moral sense,
> intuitively to distinguish between harmony and disharmony, right and
wrong,
> to realize the discordance of the worlds with the ideal reality or
existence,
> and the havoc caused by anger, and so on, on our being.
> 


"House Music is inviting to the Soul"
For many of us, that is the very essance of raving, what can happen between

each other at 4 in the morning.

The Lunatic Adam wrote:

>Shieeett.. I wish there were 7-11's at all raves.. Slurpees, coke, nachos,
>water.. all
>for under 5 bux.. That'd be pretty cool...
>
>Hmmm If anybody throws a party and has some sort of 7-11 inside with CHEAP
>ASS FOOD AND
>DRINKS.. I *WILL* give major props to.. Hehehe.. But that'll be in my dreams...

That's actually not hard to do. You just have to get something like those
food wagens you see and lunch time in parking lots or at street corners,
the RV sorta looking things. You need good people that won't jack up the
prices also. I've seen mobile taco bells when I worked at Moffett Field in
Mt. View. There also are Burgr King  and KFC ones. Why can't there be a
7-11 type. If I'm not mistaken, at Freedom 96 there was some kind of
trailer that had food and drinks. A little pricey, but it was cool. Hell,
I'd offer and have offered to bring my BBQ to whoever wants to use it. That
offer always stands, however I'm not going to sit over it like I do at BBQ
& BEATS.

So, if anyone wants to use it for a party, just ask.  I think by also
having that BBQ at a "rave" there would be a better chance of passing the
party off as something other then a "rave". But of course the party would
have to have an outside area or something.

Tim (knucklehead)

Happy Halloween!  You can celebrate all weekend with lots of stuff both
Friday and Saturday.  I removed some stuff from the weeklies (things
I haven't heard about for a long time), so if I accidentally dropped
a living party, let me know.

Also, remember to vote on Tuesday!!!


                                THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://www.hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/gencal.cgi
    
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Upcoming Parties in the San Francisco Bay Area

   Thursday, October 31st - Feel Good Entertainment and Funky Beat
   ThurZdaze presents _The Halloween Spirit_
   Kimo, Jazz-E, Garth, Simon, Tayco, Essence, Frank Nitty, Ghost,
   Tripnotix, Paucus, Spinner, Chad, Jin.
   $10 w/toy donation if you wear a costume
   9pm-6am, . SF. 415.915.1704 510.340.9401

   Freaker's Ball II_
   Markie, Garth, Dubtribe, Tracy, Tom, Chris, Keone, Pollywog, Moonpup,
   Jay Hartley, special guests.
   presale tix available oct 11 at Capricorn Music, Santa Cruz
   408.425.3316 415.965.5045

   will be first Friday of each month.

Info Lines

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.568.1338
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday morning 9am-11am - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon - Beats, Breakz
       and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford).
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench. Varied techno sub-genres, noise, spoken word, world
       music. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

   Greetings adventurers

Here is the 411 on Samhain 

It is not snowing at the location the snow line is higher up. It will be
cold at night though. The main dancefloor is heated if need be as well as
the cabins 
there are heated showers. Also available is cafetiria style food and vegiterian 
food. there is bed space indoors for approximately 200 people indoors as well
as lots of space to pitch your tent (I think I will do that).If you want to
venture up into yosemete wich is approximately 40 minutes away we recomend
you bring snowtires as there is snow higher up. 

Directions is as follows.

580 east past Altamont take exit for L.A. off the 580 and take 132 east to
Modesto take 99 south to merced then take 140 east to mariposa approximately
10-11 miles past mariposa heading toward Yosemete you will see a sign saying
Samhain and balloons and such (Whispering pines) Please carpool.


Tickets are $25 and can be obtained at F-8 @ 1816 Haight st or Getta clue.

gen info 415 - 273 - 1845
 

directions transport and weather call 415 - 208 - 1820



See you up in the trees

Ayahuasca

At 5:50 PM -0000 10/31/96, Ariel Stallings wrote:
>>>> John S. Lee <jsl@netcom.com>  10/30/96, 09:14pm >>>
>
>The real problem here gents and ladies with the, "youth" is that THEY
>have been under constant attack.  <snip>
>>>>>
>
>I think part of the problem is that it's a "they" have been under
>constant attack...It's a weird day when you chose to separate
>yourself from youth culture...

Many things in life are not a matter of choice, instead it is often a
matter of fact.  I do not play in sandboxes with 3 years olds, I do not go
to junior proms, or senior proms, I do not hang out with 16 or 17 year olds
as a general rule.

But I tell you what, I can dance, I listen to house music.  I make house
music.  I play house music.

I am very happy with myself and my standing.  And choose to associate with
those I have the most in common with.

Please remeber, YOUTH culture is generated by a bunch of greying white
males.  Youth have very little to do with the manufactured culture they
immerse themselves in.

>It's hard to say how old everybody is
>on this list, but suffice to say, a lot of us are only 5 to 10 years
>past being "youth"...

And there are plenty who are much older than that.  Rest assured.

>by making it an "us" "them" thing it just
>creates a deeper cleavage between understanding what's really going
>on.  I mean, I'm 21 and I hope to consider myself a "youth" for the
>rest of my life!
>
>>>>>>
>People follow by example.  This goes for kidz too ;) <- (their future
>is in our hands)!
>>>>>>
>
>OUR future is in OUR hands...you know?
>
>Ariel

Hey Ariel,

Let us say that we differ in view.  I am far past being a child.  I have a
child of my own and I am concerned about his future.  I was speaking as a
parent who has to raise a child.  My child is not my equal, he is my child.
That is how societies grow, and are nutured, and how information is passed.
It's natural, and to me, not a matter of taste or academia.  Humans are
natural, thus we are animals.  The child/parent relationship is mimiced
throughout nature.

I do not want to be a "youth" for the rest of my life.  I am GLAD my 20's
are a memory, and look forward to apporaching 40.  I revel in the fact that
as I get older I get to see the world change.  I do not want to see the
world as a child, although I do miss the wonder at times, but am even more
grateful when I recognize the wonder the world has to offer.  Age is not
something I run away from, it is something I accept, and even revel in.  I
admire my seniors, and learn of the life they have lived.  We can all learn
something  from those older than us.  Youth, IMO, has it's place, and time
in a person's life.  As one's life changes these things become more
apparent.  Not to be patronizing at all, but how you think and how you view
the world will change as you get older.  It already has; you do not see the
world through the same eyes you did when you were 6, or 12, or 18.  And as
you get older, things will continue to change.  To me, this is progress,
evolution.

Our children's future is in our hands.  They, the children, have to deal
with the future we plant today.

Age is a good thing.  And I am glad I went through my teens, my twenties,
and am going through my thirties.  Life rocks, and it gets better as you
get older.

trust.

Peace,
John


P.S.  Damn reading this shit, I fell like my next evoltionary phase will
involve diapers (i.e. Depends).  Eeech!  Did I say something about looking
forward to getting older....  ;)

Hello everyone!

        Tomorrow night, Friday the 1st, there will be a benefit party for
the Pacific Sound System (as some of you might know). The Pacific crew has
consistently thrown some of the best underground parties around. They are
completely devoted to helping our scene, by filling their parties with tons
of positive energy. They have, for the past three years, provided a free
party almost every weekend during the summer. (As well as providing the best
new year's parties around!!) The energy that they have created and put into
their parties cannot go without notice...

        So on that note, it would be a great "thank you" to the entire
Pacific Crew, if you would come out to the benefit party tomorrow night! It
is going to be completely amazing!! There will be at least two rooms (that I
know of) filled with the most intense vibes!! You do not want to miss this
party!!! This party is being put on by a whole bunch of people who know and
love the P.S.S. They/we/you are doing this only out of respect and love! So
come out and show your support to the Pacific Sound System!!!
